A must stop area.We walked up and down the prom and found it absolutely gorgeous. The little cafe's are just the right distance away from the beauty and several little structures like plane statutes, castle models and replica artilleries continue along the side.Tiny wine trucks sit along the edge of the walls on the approach to the tower and provide the perfect accompaniment to a gorgeous view. Just walking around the tower is brilliant enough without entry.Next stop on the bus is Jerónimos Monastery so you have loads to do in the area and hours to enjoy the sunshine!!

So Cool!. We went here and would have loved to go inside but the line was very long so instead we walked around the outside and enjoyed the view of the river and Atlantic Ocean. Definitely worth the trip even if you don't go inside!

Badly managed beautiful heritage site.. Visited Torre de Belem in mid August at 16:00pm on a Wednesday. Beautiful tower in a picturesque setting with terrible management. Do not visit the tower unless you are willing to queue for 3hrs.The queue system is non existent with those with pre-booked tickets and those without tickets in the same queue which lasts 1hr. This queue is on an exposed bridge in the sunshine. We decided to prepay for a ticket in the ticket office (the ticket office is crazily located in the tower which allows those who skip the queue to walk straight into the tower) and upon returning to the queue, as we did not want to skip, we were told that we could not enter the tower as we had already been in the tower (?!?) - this displays the lack of communication and organization in the tower. Finally, after entering the tower, we walked upstairs to climb the tower - we were then told to queue for 30mins to enter the secondary tower to climb the tower. This queue was in addition to the 1hr queue outside the tower. One staff member attempted to prevent visitors from climbing up the tower while her colleagues sat downstairs idle.After waiting in the tower, we were brought to the second floor. We waited for 30mins in an overcrowded room before deciding that we had decided to waste 2hrs of our lives in a queue without seeing anything. The tower is obviously beautiful from the exterior with an attractive first level but the tower is understaffed and terribly organized. The staff that are on site are rude and unhelpful.Have visited several unesco heritage sites but this has to be the most badly organized heritage site in the world. Definitely ruined my experience of the beautiful area of Belem. Please re-organize the ticketing system and queueing system as it will have a negative effect on the attraction.

Torre de Belem must see. The view is astonishing, if the weather is bright. First sunday of the month is free entrance. You can see the bridge, the jesus statue on the other side.There are restaurants around you can eat and drinks. From the central to get there was around 30 min because we stopped on the half way to visit an other attractions :D "Jerónimos Monastery"When we went there was raining but the best time obviously when is sunny.

A piece of Portuguese history. Finished in 1520 the tower is a special part of the history of Belem. It has lots of interesting information about the period when it was built. Also a great place to watch the sunset

Perfect park break. Beautiful tower and park. The perfect place to relax.Grab yourself some frozen yogurt from #weeelyogurt or enjoy a good cappuccino from the cafe next to the tower and just take in the view

Don't bother to waste your time here. The tower is awfully congested due to bad arrangement. People basically spend 1-2 hours waiting in the line at the entrance (even when you have prepaid tickets), then wait another hour on the first level for the stairs to be cleared and to climb upstairs. When you finally arrive at the top, you only find out that there is really nothing to see except for a bit of the view. However, the view is also nothing spectacular since such view can be captured at other city landmarks as well. Despite there is a sign saying that only 120 people are allowed in the tower at a time, the top was over crowded, which makes it impossible to take a decent picture. After several hours of standing still and waiting in the line, you basically walk away with nothing. So I wouldn't recommend to visit this place unless you really have nothing better to do.

Great place for walk. We wanted to see Belem to learn from the old history connected with the Tower and the Monastery there. We could not see them, as it was closed on Sunday evening. But we enjoyed a great walk around Belem, from the Tower, through the Cultural Center, the beautiful Parks and fountain, and then for a Custard Tart at the famous Pasteis de Belem (bakery of Belem). A nice treat with a good coffee! For a cheaper meal, we went to TelePizza with our teens, but there are much better choices of place for meals and coffeee in Belem. To get there, you need to take Tram 15 from Metro station Cais de Sodre (or buses 727, 728, 729, 714 or 751).
Outside is enough. Nice construction, but we are not thinking it worth to queue, pqy to visit inside. it's closed on Mondays
Interesting monumemt. A huge queue to visit , up to my opinion worth to take pictures in front and enjoy the entourage rather than to wait in the queue
Nothing much. A very impressive monument from the outside, but empty on the inside. Great location by the Tagos river..Don't bother if you miss it..

Nice views, unbearable queues. Great view on the riverside and the river, it's free to visit with Lisboa Card, but the queues are unbearable in the heat. Although it might have been our mistake to go there on u Sunday.
Good but dont bother going in. Really amazing sight of Belem but wouldnt recommend going inside if you have been up other viewpoints e.g the castelo is much better!

Interesting. The view from the top of the tower was amazing. A definite must see. Get there early as everyone who goes to Belem wants to get into the Tower. All museums in Belem are closed on a Monday.

It is a Tower!. Yes, it is an iconic sight and, if in Lisbon, you ought to see it but is it worth queuing in the midday sun to get inside? No. Having bought the combined ticket at the Monastery, it seemed a shame not to go inside but sense prevailed and we found a quieter way to enjoy the area. Tour buses and hustlers of tourist tat and selfie sticks spoil the whole place.

Expect to queue. The Torre itself is very iconic and full of history/heritage, offering a great view out onto the sea and the nearby bridges.You will have to queue a long while - once in the Torre, we were forced to wait 40 minutes down on level one while waiting to climb to the peak.But, it's definitely worth it if you have time to waste, and the nearby cafes/restaurants are ideal for a post-Torre drink.You can spend a couple of hours at the Torre easily, and it's ideal for those on a budget, with cheap entry which goes towards maintaining such an iconic spot.

Well worth a visiting!. Visited here during peak tourist season of August. We had to queue for around 20 minutes although after arriving we noticed it was possible to book before hand to avoid the queue. Also after going into the torre we had to queue again before reaching the stairs to go up the torre. The stairs are quite steep so if you are not confident on your feet I wouldn't recommend this for you. Otherwise after reaching the top of the torre there were some splendid views of Belen and Lisbon area.

Absolutely beautiful but not much to see/do. The tower is stunning, no doubt about it. We bought a combo ticket at the monastery and came here afterwards (with a stop at the modern art museum on the way). We happened to have decent timing so only had to wait maybe 10 minutes to go all the way up, and 5 more to start down, but there were people behind us who were going to have to wait a lot longer to come down. There isn't much in the way of explanations and not much to see, even from the top. It was a hot day and uncomfortable to have to wait in the sun to come back down. I am glad we went but would not repeat.
Tourist apota. Hit this first so you don't get stuck on lines for the monastery. Nice views of River. 93 step staircase to get to top. Cool history.
Didn't go in as the line was enormous. The 'floating' castle, an awesome architectural example. Didn't check out the inside as the queue was enormous and it was super hot! Worth a cheeky look!

Portugal's Epic Symbol. This tower built in the early 15th century by King Manuel is a tribute to Portuguese naval exploration- which was by then already passing. It is a building invoking Manuelite style- with the ornateness that brings to mind a wedding cake. It is similar- if much smaller than the nearby grand Monastery of the Jeronimos. It's not free and the queues can be long. Nevertheless, the park area a biting the silvery green Tagus river is pleasant. There are quite a few restaurants and bars within walking distance. You can also visit the Monument to Prince Henry and the Portuguese navigators- Dias, da Gama and Alves of Brazil. If you are interested in history don't miss this sight when in Lisbon

A symbol of Portugal sea power. That tower means a lot in Lisbon and Portuguese sea strong history. It is well preserved, but there is a big queue to get into because they allow only 50 people maximum inside.

Something to di. The queue was long to get in but quite contented to just hang around outside. It was a great respite from the heat being on the Atlantic side. Lots of stalls selling drinks even wine with a view (wine glass factored into the cost for taking home). A good place to while away if one has time to spare. Very relaxing.

Quick visit . Nice attraction for a quick visit when in Belém. Don't expect to spend long here as it's a basic tower. I'm claustrophobic so couldn't go up the spiral staircase in the tower in the end!!

Go early to avoid LONG lines. We enjoyed our visit to the Belem Tower. We waited about 90 minutes in line as they only let in a certain number of people at a time. The line is in full sun; bring your sunscreen and water. I don't know if it was worth it to wait so long. It is a significant building and the stone details are amazing. We did climb the tower; they have a good system of dealing with up and down traffic.
Floating tower. Near the beach side. Not to much to see from the inside but another historical architecture from lisbon.

Nice journey in traditional tram to charming town nearby. If you're an art lover don't miss this charming little town, especially the museum of contemporary art. They have also a nice restaurant with a terrace with great views of the river and tower. This town is really worth the visit and I recommend to get there by tram from Lisbon as the journey is beautiful.
Mid river tower. No longer mid river, this beautiful Manueline defensive tower is now joined to the harbour by a decked walkway, making it readily accessible to tourists.
Loved this spot. Great monument,definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.Located near the Saint Jeronimo monastery so it.s good idea to spent an afternoon there.
quick site to see. Interesting to understand how it was built and when built, old fort so inside not much to see and can have a long line to enter

Poor management of queues. How can the organisation in charge of this historic building leave people queuing ages on hot sun by over 30°? A lot of people give up to the visit and it's a shame for the city of Lisbon and also a big loss of money.
Its a tower at the water. Its not too bad and even better from the water but don't get over excited as it is just a tower t the water.... And that all there is to see there...

A must see World Heritage Site!. Despite the long queue, this attraction was definitely worth the wait. The stunning building in an amazing location is an iconic Lisbon image. The roof of the prison cells are very low and there are a lot of steps to the top of the building so be prepared and wear suitable shoes!Tip - Prebook your ticket to save queueing time
Bad. Very long queue under the sun. More than 2 hours for a visit that is half an hour long. The view from the tower is not exceptional. Too many people not very well managed

Very nice. We didn't enter the tower but I can say it's beautiful from outside. It's worth to go for a nice walk around that area, take pictures, have a drink. There is also the soldiers monument and you can see from there the bridge. The day was hot but a wonderful blue sky. Great for pictures.

Torre de Belem. The Torre de Belém (Belém Tower) is undoubtedly the most emblematic monument of Portugal. The tower was built in the 16th century by the river Tagus to control the entrance to the city by the sea. Very beautiful architecture ..

Nice to visit, but is it worth a long waiting time?. I bought a combination ticket at the Monastery which includes entrance to the Tour. With this pre-paid ticket you can pass the long waiting line and go directly inside the Tour. It is nice to see the tower inside and to enjoy the view from the top. But I wouldn't like to spent one hour in the waiting line for this. You can also see the beauty of the tower from the outside.
Lovely tower. Great view and place for the kids to run around. There's a small beach and great sunset view. It's hard to get a taxi to the train station from here though.

Short but amazing tower. It was quite a walk to get to the tower from where the bus stopped at belem. The walk by marina was fascinating because you would see the bridge which image was based to golden bridge of San Francisco USA. The tower looked amazing from outside. We weren't able to get into the tower as it was close when we get there, reason we didn't know. We just had a picnic on the park in front of the tower at least we had the good view. It was good trip and good find.

Go at sunset. The Torre de Belem was closed when we arrived, so we couldn't explore inside. However, we showed up around sunset and the colors were just beautiful. This was a quick stop during our trip to Lisbon, and it was worth it just to get photos of the exterior. Not crowded at all in the evening, and it's a nice area to walk around.

A lovely spot and so photo-worthy. In the general Belem area there are lots of tourist attractions. But the Torre de Belem is world-famous as a lovely photo spot and worth stopping. We were there at sunset and it was truly magical in the late afternoon light. It can be hard to get a photo that does not include the industrial port activity going on behind it on the river or on the other banks. It's not really worth waiting in line to get inside the tower itself. Just enjoy it from outside.
Like a Boat. An old fortress with 5 centuries. A stone icon of the portuguese discoveries. At that time without doctors, medications, internet, mobile phone, TV, radio. And Tryp. Great

Worth to visit if you don't line up. The best of the tower is the design outside. If you don't need to line up then it is worth to visit too, especially to get the nice views from the top.To avoid the queue you need pre-paid tickets, either as a combination with other nearby museums (like the Monasterio de los Jeronimos) or buying the ticket online (but be careful to print it out as they do not accept on your mobile screen). Also notice that the Lisboa card does not allow you to skip the queue. Some discounts apply but make sure you bring the right ids (student cards, big families, etc)...staff is quite stuborn.
Beautiful. Beautiful view of the place. but rather hard to reach by public transport. We took a cab to return to Lisbon.

Beautiful. The tower is a beautiful monument to craftsmanship and to the amazing creativity of the past. It was a real focal point and is highly attractive . Even my teenage daughter admired it's beauty . Worth visiting
Portugal family trip July 2016. beautiful landmark nex to the water. You may go in to visit however due to hot weather we didn't wait in line

belem tower. We visited the sight with my daughter who is 6 . The tower is absolutely breath taking and beautiful but lots of narrow stairs and people were not paying attention and that end of causing lots of delays. kids normally don't do well as they have to walk a lot and is not fun for them!

Beautiful moorish tower. Release your inner child by scampering up the narrow spiral staircases, peering through the battlements, and admiring the awe-inspiring beauty and intricacy of this stunning monument. Be prepared to queue though. It took us over an hour before we got in. Worth it though.

Nice place to visit, ridiculous cues. A place you must visit as they say in every brochure. Indeed a beautiful structure, but so touristy that the cue was ridiculous. In my opinion, don't go inside, just enjoy it's beauty on the outside, buy yourself an ice cream, en chill in the shade in the surrounding park.

amazing building. However you can view it from the outside and then skip the queues and the long walk up and go to the discovery museum where you can take a lift to the top and have the same amazing view! There is also a very interesting exhibition downstairs about memories of the exhibition of 1940. There is an additional movie- however it was only at 3pm and we didn't want to hang around for a couple of hours to see it.

Take a TukTuk. Might be a bit more expensive than a bus tour but for sure more personal and merting your desires as it stops for you eherever you want. Plus the driver is also your personal guide who takes you also on tour by foot if possible
Closed on Monday?. Beautiful building. We loved the tower from outside and would have loved to visit inside. Unfortunately it's closed on Mondays!

Belem is ok... the private guide we hired made is better. Interesting history, but you must have a guide to appreciate this aspect. Otherwise, Belem is a bit far out of the way for most of central LIsbon and is a waterfront promenade with some statues and tower...

Worth a visit. This tower was originally built as a defense mechanism and a landmark centuries ago much further in the sea than it is today. The grounds are worth a visit, although we didn't feel compelled to enter the tower. Be sure to visit Portugal's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier nearby.
Buy the pass!. Great site, but buy the pass so you donor have to wait in the stupid line!! You can get a ticket for 5 museums, and even if you don't see them alloy skip throne.
Great place . Had a fantastic day out at Belem. Very easy to get to and a nice walk in the sunshine. Lots of shops and little places to wander and the best place in Lisbon for "natas"

Stunning from outside. No need to stand in line to go inside.. The Tower is beautiful. It is a brilliant white and sits in stunningly beautiful blue water in front of rolling hills across the river. After standing in line in the blazing sun the reward inside is just more lines in more sun to peek over the wall and crenelations. Certainly worth the walk from The Cloister of Jeronimos Monastery (which is the whole point of going to Belem as far as I am concerned). But no need to wait on the lines. Get some ice cream or a cold drink and enjoy the park and the view.

Pretty tower. I didn't enter but just from outside is a "must see" in lisbon, and if is hot don't be afraid of refresh your feets in the water close to the tower, make a little pause, enjoy the view and take some good photos of it ;)

Beautiful tower and views. This was one of the highlights of my trip. The tower itself is beautiful on the outside, and the surrounding areas are green and nice. On top of the tower you can see the city, bridges and surrounding areas. The organisation is a little on the chaotic side, but not too bad. Narrow stairs make it a little difficult to move around.

Long queues and good views. My family visited Torre Del Belem in August 2016. The tower is a couple of miles from the centre of Lisbon so we used a tourist bus to get there. The views from the top of the tower, of Lisbon and the river Tagus are spectacular, but be prepared to queue for a long time to get in. We queued for an hour outside the tower in baking hot sun, then there were two further shorter queues inside. Take some sun lotion, sun hats and water. There are no toilets on site. The queuing system does however mean that the tower is not too busy inside so you can enjoy your visit. The exterior of the tower is best viewed from the river. I got some good photos from a river cruise that passed the tower. Interesting factoid: there was a huge earthquake in Lisbon in 1755 which changed the course of the river Tagus so much that the tower ended up on the North side of the river when it had originally been built in the middle.

Party of 10. This sight was an interesting to visit as the Torre de Belem stand in the sea and it's beautiful.The surrounding area was also a nice and we spend over 3 hours which include having lunch there before we left.

A must-see place in Lisbon!!. Belem is easily reached in 20 minutes by tram n.15 from either Figueira square or from Praca do Comercio. You can get off at the Mosteiro of Jeronimos and then walk along the river for 15 minutes to get to Belem Tower.Expect long queues at the ticket office, unless you go there in the afternoon.The tower is absolutely great and is a memento of the glorious past of Portugal. From Belem all the portuguese discoverers used to leave with their ships to discover new worlds and lands.

Lovely view from the Outside. We wanted to go inside the tower, but the queue was very long, and there is no shortcut, even if you have the Lisboa Card (which the people selling the card were not clear with us about). It wasn't worth the 1 hour + lineup to get in. The views from the outside are nice though, with the river in the background, and the mini beach next to it. Nice view from the top but cues are long. The cues are long and you could wait for upto 1hr. There is a capacity limit so once it's full you will need to wait wether you have pre booked tickets or not . O cue inside the only real notable thing to see is the view from the top . Still worth seeing but it can fr chilli with the sea breeze on a windy Lisbon day even in the peak of summer .

a long queue but you can see lots from the boulevard. this is a really nice stretch of coast to wander along, lots of look at the amazing architecture built in 1514. the queue to go inside was too much for us in the heat but just sitting outside and watching the world go by is good too

Interesting reconstructed castle. Interesting history with this castle . Make sure that you go right to the top of the tower ,all 93 steps , good photo ops up there. By your ticket along with the St Jeromes Monastery tour and you save a few euros.

AMAZING VIEW. Belem tower must be seen . It’s spectacular and magnificent. There’s a bit a walk to do and some stairs to climb but it’s all worth while. Once you’ve seen the tower you can walk to the park have lunch and buy souvenirs.

Nice enough, but lost its appeal after queuing for an hour. This is a very popular attraction, with limited capacity and preference given to people who already have tickets. We didn't already have tickets and queued for an hour to get in. Based on the size of the queue when we left, we may have been lucky to get away with an hour.Once inside, there isn't a great deal to see, it's interesting enough and there are excellent views from half way up the tower. We couldn't be bothered to join the long, slow queue waiting to get further up, especially as people ignored the system the should ensure people weren't climbing and descending at the same time, which made the process extremely slow.Worth a visit out of season, or very early before the queues and only if tickets have already been bought.

You can't not do this. Only a few € to get inIt's such a landmark you can't not go hereWe had to queue to get to the upper levels but it was worth it (there's restricted capacity)Nice views out the to JC monument on the other side of the estuary and of the bridge

Worth it if you have time, but slightly underwhelming. We visited early afternoon and after quite a long wait got up to the top of the tower to enjoy the views. These were good but perhaps not worth the wait. The place itself is also quite small so doesn't take long to get round. One to do if you have an hour or two spare.

Best seen from outside. The Torre de Belem is a great building from the outside- lovely architecture. However it is space limited (only 120 visitors allowed at any one time) so the queue was extremely long- we waited for over an hour to enter and unfortunately the interior was not worth the wait - view from the outside, or only go in if the queue is small

Have to come here. if you decide to go to Belem, you must come here!!! Top visits in Lisbon. Amazing and spectacular is the least description. Magnificent in everyway. My advice is visit Monastery Jeronimo and then walk to Torre de Belem. i advice to come here early morning or around 3pm because they close at 6pm. and then when you are done, walk to the park and have lunch/snack and rest there. Fresh air!

Beautiful old building.. Well worth the visit. We took the tram to Belem and went back on the bus. You have to do quite a bit of walking to get from the bus or tram stop to the tower, but it is well worth it.
Nice view.. Worth the long walk from the train station Alges as I thought the train will stop in Belem but it did not. Good for photo ops.:)

Catches Your Eye. As you walk from the Monument to the Discoveries, you can see the Torre in the distance. It is on a little "island" separated from the shore by a walkway. Nice park area in front and many tourists dropped off by bus. We just took pictures from the outside as it hadn't opened yet.
Deference Tower. It looks great from the outside and it's very different to other tourist attractions in the area. OK
Not worth the queue. Long queues for going up and down 93 stairs.If you have been around, this tower is not that special.

Beautiful architecture. I love the architecture of this tower. It's beautiful from the outside. I can't say what the view is like from the top because even though we had free entrance with the Lisboa Card it doesn't grant you access to skip the line, so we would have had to wait on the long line with everyone else looking to buy a ticket. We didn't really want to spend an hour+ waiting on that line so we passed. We walked along the shoreline, stopping to have lunch along the way, to the Monuments of the Discoveries (which is also included in the Lisboa Card) and were able to go straight up on an elevator that takes you up almost to the top. And from here you get a great view of the beautiful Belem tower. This monument was not at all crowded and being taller than the Belem tower offered better views.

Guardian of Lisbon. The Torre de Belem watches the entrance to Lisbon - the tower was built in the Manueline style on a small island in the Tagus River near the Lisbon shore in the beginning of the 16th century - as a part of the defense system of the river Tagus.It is fairly small and easily seen in short time - if only the queues and the overall design allowed it.The queues for entrance is quite often very long (count on more than one hour), and once inside there are queues for going up and down the tower - due to the extremely narrow staircase, where two people cannot pass in opposite directions.Tickets can be obtained on the web, but do still expect long queues.It is quite interesting to see the cramped and narrow quarters, where first the people manning the towers fortifications had to live - and later the use as a secure prison (mostly for political opponents of the current regents) after surrendering the tower to Spanish forces in 1580 - a usage that was effective until 1830.A good way to visit the Belem Tower is to take the tram 15 to the Jerónimos Monastery, cross the road (there is a pedestrian underpassage by the end of the small park opposite the monestary) and then walk along the river. By taking this route, you'll also pass the Padrão dos Descobrimentos, the impressive monument raised to commemorate the golden age of the Portuguese explorations and discoveries.Going back you can take the tram 18 back from the small rotunda near the monastery (it's the old type of tram). Cafés and restaurants are also abundant in this area.
Beautiful tower on edge.. Be here in the early hours as this is a populair visiting site for tourist. The line wil be very long. Definately worth visiting.

Joint visit toTorre de Tower and Monastery. We went early so only queued for a short time to gain entry. We bought a joint ticket for the tower and monastery which saved a little money. If I were to go again would definitely investigate buying tickets online as there is a different line to get in pre booked and when we came out , there was a long queue to get in. There is a maximum number of people allowed in at one time. The tower itself is very impressive from the exterior. Inside is now empty but interesting . You follow a red/green light system to go up the spiral staircase and the view at the top is very pleasant.

Belem Tower. Avoid the crowds by visiting early--we went on a Sunday & there were long queues early in the morning. Allow approx. 60-90 minutes for the interior. Consider purchasing a combined "Lisboa Monumental" ticket that allows access to the tower, Jerónimos Monastery & the Ajuda Palace. For a different perspective, take a river sightseeing cruise: the boat passes right by the tower & you will have great photo opportunities!
Look for the Nautical Elements. Not only is there numerous elements of neat Nautical architecture, but it is a beautiful structure. A fantastic example of Portugal's excellent and powerful past

Be advised of the top. If you had a big line up at the beginning, you'll have a big line up to get down of the tower!! Bring a cap and solar cream, we had to wait 30 minutes to get down from little staircase. You can leave your strollers at the entrance.
Beatiful. Very beautiful place to just sit and relax to watch sunset. At night time they also do lighting. One of the good places to visit in Lisbon

Iconic and fairytale like tower in Belem. Belem Tower is a early 16th century building and UNESCO World Heritage attraction that we found to be the most interesting attraction in Belem during our recent visit to Lisbon. Opening Hours are 10am to 6:30pm during the summer period. Entry tickets are €6 or you can purchase combo tickets which include entrance to the Jeronimos Monastery (€12). There is a further combo ticket for (€25) that gives you further access to the Nacional Arqueologia, Entnologia and two Coches museums in Belem. The tower is a decorative fortification that is accessed by a footbridge. The exterior of the Belem Tower is particularly impressive featuring open balconies, battlements lined with rope carved adornments, Moorish style watchtowers and statue figures. It is nothing short of a fairytale-like structure that is a delight to see from the outside. Within Belem Tower, you have access to the ground floor as well as several rooms within the tower, which you can enter as you wind your way up the interior staircase. There is a large open area up one short flight of stairs and another at the top of the tower itself. The rooms you can visit are quite plain from the inside but include plenty of views to the outside world. There is a lovely arcaded logia on the second level room which overlooks the open space within the fortification and the sea. This is a particularly nice part of the tower to see and visit. Throughout your visit, you'll be clicking picture of the building, views of Belem and the sea. In the end, we very much enjoyed visit to Belem Tower. It is worth the entrance fee to experience this attraction. However, it is also rewarding just to see Belem Tower from the outside if you are short on time and don't wish to wait in the queue to enter. Note: Due to limited space and visitor capacity, entrance and visits can be slow going at times. Only certain number of people can be in the upstairs rooms of the tower at the same time. As such, there is some waiting around at times. This is something to consider if you are short on time for your visit to Belem.

Good sight to checkout. This whole area of Lisbon (Belem) allows the visitor to soak up the maritime history of Lisbon. Gardens, walkways, statues with plenty of space for the many summer tourists. I didn't pay the euros to go inside the Torre (and a guide later said he didn't think it was worth it, anyway, so I can't comment on the interior). But it's worth having a wander around that area.

A must do but not awesome. Best to visit and view from the outside , nothing special inside . Fantastic view and a nice bit of history and the most famous landmark of Lisbon . Nearby is the museum of the flame , a military museum which is interesting

To long waiting queques for such place. When you get there on a nice day you may end up waiting several times. First at the entrance, than when you are in you have to wait at the square to get in the tower and in the tower you have to go up the stairs all the way and wait again each time you want to go down one level. In addition, the interior isn't that interesting. Make a picture from the out side and move on to other more interesting sites.

Ticket with Jeronimos Monastery. Well, just a glimpse of what Lisbon is all about telling everybody that by wate, Portuguese became real and genius sea navigators and conquered a lot of islands and made it popular by now.

Not worth the waiting time!. Looking at the tower is much more interesting than going inside. It's neither worth the waiting time nor the money. The View from the top is nice but there is basically nothing else inside.

Part of the belem tour. Torres de belem is a part of the belem trip and in my opinion you should visit, it is a landmark of Lisbon after all. Do it as part of your day trip to belem and it won't dissapoinr. You will also find a military museum and monument right next door as well as the seafarers monument.
Fairytale castle. Again, long queues and very hot on the day we were there so just took pictures of the outside and walked around the outskirts.

get ready for lines. When I first visited this historical tower in the 70's it was soOoo different from now. Even had furniture from the 16th century in it. It was free, no waiting and the dungeon was amazing after listening the interesting details as (when the tie was up, the prisoners had to stand here to breathe..), all the guns were there too. It was like traveling to the past. Now, it's so different. The store inside the tower, the modernized aspect, the traffic lights in the stairs (very narrow and a lot of climbing mind you), and the chance of taking good pictures without someone in the way... good luck with that. Nobody explains the first floor where you could whisper in a corner for another person on the opposite corner without the person in the middle of the room listening.. Cute details that tourists walk by with noticing.. Still, worth always a visit and imagine when you are on top, that from there,... many ships from the discoveries passed by.FREE every 1st Sunday of the month!

Get there early. Worth a visit but need get there early Only allow 120 people in at a time so can queue for ages in the sun. Winding narrow steps to top but worth it for views. Outside there are deck chairs outside with a girl with a trolley making drinks including mojitos. Best mojitos ever. One of the places along with monestary to visit in Lisbon.

nice, but not spectacular. well, it's a spectacular outside view, but the inside it's not worth. there are a lot of people to visit inside. or upstairs you must wait long time. the access is made watched by a traffic light. but even with this light the are some "traffic jam". we've been cached by red light while we descend, so we have wait that all the people who go upstairs to get into first level. my personal opinion is that Belem tower is not worth the entrance. anyway, the cellars was nice
Nice View. Was pretty fun to wander around, very busy so didn't go inside but got some good photos on a lovely day

Overrated site seeing experience. We were already warned about visiting the Torre de Belem. And when we arrived we noticed a small tower with a huge queue of mainly Asian people. Okay the building looks nice, but to be honest it isn't that special. It's way too crowded and a lot of street vendors spoil the atmosphere with their cheap sunglasses and scarfs.
Iconic view of Lisbon Portugal. great visit to this site using tram from city center but found closed on a Monday very annoying, but plenty of other attractions to visit around the site

Great attraction. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit here! Amazing views from the top! A must see for tourists to Lisbon! It's in a lovely area where you can have a stroll along the water front and stop for a coffee along the way!

Go to the top and look around... This monumental tower built as early as 16th century has got an elegant architecture and gives opportunity to look around from the top. It is not difficult to climb the stairs, however be prepared to wait in line for about 15-20 minutes depending on the number of visitors. This is very rational, as the space is narrow to allow passage of one person in the staircase.
Beautiful. Great walk around the water front and to Belem for coffee and treats - Lots of see and do and experience as this is living history
My favorite's area. The sea, the monuments, the museums, the restaurants... Everything is perfect here I wish I could have spend more time here !

Great viewing of this iconic tower.. Unfortunately we had not checked the closing times.....we arrived in the area, wandered round a bit, had an ice cream. Then walked to the tower entrance to find (along with dozens of other tourists) that it closes at 5pm. It was 2 minutes past : (Oh well, the exterior views were great.

Torre de Belém . Make a trip to this beautiful, historic site. We opted for a tuck-tuck tour of the Belém district. I would recommend it highly! We didn't have to walk a whole lot, our driver Ze was knowledgable and kind. We saw the tower of Belém and the Jerónimos Monastery. Both are rare and beautiful examples of Portuguese architecture.
Impressive piece of history . It is indeed worth to pay the 12 euros for entrance in both monastery and the tower. Two beautiful pieces of architecture and a lot of history on them.
Waste of time and money. My advice is to take pictures from outside. It is not worth to pay, go inside, wait in the queue and go to the tower.

Visit the Tower!. Great views and worth the small lines. The trips up and down the stairs are not well-timed so that people are passing on the narrow spiral staircase, but the views are worth the hassle.
Cool views. If you like a nice view and want to take nice pictures of it. The Belém Tower is one of the better places to visit.

Nice climb. This tower on the coast of Lisbon had excellent vistas and an historic feel. The inside stairs were interesting in that you must wait for the other groups going up and down - its that narrow.

Amazing piece of Lisbon's history. One of the main things people visit Belem for, and I can see why. Spent a few hours here, which I wasn't expecting as it looks fairly modest from outside. It's a bit like a TARDIS, and there's lots inside and out to look at and read about. Lots of information throughout the tower of its history and creation. Beautiful inside and out, and a really interesting place to go. Also has excellent views of the 25 April bridge and the Lisbon coast. Was €6 when I went in June, so really good value. Highly recommend!
Great view!. Visited here as part of the hop on hop off bus tour. Incredible view from the top so well worth a visit

Best time to go there is at sunset - amazing colors!. It's so nice there, even though just going for a walk, coffee or chilling. Definitely "a must" to see and take pictures, while in Lisbon! ;) Take an old tram, to experience the proper Lisbon feeling! (or electric one, if you are in the rush, cuz old one will take much more time)
Worth seeing.. Busy but in a nice setting - with plenty of much needed shade when we were there. Very busy if you wanted to climb the tower.
Belem in the Charming Lisbon. The tower is really beautiful. You have to go with plenty of time. I love Portugal !!! After Lisbon its an excellent idea visiting Madeira Island.
Beautiful Tower. Beautiful tower by the beach... Certainly one of the highlights of Lisbon & a must to visit if you are in the city... Next to a few other attractions too...
Very cool to see but not worth the climbe. This area is very cool to see, but the wait and climb to the top could be avoided. very touristy area but a great place to see a lot of interesting things.

To crowded not worth the wait. Beautiful castle with nice views. However, the walk was long in the hot sun and the line was very long (many people visit the monastery then come here next). Watch for pick pockets and street vendors in the area. Right next door across from the monastery you may alternatively enjoy the better vistas from the Monument to The Discoveries. 8 Euros for an elevator up to the vista lookout. Small crowds, worth the view! Just visit the outside of the castle for photo opportunities instead.
Historical site. We visited the Torre de Belem early in the day but it was still very busy. It opens at 10am and closes at 5pm.

Maritime discoveries. A fortress constructed at mouth of Tagus river for military defense. The tower was Tower was the starting point for the voyages of maritime discovery, and was the last sight of the homeland for the adventurers. It was the lamdmark of the Portuguese for their golden era of age of discoveries.

"Well-presented and fascinating maritime historical site". Torre de Belem lived up to our expectations and existing knowledge, but the little-known posted anecdote regarding the famous "Portuguese rhinoceros", was a fascinating historical snippet! Well-administered, efficient and spotlessly maintained maritime defense fortress. Warning: the 93 steep steps to the top of the tower may be daunting to senior citizens!

look from the outside. This iconic building is well worth a visit from the outside. If you want to go inside you queue for a very long time for tickets and entry and there is not much to see. To get a tower view is another long queue with limited access

Beautiful Site but Crowded. This is a beautiful landmark that is well maintained and also has beautiful views of the water and the bridge. You can explore multiple levels of the tower, each with it's own character, including the basement where prisoners were held. It would have been more enjoyable had it not been so crowded, but we did go smack in the middle of the day; perhaps a morning visit would have been quieter? I recommended buying the multi-pass so you can see all the sites in Belem at a reduced price (Don't miss Jeronimo Monastery!!!)

Really crowdy place with lot of street vendors and beggars. On the walk from the Monastery you cas meet a lot of street vendors selling selfie sticks, scarf and etc. You have to refuse them almost every 10 seconds of your 20 minutes long walk and it is really annoying. Tower is nice, but there is a big queve for entrance. We expected more.

Best view was from the river. It was sad to see t he Torre de Belem covered by scaffolding. I know renovation work needs to take place but photographing it like that was a bit of a let down. We managed a wonderful s unset cruise and saw it by the river which made up for the days visit

Visually impressive. On a day out to Belem we visited the Monastery, and chose to spend a few euros going to the top of the Padrao Dos Descobrimentos - in english its the big white monument you can go to the top of, see for miles and take superb photos. We walked down to the Belem Tower but decided that the only thing to be gained by going inside was the view and we'd just been up higher than that anyway. We decided that the Belem Tower was probably more impressive when viewed from the outside than by going inside (translated: there was a queue to get in and I swear a glass of cool white wine was shouting to me). From the outside it certainly is spectacularly beautiful and the walk down the coast to get to it is easy and interesting. I would recommend a visit even if, like us you choose not to go in.

Great Visit to Torre de Belem. The tower itself is beautiful and has fascinating architecture, well worth the visit! The queue to get inside was long and we didn't go in, but we enjoyed the trip nonetheless.

Great views of the city. Well worth spending an afternoon in Belem and this with the monastery is one of many hi lights. It's about 6€ entry and you can buy a combined ticket to see other attractions. Prepare for a short queue to go up to the top but all worth it.

Beautiful but busy . Torre De Belem, is an extremely beautiful situated at the mouth of the Tagus river and serves as a gateway to Lisbon. It was built as a part of the defense system, but the architectural style is absolutely beautiful. You can buy the ticket along with Jeronimos monastery and save hours waiting in the queue at the tower. The 1st level terrace is spectacular and gives you great views of the city and the tower itself. The queues to go up on the higher level are really long and not worth the wait as the stairway going up is really narrow, you hardly get 2 minutes on the upper terrace when you manage to get here and I prefer the view from the 1st level.

History and tradition. We will be back again! This place is full of energy, people, history, architecture and of course, pickpockets. If you want to go inside this little fortress, be prepared to deal with the lines. Still, the surrounding landscape alone, is worth the visit.

Cool place. Not sure it is really worth paying to go inside. This tower is pretty neat but I don't think it was worth paying to go inside. There was a pretty big line to go up in the tower and we didn't want to wait around for that.

Torre de Belem. There were no archaeological relics on display, but it was still neat to see. The narrow spiral stairs to the top restrict travel to one direction. If you are able-bodied, try to get to the front of the line, otherwise let those who are go before you. We managed to be up front and there were still people coming up the stairs, gasping for breath, five minutes after we had been there.

Neat structure. Neat structure next to the sea, but smaller than the pictures you see may suggest. Walked there from the monastery. There's also a nice park nearby. Worth a visit if you're in the area.

Gorgeous building, turn up early to avoid the queues. We arrived shortly before 10am on the first Sunday of the month, when the tower is free to visit. We queued, but only until it opened, then were straight in. When we left, there were people queuing for some time to get in, as the building only holds 120 so it's a system of one-out-one-in.The building is its own main attraction. There is some historical information in the various rooms, but basically it's the fabulous architecture and the views that are worth going for. Personally, I don't think it would be worth queuing more than 30 minutes to get in, especially if you're paying for entry.
Traditional point to visit. . It is impossible to visit Lisbon and not got to Torre de Belem. But be prepared for long lines if you decide to go upstairs.
Nice views. Nice views but overpriced and can get very crowded. Go as early as possible. Narrow stairs. Silly tourists don't understand their sophisticated traffic control system.

Great building and views. The approach to the building is beautiful, but if you're queueing for a ticket you have a long wait and an even longer wait to get to the higher tiers. The staff seemed a little overwhelmed and were randomly directing us to the gift shop only to have to loop back to get up. The queue was so long to go to the higher levels and they just keep people waiting that we left before getting much higher. Definitely go at quiet times of the day if you want to enjoy the architecture and views, but there's not much else.

Watch from the outside. Waste of time and money. Came on free Sundays, took almost an hour to get in only to discover that I need to wait another 40 to go up the tower. There's nothing much to see inside, and the view from tower is nothing special. An awful waste of time and, if you pay, money.

Can't miss attraction . Beautiful site to visit in Lisbon. Try to see it with a guide so you can get the full impact of this impressive site!! This was our first trip to Lisbon and we were told this is one of the standards and it was!

Worth the climb?. Yes. The best way to get there is by taxi. It is said that the tower was the last thing the sailors saw when they set sail, and the first thing when they return home. You have to climb 93 steps in order to get up top and see the view. Be aware that the steps are spiral and abrupt. In every first sunday of every month the entry is free of charge.

Not just tarts !!!. Had a fab morning here....Walking,views,people watching,architecture..... As well as fab carts selling home made traditional lemonades,cocktails and ice creams...We traveled here and back via the fab tuk-tuk's( be warned prices to vary.... Only 5€ each one way..... But on the way back we were only charged 5€ each Adults( child free)!!!!Glad we went.....And dont forget your tart!!!!'

A long walk from Jeronimos Monastery. After a long hot walk from the Monastery we found another queue to get into the tower, so opted for a snack in a shady area instead. Sunday is obviously not the day to attempt this visit

Belem Tower. It is worth taking a taxi or tuk-tuk to see Belem Tour. It's a beautiful park and the tower is situated at the entrance to the Lisbon harbor. The architecture is fantastic and well worth seeing when visiting Lisbon.

mystic. Managed to see this as a cross product of a different tour. saw it at night which added to the mystique of the place and ZERO tourists....so you could walk around and get some great shots...didn't go inside as it was nightime- but imagine notyhing more to see than what can be seen by doping other things in Lisbon- still an iconic place to view
Along the River.. Walk along the river and there is plenty to see including this wonderful site. Stop off at the cafe and enjoy the sangria.

guide needed. If You have a guide - it will be interesting to look and listed - actually, this Tower protected the city and has a lot to tell You. What impressed me - it's blind-friendly miniature to be touched and studied - great respect for people with disabilities

Beautiful view and architecture but that's it.. The tower is beautiful, but that's pretty much it. You won't find anything interesting inside. There are too few historical information panels to read. There is a video in Portuguese we couldn't understand. The whole thing was a bit underwhelming. But, I guess, you need to see it if you visit Lisbon.
Watch the tower. This nice old watch tower is hard to miss in the waterfront park in Belem but not worth a trip if it is out of your way.
Great Park. Here you get to see the Torre de Belem as well as seeing the statue of Vasco de Gama and the other intrepid Portuguese explorers. It was a great stop on our tour of Lisbon

Good view from the outside. The Torre de Belem is frequently recommended as a top attraction on most visitors lists to Lisbon and from the exterior it is worth visiting to take in the history and design of this structure. I chose to visit the monastery first as it was nearest to the bus stop and on entry you are given the option of a ticket to gain access to both the monastery and the tower. I would recommend this option as it allows you to avoid the long queues at the tower when you arrive. The tower itself is approximately a 15-20 minute walk from the monastery and provides you with a pleasant walk along the river front taking in the small harbours and restaurants that occupy the approach. If you approach from this direction you are greeted with a shot of the tower and the wooden bridge and queue waiting to gain entry. If you have brought your ticket in advance you can bypass the queue and go straight to the front.. This is not advertised or directed however close to the front of the queue there is a separation for ticket holders and those looking to purchase. On my visit the ticket holders queue was empty and when I joined this I was directed inside bypassing the queue of around 50 or 60 people. If you have a duel entry ticket walk past the waiting queue and go to the front.The inside of the tower is somewhat lacking, there are cannons inside the interior main level however no real description of the history or purpose of the tower. There is a small staircase that goes down to the lower levels and cells, there is no real description or detail as to the history or purpose of these cells, there are very low and require bending to get inside. I would personally bypass this as there are no views or reason to go down. Instead go up to the first level. Depressingly you will then find another queue to reach the top level. You can capture some nice shots of the first level and the structure itself from here. There are approximately 4 small observation towers you can sit inside momentarily to get a shot of the river and bridge. If you wish to go to the top level which seems like the only point for paying to go in you're then required to join the queue to go up the staircase.On the day of my visit there was an approximately 15-20 minute wait to get inside the tower first, then another 10 minute wait as the single circling staircase was emptied to get to the top. In my opinion this largely felt like an accident waiting to happen as they have installed some form of alert siren to let you know the stairs were in use but from the top this was largely being ignored. There is no suggestion here how to improve the building without major renovation work but whilst an employee was providing an element of queue control on the first level at the middle and top there was no one. The staircase was narrow and circular so you need to have good attrition and fitness to climb to the top.The views from the top were pleasant but not spectacular. You were afforded a view of the bridge and the river and the military museum close to the tower. And then began the process of joining the queue at the top to get down. My total visit to the tower was about an hour, half of which was in the queue to get to the top to get some pictures of the surrounding area. On leaving the tower you can walk around to the opposite side and get some better pictures without the bridge and queue of people. This I would recommend you to do. In summary if you want to visit this tower to capture that image used to advertise the attraction save yourself some money and time and just go around and take that picture. There is little to see inside and you will save yourself time from standing in a queue. If you have a joint entry ticket and you do want to go inside make sure you bypass the initial queue of people otherwise you will spend more time in a queue than feels necessary.

Game of Thrones styleee.... This building is amazing. We didn't go inside but the view from the top will be great. From the outside the building looks very historic, significant. We visited when using a hop on/off bus.
Overrated . I get that this is an historic site. But due to its size, you have to wait in line to go up the tower 30-40 min. Nice views but not impressed . Spend your time elsewhere .

Overrated. Better watch it from the outside and don't waste money to get upstairs. It really doesn't worth it: nothing particular inside, not a fantastic view. I was really disappointed for 12 euro wasted both for Jeronimos and The Belem Tower. There are a lot more interesting things to see in Lisbon.

Great From a Distance. My first glimpse of the Torre was filled with awe. Unfortunately, upon getting closer, I was appalled to see all of the trash in/around the Torre including the filthy water surrounding the Torre. There seemed to be quite a bit of deferred maintenance around the site and the mass of tourists waiting in line to get into the Torre (not to mention the hordes sitting around the Torre) was circus-like. My advice is to visit the site in conjunction with the nearby Padrao dos Descobrimentos, Mosterio dos Jeronimos and the underappreciated Palacio Nacional da Ajuda which, in my opinion, is the real gem.

Nothing too special . It's good to see. Waited for 30+ mins to get in, just for the view. It's quite a walk from the monastery but it's on all tour books if you visit Belem. I would say nothing special but good to see.

Historic tower. 500 year old tower built to defend the mouth of the river. In very good condition. Wouldn't have wanted to be one of the poltical prisoners locked up in the basement. Great views from the top if you can face 96 steps on a small spiral staircase. Opens at 10.00 and best to get there early to beat the queues. Good value at 6 euros.
Don't expect a high tower!. Lower your expectancies and you'll be able to enjoy this beautiful construction. A lot of historical value here and the surroundings have a really cool vibe.

Gorgeous views! . We bought a combination ticket when we visited the monastery so we got to skip the long queue outside. We then looked around the lower levels. To get to the top of the tower there is only one staircase which is one way so we had to queue. We queued for about 15 minutes and then we thought we could go up, no, we got taken into another room, and they put up a sign to say it would be another 30-40 minutes, we waited for about 25 minutes before being able to go up to the top. Many people were sitting on the floor as it took so long to queue. However I'm not sure what else they can do to prevent this as the staircase is only wide enough for one way at a time! The views were fabulous though!
Great to visit museums. For visiting museums it is a great area. There are some bars and restaurants too! But to go shopping or walk the streets you should better go in another district.

Beautiful very old cathedral 20 min by bus from Lisbon. . Very beautiful old cathedral 20 min. by bus from Lisbon. .. In Belém you see the Atlantic Ocean, magnificent maritime monuments and boats going along the wide Rio Tejo brings you back to the age of discovery, where Portugal was a dominant colonial power. And when evening time comes it thins out in the streets and the soft light paint the monastery towers golden, you can even leisurely from which to explore this neighborhood by the river .... NB. A tip; Get up early and go directly to Belem's top draw the great Mosteiro dos Jeronimos to the stunning church and monastery. .. Almost ... all to yourself. Then you take the tour of the Museu Nacional dos Coches .. Eat lunch (prices are to overcome) takes you on one of the bistros overlooking the park on Rua Vieira Portuense .... Very worth seeing
Better in the research than in person. An interesting site ... especially if you are a photographer. But after that, well, it kinda fizzles.

A must see part of Lisbon. We came in the late afternoon via a Tuk Tuk tour and enjoyed seeing the lovely views and learning about Lisbon history. While the line was short to initially get in the site, the wait to climb up the tower was long. If you are traveling with another person or group, once inside the site, get in line immediately and then trade off waiting in line while taking photos. You can also take great photos at the end.
Well organised. We were lucky to buy our tickets at the monastery so we avoided the long line of tourists standing on the bridge. Its better to start your day early to avoid the crowds.

Great views and history at the same time. Stopped here as it is one of the destinations to see while in Lisbon. Great historical place to see where famous sailing vessels left (Vasco de Gama, etc.) to explore the unknown world. Very narrow staircase to get to the top but they keep the queuing to a minimum. You have to expect this due to the single person winding staircase. Folks who complained about this in their review need to respect the safety aspect of this. Other than this it was a great place to view the bridge, Rio Cristo statue and the harbor area.

A fancy thing today... When we saw a long line of people at the ticket office under the stinging Sun, we were glad we had bought tickets in the Lisbon Jeronimos monastery, which we had visited before. This allowed us to enter without a long waiting. The Belem tower - one can fancy - used to be in the middle of the river, and the earthquake had moved her onto the bank to surprise the residents. 500 years ago it seemed a frightening fortification, - now it looks homey, like a great children's attraction. It is worth visiting if one had prepared himself to develop a feeling of history. You just picture how it was all in the past... Here were the prisoners, here were the soldiers, here were the top military men, the kitchen, the flour cellar, the armoury room, but where was the toilet?... Inside the excursion is a bit chaotic - too many tourists wishing to get inside and you need to hurry up get down if you need to hide away from the Sun on top, as the people are circulated in shifts of 120 each. 120 go up, 120 go down inside the narrow staircase.It is a part of Lisbon's history, and you cannot avoid it!
Nice historical tower. The location and tower is interesting. The visit of the tower top is an annoying waiting in queues. One might think of some better organisation.

Awesome views . Bit of a trek in howling winds and rain to get there but it was worth it. Just enough information and fanastic views out over the river and over towards the city. Almost blown away at the top but very refreshing! Well worth a visit.
Lovely place. Fine for a walk along the river or on to the (Military) museum - plenty of cafe's & restaurants. Belem Castle is nice to see - but we didn't pay to enter.

Fascinating place.. Went on a weekday at around 11:00. Twenty minute wait, but well worth it. Great views of the Tagus River and the history of the tower is just as compelling. The 6€ fee is reasonable. Be prepared to climb up narrow curving stairwells; but it's a tower, so you should expect that. When we left the tower, the lines were three times as long. Since they only allow 120 people in at a time, that wait might be a bit too long, especially on a hot summer day.
Experience the marine history of Lisbon. Belem is a twenty minute tram ride from the centre of old Lisbon. Once there you will be spoilt for choice for culture and history. Don't miss it.

Another tourist in Belem. This completes the important sites in Belem, together with the Jeronimos Monastery, Monument to the Discoveries and Pateis de Belem. This can be reached by walking from where the tram stops at Jeronimos Monastery. It's quite a far walk going back to the tram ride from here but there are taxis available near the road,

beautiful <3. we were lucky as it was not overcrowded and day was breezy but hot...tower is incredibly impressive !!! great view and located just by the water, gives it to it's magic !!! Go for a walk around and then enjoy an hour or so in the park next to it ,,,perfect day out <3

Nice view but not essential. This former fort is mostly visited as a viewpoint, which requires climbing 92/93 (the signs differ) tiny winding steps up a spiral staircase. This is claustrophobic and made me a little dizzy. When you get to the top, it's very windy, and you can't go down until all 120 people let in at once have made it to the top. Then everyone can go down. You can stop at the intermediate floors on the way down, which have interesting educational placards, but the fear of missing the down period and getting stuck while the next 120 went up made us rush through and head out ASAP. The waiting time is clearly signposted as 30-40 minutes before you even cross the bridge to the tower, and is a reasonable estimate, depending on when in the cycle you arrive. The historical information in the other parts of the tower is not much beyond what we learned at the monastery, and not worth a visit if you're not going to do the climb.

A train to Belem and Cascais. We took the trams and trains all over Portugal, what fun. We went to Cascais and on the way back stopped in Belem. This was a beautiful sight and photo opt at any angle. It does charge a fee, but if you have a Lisbon card (which I totally recommend) is free.It closes at 5:00 daily, so plan on that.

Too busy . We visited the tower when in Belem. We had high expectations but they were only just that... It seems to lack some historical information and the queuing system to go up to the tower is ridiculous. Going down is even worse... Not worth the wait to go up... It has great potencial to be a great building now as it used to be.

An historical must view!. Formerly an ancient fortress by the middle of the Tejo River, the Torre de Belém guaranteed the entrance of Lisbon’s harbor. Made to seem as a ship made of rock from the sea, this fortress was able to defend Lisbon from his enemies.Nowadays, it holds some interesting public exhibitions and gives you a view to Belem landscape.

Beautiful monument, do not pay to enter!!. The Tower is a beautiful construction that is best enjoyed from the outside. Trust me!We had to wait nearly an hour to get into a space where theres absolutely nothing and to go up the tower is another hour to get a view that's quite limited in comparison to the one that the Navigators monument offer (which is 10 mins away on foot).In fact, if you wish to truly enjoy this beauty, be sure to take a boat tour to experience it the way it was meant to be seen.
Historic but crowded!. We went on a hop on/off tour and the crowds to the entrance were large. We did not enter the facility because of the line but got some great photos of it and the river
Beautiful. All the museums are free the first Sunday of every. So we got in for free was not expecting that. The views are great.
A monument of history. This is a small beautiful tower which was used at one time as a fort, prison and custom office. This historical structure is a land mark of Lisbon.
Impressive. We did not go into this due to time constraints, but it is situated in a striking position on open ground. Good for photographs and getting views of the Tagus estuary.

Historic building. The tower is a very interesting building that was used as fortress, prison and customs office. Access to the top level (about 93 steps in a very narrow starcase) is strictly controlled but worth the wait
Beautiful old tower. It was a delightful day for a stroll down to the tower from my hotel. A beautiful site and sight! Best not done on a Sunday when there are big crowds!
Relaxing spot. Cool spot to rest my feet. Easy accessibility by public transportation. Great place for pictures. Close to nice park. Don't miss the pastry shop nearby.

Small tower yet beautiful. The tower is a small one, yet the beauty of the architecture need to be appreciated. The base of the tower is in the water. There is a park adjacent to this tower with lots of greenery.

The tower at the end of Lisbon. The Belem tower is right at the end of Lisbon. The tower looks beautiful and the view of the city from the top is just amazing. You can see the monastery, the bridge and the ships in the water; the whole thing.They allow only 120 people at a time in the tower and they do it in batches. There is just one staircase up, with steep stairs some 200 of them. Once you reach the top, there is a small landing to enjoy the view and click as many pics as one wants. Nice place and a must see.

Nice Historical Landmark . Visited the Torre de Belem with my family & we all enjoyed it immensely. Best to get there early, or to buy your tickets in advance as the line ups are quite long (take some extra patience with you, especially as you'll be in line in the sun) The tower itself is quite nice to walk around and see. There are 2 levels up which you can visit, and one lower level (where the prisons were) The highest level has quite a bit of a wait as it's to go up, or down, 92 super narrow stairs to the highest level of the Torre de Belem. Once you are up there, the views are absolutely breathtaking. The lower level is also quite interesting to see. Overall, nice place to visit with the family. As for price, not sure how much it costs as it was free with our Lisboa Card.
Must see. The tower itself is beautiful, but be careful - it can be a bit windy.I recommend visiting it early on the morning, buying tickets in advance. Later in the day it can be really crowded.
Torre de Belem. If you go to Lisbon and miss this landmark shame on you. You can get out here many different ways and it well worth the visit.
Interesting architecture . We got here on a Monday when the tower was closed - not sure what you can see when it's open. It's partially in water but it's still well preserved.

History and great views. We took full advantage of our Lisboa Card with allowed us free entry to this attraction. This is a wonderful way to get a sense of the history of lisbon and its navel and maritime history. Not a good recommendation for people who don't like steps and activity is limited due to visitor numbers being managed for health and safety issues.

Amazing historical place. This is the place from where the crazy sailors took off to discover the world!!! Make sure to come and visit the site, its pretty for sunset and pay attention to the reflection of the tower on the water.

Amazing. You don't have to spend money to enjoy the beauty of this iconic landmark, The river edge laps up in front of it, and many visitors were taking photos with the tower in the background. We just walked around the outside, but even that was worth going to Belem for.

Very disappointing . Years ago this was a must see for a trip to Lisbon. We take a group there every year, but will no longer be taking them there. They have changed the way you can go up into the towers and now it requires a very long wait needed together at the bottom. You have to wait there until the current group comes down. Then you are all marched up to the top together and must stay there until they say you can all come down together again. There were so many people that it was impossible to get anywhere close to the walls to enjoy the view. They also refused to give the American teenagers the student discount because they didn't have a student ID card like the Europeans have. Their passports were not good enough to prove their ages. When my husband explained that America does not have the same type of ID cards for students, the response was, "you could be lying". This is totally inappropriate and we will not take anyone there again. This is the same woman who last year have them the student discount! Enjoy the beautiful view from the outside, and then go on to see something where you will be treated with respect!

500 y old and going strong. Stopped to view the Torre on a bike tour. It is built right on the Tagus River in view of the 25 de Abril Bridge. Did not go inside since it is empty. Wonderful view of history of a 500 year old structure.
Sunset time. It's amazing to walk there and have ur sunset wine , u can stay all the day there just walk have a lunch or so , torre de belem u have to see it
Beautiful views. Tricky steps but well worth it!! Also don't miss the café offering views of the tower after you come down. It's perfect for a nice break after all the climbing
Great views. Great views from the top but a long queue to climb up they only allow so many in at a time but it is worth the climb for the views over the city

Interesting historical place. Worth a visit inside to see the cannons, battlements and dungeon room. If you take the tram out here, don't get off too soon. We followed the crowds and ended up short by the monastery and had to take a tuk-tuk the rest of the way. Nice cafes outside.
Nice place for a quick visit.. Good place to visit for free on the Lisbon card. Very busy on a summer Saturday so didn't get to top. Go by train, not tram: too busy to get on!
Fantastic Piece of History. This is a beautiful building, and very interesting to explore. Be sure to check out the dungeons and the tower views.

Nice stop on a walk. No need to buy the ticket to explore within - I'd recommend walking from the Monastery to the seafront, then head towards the Tower while strolling along.
Keeping walking past it to see a war memorial and some sort of cancer research building - nice views from the waterfront!!
Don't Bother.. Took the train from Lisbon to Belem, and I know it's a National Heritage but there is nothing there apart from the tower and a large church. Nothing else to do there.
A piece of history. Next to river Tejo and other important monuments/ museums, such as jeronimos and palacio de Belem. Don't forget to ask for a pastel de belem.

Great location . The tower is much smaller than I imagined. The location is great. It's easily accessible by train. While you get off at Belem, you can explore and see a lot of other interesting sites. I went against the advice of most reviewers and actually lined up to get into the tower and climb to the top. But it's worth the wait if you are interested in getting some great shots of the panoramic view. And walking along the water to the Torre de Belem was awesome!
A beautiful place. A must see in Belém, specially on a sunny day. You can enjoy the outdoors area and visit this monument.

Worth Queuing. We visited on a Saturday and so it was very busy but the queue was not unreasonable and the Tower well worth the wait. This is a quite unique building with lots of history. Make the effort, don't miss it.
Beautiful point to see sunset. I loved this place. We sat there and saw sunset and it was so surreal. The Belem tour is very iconic and very beautiful.

Great View of the city. . The Torre de Belem sits at the mouth of the river and affords a wonderful view of the April 25 Bridge and the rest of the city. It is just one of a number of attractions in the neighborhood of Belem. You need to buy a ticket to see the tower, but they have a combo ticket to see several of the attractions like Geronimo's monastery. Go early as they only allow 150 people on the upper observation deck at a time. If you purchase your ticket at one of the other nearby attractions you can skip the line. If you go to Lisbon you must plan on spending at least one day in Belem. Many of our favorite places were here.

A castle in chess. First thing came in my head after seeing it a castle piece in the game of chess. May it was designed by this idea ..I wonder.Its a tower and compact castle .. hence its so cute. I could not go inside as I was late and it was rainy day so no photos either, but with my tourism experience, I would recommend to visit this.You can sit outside and do selfies, eat ice cream and also visit the army museum next to it but, bare in mind its a kind of walk if you would like to hit other attractions near by. Belem is all about walking.
Belem. Lovely area. Quiet and full of history. Famous pastry shop. Very long queues but go into restaurant section and avoid queue . Beautiful parks . The river looks its best here. Great Museums.

Perfect castle by the sea. This tower was built in the middle of the river until the earthquake and Tsunami in the 1700. now it is against the shore making access better! Looks amazing 6 euros to get in and not sure it is worth the que or the effort except for the view from the top.

Loved seeing this place. This place is a must see!! We got off the open top bus and had a walk bext to the water and saw this place and sat diwn and had a drink looking at it. Its a great area to visit.

Only if you have the combined ticket...otherwise just see it from the outside. The tower was pretty enough, but it's really just a quick stop. Most of the sights in Belem are overpriced unless you buy a combined ticket. If you have seen a lot of old buildings, then this is just more of the same. There is not a whole lot to see, except some nice water views and other photo opportunities. If you want to have a good time on the cheap, I would just hang out in the park beside the tower. It's free and you can still get some good pictures from the outside (which is cooler anyway).
Robust ancient architecture. I like the robust, ancient architecture of this tower. Also the fact that it is standing partially in the water makes it very impressive. It is very well-maintained.
Great monument from the early 16th century. Great monument on the banks of river with three sides covered by water, and the front side could only be seen through a boat.

Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. The views from the top of the tower are stunning and we got some great photos
Tip - try to book this in advance. My boyfriend and I didn't and had to wait for around 45mins to enter.

Nice Tower. It is a really nice defensive tower in the riverside of Tajo river. You could visit it I do not remember the fee for entering inside. Monastery Jeronimos is very near
A must-see in Lisbon

Military and religious services - that's where the money goes!. This beautiful building serving as a defence post for the Tejo river and Lisbon. It's gothic style and rich ornaments passes well beyond that of purely military purposes. An absolute must for any visitor to Lisbon.

Former Portugal defense.. Very nice place. Visited by many people. Weekends is leisure of the local population. Many play soccer on the grass. There is also a miniature of the tower which is interesting.
Great history. This is well worth a visit location and the amount of attractions in the immediate area. Great views and restaurants for brunch.
Trade mark of Lisboa. It is the best place for the characteristic photo of Lisbon. The position is the point that the river Taco joins the Atlantic Ocean. Very nice spot
Feel like a tourist. Overrated, annoying. Don't go unless you want to buy sunglasses or selfie sticks from street vendors and enjoy the feeling of being a tourist.
Great to see at sunset. We did not go into the structure. Simply appreciated it from the outside during sunset. Worth a visit if you're in Belem.

Worth seeing. Of course it's worth seeing and taking lovely pictures and stroll around. Maybe you might overhear a guide talking about the place ;).
But I would save my money for other things to do in Belém instead of entering the tower.
Great history. this was a good visit except the crowds are maddening during summer. Prepare to wait in line to enter. The view is excellent though.

Worth the trip to Belem. We visited Belem and included the Torre de Belem as our first stop first thing in the morning when it opened before the crowds and tour groups descended. It was peaceful and not very busy so we were able to enjoy the views from the various levels of the tower. Definitely worth a visit and the views from the top.
great Castle. Actually it is one of the nicest spot at lisbon and definetly recomend you to go ... you can go little bit earlier to enter easliy and also its a nice spot to taking pictures
Torre de Belem . In Lisbon good place to visit and you can go to the famous cake shop. Don't be put off by the queues. Go inside it massive and waiter service
