torre de belem lisbon. beautifully ornate tower inside and out well worth a visitset on the river side with superb views situated in belem district close to other historical venues and restaurants
great view. History and views. You won't stay more than a few minutes here... but its definitely a must see place and with great views.
Come early. Come early to avoid the lines to climb up the tower. It will be quite a morning workout. Get the Lisboa Card for free entrance and public transport to this attraction.
Beautiful. A piece of art at the side of the coast. This building is beautiful and full of history. You must stop by and visit while in the city.

Must see. Unfortunately when I arrived before 5.00pm the Torre was packed and they weren't letting anybody else inside before closing time. Nevertheless I got to see this wonderful building from the outside and will simply come earlier for a visit if I'm ever back in Lisbon.

Lovely landmark to visit!. Visited a few weeks back! Beautiful building indeed and well worth a visit! I took lots of photos of it and didn't have time to wait in line to venture to the top to take more. I've read where the harbor area is beautiful from atop the torre. So, I guess if you have time and want to spend a few dollars to go to the top! You should do it!

Not Much To See Here. The Belem Tower was built in 1515 to defend the harbor and sits on the banks of the Tagus River. It was originally a lighthouse and later used as a prison. A concrete walkway leads to the tower from the green space, but it was closed off. So the only thing to see here is the various views of the outside of the Tower. It’s worth a stop but not a great deal of your time. Parking is available on the street, and if you’re lucky enough to get a spot, as most space is taken up by tour buses, you can walk down to the Monument of the Discoveries which is also on the Tagus River.

Not as spectacular as it seems from photos online.. Smaller than tour guidebooks might suggest. Situated in an underwhelming area, always thronged by tourists and ice cream sellers, it is nonetheless worth a visit, if you can stomach the crowds & the endless sightseeing tourbuses.
Great views. This is a great historic place offering great views, try to visit on a sunny day. You can go up and take nice pictures

Beautiful tower but crowded and overly touristy. This review will be pretty much the same as the one I wrote about the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Not that these two attractions are very similar but their set-up is: crowded and touristy. Don't get me wrong, the tower is stunning and definitely worth a visit. However, I would skip paying the entrance fee and just look at it from the outside. The interior is not that fascinating and the queue to get all the way to the top way too long. There is also hardly any information about the tower itself, its history etc. so I would simply admire it from the outside.

Be transported to the past during your visit!. An amazing place with a "window to the past"! Very charming! The Tower has a great history and the view of the Tejo river is spectacular. Well worth a visit.

unique momument to visit, it was from here we portuguese begin the discover of the world, very important to not forget. unique momument to visit, it was from here we portuguese begin the discover of the world, very important to not forget

Faultless Tower. You can visit the tower and enjoy the ornate architecture without going inside but if you have time to go in there are several interesting things to see.A bit of a queue when I visited but a much slower queue inside to climb to the top as there's so little space up there.Terrific views from up top but we were only given a couple of minutes to enjoy them before being urged to leave by staff members.
Tour stop!. We stopped at the Torre de Belem as part of our Lisbon city tour. It's a bit of a walk from the main road, but an example of the incredible architecture of the period.

Enjoy the sea breeze. We didn't feel like going in, but enjoyed lazing by the tower and watching the ocean, feeling the sea breeze, and enjoying the sunshine. It was a 6 euro per person round trip ticket from the train station. Nice way to spend the morning.
Best part is the outside. For those who visited italy this is a simple tower inside with a poor view and a big line inside to go up. The out side aspect is the best part, a tower in the sea.

Hard to find but worths the effort. Maybe it is just me (with less developed orientation skills :)) who had some difficulties to find this place but far not impossible. The tower itself and also the view deserves the excursion, as it is a bit far away from both the city center and the centre of Belem.
Gorgeous. This is a must see. Stunning views, amazing architecture, timeless structure in the heart of the Lisbon area. Definitely a must see.

to be seen. A nice walk to this 16th century fortified tower. Unesco world heritage site.Jeronimos Monastery nearby. The tower was built on a small island in the Tagus River near the Lisbon shore. Worth seeing.

Nice stroll. Unfortunately, the Tower of Belem was closed when I wanted to visit it on a Monday (not main season). But there are several monuments in walking distance, so I had a nice stroll on the coast and took some awesome pictures.

Fascinating but can get crowded. We bought a combined ticket for the Torre de Belem and the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and this makes it a much more reasonable price. They are about a twenty minute stroll apart. It is also worth trying to time your visit as tour buses seem to arrive first thing (probably stopping in Belem on their way to Sintra) or later in the day (probably on the way back from a morning in Sintra). We were at the Torre de Belem at about 2.30 p.m. and there was no queue to get in but when we left about an hour later the queue stretched back about 30 yards or so. The Torre itself is fascinating in terms of architecture and worth seeing for that and because it seems to be a symbol of Lisbon. There is only one way up and down to the top of the Torre which means that a queue forms as staff let a certain number up for a few minutes before ushering them down again. This means that the top of the tower is very crowded for a few minutes - we waited until everyone else had been ushered down and then asked the staff member if he could take a photo of us which was great as we were obviously then the only ones there. The view over the esplanade and up to the Padrao dos Descobrimentos monument is also worth it as is the stroll back up the esplanade into Belem after the visit.

Standing in Line for a bit of view and a lot of money. Waited to get in, then some more to get up and then again to get down.Could'd really go into the tower rooms because if you take to long then you might have to wait again to get down... So it is really cool building and if you're in the area you should take a look. But there is really no need to go inside

A must visit. Belem is a historical area of Lisbon. Very easy to get to by train. The Tower of Belem is a must place to visit, and its free with your Lisbon card. The iconic defensive tower built in 1515 Manueline style fortress to guard the entrance the entrance of Lisbon's harbor. The Torre de Belem, as its called was the starting point for many voyages of discovery. It is a monument to Portugal's Age of Discovery, often serving as a symbol of the country and A UNESCO World Heritage Monument. It incorporates many stonework motif. Be prepare to wait in line. The visit to the tower is a must, great view od the city. Must See!

Beautiful architecture . Lovely tower with a great view of the bridge. Feels surreal, and at times reminiscent of game of Thrones. Climbing stairs to the top can be a little hazardous - cramped and difficult if others are heading in the other direction - so be mindful of this if you have mobility issues. Still worthwhile to visit when exploring Belem
What a place.... This place is simply breathtaking. I walked out to the tower a couple times and it was well worth the time and effort. The views are top-notch and the bridge is close.

Great piece of architecture - must visit. My wife and I visited Torre de Belem and we really loved it, it is close proximity to train and tram stations and the public transport is reliable and cheap in Lisbon. You can travel on the train for 2.50euro from Central Lisbon and it only take 10-15 minutes and once you there, you can see few of the attractions and Pasteis de Belem for the best custard tarts in the world too. Torre de Belem is amazing how they built it back then, it has a great ocean views of the city and Cascais.A must see attraction and it is not expensive to visit, sorry I don’t’ remember the ticket price but you can buy the tickets on arrival.
Excellent view of the river. A beautiful land kept tower on shore in which people could see incoming fishermen returning after working on the see.
Great place to visit. The tower was small but with great views, and architecture. A bit unorganized and unclear on who gets to go up or down the stairs, but still worth seeing!
Great Views. If you want to see another great monument in Portugal, this is a must-see. Fantastic sites and beautifully crafted.

Very cold and wet day. We were unfortunate that the day was grey, windy and wet. It was very bleak and yet there was still a long queue to get into it. I was glad I went but if I only had a day in Lisbon I'd skip Belem!
Nice site along the riverfront.. We stopped here as part of a tour. Nice, scenic view along the river. Various vendors of food and souvenirs in the area.
A dream come true!. A very emblematic monument from the city of Lisbon, our lovely capital. Grear arquitecture, beautiful setting and the dream of conquering other distant places.

Worth to see. That was a short visit to the monastery. It is a place worth to see, quite unique. I was also next to the tower guarding the entrance to Lisbon from the ocean. The structure looks nice, but I didn't go inside. There is impressive view on bridge that was built by the same engineers as Golden Gate bridge In SF, USA.

Beautiful tower. This tower is worth visiting as it has historical meanings. Coincidentally, it is near the area of Mosteiro dos Jeronimos hence, you may want to visit them together You can take a train and alight at Belem Tower stop (in the direction of Cascais)
Nice views. It has nice views. You might have to queue. If you have Lisbon purple card you can jump the queue as you won't need to buy them.

Must visit. . So glad we stopped to see this! I would say it is a must, and there are a few ways to get there to make it easy on you. You won't need to spend much time there but certainly worth the trip!

Very nice sightseeing place. It is a nice monument that is part of Belem's beauty and attractions. I dont know if it's worth entering, since I havent done it, but from the outside is a beautiful tower.
Worth seeing. Worth taking the tram or bus to Belem and pulling in the tour of the tower with its long history & great views from the top

Beautiful tower with great ambiance around. Surreal place to visit and do not forget to visit Belem while in Lisbon! This is an iconic structure on the banks of the Tejo river. Built to guard against the pirates, this structure has Portuguese African architecture. We were not able to go inside as it's closed on Mondays, so do check the open days and schedules prior to your visit.We spent a lot of time in the area around the tower, with a musician playing beautiful music and lots of happy tourists. In all very enjoyable and must visit. Do try out the chestnuts from local vendors.
Beautiful to see. Great to walk around and see this, very interesting and fun. Not easy to go inside if you have a baby stroller or in a wheelchair.

Historic tower connecting Lisbon's river Tagus with you becuuse of its accessability.. The nicest thing about this beautiful little tower - Torre de Belem, is that water laps at the base of the building and there are huge sloping steps that allow you to sit or dip your feet into the river. You can relax while you contemplate the historica significance and position of the tower, get a sun tan and connect with nature at the same time.

They should clean the debris at water's edge. Otherwise, it's a great monument, with a lively history, as told a by guide Fred of Sandemans walking tours. Easy to reach with public transportation for those who don't mind a walk along the river.

Good Photo Op - Dont Bother Going Inisde. The Belem area is nice to walk around - the riverfront, shops, restaurants. And the tower is historic and interesting looking. So its a good photo op, but the line is typically long, and nothing special to go inside.
Historic Lisbon. Well worth a visit, to avoid the queues, try lunch time, 12-2.00pm. the queues in the morning were very long.

Nice tower but disappointing surroundings. Not far but quite a walk to reach Belem which I had hoped would be a nice area. Monetary and Tower are beautiful but everything around is nothing special unfortunately.

The most iconic landmark of Lisbon - It's worth a visit. The Torre de Belém (Belem Tower) is undoubtedly Lisbon's most iconic landmark. The tower was built in the sixteenth century as a fortress to guard the entrance to Lisbon's harbor. I bought a CD there. Whenever i hear this CD, i remember my visit of Belem Tower!
A lot of history. You feel a lot of history there when you visit. The architecture is beautiful and you'll have a great feeling of the Portugal's sea-faring heritage.
Belèm Tower. Impressive structure on the waters edge, my favourite sightseeing spot and great for picutr taking. Best time to there is in the after when it's less crowded.
Beautiful. Evocative of Portugal's sea-faring heritage and architecturally extremely beautiful. I really would not want to miss visiting this monument when visiting Lisbon.

Great piece of history. A rainy day activity on the outskirts of town. The tower is pretty cool, even looking at it from the outside. On the inside there is not much to look at, but climb the tower for great views over the water.

Amazing monument! . Belém Tower was built in 1515.
The tower is full with Manueline decoration, with crosses of the Military Order of Christ and some naturalistic elements such as the rhinoceros, said to be the first such representation in stone known in Europe. Amazing view from the top. Worth it.
Overpriced. There is a charge of 5€ which is a bit pricey to climb 120 steps for a view of Belem - i would recommend not to pay to go into this.

Must see in Belém. This tower desires not only a visit but also photos and time to appreciate it. You can go inside and have a tour. At the external part, you can enjoy a calm and beatiful part of Lisbon, clean, safe and amazing. I usually run in this region and is such amazing every time I pass around.

A photo-op... Being in close proximity to Jeronimos Monastery is a great advantage to this monument, which apart from its place in history is at best just a photo opportunity because of its location on Tagus river. And that's what we found most people quickly doing on 15 minute stopover.

Beautiful building soaked in history . This is a beautiful building with good views over the city.The architecture is great. If you have a Lisbon card this attraction is free.Although I appreciated this building I think two things could be improved:-more information on the history of the building (this was limited)-a better queueing system (when we got to the next floor we had to queue about 20 mins to get up to the next stage - at the top it was 10 mins queuing to get back down)You're probably looking about an hour at this attraction.

great tower to visit.. this please is really worth visiting when you're in Lisbon. Belem is very close to the City so you can go there and only spend a few hours. you can enter the tower and visit inside.
Beautiful sight, lovely location.... The Belem Tower is located right next to the river and in a large square. This historical tower is awesome except we cannot enter it! And it was very breezy...
A symbol of Lisbon. Nice tower build in 16th century on a very small island close to the river shore. It is a good objective for architecture and history lovers.

Beautiful castle by the water. This is a relatively small castle so you can get in and out very quickly. The most interesting part of the visit is to go up the narrow staircase to the top for very nice views.
Iconic Lisbon sight! . Best visited early before the coach trippers arrive! Didn't go inside as Qs too long but took plenty of pics! Worth a visit!

Interesting tower!. This is one of the highlights of a visit to Lisbon.
It's a very interesting tower, overlooking the river and as its a highlight, it's very busy!
It has nice views, back over the city, but also over the river, the bridge and the Christ statue.
It's also very photogenic from the river on the cruise.

Amazing. Lucky for us we were able to visit Belem Tower on a beautiful day. We purchased tickets to tour the inside and highest level and I felt it was worth it. From the top, you can imagine the lookout of ships during the time of the tower's use. If you have small children, I would keep them close and some of the views can be dangerous.
Interesting but we were there on Monday . Everything in Lisbon is closed Monday but interesting walk by near the closed monastery. The discovery monument is open. Worth a walk by.

Great from outside. It was crowded, we waited in the line with our Lisbon card for quite some time. It is a great picture taking opportunity, especially from the outside, and 93 stairs sound harder than they were. But if I would plan my day again, I would stick to entering the Padrao dos Descobrimentos and not this one. I prefered a view there even though they are close one to another.

Great from outside. We took a Lisbon pass not to wait in line and this was actually the most irritating place because it was a huge line nevertheless. From outside this place it stunning. We took so many pictures. 93 stairs weren't a trouble for me. But I am not sure if it is worth visiting inside of both Padrao dos Descobrimentos and this one, just pick one depending on the time available (the line, remember :D ) and your personal preference. They are very close. I prefered the Padrao view, and most of my collegues agreed. But I liked Torre stone just a bit more in the inside. In my opinion I would choose only the Padrao next time.

Lovely place . Ok, so I know many people queue for ages and pay tickets to visit the inside of the Tower. I've never done that and I will never will. Locals have told me there is nothing to see inside, nada de nada.I've been there 4 times and everytime I've just enjoyed the outdoors. The tower is a magnificent piece of Manuelino architectural design and the area around it is absolutely lovely. We even had a picnic there, the cafeteria next to it is cheap and the coffee is very good. So I would say it is a must see if you are in Lisbon, just don't bother with the inside and enjoy the sun over the Tagus River.
Average. A lot of queuing for little reward. Good views over the river but not exceptional. Advise to visit early morning.

Well worth a visit. Caught the tram from the city to Belem. Very easy to get to. Be careful when you queue to get in a some of the bigger waves can splash through the wooden walkway over the water and wet you. Lots of steps to the top and they operate a one way system which is good as the spiral stairs are very narrow.

Just ok.. Second time I've been here and still very much unimpressed. The history behind this tower may be interesting but the tower itself is not. Very crowded and full of lines. Focus on de Jerominos Monastary nearby, much better.
Amazing tower from 16th century. Unesco cultural heritage and very beautiful. Take tram 15 to Belem.Stunning tower and a nice walk along the water.
Tower on the Tangus River. Although we did not go into the tower, the outside was quite nice. Hard to believe that it was able to withstand an earthquake.

Brilliant place; but no need to stay ages.. Very good place to visit, but so busy!Recommend buying a pre-booked ticket to avoid the ticket office queues (available as a package deal from Monastery de Jeronimos (10 minute walk away))Superb architecture and great photo opportunities with scenic views abounding. However, not a lot to actually see inside, but very atmospheric nonetheless. Note: when going to the very top, be aware there is only one set of steps going up & down with a traffic light system in play (about 90 steps in total, expect queues & there are no hand holds, so take care)

Queue queue and queue again. After queuing for 40 minutes to enter you then queue for the first level entry and then queue for the second level entry and then queue to exit. I read a review which said don't bother just admire from the outside. Having had this experience I tend to agree with that assessment. The only up side was being able to buy a combined ticket into the nearby monastery and so avoid queuing for entry there. Otherwise there isn't much more to be seen from the inside which can't be seen from the outside.
Monumental. We couldn't visit (it was Easter) but had a great time around the tower. The kids loved playing in the sand and the sight is great!

Historical. Is advisable not to miss the wine on b the sea shore with the small cubicle shops. The fort is decent, nothing exceptional, but it does give a feel of the old world soldiers. The surroundings are definitely charming

Must see in Lisbon. The Tower of Belem is a must see sight when going to Lisbon. It is especially nice on a sunny day. I have not been inside but it's nice to just walk around the place and have an ice cream.
Small but iconic. Getting to the monument was very exciting as we had to fight our way through the rough waves. A raincoat would have been welcomed.
A M A Z I N G. Torre de Belem is on eof the main reasons me and my fiancee have decide to visit Lisbon over all. Perfect sunny day, stunning sights and amazing views. Pure gold!

Worth seeing. A very impressive old fortification definitely worth seeing. However on going to the ticket office the person behind the desk was so rude to us we just turned around and walked out.  Tip, if you want to get concession entry price for over 65's you have to provide proof of your age, driving licence or as we did a photocopy of your passport.

Nice church,great place to take few pics..... You have to see... Very nice church, definitly a visit worth.... Been there fuew times now, when you close there you have to visit belem to to eat the pasteche de belem.... Amazingggg

Worth the trip. We enjoyed seeing the tower and thought it worth the trip out to Belem. It was very busy though and as the number of visitors to the top of the tower is limited at any one time we abandonded our wait after about 30 minutes as it was going to take a lot longer to gain access.

Overpriced; long queues outside and inside. Visited today - not high season at all. Very long queue to get it but that only permits you to see two storeys. You are then obliged to wait again to climb the spiral steps up the tower. It is rather like the longest traffic lights ever... You have to wait until all 120 people up the tower have come down before they let a single person up it. really, you can see quite a hit of the tower just from the outside. Spend longer at the Jeronimo Cloisters and skip this if in a rush. Over rated.
Not bad if you're around. I wouldn't travel here just for this, but if you're in Belem fir the pasteis (which you should be) take a walk over here and pop in
Bleeding with history!. A must see in history neighborhood of Belem, Lisbon. You can just picture all of the historic ships that sailed from that exact area.
Nice tower, symbolizing a ship. Oncem in Belem, don't miss this place. It's made to look like a ship and reminds us of the times when the Portuguese were discovering the world.

Lovely sight ...relaxing. This is a lovely focal point ....relaxing location away from centre of Lisbon....a fair distance from centre..however the yellow hop on hop off bus from Lisbon central will take you direct there.
Sunny day and great biews. Very reasonably priced, great views - lots of climbing to be done inside however so be aware! Interesting stone worked carvings to see.

Head to Belem - just go!. Any visit to Lisbon has to see this tower, and walk about 0.5 mi to the famous monument Padrao dos Descobrimentos, and then cross the street via the underground walkway to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Wonderful, especially when the weather is clear.

Nice Views But not a Must. The views are pleasing, yet the distance to walk there from the monastery and from the city center itself, did not make it s must see for us once we arrived there-and we are walkers. If you only have a day in Lisbon explore the city center and hill views instead. If you have more..it is then a desired site.

Beautiful place. Spent a while walking around the area with my family and we all loved the building. We didnt go in as we had a young baby in a pram and didnt want to lift him up the steps inside. The area is beautiful and plenty of great photo opportunities
Nice to view from outside . It's nice to see the building from the outside, but there is really o reason to pay to go inside. The park outside is also quite enjoyable.
Interesting little bit of history. A little out of the way from town but if your tour bus comes out this way for the other larger attractions nearby make the effort to visit this, it's well worth it.
Beautiful tower. We didn't went inside, but from the outside the tower was very nice to look at. Nice park next to it and a nice atmosphere.

A must-see, but a bit sparse.. This has to be one of the sights to see in Lisbon, and although the building is impressive and the views good, there isn't much inside. The reproduction cannon are ridiculously puny. Expect to queue.

A must see in Lisbon. Not much to see other than the tower itself. We were with a guide and didn't go into the building as she said it was mostly empty and not worth waiting in the long line..other we talked to confirmed this.

Long queues detracted from the experience. The tower itself was fine but we spent most of our time there in long queues to get in, up, and down the tower (even thought we already had a combined ticket). We might have just been unlucky with our timing but we preferred the other tower just along the harbour for panoramic views.
Must see, but little there. The first floor was most interesting. The long and congested climb to the top was disappointing as there was little new to see.

Stunning. Interesting tour if you enjoy looking at castles. Comes with some amazing views of the city that are to die for. It is relatively easy to get to via the bus system and has some nice restaurants nearby. Lovely wildlife - don't forget to look into the trees to perhaps see some peacocks!

horrible customer service. we bought tickets online to save time on queque, nowhere in the site did it state that we have to print the tickets. so our tickets were not valid.and we didnt get any help from the staff. The pdf also had null values indicating coding errors.very disapointed with the service.its 2016, turists should not need to have a printer with them!

Beautiful. Beautiful setting, surrounded by water it's quite stunning. Enjoyed the walk from here along to the eternal flame and the tomb of the unknown soldier. Sad to see all the names of those who have died in conflict over the years.

Historic, Scenic View of the Targus River. The Belem Tower is a must-see when visiting Belem. The ornate Manueline Gothic style stonework is breathtaking. The narrow, winding staircase to the top may not be advisable for those with mobility issues, but there is plenty to see on the first two levels without venturing further.
Historical quick stop. Not much more to see unless you make a leisurely stroll along the river to make the stop worthwhile.

Lovely bike ride. You can rent a bike and get to Belem by bike, there's a nice view and it's about 7km, it won't take you long, and once you get there, you can relax in a lovely bar. Too bad the tower is closed on Monday, like many others attracion in Portugal.

Great views, well worth a line. After the monastery take a few steps west to the tower. The view from the top is great and the very tower is the one explorers left as they sailed for new worlds. I just loved the architecture of this period when Portugal ruled the world. Tip the tower is free the first Sunday of each month!

Great way to spend the afternoon. One of the major site to see in Portugal. Located along the river, the tower stands as a reminder of the great explorers who sailed to parts unknown not knowing if or when they would come back.

Amazing piece of architecture. located by the shore of Rio Tejo, in Lisbon, this monument is a must see. One of the icons of 'Descobertas', when the Portuguese went to unknown seas to discover the world. Best option is to take the train towards Belem and walk there.

Worth a visit. Well worth a tour if your visiting the Belem area. Easy to get out there by tram. Not too large. Easy to cover in an hour. But a ticket that covers both the tower and Monastery. Pair it with the Monastery and lunch in Belem
Worth a visit. Interesting place, beautiful views of Lisbon from the top...about 80 steps to get up there :) Worth a visit.

Worth the trip?. Not within walking distance from the city centre, you go there because of the hype. Nothing special to speak of in terms of its interior, if you only have a day in Lisbon, I'd focus on other things, but if youve got half a day to spare its well worth the trip!

A touch of history with magnificent views. Well worth a visit, strongly recommended to everyone. Just a piece of good advice: book online to avoid the long lines. Another option is to buy a combined ticket for other places to visit. It works out cheaper and saves queuing up time.

Gorgeous gorgeous gorgeous. The best way to see this is after seeing the monastery walk to the Padrao dos Descobrimentos (the large monument next to the river) and then walk towards the Torre de Belem along the river. A gorgeous walk to do in the afternoon after eating a pastry and to enjoy the Portuguese sun.
Yes!. Loved the view and the 93 steps to the top! You will have to wait to come down if you go to the top.

Great day out . Do not go to Lisbon without visiting Belem! Lovely little town, great attractions and a lovely break from the city.
We didn't go into the castle, as there were massive queues, instead opting for a trip up the Columbus monument. The views were spectacular.

a lovely day trip to Belem area. Jerónimos Monastery, Torre de Belem and Discoveries Monument easily done in a day. Don't forget to have a lovely lunch/drink in one of the restaurants (a pretty row of buildings) facing the greenery of Praça do Império.

Nice from the outside. I would not purchase a ticket just for the tower. There is nothing to really see or do in the inside. I would recommend buying a combo ticket with the monastery, that way the tower only seems like a few euros.
so much history. This place was worth the 5 minute wait to view. the walk up the stair is a must photos galore. not for the weak as the steps are hard to climb. but worth it. best price

Beautiful World Heritage Site. This is a great piece of architecture, worth seeing. Belem itself is a beautiful town with quite a bit to see. From what I understand, this was first built as a fortress to protect the habor and was one of the last thing that sailor saw on leaving. One can buy a single ticket for 6Euros or combined tickets to see 2 or 3 monuments for a bit more. There is of course, the Lisboa Card, which allows one to travel on the bus, tram and to visit many monuments and museums. If you have the time this is a good deal. This attraction is free on the first Sunday of each month. We came in to Lisbon on a cruise ship so we have to travel in to Belem. Here are some directions and an inexpensive way to get to Belem.We docked in Lisbon at Santa Apolonia terminal. This is over an hour's tram/bus ride to Belem. However, it is very easy to get there by bus/tram or train. So, exit the Port, go left and walk along the waters edge until you get to Praca de Comercio Square, one of Lisbon's main square. The square is on your right. Praca de Comercio is also called Terreiro do Paco. It is about an 8-10 min walk. It is a stopping point for buses and trams etc.Look for the stop for Tram #15E, should be ahead to the left. We paid 2.85Euros each way per person. You can buy the ticket on the Tram from the machine, which takes coins and notes. The machine gives change. Or you can buy it at a Metro station before you get on the Tram. The 15E to Belem would say "ALGES" because that is the last stop, but Belem is before this, about the 14th stop. The tram stops right in front of the Monastery, so you will know when you are in Belem. This is yet another attraction to visit. The church at the side is free to enter. You can also take Bus #728, which I think is about 2 streets over in front of Apolonia cruise terminal. \ Look for the 728 going in the same direction you would have to walk to get to the square. If you take the bus you just sit on it until it arrives in Belem. It would also pick up passengers on its way at Praca de Comercio Square.On the way back we took Bus # 728, across the street from the Monastery. The cost was less than the Tram...1.80Euros each. You can buy on the bus. We got off at Praca de Comercio and walked around to see Lisbon's city centre. It takes a different route, passing the the Alcantara Mar & Cais Sodre Train station. We saw different things on the way back. If you walk up the Main street by the Square you can get to Rossio Train Station where you can get Trains to Sintra to see the Beautiful Palace.

Just look from the outside. Travelled to Belem on a rammed tram from Lisbon city - train is much easier we found. The Torre is built into the water and is very ornate and picturesque from the shore, but I do not recommend going inside. We had to queue to enter (tip, you can buy advance tickets if you still want to go in), fine, we could see the queue and judge the timings (20 mins maybe). Once inside though, there was little to see, a Jail/ Dungeon and the entry level with some cannons and brief information, then the first level of the Torre, - nothing there except another queue to go into the main tower. So we queued again - this time for about 30 mins before we were granted access to the narrow spiral staircase - single file only - and climbed to the top. Could be rather claustrophobic for some. Once at the top - a quick look at the view and.. you've guessed it , another queue to get down. In my view a complete waste of time and money. I will not be going back, the whole experience wasted almost 2 hours of our short weekend away. And this was March - hardly high season.

One to see. You cannot go to Lisbon and not see this attraction .It is mind blowing just be aware it is very popular just take your time to get the right photos and don't be put off with all the people around you.

Just seeing this from outside and taking pictures it's enaugh. The ticket for going inside is $6 euro and not much to see besides the view. You also have to wait in line at the first level if you want to see the upper terrace since they will let only 120 person go up and wait until all of them are down and let another group.
Busy tourist spot. This place has some great photo opportunity. Very popular with tourists so get there early if you want good shots. Trams can get very crowded and beware of pickpocket.
Enchanting . My favourite visit in Belem. It's in the middle of the water and is very picturesque. Very cute. Close to restaurants and other sights too. Cheap and good value for money.
Worth a visit. Belem in general is worth a visit. Just a short tram ride from Lisbon centre. Pricey but you can just look at it without going in and look at the stunning views. Interesting.
Not a lot happening. The outside view is all you need to appreciate this venue. No insight is provided, and there's not much to see.

A jewel of military architecture. Torre de Belem is really a jewel of military architecture, with superb view and surroundings. It is more interesting on the exterior that in the interior. It's not worth waiting in long queues to visit the interior.
Worth visiting. It's in a great setting.There is not much to see inside but it's worth the visit manly for the views.Not worth in a rainy day.It's an interesting and beautiful building.
Nice place to visit but pricey to get in. Interesting to see (we walked over from the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos) but balked about paying the price to go in or go up in the tower. Historical site.

very nice. its the postcard of lisbon
perfect for history lovers
perfect place to take fotos and even read a nice book
make sure the sun is shinning

Long waiting time!. Wonderful monument but from outside you do not realise how long you have to wait to climb on top. When we thought th line outside was over and we got inside there were another 25 min waiting in a spiral shaped line....we are moving now. Is it the end of the line?

Don't miss it!. This is a landmark you must not miss! However, be prepared: you might spend a lot of time waiting in the line to enter, so arrive early and arm yourself with patience. I was here with my family and we decided to not enter, because we would have to wait at least two hours. So we simply hung around it, took photos, enjoyed the sun, the sea, the park and the amazing unforgettable view.
Beautiful place . When the line is not too extensive you should go in and taste the atmosphere. Smell of the sea, wind in the hair, the old ruin. Very beautiful!

Many Steps. Its a nice tower but to get to the top you need to wait in line for 15-20 minutes on the first level so they can get 120 people up to the top and back down again.Once you leave to the outside court yard you go inside where you wait again and then you start your ascent up 90-something stairs in a circular tower.... Not for the physically challenged or those who are squeemish about enclosed spaces. You get to go up to the top, and all the floors in between, when going down. Its 6 euro but is cheaper when you buy the Jeronimos Monastery combo ticket with it. The front of the tower is impressive with the water rolling in under the bridge. The basement is not impressive and is fairly low in height. The entrance level has the cannons and the first level is nice to walk around. You can get to the tower using tram 15 and walking about 10 minutes from the tram, to the overhead walking bridge (more stairs) and then to the tower.Its probably a 15 minute walk from the monastery which I recommend you take the river-walk that is across the street(twice - one is an underground walkway to get across) from the monastery to get to the Tower. Using that path you get to see the discovery edifice on your way to the Tower.

Travel in the timeline!. Imagine a fortress in an exotic place. Look for the details, the sculptures, the stone forms. Located on the river Tagus since the 16th century defending the Lisbon harbour. The interior is very austere. Don't miss the loggia. Skip the rushing hours.

interesting story behind it. went here with Sandeman tours, the Belem walk. The building is beautiful and has a rich history. Unfortunately when we came here we could not enter, but according to the guide its practically empty, and the things to see are on the outside.

Beatiful tower, fully enjoyable from the outside, not a must to be inside. The tower is fine, a must-see monument. If you are short of time or just prefer to better experience other monuments elsewhere do not bother visit the inside, except for the view from the top perhaps. It is basically and empty place.
😀. Really a lovely Torre de Beldm inside and out with some lovely views over the port of Lisbon! Good place to visit, lovely place to just walk around and enjoy the views.
Great but no need to climb the tower. Long line-ups. IMHO, the wait is not woth it. The tower has been renovated. Take pics from the buttom and move to the next site.

Impressive looking castle!. We visited here on Easter Sunday and the castle was closed. We never planned and going in anyway but there were still a lot of people milling about. Don't just go to Belem for this, the whole area is really nice, especially the monastery. You could easily spend a full afternoon or day in Belem just walking around or relaxing on the many park benches. If you don't mind a good walk then don't take the tram. It's gets ridiculously overcrowded and the walk from Lisbon centre to Belem is just amazing. You walk right along the riverfront, under the bridge and through lots of nice restaurants and cafes where you can stop for a drink or an ice cream.
good place on a sunny day. bring camera :P the views are nice and loads of other attractions are nearby...queues can get very long so try early mornings

Interesting museum but crowded. We went to see the Tower of Belem last week and it is an interesting site to visit. The downside was that we waited in line for an hour at around 11 am and once inside, it was difficult to move since it was really crowded. The architecture is great to see but there wasn't very much information to read. We read up about it before we went so we knew what we were looking at. To avoid the long line, you can buy a combined ticket at the Jeronimos Monestary or maybe even on line.
One of the main monuments in Lisbon. I have been there twice, and its really amazing to imagine how these great monuments were built hundreds of years ago with very limited resources
Well worth a visit when visiting the monastery. The tower is well worth a visit after visiting the monastery. It is about about a 600 metres walk along the estuary.

Queues were amazing. If you want to go get up early and get the the tram stop early to assure you seat and the first tram. If you get to Belem early you may just miss the queues to anything there. Food wise look for places away from the tourist areas.

Interesting tower not sure worth a queue to visit. We went on a beautiful March day and approached the tower by walking along the riverside so had a great view. A pearl of the Manueline style. In the late 15th century, King John II had designed a defence system for the mouth of the Tagus that depended on the fortresses of Cascais and São Sebastião (or Torre Velha) in Caparica on the south side of the river. These fortresses did not completely protect the river's mouth, and further protection was required. In his "Chronicle of John II" (Chronica de D. Joao II), which appeared in 1545, the author Garcia de Resende affirmed the king's opinion that the defences of Lisbon were inadequate, and that he had insisted on building fortifications along the entrance to the River Tagus to supplement the existing defences. To this end, he ordered the "making of a strong fort", but died before any plans were drawn. King Manuel I of Portugal revisited the proposal twenty years later and ordered the construction of a military fortification on the northern margin of the Tagus at Belém. In 1513, Lourenço Fernandes wrote a letter to his friends referring to the king's intention of constructing a tower near Restelo Velho, having determined it to be essential.The project was started on an outcropping of basaltic rocks situated a short distance from the river bank, using some of the stones being collected to build the Monastery of Santa Maria de Belém. The tower was designed by military architect Francisco de Arruda, named "Master of the works of the Belém stronghold" by King Manuel, and by 1516 he began receiving 763 blocks and 504 stones for its construction, delivered by Diogo Rodrigues, treasurer for the project. As construction progressed, a man-of-war called the Grande Nau (Great Ship), a heavily armed, 1000 tonne (1100 ton) ship continued to guard the estuary at the mouth of the Tagus until the fort's completion.The building was finished in 1519, just two years before Manuel's death, and Gaspar de Paiva was temporarily stationed to command the fortress; his commission was made permanent on 15 September 1521, when he was appointed the first Captain-General, or alcalde, and the fortress was named the Castle of St. Vincent (Castelo de São Vicente de Belém), in honour of the patron saint of Lisbon.King Miguel I (1828–1834) used the dungeons to imprison his liberal opponents,[1] while another level was used as a custom house for ships until the duty on foreign ships was abolished in 1833. The tower received military upgrades in 1589 and 1809–14.During the reign of Maria II, Almeida Garrett protested the site's degradation and under the persuasion of the Duke of Terceira, renovations were begun by military engineer António de Azevedo e Cunha. He demolished the Philippine barracks and extended revivalist elements in 1845–1846 (such as the armoured merlons, the balustrade of the veranda along the southern façade, the laced fascia in the cloister and the niche with an image of the Virgin and Child).In 1865–1867 a beacon was installed on the south-east terrace of the building and a telegraph service was started, while nearby a gas factory was built, producing smoke that aroused many protests. The first moves to preserve and rehabilitate the tower began in the latter part of the 20th century. First, the tower was transferred to the Ministry of Finance in 1940, which undertook small conservation works. Then the military quarters on the battlements were removed and the inner cloister was built. The architectural landscape designer António Viana Barreto began a three-year project in 1953 to integrate the tower with the local shoreline. In 1983 the site hosted the 17th European Exhibition on Art, Science and Culture, and various projects involving the building were undertaken, among them covering the cloister with a transparent plastic cupola. In the same year the Belém Tower was classified by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site.In the 1990s, the property was transferred to the Instituto Português do Património Arquitectónico (forerunner of IGESPAR), which began a full restoration of the building that lasted from February 1997 to January 1998; this included reinforcing the tower and bastion, reinforcing the south balcony supports with stainless steel rods and epoxy resin, treating the mortar joints, and general structural cleaning. The statues of Saint Vincent of Saragossa and the Archangel Michael received the same treatment. In 1999 the project received the Europa Nostra award for its restoration of the exterior. The Belém Tower was added on 7 July 2007 to the registry of the Seven Wonders of Portugal.The Belém Tower is situated on the northern bank of the Tagus River in the civil parish of Santa Maria de Belém, municipality of Lisbon, accessible at the western end of the Avenida de Brasília by a small bridge. Nearby are the Jeronimos Monastery to the east and Fort Bom Sucesso {Forte do Bom Sucesso} to the west), while to the north are the tower Governor's residence, the old Governor's residence for the Bom Successo fort, and the Chapel of São Jerónimo.The tower is isolated along the riverbank, between the dock of Bom Sucesso and Pedrouços, on a basaltic outcropping of rocks belonging to the geomorphological Volcanic Complex of Lisboa-Mafra. Although various guides have claimed that the tower was built in the middle of the Tagus, and now sits near the shore after the 1755 earthquake redirected the river, they are incorrect. The Portuguese Ministry of Culture (Ministério da Cultura) and the Institute of Architectural Heritage indicate that the tower was constructed on a small island near the bank of the Tagus, opposite the shore of Restelo. As development extended the shoreline progressively, more and more of the northern bank crept southwards into the Tagus, the tower becoming integrated into the riverbank over time.The Belém Tower was built from a beige-white limestone local to the Lisbon area and thereabouts called lioz. The building is divided into two parts: the bastion and the four story tower located on the north side of the bastion.The 16th-century tower is considered one of the principal works of the Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style. This is especially apparent in its elaborate rib vaulting, crosses of the Order of Christ, armillary spheres and twisted rope, common to the nautically-inspired organic Manueline style.

Not for the faint hearted.. On a recent visit to Lisbon with a friend, we went to visit the Torre de Belem. Most enjoyable on the sunny Sunday afternoon we went. There are several floors inside of the tower where you can read more on the history of the Torre de Belém.

The triumphal arch of Lisbon. There are several interesting sites to visit, while walking along the promenade- known as the Av. Brasília.One being, the Torre de Belem, which is a UNESCO listed World Heritage monument, with its status being granted in 1983.It is also known as the Belém Tower, or the Tower of St Vincent.This stopover, was part of our detailed tour of Portugal, and I must attest, the knowledge imparted by a local guide, will far surpass any information you may find otherwise.This fortified medieval defensive tower, was built between 1515 to 1521, mainly to provide, protection to the entrance to the harbour of Lisbon.The tower itself, also provides grand estuary views of the Tagus River and its surrounding area, all from the roof top terrace.The architecture style, has a Moorish influence, which is most likely attributed to the original architect having designed, previous fortifications in Morocco.If you ever tour Northern Africa, the similarities will easily stand out to you.

Torre de Belém. One of the main landmarks of Portugal's maritime history, built in 1495 by King Manuel who was an important international trader, as Vasco da Gama and later Alvares Cabral established sea routes to India, Goa and Malacca, Africa and Brazil, bringing and offering exotic products. These experiences and knowledge lead to the definition of the Manueline style characteristics, represented in monuments he built in Portugal byKing Manuel I, between 1495 and 1521. The Tower of St Vincent is an example of transition from military architecture of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, the mass of a recessed square tower of medieval character, with about thirty meters high, an advanced body of "foundation" and base, strengthening horizontal and embracing the irregular hexagonal shape, forty meters long, oriented and south of the Tagus, in order disarm with their fire batteries placed on the bulwark any attempt to assault by sea.

Beautiful tower. I went there when there were no queues or lines so I definitely enjoyed it more than most people I read reviews of. Worth a visit but needs more information. A World Heritage site, situated in the suberb of Belem a few miles out of Lisbon central it is easily accessed by tram 15 which runs along the riverside, as well as buses, taxis and tuktuks. Be aware however that the trams can become very overloaded at peak times and will not always stop.The tower is built where the Atlantic Ocean begins to have a noticeable effect on the river with waves splashing around and sometimes over the short wooden causeway which accesses it.Reasonable access charge, after first looking around the cellar gunpowder storage and cells and the living accommodation above before you access the tower.The tower is climbed and descended by the same 93 narrow steps on a spiral stairway so each step is a foot width on the outside with nothing on the inside. Definitely worth bringing along a small hand torch because there is no lighting apart from limited daylight and no handrail. There is a one way system which is supposed to ensure visitors are only traveling one direction but it doesn't work too well.I would have liked to have seen more information boards about the tower. Don't be put off by my description of the climb but it is not for the infirm and care would have to be taken with small children.Belem is the cultural area of Lisbon with a fine church, museums housed in what was a huge monestry and concert venues.

Good views, but thronging crowds & poor illustration. The Torre de Belém is a quirky, interesting piece of Maneuline architecture: the positives are the excellent views across the Tagus both east towards the 25 April bridge / Cristo Rei statue / Discovery monument, and out towards the open sea (even in poor weather conditions). The negatives are a) the thronging crowds, and b) the near complete absence of any historical illustrative/explanatory material on the site: combined with the absence of any reconstruction (furniture, dress, etc.) this means you have to do your homework in advance. NB: access to both the lower level and upper levels is not disable-friendly (also, the lower prison level is only about 1.75m high) as narrow winding staircases provide the only access to either. Undoubtedly a great tourist point, but the city council could do a *lot* more with this. The access price is €6/adult, and while it's nice to get a view from the tower, you're not really missing much if you skip entry and spend the € on a hearty main course at one of the restaurants nearby (be careful & check the menus posted outside restaurants: some places charge €12 for a main, while others half that - even if you don't speak Portuguese, don't be afraid to go in to the less posh places, they are friendly, cheap, and the food is good!).

Imperdível. Belem's Tower is an indispensable visit for everyone who is travelling in Portugal. Decorative defence. A superbly decorated tower built in the early C16th as part of the defences of the Tagus (and therefore contemporary with Henry VIII's Deal and Walmer Castles) it has been much altered from its original considerably more dour appearance. Used as dungeons and barracks as well as a defensive work, it is an extremely attractive element to the waterfront. Access to the upper floors is via a single spiral staircase, access to which is controlled by a buzzer and traffic lights. The climb to the top in a single 'trip' will get the visitor's heart rate going! The rooms inside are very splendid even if the original decorations are now gone, but the main gun deck does give the feel of what it would have been like in Renaissance times.

Bigger Than it Looks. We first tried to visit the Torre de Belem at about 1100 hrs on a day in November, but the queue stretched out of the tower and down the wooden entrance walkway, almost to dry land. We estimated we would have had to wait perhaps 20 - 30 minutes, so broke off and went to sample the custard tarts at Pasteis de Belem instead: (a good decision - they were delicious). We next visited the tower in the late afternoon, at about 1600 hrs (the tower closes at 1730 hrs in winter) and were able to walk straight in - so the advice is to leave your visit here to after lunch, as it is likely to be much quieter than early in the day. Inside, the biggest area is the lower battery, where some artillery pieces are placed at the gun ports to suggest how it may have looked in the 16th century. Interestingly, the cannons on display are breach loading, rather than muzzle loading. If you wish you can descend the steps into the dungeon/storage area but the headroom is severely restricted and there is nothing to see, so this part of the tower can be omitted from the visit. Going up the narrow staircase (controlled by a traffic light system), leads to a series of open rooms, each occupying the whole floor area, with information panels giving details of their original use. Emerging onto the roof gives a great view of the river Tagus and the 25 de Abril bridge. Apart from the lower battery, access to the upper areas is difficult and so this is not a good place for those with mobility problems. Similarly, very young children might find it difficult to get around. We spent a little over an hour exploring; history buffs might want to stay longer, casual visitors might need less time. Finally, the tower makes a good subject for photography, either early in the morning, or late in the evening, at sunset. We used public transport - tram 15E - to get to Belem (the map of the line inside the tram itself shows the best stop for the tower). Bear in mind that there is a multi-lane highway to be crossed before being able to get to the tower and its surrounding park (Jardim da Torre de Belem), so after alighting from the tram head for the river and after arriving at the big highway (Av. da India) look out for the footbridge which is easily spotted.One last point - we used the Lisbon card for our visit, and their website proudly boasts that it gives: "Priority access at Lisbon´s most popular attractions." Well it doesn't at the Torre de Belem! You have to queue with all the other visitors!

Like interesting architecture? Military history? River views? Go to the Tower of Belem.. If you're in Lisbon, you know you're going to be in the Belem, so be sure to stop here. This highly decorative, manueline style stone tower with Moorish touches was constructed approximately 500 years ago for a very practical reason: defense of the Tagus River estuary. The Torre de Belem and the Jeronimos Monastery together are considered as the complex of Belem, a World Heritage Site. This location is definitely worth a visit.Apparently the Tower was built on a small island in the river, but with the shifting of the river, it's now on the riverbank. You enter the tower by means of a walkway so you can enter when the river is up and water actually surrounds the tower. You can go into the stone guardhouses and imagine yourself many centuries ago on the lookout for enemies invading the river, and you can go below and see the cannon positioned for firing at ships daring to breach this entry into the port of Lisbon. I liked the aspect of being able to see beyond all of the carved stone decorations of the past to contrast with aspects of the present, such down the river (like cruise ships) or across on the opposite shore or to the April 25th bridge.This tower was used for various purposes once its days as a part of a defense system were over. There is a lower area that was apparently once used as a jail, and it consists of empty arched rooms with low ceilings, leaving me to wonder if all the prisoners were very short or if being made to stand stooped over was a part of their punishment....

What an Awesome bit of Defensive History. Picture another one of these across the river. A ship comes in through the channel and both sides bombard it with "skipping" cannon balls, bam, end of threat. The waters have come, making it more of an island fort, and receded, like now, with a huge semi-circular set of steps-seats going well into the water. Under the plank walkway to get into the tower you can still see stairs from an earlier era. Each level has its own beauty and views. The 93 steps are broken up into the four levels so it isn't a full on press. Each floor had a purpose. The top floor was the chapel, next down was the audience chamber for gatherings, below that the King's quarters, below that the Governor's chambers then the upper and lower batteries. The defensive fortifications are really ingenious and entirely effective. What a great piece of history. The one quirk is the signal system letting people know if up coming people have the right of way or down going. It shows the minutes until change but some folks just don't pay attention and it messes things up causing some frustration. If you don't want to pay to go in there is a model in bronze outside which is a nice representation.

This is supposed to be controlled by a system of red and green lights to signify upward or downward travel. In practice it was organised chaos with people trying to cross on the stairs.There was little supporting interests, just the actual tower.If you're into the view from a tower and you like to take your picture at numerous angles then go, if you'd rather understand a bit more then stay in Lisbon and Google it....

Small but delightful. Sitting on a rocky part of the riverbank is this defensive tower which aimed to protect the Tagus river mouth. Built with light grey stone in a distinctive style it is one of the must-sees in Belem. Consists of three lower levels, and several levels up the narrow tower steps. Provide an insight into the importance of shipping in 16th century Portugal.

Unique, but more info needed. This is one of a number of things well-worth doing on a day-trip to Belem. It's an amazing concoction of Manueline style and is reasonably well-preserved, although it was nice to see them working on it the day we visited. There's also a nice view from the top. What's not so good is the system they use to allow only 150 people in the tower at a time. It frankly doesn't work - there were many frustrated and one of two irate people in evidence when we were there - and the authorities really need to give it a re-think. More annoying still was the lack of information provided on the history of the tower. The promised video on the fourth floor was not forthcoming - in fact the monitor was no longer there, just some cables and a dust-encrusted electronic box of some kind. Not good enough for what should be one of Lisbon's premier tourist attractions.

Enjoy the Tower from the Outside. This is a beautiful structure to view from the outside. However, the inside was not worth the wait.
