You do need to be quite fit to go up the stairs and there isn't access for wheel chairs at all, due to the original architecture of this building. Other than that, this monument must be visited when in Lisbon.

A vessel shaped tower monument. Once, back in the discoveries time, this monument was isolated in the middle of the river Tagus, surrounded by water, taking guard of the entrnace of Lisbon, as may some boats may approach.So, this was a both a defense monument as well as prison, as you may see the gallows inside.Upwards, upon the balcony's, you can overwhelm yourself's with fantastic views over the river Tagus, spanning from central Lisbon until the entrance of the river into the Atlantic Ocean.Most certainly it pays a visit for any foreigner.
NICE. If you are japanese and your finger is tickling evertime you see a massive monument of some kind....this is the place... :)

Interesting. We enjoyed the tower. We were staying in the Belem area and went for a visit to the tower. Interesting building and museum. This one is quite like that too ... its lovely and all but ofcourse it is full of non local people. So if you are more into local people of Portugal (Lisbon) you wont be here long.

Great attraction.. This attraction is well worth a visit but the lack of adequate staffing levels during peak season is very frustrating. Best to visit early in the day so you don't waste several hours queuing for a 30 min visit in the heat of the day.

Landmark. One can't come to Lisbon and not visit this landmark monument.

Beautiful Piece of History. If you want to be transported to Medieval Times, this is the place for you. It is little but with so much history. We took amazing pictures inside and outside.

Nice visit!. It defenitely worths the visit! A nice architecture, it actually looks like a boot and it has history!

To many people. This lovely monument is parte of the portuguese history and it represents a lot for the portuguese. It was built by Francisco de Arruda in the year of 1514 during the reign of João II.

Beautiful tower but not worth a long wait to get in. The Belem Tower is indeed a beautiful monument worth visiting. However, if there is a long line and you don't have a pre-purchased tickets, don't kill yourself to get in. The view from the tower is just OK and the Tower itself is rather empty inside. However, if your goal is to explore the interior of the Tower, definitely buy tickets ahead of time.

Don't bother - there are better things to see. If you are in Lisbon for more than a few days, it is probably worth visiting - but it is most impressive from outside, so save yourself €6 and several hours of queues and observe from outside. If you are going in - make sure to get a dual ticket (€12) which entitles you to skip the queue at the nearby monastery. Take a taxi (~20 mins) or the overground train (3 stops from Cais do Sodré) as Belem is a little distance from central Lisbon. We arrived 11am on a Friday morning and had to queue for approx 1-1.5hrs to get to the ticket office. Once inside, the interior is in all honesty fairly dull, and there is not all that much to see even from the top of the tower (the opposite side of the riverbank is predominantly industrial buildings). There is a ridiculous traffic light system for getting up/down the tower's spiral staircase - very frustrating (see other reviews on the topic). Left the tower with a somewhat bitter taste in my mouth.

Make sure you can go inside before you buy tickets. This is a beautiful tower landmark in Lisboa. We purchased tickets in conjunction with tickets to the Monastery. A beautiful but empty tower with poorly managed long queues. Nice looking tower in the Manueline style. However, it's al empty, completely! You queue there for ages and there is nothing to see except other tourists who also look at you since you'll be the only thing these bemused people will have to look at. They missed an opportunity to make this historical building educational. You queue at the bottom to come in, you queue some more to go up each floor with angry tourists overwhelming the staff as there is a traffic light system to go up and down the very narrow stairs. Then, once you've queued 3 times for significant periods of time, the only remote matter of interest -a film of several minutes on the tower- you find that the equipment is bust with no warning from anyone. So, let's recap:PROS:BEAUTIFUL ARCHITECTURETIKING THE UNESCO BOXWATCHING PEOPLE GETTING ANGRY FOR EACH OTHER FOR NOT ABIDING BY THE TRAFFIC LIGHT SYSTEMVERY CHEAP IF BOUGHT WITH A COMBINED TICKET (such as the one with the jeronimo monastery nearby)CONS:THE TOWERMost interesting part was a couple of jelly fish hunting nearby.
Beautiful spot. Unfortunately didn't have time visit this beautiful monument from inside however we were amazed anyway.It's gorgeous.
Good to look at for 5 minutes . That's about it. Took a few pictures and carried on with the day. There's some posters that have the history of the previous prison which were informative.

Cool. great view but the tour is so small with narrow tunnels which make it difficult for tourist to enter and leave the stairs for example.

Don't go to the top!. Very pretty from the outside but go yourself a favor and do not go in. The view from the top is underwhelming anyway. There is only 1 very narrow winding staircase to get to the top. It only allows 1 way traffic. They implement a timer system where for 1.5 minutes you can go up and for 3 minutes you can go down. However, it is the honor system and once you are at the top you are stuck, at the mercy of an army of inconsiderate people that continue to go up when they aren't supposed to while the time for going down ends and you are stuck for another cycle. There is not enough room to get past them and these people get mad at you when you tell them to hurry. After 3 iterations of this, I heard the guy behind me talking to his girlfriend in a language I didn't understand and I turned and told him that I knew exactly what he was saying. We were going next time no matter what. He smiled because that was exactly what he said. We had to push past a few people but we finally got out and we regretted going up in the first place.

Looking good from the outside. They just closed this right in front of us without any warning or general message to inform of the reason. The tower is very cool from the outside so go take pics of it, but ONLY GO IN if you want to wait in long lines once you are in to see the views from the tower. We had seen better views from Alfama so were unimpressed with the amount of time and waiting it takes , just for a river view. The stairs inside the tower only accommodate one way foot traffic so once you FINALLY make it to the top tower from waiting in lines, you have to WAIT in a huge line in the hot sun, to come back down. We hated the experience and have nicknamed this place the tower of terror after a Disneyworld attraction. Be warned.

Historical building with nice architecture, but expect long queues. We visited the Belém area on Monday, and the area is bustling with crowds. The tower is located around 1km away from the Belém train and tram stations, and be prepared to walk in the sun. We were prepared for that so it was ok. The queue entering the tower is very long, so we decided not to enter and appreciate the gothic architecture from the outside. What you could also do when you're there is to walk further west to the war memorial where it is considerably less crowded.

Nice history, but very large crowds that move SLOW !. This place is nice and a must see in Lisbon, however the crowds are large and it's slow getting thought. The surrounding area is worth visiting, and it makes a great place fir pictures.

Postcard Portugal. How can one not visit the landmark that fronts the major postcards of Portugal? Of historical and sightseeing value, no tour of Lisbon is complete without it. Expect long lines to the top however.

The panoramic view is not to be missed. I have heard so much about the place that I couldn't have missed it. It's worth the visit (although it was a short one). The panoramic view on the estuary and all the surroundings is truly beautiful. Dont' forget to buy some Pastéis de Belém on your way back!

Belem area of Lisbon is just beautiful. Defusing ell worth visiting.. We travelled to Lisbon from Vilamoura for the day. We got a taxi to Belem area which cost 15 euro from Oriente station. Having done some research prior to travel, this was an area which seemed yo have lots of things to see. I would recommend visiting here as there are various things to see within walking distance of each other. Only issue is there are lots of beggars which is pretty frustrating. We walked around the attractions, although you can pay to enter.

Visit early and avoid the crowds. I smallish fortress with a few interesting features. My son (11) like it and we talked about how enemies could attack the fortress and how he would do it in Clash of Clans. (If you don't know what this is you are too old ;-) Some nice photo opportunities there with stone carvings. Pro tip: Come early before the hoards invade! We came when it opened around 10 am and came by later around 12am and the lines was very long to get in. And make sure to climb the 93 steps to the highest tower. Note that there is traffic light that regulates if you can go up or down the stairs. They too narrow for people to meet and pass. Enjoy!

Interesting. This tower was originally in the river but is now at the edge of it. An interesting place to visit and you can avoid the long wait and queues if you buy a combined ticket at the monastery. You can climb up the steps to get a really good view of the city and river.

Most beautiful place in Lisbon . Absolutely gorgeous place! Can be reached by train and a short walk (7mins + 10mins) from the center, return trip costs 3 euros. Great parks all around torre de belem and a few museums and other places you can visit. The queue wasn't too long.

Beautiful Attraction. The Torre de Belem is an historic site which should not be missed on your visit to Lisbon. Located in the Belem area of the city, the fortification does not take too long to explore.A narrow staircase has to be negotiated to get to the top of the attraction which has a traffic light system to allow people to move up or down. However, it is worth the climb for the great panoramic views of your surroundings.The tower contains a lower level armoury area complete with cannons and a dungeon (which was used as a prison up until the 19th Century. It has North African Moorish styled watchtowers, shield-shaped battlements and a carving of a rhinoceros. The entrance fee for the tower is 5 euros but it is free on Sundays between 10am and 2pm. You can also buy a combined ticket which also gives you entrance to the Monesteiro do Jeronimos. I therefore recommend a visit to the Torre de Belem.

Interesting, But Long Wait. We had to wait a long time to get in here during the afternoon. People that had combo tickets from the monastery and here got to go through a short line on the right. Would definitely recommend doing that if you are touring both places. There are lots of steps to climb and due to tired knees and the heat, we just stayed on the large viewing area. I think if you want a view of the city, you'd get a better one form the Discovery Monument.
Stunning. A guard tower built at the entrance to Lisbon, the architecture is beautiful. Take some time out to grab a drink at the nearby café to really enjoy the magnificence of it.

exciting city break. We had an epic time in Lisbon. There is so much so see and Torre de Belem shoul not be missed.We visited it early in the morning surrounded by peace and lit by the sunrays. It shouldn't be missed.

Great historic site. Visit here the first Sunday of the month, and it's free! We passed by on Monday, and there were NO lines. Very nice views of the river. A historic site not to be missed in Belem. Just a short walk to the next tower, closer to Lisbon.

Beautiful buildings but huge crowds. We visited the Torre and the Monastery.Very interesting buildings, so refined for what was meant respectively as a defensive structure on the Tagus, and a place of prayer and meditation. Avoid the Sunday early afternoon because of the free entrance up to 2 PM which generates a huge line. Also going up the tower of Belem can get ridiculously frustrating on busy hours, with people not respecting the green and red lights (no kidding), and therefore a line builds up to go back down the tower.Note that guides are still wrongly quoting that the 1755 earthquake shifted the river, where that tower would have originally been built in the center. Not true. Do your research if interested.

You cannot lose this place. If you visit Lisbona even just for a weekend you have to go to Belem! Go by tram number 15 very easy and cheap and fast (15 min) you can admire the famous Tower, the "Monastero dos Jeronimos", the “Padrão dos Descobrimentos" very very amazing ...!!!

This is a facinating area just beside the wonderful monument to portugals naval explorers and beside the monastry.. It is a simple but wonderful place evocative of long ago when the seafaring area was subject to attack. the views from above are spectacular. The nearby geronimos museum helps to authenticate a place full of historical interest and beauty.

Torre of Belem - Point of departure of Portuguese Explorers. it was humbling to realize that this was the point from which many of the Portuguese explorers set sail on their voyages of exploration and discovery during Portugal's "age of discovery"
Beautiful views from here.. This was a beautiful castle that you could walk along the top wall all around it and get great views of the city. Definitely worth a look for the photo opportunities.

Great site, amazing view, but disorganised. One of the most beautiful views I have seen, but on a busy day, going up to the top was barely impossible. Narrow stairs allow one person to go up or down at a time. Despite staff efforts, it took us a looming time to be able to go up or down. There should be staff there, organising it. You gotta see it, but avoid busy days.

Incredible. A must see if you have any interest in the amazing history of Portugal as it relates to the world of exploration and discovery many centuries ago... almost too hard to take it all in! Unbelievable!
Interesting tourist spot.. We enjoyed this as our first real attraction in Lisbon . It was a great view from the top. It was breezy. The line was slow but not too long.
Interesting part of Lisbon's history. Out in the Belem part of town a little far from the main part of the city. Use the Hop On Hop Off system about 20 euros each. Was not open to public.

Definitely worth seeing on a trip to Lisbon. We caught the tram 28 and got off near the Belem Tower and walked along the waterfront and saw the Tower, antique markets were also on in the park. Its a short walk to Padrao dos Descobrimentos. We then caught the train from Cais de Sodre back into Lisbon...good view of the Bridge and Cristo Rei statue from here.

Worth seeing. We went to Belem on a Sunday, and the lines were so long and it was so hot that we ended up not going inside the tower. However, the outside of the tower is gorgeous as is the whole setting and the oter monuments (the Jeronimo Monastery and the Discovery Monument).

Great morning in Belem. I spent a lovely morning in Belem.Took the 15E tram from Praca do Commercio, and after about 25 minutes went down on the Torre de Belem station. This tower is so beautiful and you must see it for yourself. From there, I walked 5 minuets to the monument of discoveries which is nice too. From there, another 2 minutes walk to the Mostiero dos Jeronimos (there's a underground passage to the other side).Finally, I went to the close Pasteis de Belem bakery for some great (and cheap!) pastries, and then headed back to Praca do Commercio with the same 15E tram.Highly recommended!
Quick visit to Belem. For. Quick visit to Belem take a taxi from Lisbon to the Tower of Lisbon then walk over to the monument of discoveries and then Jeronimo's monestary.

Good, but not at all. we went on Sunday... Lots of people, lot of cue. But it goes fast. Once inside, you are not allowed to see the prision downstairs. If you go to the tower you will see a traffic light to ensure the traffic inside the towers stairs moves correctly. And is a little bit confusing with lots of people an lots of stairs... The rooms are empty... Only canyons at the entrance. But at least for 3€ (student) it was worth it.

Must See. Did not go inside, but in my opinion the best sight to see in Lisbon. There are others within walking distance (Monument and Monastery) so this area definitely deserves at least half a day. Be very wary of pickpockets on the 15 tram as it gets very crowded.
Real Live History. Hated history at school but enjoy it up close and personal. Did not know that the founder of Brazil came from Lisbon and also this tower was once in the middle of the river.

Beautiful...but just admire from the ground!!. As a history teacher & a lover of Lisbon, I was determined to get to the top of this hugely impressive & vitally important tower...as a tourist on holiday...I wish I'd just viewed it from the ground. Only pay to go up if you're visiting in off season or if you want to stand in a permanent queue!!

Excellent experience!. Wonderful place to go. It has different and important monuments like the Jeronimos Monastery (Mosteiro dos Jerónimos), the Belem tower (Torre de Belem) and the Monument to the Discoveries (Monumento aos Descobrimentos). The "pasteis de Belem" are excellent and a walk through the neighborhood is an excellent plan.

Nicer from the outside. Not much from the inside and the views inside are not as nice as the view of the tower itself. Daft one-way system employed in the tower simply doesn't work that to us idiot tourist, if you do go get a ticket for the monastery too

Amazing view!. This ancient guard tower is a little bit far away from the city center, but it offers an amazing view of the river Douro.Only bad part: the line. Once you enter who knows when you can leave. There is a narrow stair to go up, and the turists flow is controlled by a traffic light (that barely no one respects), so you could remain blocked on the top of the tower for a while!

Not worth the long queue. A pretty view, but if there's a long queue it's really not worth wasting half the day standing in it and there are more queues inside. And it, like a lot of Lisbon attractions is quite expensive.
River Fortress. This old river fortress is awesome! There are replica canons inside to show you how the place was fortified. You can go to the top for the views of the river and Belem. Don't miss it.

Visit with a Tour Guide. My dear readers..For people who want to see the site please just visit and take the regular walk.For tourists who are interested in the sites historical significance and what the site entails then visit with a Tour Guide. Tips: 1) Wear comfy shoes there are 93 steps to climb in a tiny stairwell (this is fun by the way)2) Visit early in the morning since the que does get long at mid day.3) Visit the Fallen Soldiers site next to it. It's worth it.

Need to fix the stairs signs. With the summer heat and the small long stairs to go up and down the tower, everybody is a little moody as it is. When I visited Torre de Belem, the electronic signs tell visitors when to go up and down the stairs were not working. I understand it is a technical issue and it may happen, however, I do think that one worker trying to control the crowds through 4 floors is not enough. A lot of people were fighting with each other and the guy was obviously nervous as well. Not a pleasant experience. The place if very nice and worth it (if the signs work ;)

Loved this. The glowing white stone against the azure sky, such a beautiful sight, there is so much to say about Belem, the museum's, monastery, park, fountains, the most amazing statues and sculptures, and the tower itself which has had so much difficult history and frankly misery and yet is just the most beautiful building, amazing

History and Beauty. The Torre, or tower, and the Monument of the Discoverers are on the river side of the tracks. If I went again, I would start with these two. They are also farthest from the Belem train station. From the monument, it's just a quick duck down a stair and tunnel to come up on the other side of the train tracks to go to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos.The Torre de Belem played an important part in the defense of Lisbon along the Tagus, and that history is presented quite well inside. For safety reasons, only a certain number of people are allowed in at any given time. If you can, purchase your tickets ahead of time; you won't have to wait long in a queue to get in. There are combo tickets with other museums (the Monastery, for example). Another option is the Lisboa card, which gets you into the Torre for free (but you'll have to wait in the ticket queue).The views across the river are quite nice, and with the bridge in the background, you can get some nice photos. I wanted to go up higher in the tower, but the queue to go up above the second level was too long, and I was pressed for time. Perhaps earlier in the day it would be better.The admission is not expensive for a nice piece of history, and with a combo ticket or Lisboa card it's even less expensive.There is a nice park adjacent to the Torre, too, with some shade trees.

Very nice Tower, but don't expect much more than a tower. There is nothing more than a tower, but it's admitteably a beautiful tower with an amazing view. I would recommend to go there to take cool pictures, enjoy the quiteness and take a break from the city.

Great from the river. Visited this attraction for many years and love the history and majesty of its importance to the Tagus and Lisbon.This year saw it for the first time from the river and it looks even better.Great to imagine how the explorers felt when returning to see this historic site.
Good but over-rated. Looks great on pictures, history of the place is obviously important with its strategic location. However, generally speaking, this is an over-rated attraction.

Nice sights. Used the hop on bus to get there. We didn't go into the tower, but walked around. The tower was great, you could see the cannons that would hold the fortress. There is a military museum there as well and a monument that is guarded for soldiers.
Must see. We walked from the old town to this site (1.5 hours) on the bike path near the river. It has excellent views all around and had a festive atmosphere in the surroundings.

Beautiful building and place, just prepare for crowd. Torre de Belem - and Belem itself - it's a must if you are visiting Lisbon. It's easy to reach with public transport. Just as the Monastery, the tower is very popular, so prepare for the crowd and the queues. The only annoying part is the aggressive gipsy street sellers in the area. Can't make two steps without someone pushing an unwanted item into your face... Hope this will be solved and then it's a perfect visit.

Amazing architecture and vistas. . . but avoid the line!. A can't-miss sight in Lisbon. . . amazing architecture, and great views of river. I recommend buying your ticket at the Museum adjoining the Monastery . . you can buy a 3-way combo ticket that lets you skip the entry lines at both the tower and (breathtaking) monastery (which are usually both VERY long), and see the museum as well. Also, consider visiting at sunset (see photo) - amazing light and no crowds. Do not skip Belem is you visit Lisbon.

Amazing history and views but prepay ticket. We walked here after visiting the monastery. We bought a ticket from the monastery that included both. I am happy we did since the line to get in would have been an hour if we bought tickets there. We were able to walk past everyone waiting in the sun and heat. The history of the tower and its sister towers was really interesting. Great views from many different levels. Since the stairs are very narrow they have a "traffic" light system for going up and down. It can be a nightmare if arrogant jerks ignore the light and decide to go the wrong direction anyway. Price is very affordable.

Historic landmark. Essential visit, purchase the tickets from the museum de arqueologia for the attractions you want to see first or waiting will occur. Once bought ticket walk straight across the bridge for queue stating prepaid tickets and save 1-2 hours. Unique building filled with exploration and maritime history . Jail at bottom has no height so mind your head and the spiral staircase to the top of the tower is 93 steps and very cramped so do not attempt if afraid of small spaces.

Tower of Belem. It's an icon. You have to go. There's just not that much to see inside. It's a prison . It's cramped inside. The spiral stair case is a bit of a nightmare . You have to do it.... The best part is the main deck outside .

Prepay for your ticket and avoid the queue. This is a popular tourist attraction in Lisboa, and for good reason as it is representative of a time when Portugal was a great maritime power. When the tower/ fortress was built in the early 16th century it was in the middle of the Targus Riiver. Since then so much land has been reclaimed it sits next to the shoreline. The building features some fine Manueline architectural detail and views along the riverfront, though there is not a lot to see inside the tower. When we visited we had to queue some time in the hot sun. Those who had pre-purchased their tickets skipped straight past. There is also some queuing involved to get to the top of the tower, though it is not too onerous.

Truely Amazing. This was just one of the amazing stops that our driver took us to on our day tour We jumped into Mercedes Benz at the Cruise terminal and the driver drove us around the sites of Lisbon for 5 hours. No hop on/hop off buses for us and the price was just the same if not cheaper than the ships organized tours. This is a great way to see Lisbon and many other cities of the world using chuffer driven cars with drivers that have extensive knowledge of their city

Glory of Portugal. It is the starting point of the discovering route to explored all over the world from Portugal in 1515, the beautiful tower is the symbol of glory era of the country's expanding, the amazing beautiful moorish design attracted lot of tourists, but the tower little small so that it need to take times for the single way lift for up and down, but the beauty of the gothic interior and the wonderful stone carved outside, earn the name of Landmark of Lisbon.

interesting. An important historical place. Near several other monuments.
you can see all city from the edge.
it´s a place to be on your list.
beautiful as always. A Lisbon landmark. A must visit for tourists, Torre de Belem is in a beautiful location next to the river.

A lovely period building but that's about it. A wonderful building but there is not much more to do in the area. There is a lot in Belem, so make it part of a day, rather than a trip just to this. The sea view is lovely and there are some places to eat near. Thee is a museum next to it, so a good cultural place to visit.

Tower was closed!!!. Went there on a Monday afternoon, the signs said the tower was open but there was no access for anyone. Nice place, though, and a lot of other things to do in the area - so I'm glad we didn't go to Belem for this attraction alone!
very beautiful for a few pictures.. Empty inside, not worth the money to go inside. Sunday morning it is free, so You may take a ook inside.
What a romantic spot! . You must go to Torre de Belem and take a casual walk in the river walk and view the romantic tower! There are several places to sit and have a lovely lunch and cold drink!!

Pictures don't do it any justice. This is one of the places that you simply HAVE to see with your own eyes. It's absolutely gorgeous. The the detail in the stone carving is incredible. It's amazing that someone could make a hard material look and feel so light and airy. Pictures simply don't capture that level of detail. Go early in the morning to avoid crowds and the the best pictures. Seeing this was definitely one of the highlights of my trip to Lisbon.
Beautiful View!. Nice architecture accompanied of a beautiful view to the water front, relaxing nice breeze and the sound of water, a place to enjoy for a moment.
Torre de Belem. Beautiful, striking and sited in a pleasant spot for a coffee in the sun or a stroll along the front. Easy to get to on Bus 728.

Quick stop along the waterfront. Small tower on the river front with a lot of history. Doesn't take long to walk through. There is a small fee so if you are budget conscious I would skip the inside tour and just admire it from the outside.

Brilliant view. Magnificent views, not too pricey (cheaper for students so remember to take your student card to tourist attractions!) the stairs in the tower are pretty steep and narrow so if your claustrophobic that could be a bit of a nightmare!

Fantastic place on the Tejo river. A great place to visit even though it is just one rather small building. The location is great though. The tower is located in the river itself and can only be accessed over a small bridge. The whole area is a great walk though; just reserve 30-60 minutes to walk along the river and take time to sit down and have a coffee (Bica) and some pastry and enjoy the view over the river down to the tower and the fresh sea breeze.

Nice, worth a visit. Compared to other objectives in Lisbon, this one is not that expensive and you will not feel disappointed. It will take a bit long to reach he top, "traffic lights" for stairs, if crowded - it might take longer but at the end the view is quite beautiful and if you are in the area - why not? Not far from the monastery...

Nice view. We visited when it was cloudy but nonetheless it was nice. It's interesting to see the small room where they held prisoners. You can also take a picture with the cannons and other stuff which was fun :)

Nice view, simple location, won't catch the sunset here. We ended the day by walking from the monument to the discoverers to Torre de Belem along the river. It has some great views of the other shore and the bridges, but don't count on catching the sun set from here. The sky looks gorgeous at dawn, though.

A Belem Must!. If one is visiting Belem there are three things that must be done; the monastery, Belem Tower, and the Monument to the Explorers. Pictures do not do this place justice. Its size is shocking based on the photographs we assumed it would e fairly small. We were surprised at the size of the Tower and of course the history surrounding it.

Smaller than I thought. Wel, this is probably one of the "must sees" in Lisboa. It is worth the effort going all the way out here, but it is not that fantastic. By taking the hop on hop off bus, you can make it smple for you. It was much smaller than I thought it would be. The views are nice, and when the queues are too longf it is quite OK to just walk around on the outside.

Great historical fortress. This fortress was built in the middle of the Tagus in 1515-21, the building contain the beautiful Manueline decorations, became a symbol of Portugal's great ear of expansion. The tower's balconies and roof panoramic view are great.

A big tower. This is a historic tower from which you can see up the river and out to the ocean. The views are nice, but in order to get to see them you have to climb a stair case so narrow that the traffic flow is regulated (at the bottom, you have to wait until a light turns green so you can walk and at the top you have to wait until the light turns green again). We didn't have to wait too long in either direction, but I didn't think it was that great.

Hop on hop off. This part of lisbon is very beautiful.lots of historic sights to visit.By taking the hop on hop off bus it is easy to get to and not expensive.Tou can tour on your own.It does get crowded so be prepared for crowds. It is definitely a tourist attraction and one not to be missed

A must if in Belem.. Can skip the queue if already hot at same time as the monestry.
Great views, saw jelly fish from the tower on the water below.
Only 120 can be on the tower at one time so there is a well design system to get people up and down at different times as not enough room to pass in the tower.
Stop at the Tower. Interesting history and views from this waterfront great spot to take in the large harbors beauty. Has guarded the river entrance for 600 years.

Historic. A beautiful monument right on the River in Lisbon. This site is part of Portugal's rich history. The location is within half hour of downtown Lisbon and is accessible by public transportation.

History and beauty. The Tower is beautiful you can go up to the top wait for the sunset there the views are
spectacular .

UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Tower of Belem an the Monument to the Discoveries in Belem are worth a visit. Our guide told us Henry the Navigator only went to sea one time and got sea sick and never went back.

Amazing building - setting is a little isolated. We drove from Lisbon - this is on the river side so a little tortuous due to the dual carriageway
Irritating "mind your car" assistants that you get in all the tourist traps
Building is stunning
We didn't visit the inside
The view across the river us a little industrial

Nice relax place close to Torré de Belém. Torré de Belém is nice place which take you to age of discoveries. Because it is last place which sailors saw when they went to discover new places. Close to Torré is nice café. You can take a rest here and see Torré.
Nice afternoon wal. Worth the trip from Lisboa, very scenic. And you have to travel down to this area if you want to sample the genuine pastiles.
Must See. Must see it's one of the most iconic monuments of Lisbon , you can also enter the tower and see it inside also you can take a boat ride .

Nice tourist spot to check out. very nice area of Belem. Beautiful waterfront with walking path along the river. Torres de Belem is a beautiful back drop for a souvenir when coming to Lisbon. Lots of history, you can walk across the bridge into the Torres or relax on the steps in front of the small beach!

The Discoverers & Discoveries of Portugal!. To understand and experience Portugal is to experience it's past. Torre de Belem takes you there, and a must-see is the Monument to the Discoveries a stone's throw away. Do go inside to the museum and up to the top of the Monument and look down!
July 2015 visit. Worth a look around .ticket for Jerinmous monastery and tower can be purchased together .can walk to it from monastery
A bit of history.. The Tower of Belem is a great photo op. The historical significance is unimpeachable, and it is worth the shelep, even if only for a photo op.

Better than expected. Stopped off here while using the on/off tourist bus. Almost decided against going in but so glad we did. A very surprising building with good views across the river, lots of nooks and crannies and spiralling stone staircases. Some very pleasant photographic opportunities. Three or four other tourist attractions very nearby.

Visit the tower but do not go on upper floor when busy. The tower is interesting however do not waste time going up the top for the view if it is busy. After waiting to climb the circular staircase you will be 'stuck' on the the top with a very long queue to go back down. The view on the top is not worth the time. It is very similar as the view you will see from the lower outdoor deck.

Stunning!. Although we did not get to visit the inside of Torre de Belem, we did take excellent photos at night. The Torre is closed to the public on Mondays so we didnt get the full tour.It is beautiful from the outside and even more amazing at night.

Manueline style tower with cool towers and turrets.. While you can't go inside, this almost 100' 16th-century tower is worth a stop. Built in the style of the Portuguese Late Gothic Manueline style, it's castle-like form has crosses of the Order of Christ, armillary spheres and twisted rope forms and knots which are typical to this style. The walls have spaces for cannons and the bases of the turrets have images of beasts, including a rhinoceros. It is really a shame you can't go inside!

a very unique fort. a beautiful monument designed to protect the city from attacks in the middle ages. It looks like a castle but once inside the 3 ft thick stone walls shows its real purpose. Great view of the city and across the river. A must see if you are in Lisbon
Nice.... It's a nice history place, not outstanding. It could be a part of a tour in Belem. We have to wait when you want to claim to the top of the tower.
Unique building in Lisbon. Short walk from our apartment right across the ´Pasteis de Belém'. Well worth the walk, even though it was raining a bit.

Nice. Wonderful place and great view.
Just come wen it's not to hot you will enjoy more. The wiew is wearth the drive :)

Excellent view. When your in Belem go to the water and walk up into the castle for the best views of the waterfront and beyond. When you are done go across the park to the best pastais de nata in the world. This place was the original one started in 1833 and they don't come any better than that, but plan on waiting in line but it is worth every minute you are there. They are warm when you get them and you will be glad you waited.
Fun thing to explore. must see if you are in Belem. I thought Belem was one of the best parts of lisbon. I'd definetly reccomend a day in Belem and a stop at the Tower.

Long trek there for disappointing visit. This tower is highly rated on many Lisbon tourist websites but really isn't worth the 2 hours it takes to go see. First of all it's a 20 min walk from the train station unless you hire a taxi or tuk tuk. When we got there, the tower was cool to take a picture of but it's not that tall and we didn't see the appeal of going inside. We tried anyways, but the line was paused for 30 minutes because too many people were inside and there is only one narrow stairway! Poorly run and not as impressive as we were told. Go to the tile museum instead..

Unique Attraction for Lisbon. Belem Tower is a unique fortress on the waterfront to watch over the incoming threats over the sea. It has gorgeous views on the city as well as a beautiful architecture to visit. I recommend interested visitors to go there early to avoid crowds in the afternoon/evening time. Going there is a little difficult with public transport. So it is good to combine with the other attractions in Belem such as the Pastel de Nata at Pastéis de Belém (see my review).
Spectacular. Tower is really spectacular but for me the queue to get in was very tiring in the heat and too long to have to stand waiting.

Worth a visit. Torre de Belem is right on the river in Belem. It is an old battlement that defended the port from invaders. It is always fairly busy with visitors, but is worth visiting. To get right up to the highest point there is a fairly small spiral stone staircase which has stop/go lights to let you know when people are either walking up or down, so when there are plenty of tourists it can take a fair while getting up to the top and then back down.

Nice views. Bought a combo ticket with Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Just walked over from the monastery, so no queuing to buy tickets here. You get good views from climbing to the top...it is only one way so there is a small wait to go up or down.

Tower where Portuguese Caravels left to find the New World in 1500s. Interesting small castle with a small souvenir shop. Still has many of the original canons that were posted at several port holes. Several levels. A good start for the sight seeing of other larger castles in the Lisbon area (Cascais and Sintra are recommended side trips if you have an extra day)
good views. Good views over the water from the top and very picturesque. However it was a bit crowded and there is only one stair-well to get up and down so you have to queue and wait at each level

Many things to like. Fortresses, the waterside, panoramic views, mini-cannons.... if any of these things appeal to you, then I highly recommend Torre de Belem, especially if you are in Belem. Great place to play photo-tag. NOTE: We visited on a Thursday afternoon; there was not a crowd and we got right in. Passing by via train on Saturday, though, I could see a line to get in.TIP: Belem can be a long ride by bus/tram from downtown, so it makes sense to visit the major attractions in one shot. If you decide to take this approach, consider getting a Lisbon Card; you will get your money's worth out of it

What and incredible place.. Lot of history over there. Very impressive construction from outside. We tried to get inside but it was almost the closing time and the guard did not allow us to pass. Take a quick look on the posters at the cornice will help a lot to understand about the Torre.

Average if you only see it from top of a hop on hop off bus. With limited time in Lisbon as a cruise ship port of call, we opted to ride a hop on hop off bus. This meant we only glimpsed the Tower of Belem from the street. The grounds looked lovely along the shoreline, but we had sailed under the bridge and right up to Lisbon with magnificent views. So not sure we missed many views.
Great spot to visit. The view was amazing. There is a bridge similar to the Golden Gate. The only bad part is the public restrooms. It was still a lovely view.

Nice views. The tower has a great view of river and the Abril de 25th bridge. Nice little park to relax in afterwards. Lines can get a little long which can be annoying in the summer months given you probably line up longer than you are in the tower itself.
A must see whilst in Lisbon. Beautiful views from the top .. Always busy, but worth a look for sure Plenty of information about the history too which is nice
not worth the price. Long lines and hefty entrance fee to see nothing more than what you can see from the shore, plus it's out the way. Go to the naval museum instead.

Paddle in the water and see the sights. We took the train to Belem from central Lisbon and walked along the harbour front- interesting to pass the Explorer's Monument with map inserted into the pavement- and on to the Belem Tower- we didn't pay to go in since it was the external features that seemed the most interesting- there is a small space to paddle in the water- refreshing and not so busy

Worth it we thought. Went out with my daughter by the trolley (15) from Lisbon. We loved this and the monastery of Jeronimos. These were free entrance with the Lisbon card (we bought the 3 day card and felt it was worth it). Being able to climb up inside and get pictures all around was great!

Best view, from the river Taag by boat. My girlfriend an I saw the torre de belem from the surface of the water. A unique sight. As it was ment to see. To display the majestic Lisbon prestige from former times.

A must if you are in Lisbon.. The tower of Belem is truly breathtaking. The building is very well maintained and takes one through its various uses throughout history.
The entrance price doesn't feel expensive and various concessions are available in addition.
The ancient, spiral staircase would be difficult for those with mobility problems but the views from the roof are worth the trek.

Back to history of overeses expenditions. Torre de Belem is nice composition, it is situeted in water, with nice viiew. You can feel from it history of Portugal overeses expeditions. Architecture of Torre is very detailed.

The most stunning monument in Lisbon!. Torre de Belem is definitely a well deserved iconic symbol of Lisbon. It is artistically beautiful, with a fantastic history and superbly located right on Tagus river. Although it is beautiful from the outside, a visit inside is a must, not only for the monument itself but also for the amazing views of Lisbon and the river. It is very close to other main attractions like the Jeronimos Monastery, The Navy museum, the Planetarium, the Discoveries monument, The Belem Cultural Centre, and also Pasteis de Belem!!! The space around it is beautiful and there are some pleasant cafes. The sunsets near the tower can be wonderful.

Beautiful tower, great views from top. I really enjoyed visiting this area. It's right by the water, and you can take beautiful pictures of the water and the bridge from here. It's worth the ticket to go in, although if you are also going to the monastery it's worth getting a joint ticket for 12 euros for both (saves you 4 euros). It's an old tower, but you can go up to the top and take great photos. A MUST SEE!
Belem . Well worth a visit as very close to other attractions. You'll need comfy shoes as a small walk between each.

A Must see. A mast see UNESCO fortress in Belem close to Lisbon. 500 years ols and still picture perfect. Great views from the top of the tower. Buy your tickets in advance if you can the line can be quiete long. The is a combined monastery /tower ticket for €12 for adults. A number of cafe near by that you can eat and drink at while looking at the fortress. There are displays inside and old cannons . Recommend

Lovely monument. This is such a lovely monument. It looks a bit like a ship about to sail. It has water all around it. There is a small beach as well. There is parkland all around and a small café just past it. Really nice area to look around. We got the red open top bus to Belem and got off to look around then waited for next one to come and this took us back into Lisbon City. Little shops and yacht arena.
Nautical history of Lisbon. Historical place with good walks around and nice parks on the way. Belem itself is a lovely area to explore, and the tower adds to the whole nautical experience of Lisbon
Good for an hour. The architecture is lovely and the sea was a bonus for our younger children. The views are lovely and there are binoculars for hire, which the kids thoroughly enjoyed.Worth a go.

Worth a visit! . It cost 6.30 euros to go in. We didn't paid for it but it still worth to take a look by the outside. There is a big garden where you can do picnic. What we did was buy the Belem famous sweets and eat them there. It was really chilling and pleasant.

Lots to see here!. Everyone is familiar with the Tower of Belem, but there is much more here to see! The statue of Henry the Navigator, the world map inlaid in front of it, the monastary, WWII memorial, the list goes on and on. We visited on a Monday when most exhibits are closed but we still enjoyed ourselves immensely because of our tour guide Alex from Top Ten Tours. Most of the attractions are free on Sunday (double check this) and the area can be quite crowded as well. Beautiful visit!
One of the memorable visit.. I loved being in this place. The park nearby allured me and i was there for long time. I promise I will be back here once in a week.

Iconic Tower of Lisbon. The is a richly ornamented tower which is emblematic of Lisbon, if not Portugal. Built in the 1500s it was monument to Portugal's power. The façade is quite beautiful and a very nice picture shoot. Though you may go inside to the top for a view, we did not.

More beautiful from the outside. Wouldn't go there a second time. Ok. More beautiful from the outside. Use you precious time for sightseeing at the monastery.The traffic light system inside in the narrow staircase worked well. Please pay attention to that.

Not worth it. We bought a combined ticket for the monastery and the tower. The tower was disappointing. First, it's quite a hike from the monastery. Secondly, it isn't that photogenic. Finally, there is a green and red light system to get people up and down the narrow winding stairway to the roof. Rather confusing. And the view up on top isn't that great. I wouldn't recommend this one.

Beautiful.. This place is well worth the trip, but it did frustrate me a bit. First, buy your ticket in advance. The line to get in is very long, and they only allow a certain amount of guests in at a time. Second, I would recommend heading up to the very top of the tower first, and then working your way back down. The stairs are so narrow that groups can only either go up or go down and they have this system of lights telling you when it is safe to go down and when it is safe to go up. It seems like everyone completely ignores this system, and so there is a traffic jam of people trying to go up and down. This gets to be a little annoying, but its definitely worth it! Go all the way to the top right away and get this part out of the way first, and then enjoy the rest of the tower on your way down.

Might be worth a walk if you have the museum on your list of things to do. Somewhat disappointing in that the area has more to offer than the Torre (museums, for example). Take the bus (527) from the Marques De Pombal "square" (or any point en route to Belem). See the waterfront area and then head off to the museums or other attractions in Belem.

Can't believe the age of these places. Coming from a very young country like Australia we have trouble getting our heads around the age of buildings and monuments in Europe. Had a short wait to get in but it was worth it. Years of history behind these walls. Even more impressive being surrounded by water. Excellent idea of having a light system to let you know when you can go up or down. Pity some people ignore the lights and make it very difficult for the people doing the right thing.
Great weekend with friends. As we did the monastery went to the tower. Again very good. look for the prepaid ticket queue.saves a lot of time

great symbol of Lissbon. Walking alongside the embankment you can reach the Belem tower. It looks so nice towering from water. Take a pictures from different side depends the time of the day and sun position. You can visit the Armory museum next to the tower and then relax at the restaurant just in between these two sightseengs.

One of Lisbon's most famous landmarks. Get a day pass and hop on the bus and hop off at the Jeronimos Monastery and it's a short walk along the river front to Torre de Belem. Beautiful architecture. We saw it when it was completely surrounde by water, makes for some brilliant photos.

Very cool. This was also shut as the day we explore Belem was a Monday- where all museums/ monuments are closed. But it was a very cool area. I really wanted to even though we knew it was shut. It was cool to see the paintings of the tower in raging seas! Loved it. I also loved the model of it designed for those hard of seeing- what a lovely touch!
powerfull. It proudly rises from the shore.The wind was blowing, I felt adventurous and happy.Of course, tourists are spoiled the picture, but I was also one of them ...

Beautiful monument! . It's one of the best places to visit in Lisboa! The tower is best seen in the evening. Very peaceful place. The architecture is wonderful!! The cafes close by are also good. So hop on and go to Belem to spend a great evening there!!

Beautiful view and interesting stop. Worth the trip down to see the Torre de Belem. Beautiful views from and enough history to keep 4 teenagers interested. Easy to combine with a visit to the church and cloisters, which makes for a nice couple of hours.
Better views down the road. This tower is worth seeing but there is another bigger lookout in the same area that is cheaper and has far greater views

Must visit. We got to the tower on the end of a busy day, just beore the closing time. It wa s agreat experience, with nice views over the river and the 25th April Bridge, as well over the monument.Has several floors, and a funny and effective traffic sistem on the stairs, which shows you when you can go up or downstairs, and when has to sop, because otherts started to go against you :)I liked this attraction. had combined ticket from Jeronimos Monastery.
a real symbol, not to be missed. lovely building, along the river, and what has become a real symbol of the city of Lisbon . no cars allowed nearby which is great

a piece of seafaring history!. built in the 1500s, it was the last thing many sailors saw leaving the harbor and the first thing they saw returning. An example of manueline architecture. It once stood in the middle of the Rio Tejo when the river was wider.

Torre de Belem.... The first time I went there, I walked all the way, past the Time Out Market/Mercado da Ribeira, the Cais do Sodré train station, the Museums, Alcántara, the Docks, the April 25 Bridge...from a distance you can see the Padrão dos Descobrimentos and the Torre de Belèm... every step that brings you closer gives you a different perspective... do not miss going there! As a reward have some delicious "pastel de nata" at the Antica Confeitaria de Belem...
Beautiful views. Old tower is definitely worth visiting despite being a little difficult to get to using public transport. Be prepared for some walking. Otherwise a great place to see

Not worth climbing---see tips.. Walking down to the tower is a nice stroll (and then you can walk along the river to the Padrao dos Descubrimientos), the Contemporary Art Museum, and'or the Monastery. If you do go inside, buy the combo ticket for the Monastery to avoid a long wait in line there.
Within the water. Constructed in 1521 by architect Diego Boitaca. Vasco de Gama sailed to India from there. Originally in the land but moved to sea by 1755 earthquake.
Belem is a highlight. it is worth spending a bit of time in Belem. Situated on the impressive Tagres river it has a lot of historical buildings including the tower and Jeronimos monestary.

Nice photo opp. Nice to visit to take pictures. Nothing to see inside but the view up the tower.
150 people max in the tower so plan accordingly or will have to wait outside in the sun.

Nice view. Admission included in Lisbon Card, we stopped by after visiting the Monastery. Please know that the main street where the Tram 15 runs is NOT on the water, thus you cannot see the tower from the tram track (or in our case, sidewalk). There is a overpass walkway to take you over but you have to cut down a side street.I personally will NOT suggest you to pay just to see the inside of the tower. While interesting and noteworthy as a tourist attraction, there is not much to see. However, if you have Lisbon Card, or does not mind paying extra €2 as a duel ticket with the monastery, go ahead. The view is good, you get a clear shoot of the Ponte 25 de Abril bridge (aka the "Golden Gate Bridge") - but as a tour guide said: You're in Lisbon, you don't have to pay for a view.TIPS: there is system to the 1 stairway madness (yes, it's a single spiral stairway that take you up to the top, then down to exit). Look for the arrow indicator above the entry way on each level. When the UP arrow turns green, you can walk up. When time is about to run out, you will hear an alarm. That means you need to get out of the way for the down traffic as soon as you can = get off the stairs into the nearest level. Then the DOWN arrow will turn green, so that people can get the heck out of there. It alternates and it's a good system if everyone understands and follows it.WARNING: because no one explains the system when you walk in, most visitors don't know about the arrow system. You will find yourself in queue forever trying to get down from the top. PLEASE share the info so that everyone can get in & out quicker.
Grand old building. Fabulous building but be careful which day you go as one day is free and it tends to get jam packed. Could spend an hour or two here quite easily

very pretty. this old building is definately worth a visit. it only costs 6€ to get in and its worth it. there's not much to see, but its a piece of the portuguese history and in good weather its very impressive

Lovely place to spend an evening!. It's a very busy tourist attraction in Lisbon. As one would expect queues to enter this are super long! The best time to visit is evening as you can enjoy the views of the bridge at night as well. Anytime before that would make it very difficult if you do not like the raging sun on your back!! Also it's a pretty decent walk away from public transport or the tram. So go at a good hour if you must!

Wonderful tower. It is a fortified tower on the bank of the Tagus river, built in the 16. century. It is built in the same gothic style as the Monstry nearby. The whole tower is full of stone decorations, really beautiful. And if you go upstairs, it has four floors, you have wonderful views. You can reach by public transpoer, by tram or bus.

Great Tourist Attraction and Learn about Portuguese History. Torre de Belem is a great destination to visit - allow about two hours, it is in a park along the river and there are other things to see and do as well. This tower is well preserved and visitors are permitted to go all the way up to the turrets, and down to the dungeons. One of a few buildings not destroyed in the 1755 Lisbon earthquake, due to the fact that it was in the middle of the river (at that time, now along the shore) and was an earthquake-resistant structure due to riverbed. We had a very short line the day we visited and as a result it was not over crowded as it might be on a weekend. Views from anywhere in the tower are awesome, and visibility is quite good. The "Golden Gate Bridge" knock off can be seen from this venue, spanning the river. There is a snack bar for a coffee or light meal in the park area. Two caveats: #1 pay to use the public toilets - nominal fee goes toward upkeep #2 spiral staircases (to top of tower and to dungeons) may be a challenge for someone who is unsteady on their feet or gets dizzy easily.

What a beauty!. The line was long but it was totally worth it. The tower is fabulous. Be prepared to walk up many many stairs. The view from the top is totally gorgeous. If you plan to attend the monastery, it is best to buy tickets for both attractions in one go to avoid at least one big line.

must try cakes in passeterie de Belem.. This part of Lisbon is very nice, you can reach there by your car, bus or tram. Jeronimos Monastery, Torre de Belem, Lisbon bridge view and the Sailors Monument is nice. It is nice to have a walk along the river. Top attraction was the visit in passerie de Belem, which offer tasty cakes which are made according to Jeronimos receipt from XIX century. MUST taste it, you can try those cakes everywhere in Portugal but there are the best!
Torre de Belem. Visited the Torre but were barred from entering by a chin stopping people from going over the bridge and into the tower. Did notice a few days later that people were allowed in

Beautiful Fort on the Tagus River. We walked to the fort and were rewarded with some spectacular views from land. We didn't pay to go inside the fort because it wasn't that large. Great areas to lounge or dine around the fort if you want to rest or refresh while have a very nice view of the fort and river.
Tourist Trap. In the overall scheme of things in Europe, this tower is kind of average. Nothing really that makes you say WOW! It is a nice, granite structure that protected Lisbon.

The Best Part is the View, BUT.... ...to get to the top to see the view, you have to walk up a narrow, one-way circular stairway. At top and bottom there are red/green lights to start and stop traffic- so those going up don't run into those coming down.It wasn't expensive to get in ( especially with a combo ticket)- but the best part is the view and there are plenty of other good views around Lisbon!

Important part of Lisbon History. The tower is an important attraction to view, but it is very small for the number of tourists that visit, and there is a lot of confusion about getting up and down the very narrow spiral staircase that leads to the top of the tower. One person can cause an awful traffic jam, so it takes a lot of patience to experience the tower. The attraction is a bit out of the way, but only takes about an half hour to view entirely. It is worth it if you have the time, but not a must-see if you are short on time; it is possible to get a good idea of what it is all about from the outside, so it isn't strictly necessary to go inside. I don't regret it, though!

Ready to explore the world. We found the Torre de Belem an interesting historical site. The stairway to the top is quite narrow but the view at the top is great. The only downside beside our ca. 45 min wait to get into the Torre was the jammed stairway. You get a signal at the top or the bottom of the staircase when to walk. For some reason it got jammed and even though we had the green light to walk the staircase was jammed and the light got red again. Some people got frustrated. I would suggest that once you start your ascend go all the way to the top. Then visit the different floor while descending or vice versa. The big monument about Portugal as a seafaring nation is close to the Torre. In front of the monument is a huge world map on the ground. You can learn which nation occupied another nation and at what time.I found it quite interesting.

A Wonderful Tower. We didn't go inside the Belem Tower but it is Lisbon's most iconic landmark.It was built in the 16th Century in the Tagus River to control the entrance to the city from the sea.The fortress has surprisingly beautiful sculpted balconies and fine limestone ornaments.We wish we could have seen the interior but it was closed when we were there.
Looking at it from the outside is enough. The stroll leading there is great. Not worth getting in. You get a nice view from the outside which is enough.

Make sure you cross the road and try the Belem pastries...custard tarts. Great place to take photographs, lunch nearby and relax. As we were being escorted on a tour I only had a short time there, but also managed to visit the war memorial nearby. There is a lot to see and visit nearby .

Huge, impersonal plaza. The tower is very interesting, and a reminder of important events. It is well-done and includes other sculptures with a large garden nearby. The train stops right out front.The square is so large, it could handle the debarkation of cruise ships or handle a good-sized fair or concert. As it is, is gives the feeling of vastness of the ocean beyond, which the folks portrayed on the tower set out to conquer.

Great to see, not to go in. This Lisbon landmark is a must see from afar, however don't waste the money to go in. Climbing the tower itself is a nightmare. The narrow spiral staircase only really accommodates one-way traffic posing a problem for multiple tourists wanting to go up and down. There is a system of lights that are intended to direct traffic going up and coming down, however one slow person in the group (and there's always one) and it's a free for all. The views of Lisbon are far better from Castelo de São Jorge.

Great history . Such amazing place and so much history involve. Watch your purses. A lot of women trying to sell things around. It was safe, but way too much people trying to sell you scarfs, glasses.......don't open too much your money out. For sure stop o. The way back at the pasteis de Belém store and eat some of these delicacy! Best dessert you will ever eat

Don't waste your time. As a previous reviewer said - is this it?? We stood in a long queue in the hot sun to get in. There was general confusion about why there were actually two queues. It turned out that one was for pre-paid/booked tickets. Nobody at the Jeronimo Monastery, which we had just left (and very much enjoyed) told us that there was the option to buy tickets for both attractions at once. There was absolutely no information about the tower - with daily queues like this, one would have thought that this would have been an ideal place to put up posters telling us what we needed to know about this very important piece of Portuguese history. Neither was there much information once we staggered across the threshold. It was very crowded, very small, and there was general chaos about who was supposed to go up and down the narrow stairs when. If you suffer from claustrophobia, be warned - this is not for you. We abandoned this mission when somebody shouted at us for we were not quite sure what. A very unpleasant experience.

Interesting Belem Tower Experience. We did the Big Yellow Cruise from the Terreirs Station from the Underground at the Harbour. The cruise takes around 1.5 hours and went under the bridge and we got a good view of the opposite bank ships and the large monument which looks over Lisbon. Further on we crossed back across the Tagus River and a had a good photographic view of the Belem Tower, the Discovers Monument and the Container Port. Good value for 17 Euros on the cruise for around two hours. Reductions for children and Seniors.

So..... If you are not going to visit the monestary I do not see any reason to go all the way out here.The view and the the tower is nice enough, but I did not find it so interesting that I would spend an hour in a bus (which it took us, as no metro goes here).We chose not to go in, as the line was long, but it is low, small - so what would you be able to see?? We even had the Lisboa Card with free entry, but I was left feeling - is this it???

good fun. We bought combined tickets for the tower and the monastery, which was lucky because when we got to the tower the line up was about 200 mtrs long but we were able to stroll past everybody and just walk straight in. The tower was interesting and fun to explore. You have to be a bit patient to climb up to the top. There is a very narrow stone spiral staircase which is controlled by a stop/go light system. Unfortunately too many people ignore this so the ensuing traffic jam and arguments carried out in about a dozen different languages is good fun to watch in itself-as long as you are not directly involved. If you can keep your patience and temper you will be rewarded with a nice view from on top. Well worth a visit.

Change your times please!. We arrived thinking we would miss the crowds at 5.30pm on 9th June. Opening times to 18 30 last admissions before 18.00. We missed the crowds as it was closed. Come on do not shout at the door go away I can hear you. My advice arrive at 3 latest you cannot trust this place. So wrong.
Pretty place . A beautiful place to see if in Lisbon. It is quite small and crowded, so in my opinion you don't have to go in, it's not that special.
Worth seeing. Worth seeing and near other tourist sights and attractions. Take the number 15 tram from down town Lisbon to the stop after Belem. Nice walk along the river side.

Belem tour. I strongly recommend to take a tour to Belem, especially if this is your first visit to Portugal. You would understand this country so much better starting your experience with place where raise and prosperity of Portugal was born. Carriage Museum and Palace, must see attractions. Although they are no very publicized for some reason, they are high quality museums and give you a good start for further exploration. Try Belem famous pastel da Belem and other local delicacy in centuries old café.

Not very successful, but photogenic. We were told that as a defensive position it didn't work: the cannon men were so superstitious they had to do ten hail Mary's after each volley to spare them having the cannon balls come back at them. It left a lot of time between volleys for enemies to advance. The tower is a remnant of the seafaring history of Portugal. It's a pleasant place to visit, and the view from the top of the tower is lovely. The tower is accessed via a one-way stair, so hope for not too many people.
One of the low points. Was a bit of a waste of time, and way overpriced as its only really a lookout point. Beautiful to look at but if you want a good view go to the castle and save some money
Fun time. beautiful to see, but remember to take good walking shoes and explore everything. there is also a bit of a wait depending on when you visit.

Class, well worth a visit. This was one of the first attractions we took in on our recent visit and we were well impressed. Although we did have to queue for a bit it was worth it and our admission fee was included as part of our Lisboa Card. Its amazing to think the tower still stands after so many years with so much history attached to it. The stairway to the top of the tower can be tricky to navigate and if you were to arrive here with a buggy/stroller then you wont be getting to the top.
Absolutely Amazing. A not to be missed site in Lisbon.Well worth the small admission fee.Allow yourself lets of time to truly appreciate this magnificent ancient castle.

Interesting. This is a place that we didn't want to miss as it is such a landmark. The line was about 30 minutes. If you are physically handicapped in anyway this is not the place for you as there are a lot of stairs. They are very narrow, too, and sometimes it is hard to negotiate who is supposed to go up or down!! There were great views from the top! It is such a picturesque place. This is something every tourist needs to do.

One of the most impressive monuments in Lisbon. Torre de Belém is among the best monuments to pay a visit to in Lisbon. Its location is fantastic, enabling you to experience the best Tejo's view and to go and see several other fantastic monuments and places, above all the best of the best, the "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos". Just across, you will find the modern cultural and arts centre CENTRO CULTURAL DE BELÉM, which excels in providing Lisbon with all kinds of cultural activities
Great Views from the Top!. It's a hike -- one way traffic on narrow staircase -- to the top so beware. Not for those who are claustrophobic.
See the Armor. I visited Torre de Belem many years ago. There is a collection of armor that is fabulous and worth seeing. (Travel date is incorrect.)

Obligatory Tourist Stop. A visit to Lisbon will not be complete without swinging by Torre de Belem. (It would be similar to going to Paris and not going to the Eiffel Tower.)
Nice park, nice monastery across the street, close to famous Pasteis de Nata - YUM!!!

Symbol of many happy returns and other not so happy days. For years the sailors knew that when they saw Torre de Belem they would soon land home. Unless those carefully arranged canons were pointing at your ship of course. The Torre later became a prison mostly for political prisoners, which means that it has been a temporary residence for some historical figures of Portugal. The roof terrace looks very similar to the Gaudi works in the famous houses of Barcelona. The view is really nice and the staircase will give you a short aerobic training and the proof that people cannot understand that we have universally agreed to stop when we see a red light.

Beautiful Tower right on the coast. it's a wonder tower, and its on a beautiful spot right on the coast, can be quite crowed with tourists, a few street sellers selling drugs, but that's just the way it is with the major attractions in Lisbon. a must see in Lisbon.

Amazing experience. Waited on line since we did not hVe an advance ticket but the line moved ok. The views and the picture ops were great. Right on the water and great history. Certainly worth the trip. There iis a water closet in the cafe but you will need to pay.

Beautiful Tower. Torre de Belem is a wonderfully preserved fortress on the Rio Tejo. Great views over Belem and the river. If there are many visitor avoid climbing the stairs to the top of the tower- waiting to climb and descend is a frustrating experience and the views from the top are not much better than from the lower levels of the fortress.

Belem Torre and Belem Itself, Magical. Take at least a half day to visit Belem and its Torre (Tower). The tower sits right on the River and is an amazing piece of architecture. It is one of many sites to enjoy in this neighboring part of Lisbon.

A historical mark. This tower is an important mark of the history of the portuguese discoveries all over the world. It represents the heroism of the people that went all over the world in tiny boats simply filled with courage.

Very interesting. Do not pay for a tour, this is very easy to get to by train from Cais do Sodre train station in Lisbon with regular trains.A short walk from the railway station will find you at the tower, very impressive moorish designs, it would have looked amazing when it was in the middle of the river, it is now a few feet due to silting and earthquakes. Very close to other attractions in the area. We did not go in as there were massive queues from tours.
Evocative & quite lovely.. A must-do in Lisbon, somewhat dizzying stairs but worth it. I had a combined ticket with the nearby Monastery & the queue consisted largely of myself.

Beautiful views. Old tower that was once an island. It was part of the defense system in days long ago. Now you can climb up to the top for wonderful views of the ocean, the sail boats and the Christ statue. It combines Moorish, Gothis and Renaissance styles of architecture.

Terrific historic attraction, but pay attention to the traffic light!. Very interesting historic fort. The views and photos from the upper levels are great. If you go down into the old prison area in the bottom watch your head! It's fun though, to explore the old structure. There is a "traffic light" that is supposed to control the flow of people going up the very narrow spiral stairway to the upper floors (and balcony). It's so narrow that only flow in one direction is possible (up or down) at a time. But people don't always follow the traffic signal, so keep that in mind as you enjoy the views and historic chambers.
Beautiful pictures. The line was hundreds long so we didn't go in. But took great pictures around the tower. Right on the water so it's really scenic

Small yet interesting landmark. Given its location in the area of other major tourist attractions in Belem, there's no point in -not- paying a visit to this iconic old defense tower.The tower itself, once situated further out in the water, as can be seen on paintings from many centuries ago, is fairly small and 30ish minutes should be enough for most visitors to see the interiors, which honestly aren't that special. The views from the top are grand, yet if you already have, or plan to, access the top of the nearby Padrão dos Descobrimentos (discovery monument) I wouldn't bother standing in a queue or paying for a ticket to go inside.

Nice view and good deserts. This place is historically important for Portugal. It is beautiful, in white color stone, you can visit it in Saturday or Sunday is free before mid-day. Then you can go to eat “pasteis de Belém” with a good expresso. The park is also a nice place just to stay and walk around.

World heritage monument with a great view from top. We walked along the lovely shore after vistiing the Monument to the Portugese Discovers. The tower is surrounded by water. One has to climb the steep, narrow stairs, for a great view out to the open ocean, back to the "Discoveries" monument and of both the huge suspension bridge & tall Christ Statue & monument on the far shore. Take time to read about the history of the tower. We took a regular city bus (#714). from central Lisbon near our hotel all the way to the "Discoveries". monument for only 1.40 euros each way if you charge the Lisbon bus card. The tram runs the same route , but for twice the cost & is much slower. Also one saves several euros if you buy combined Belem tower and Jeronomo Monastery admission tickets instead of buying each separately at each entrance.

WORTH IT BUT. Excellent views from the top of the tower but the management of the people ascending and descending on one very narrow staircase was awful. People were ignoring the red & green lights so if you're claustrophobic don't bother.
What a view. Well worth a visit. Not expensive. Make the effort to climb the tower as the views are fantastic. Best view is looking towards Lisbon.
OK, but nothing special.. If you're passing, it's worth a look around. A lot of history and some old cannons. If it's busy, you have to wait your turn to access the spiral staircases.

Expect a fort in a beautiful landscape. The fort is sourrounded by water. It is its magic. Keep yourself informed about the history and take a look at the view when you are at the top. It is also a nice walk. Do not recommend spending much time there but it is well worth a walking to the tower.
Great view. It's a world heritage monument, and worths the visit.It is a monument to Portugal's Age of Discovery and have a great view at the base and from the top (if you wish to go there).

Welcome to the Tejo gate. Small fort with great historic value. Great view from the top.
Looks like a boat and also a wedding cake.

Just Another Tourist Attraction . At the base it was interesting to see the fort surrounded by water. But that's where it ended. It felt like I was walking into yet another "tourist trap". I took some nice photos but that's where it ended. Go visit but keep your expectations low.

Small but interesting.. Well worth the 15 minute walk from the Monastery. Jolly nice café nearby with great speciality salads. Red/green lights on the spiral staircases a novel idea which works. Get your tickets in advance at the Monastery Cloisters and avoid the queue to pay.

Old tower with good views all around but not worth the wait. Deceptive short line kept us at the tower entrance for over 2 hours!! and then the tower was not even worth it. Would have rather spent that time by the river side itself.

Landmark with a view. It's a beautiful monument that epitomizes Portugal golden era. There isn't much to be seen inside but the stunning view. The stairs are so narrow there're turns to go up and down, which makes it a little difficult to access by elder and handicapped people. Arrive before 10:00 to avoid the long lines

A lovely landmark in an outstanding location. We went to the Belem Tower on a bus excursion, but you can easily go alone. It's surrounded by a lovely park area. Some people went inside, but we did not, so I can't say what that was like or whether there was a fee. You definitely shouldn't miss it when you're in Lisbon. It's impressive and the view is a good photography opportunity.

Interesting site. We enjoyed our visit hp here to the tower last month.it was an interesting experience.not that much to see when you are on the inside,more impressive site from the outside.climb to the top for a greatview across the river of lisbon.I wouldnt que for this attraction but of interests.
remember the old tours. It's good to see it & visit it if you can queue . At least seeing it from the outside is pretty nice. WE had to wait as the queue was terrible.But it's worth it coin so....

Beautiful morning activity. My friends and I went early morning to relax here with breakfast and it was lovely before all the tourists hit. The peace and serenity is bliss and the best way to start any day of touring!
Maritime museum. This was a veal experience I had never seen so many ship models it was fascinating. There was a lot a very interesting information

Definitely Worth A Visit. I only got to see the outside of Torre de Belem, but it is a beautiful building right by the water. You can take a nice walk along the Boardwalk in the Belem neighborhood before reaching the Tower.
