Definitely at least worth a visit to check out the outside and to walk through the busy and scenic neighborhood.

worth a visit. We went there on a Sunday and it was surprisingly quiet, not too many people around. It is a nice stroll from Belem center, however make sure to take sun protection. When we went, it was 31 Degrees warm and there is no protection at all from the sun if you walk along the river from Belem center until the landmark. You can easily spent half a day or a day in Belem, visiting the tower, the monastery and the center of Belem to eventually eat some fresh fish and a delicious pastel de nata.

Much to see. We spent almost a day in Belem, starting our tour at the tower, which is interesting from the outside and there is a nice view from the top. In about 10 minutes walking distance is the Monument to the Discoveries, a huge white towering monument shaped like a ship. On the other side of the main road is the Monastery Dos Jeronimos, which is definitely woth visiting. We also went into the botanical garden, a green oasis full of palm trees, a romantic, although a bit run down place.

Nice Landmark. The tower is most scenic from the outside. Once inside, the main courtyard (quite small) offers a good view on tower details, but if the lines are long (if there are any lines at all), climbing it is not worth it. The narrow stairs only allow people to pass in one direction, managed by a system of traffic lights. This adds to the wait whenever you want to change floors

500 years of history - and stunning views. We visited late in the day so no queueing and enjoyed wandering around this lovely fort - which used to be on an island before the surrounding land was reclaimed. There are still echoes of its island past as you approach over the narrow bridge (luckily the only fighting that you have to do nowadays is to get a good position for a picture!).The ornate architecture is a tribute to the glories of Portugal's success as a colonial nation and the power of their King Manuel.There is a useful one-way system to get to the top of the tower - which is worth it for the views.

Queing all the time. Queing all the time - to buy tickets, to go up, to go down. In the end, there is not much to see inside. On the top the view is very nice but not worth 2 hours spent in total. If you go there avoid peak times.

Worth seeing outside, didn't pay to enter. Since we had plans to see the Castelo de Sao Jorge, Palacio de Pena, and Castelo dos Mouros, we opted not to pay to enter the Torre de Belem. In all fairness, I'm not sure it's okay to fully review this attraction. We thoroughly enjoyed seeing the torre from the outside, but were deterred by the line of people going inside and our assumption that it wasn't worth the euros to enter. Instead, we enjoyed its visual presence on the water and went to see the sailors' monument down the seawall and enjoyed a waterfront patio beer in between the sites. It is indeed iconic, but in terms of towers, castles and palaces, the 20 euros we paid to see the two sites in Sintra provided much greater bang for the buck...but again, we didn't enter... so I defer to others if they can provide a better review of why it's worth the entrance.
Massive queues. Took us an hours waiting time. Lesson is to buy ticket elsewhere and jump the queue. Great views but inside very average.

One of the most important Portuguese Monuments. For those who love ancient castles and monuments, Toore de Belém is wonderful, located at the Lisbon side of Tagus River, offers a great view over the entry of the river.
Dont forget to see all the details on the windows and specially the Rino in one of the corners.
Great!

A must if you are in Lissabon. We made the 20 minute train trip out to Belem to visit the Centro Cultural de Belém, in particular the Modern Art section. It was one of the best presented exhibitions of modern art we have seen - well up in the leasgue of Tate Modern etc. The building is itself worth a visit.

Best sight in Lisbon. We had a great visit to the Torre de Belem. It's a pretty castle on the edge of the river. Lovely for a wander around and some great photo opportunities. A little piece of history on the waters edge. Well worth a visit.

Nice tower with a beautiful sight. The tower is a really spot to visit. The ticket wasn't expansive at all (students ticket). If you are just interested in watching the tower's architecture there is no need to buy the ticket to get inside, but the view from the top of it is really nice and relaxing.

Iconic Manueline Fortification.. A combined ticket to Mosteiro Jeronimos & Torre de Belem is €12 per adult.Use your Viva Viagem card ( €6/day) to travel to Cais do Sodre on the Green line and take the 15E tram to Belem.The Torre de Belem is an ornately decorated fortified tower. Note that the spiral staircase from the deck to the top of the tower is so narrow that a traffic light system is in place to control the flow of visitors. This means that a quick trip to the top might take some time!

Interesting architecture. Nice tower overlooking the river. Not much inside though. We had the Lisboa Pass, so it was worth going in. Definitely buy the pass if you are going to see these attractions. You'll save a lot of money.
Beautiful Tower with a river view. Magnificent view of the Tejo river. Enjoy the great breeze at the top. Return at dusk and watch the towers turret turn gold.

Important historical spot, but climbing the tower can be claustrophic. This is a "must-see" in Lisbon and very picturesque. But think twice about climbing up inside the tower. It is narrow and steep, which is why I lowered this from "Very Good" to "Average". Personnel were supposed to be controlling the flow up and down the tower steps, but it was poorly managed so people had to squeeze by each other. This was dangerous.
500 years old, amazing. Again, this is another site worth a day trip to Belem. Like the other sites, lines are long, but it is a really great thing to see.
It's all in the details . A UNESCO world heritage site... Located in the best place in Lisbon... The white stone... The perfect details... Is what makes this place a beautiful place to admire

Top floor not for the Claustrophobe. A fascinating historical landmark not to be missed. The Tower is authentically restored and maintained and there are some interesting historical explanation boards, if you can get to them. We were there in April and it was already crowded, so I imagine it will be less pleasant to visit during the tourist season. But go anyway! The spiral staircase is ingeniously handled (you'll see) but because of the wait, you might be tempted to miss going all the way to the top. Don't give up! By the way, we rode a Tuk-Tuk from Mosteiro do Geronimous and were really glad we did - it's a long way!

Nice place. That tower is a witness of discoveries, and for American / South American people this sounds as amazing. However, keep in mind that this was a fortress, then there weren't too much to see rather than weapons and rocks. Anyway, this is great - the only drawback is the walking line from Jeronimos to Tower, which is the only way to get there. It isn't so close, then be prepared to walk.

famous landmark. beautiful landmark, but too crowded. Tourists everywhere, queueing or taking pic (including me :D). Better go there in the morning to avoid the heat. Really wanted to see this place on the evening but didnt get the chance. But I would certainly say that this place is a must visit :)
Lonely tower. We caught a tram to Belem, absolutely packed. Mainly tourists. Got off and walked to the tower. Low tide gave it a sad look. Plenty of people in the queue. A mini castle.
Nice place. It doesn't take long to visit but it is a very nice site. The views from the top of the tower are very nice. I recommend visiting this site if you are in the Belem area.
Beautiful. It does require you to go a little out of the way to get there but it is totally worth it.The walk from Mosteiro do Geronimos is quite long but enjoyable
Need to go. Great mark of Portugal, if you came to Lisbon you need to check...Near to the river Tejo, great view.Enjoy the sun and view.

Excellent photo site. Place worth visiting, but try to avoid crowd and come early in the day. The tower is more excited from outside, there is nothing much to see inside. But the view from the top is great, so if you like to cue, take your place in line.

Beautiful tower. The tower is located on the Tagus river, therefore the view is great. It is a precious testimony of the wealth and power of the portuguese kingdom. A must to see, but you need to be patient as the place is extremely crowded.

Bad organization. Don't lose to much time visiting the Torre de Belem. It is a nice tower and you should visit it, but leave the 4 first floors for what they are, the 5th, roof top is the only one wothh visiting next to the roof top of the lower part of the building. You can visit the cellar and "ground level" but besides some canons and a gift shop there is nothing to see. Climbing and descending the tower took lots of time due to the waiting time for using the small stairs.

Awesome watch tower. I see why this is so highly rated. It's a lovely little watch tower with great views. It is out of Lisbon city centre but the trams run near to here (although we got off early and enjoyed a lovely scenic walk along the harbour.) Must see.
Pretty and nice virws. I feel like this is a must to see. We stopped here to walk around for a bit. Beautiful views of the river and across. The line to get in was fairly long so we didn't wait.

The emblematic tower of Belem. This tower located along the Tagus river, marks the starting point of the Portuguese maritime discoveries , it is also a precious testimony of the Portuguese art of working the stone and interpret the Gothic style , complementing an architectural ensemble with the neighboring Jeronimos Monastery .
Great place to visit!. Fantastic location- busy , so visit early in the day. Lots of other places to visit nearby! Lots of cafes & tourists stalls on the sea front!

A Little Underwhelmed. So, first off, this might be biased because I didn't tour the tower. The day got away from me and my group, and we didn't actually get out there until it was night time and totally cleared out. We got off at the Belem station and walked a distance in the direction of the tower. Through the trees I could see something lit up all gorgeous near the water and began to tell my group, "Hey, wait up guys, I want to check out this monument!" And then I realized that it was the tower. It was smaller than I thought it would be. Regardless, we walked all this way, so we went up to check it out. The tower is very beautiful, especially at night all lit up against the dark backdrop of the water. The park is quiet and pretty, and as it were, the moon was a massive gold disc rising up just beyond the Jesus tower in the distance, so that was really, really, really cool. We got some great pictures, but none of us were left wishing we got to tour the tower. So, it's nice, but if you have limited time in Lisbon, if you don't make it to this landmark, know you're not missing too much.
Day trip to Belem. Worth a visit- started the day having their famous pastry and coffee. the tower was the most memorable - it is the recognizable symbol of Lisbon and Portugal- climb to the top.

Beautiful but overrated. A very nice fortress guarding the entrance of Lisbon port from the 16th century. However, it is quite small and the corridors to go up and down are really narrow, making the visit less apprciable due to the high number of tourists. I had a Lisbon card so I did not need to pay to enter, but I find the price for this Tower really high (I think that it is a general problem in Lisbon where you have to pay for any simple place you want to visit...).

Worth taking a look at. I'm not sure I'd pay to go inside, but it's an impressive structure, protecting the entrance to Lisbon.If you go on a Sunday, it's free to enter from 10, but this does mean that there are a lot of visitors
Simplistic . No need to enter, its cramped and full of tourists, just admire the view from the outside. It's very busy and highly touristic.

A day in Belem. Well worth a visit for its historical value, but it does get crowded. One of the structures that survived the 1755 earthquake. Getting to the top of the tower was chaos. There is a system of stop/go lights that nobody takes notice of, so we waited probably 30 minutes before it was possible to climb the narrow stairs. The view from the top was OK, nothing great. The historical information and importance of the structure was good.

dont use the train... use a taxi or car..... Well we wanted to go there.. got on the train... stops were 1 km + more walk to the fort and we were already exhausted with the kids... just get a taxi to get u there from the train station. Not far with a car just not walkable with kids. But if u are alone or with a fit partner,u can definitely make it. atleast we saw it twice from the train lol

Good views. Not too much to see inside, but still worth a visit as the views from the top are worth the effort. Not too sure as to value for money as we had our Lisboa cards and entrance is included. The only criticism I have is that the 'traffic light' system they have to control visitors going up and down the spiral staircase can leave you stranded on one of the interim floors waiting for a space to go further up. Not a serious issue, but one to note if you get stuck!

Number 3 on My Lisbon List. My number three Lisbon sight behind the Castle and the Monastery (from which the tower is a short walk). Built on an outcropping of basaltic rocks situated a short distance from the river bank, it has nice views of the river that it was built to protect. As a military fortress, it's kind of neat looking but wasn't very effective. It also served as a dungeon.
Torre de Belém. Wonderful building in wonderful milieu. Lot of tourists and as usually at any touristic spectacles - long wait at the entry. But worth it! :)
I loved it. My girlfriend not so much, but a real boy toy!. It's a bit of a trek but it's hard to be disappointed in a military tower that has all the finesse and grace of a cathedral
Historical beauty.. a must see!. Great learning experience on Portugal and Lisbon history. Exiting museum inside and fantastic views of the harbor area.

Unbelievable. A must to visit.. Had a great day went on the bus to visit Belem. My husband is very interested in its history. The weather was beautiful so that made it even better. It was as you would imagine busy but not overly busy. I expect in July and August it must be heaving. Well worth to visit.
Another beautiful castle. Yet another picturesque castle close to the centre of Lisbon. Take the short train ride from the city centre. A great place to take a riverside walk and enjoy a few sites

Really interesting castle with a lot of history. The visit to Torre de Belem was certainly worthwhile, even although it was quite busy with school groups. I would include this on every visit to Lisbon

Good for Tourists and History Buffs. One of the principal historical sites for a visitor, the Torre gives us a view of the age of exploration. We did a quick walk but would like to warn visitors of possible pick pockets and street vendors who don't take no for an answer.
A must see. An important historical site that takes you back to the Age of Exploration plus great views of Lisbon

Stunning Architecture . We enjoyed the trip to the tower, although the stairclimb to the top is frustrating as on a busy weekend you virtually join a queue to return back down. We bought a combination ticket for the monastery cloisters, left hand queue, & additional access to Torre de Belem. Do it in this order as when the tower is very busy, use the right hand short queue and walk past everyone else queuing.

Patience is a virtue for those stairs!. The tower was a great piece of history to check out and provided some lovely views down the Tagus of the rest of Belem and out into the Atlantic. I would say that navigating the complicated stairs system is the most frustrating part of this monument. There is only one staircase that is meant to have a "down" time and an "up" time. Unfortunately, the person at the bottom (the only staff member) didn't stop people early enough so by the time there was space for people to start descending, the light had already changed back to red. Would be nice to have another staff member at the top of the stairs to help out with this logistical issue.

Great views. The monument itself is a nice place to visit since it is a big part of Lisbon's history. We bought a combo ticket at the San Jeronimo monastery that included the tower. We walked from the monastery to the tower. When we got there the staff closed the tower because there were too many people inside. We waited about 45 minutes before we were let in. In my opinion if you go to the site and read the historical facts on the information boards and take pictures of the tower and adjacent views that is more than enough. Save your money and stay outside.

Great view, complicated logistics . This is a historical monument and a symbol of Lisbon. It is about a 15 min walk from the Monastery of Belém so I would recommend to visit it if you are in the neighbourhood. The views are great and overall I would consider this to be a not-to-miss attraction that is fairly accessible. A small tip is to buy your ticket before hand because the queue at the monument can be long. The best place we found is the museum queue at the Monastery (left most lane). You get a cheaper price if you combine attractions and you can skip the ticket queue when you arrive. One big inconvenience is that to get to the top of the tower, the stair is only large enough to accomodate people going one way. A light system was setup but the concrete result is that a lot of people end up at the top and cannot go down because people keep coming up. We ended up staying at the top for more than 30 minutes until everyone decided to ignore the traffic system and go when the next opportunity came. Overall it was worth it but the experience could have been more organized.

Lovely Atmosphere, Great Pictures. We didn't go inside as the queue was insane for this but it was impressive enough taking lots of photos of it and the surrounding area. It really is a lovely atmosphere around here, beautiful scenery on the river with all the yachts and lots of benches and picnic areas to sit and soak up the surroundings. There are also very informative history boards just outside which give a very comprehensive history of the Torre so we felt like we didn't need to go inside anyway but if it wasn't so packed, we probably would have made the effort to go inside as its lovely looking from the outside, a very iconic building for Lisbon.
Beautiful Manueline architecture . Although we didn't go inside, this monument is definitely worth gazing upon as it is beautiful It's a bit of a walk from Belem center but worth it.

Don't deny yourself the experience!!!. Belem has so much to offer, including the Monastery of Jeronimos, the Museum of Coaches, the Marine Museum, the Discoverers' Monument, the Planetarium and many others. The Monastery itself is an impressive building which is worth visiting if you are spending more than a day in Lisbon, as it is absolutely beautiful. The tower of Belem resembles the monastery in terms of architecture and design, but it can be very windy at the top of the tower (especially outside the summer months.)Another "must" stop in Belem is the Pasteis de Belem (opened in 1837) which offers incredibly custard pastries for approximately one euro each. Here is a tip. There is usually a long line running outside of the shop, but you can simply bypass this line and find a table (as the long line outside the bakery is for takeout.) The Berardo Collection Museum is also in the Belem area, and offers free admission to see works by Dali, Picasso, Duchamp, and Warhol. How often to you get to see works by Picasso for free?Belem is easy to reach via the train service from Cais do Sodré, or by tram 15 from Praça da Figueira.

Impressive. You can easily ride the train to Belém, it's only a short ride and the ticket is affordable. Belém's architecture is impressive and stunningly beautiful, but I'd definitely recommend to take a tour since there's a lot of information about the different buildings in Belém you shouldn't miss. And definitely give those Pastéis de Belém a shot!

great pictures. can take great pictures of this iconic building, did not go inside as lacking time to do so, but the pictures were amazing, and just walking to this from the station, seeing the monastery and other iconic building on the way definitely made this worthwhile!

Iconic. A remarkable historic building with superb signage on surrounding billboards telling its fascinating history. Close by is a very moving war memorial and, not too far away, an outstanding fish restaurant.
If you have space it's a good place to be to soak up the atmosphere of part of this interesting city. .

Long queues and not worth the bother. Long queues as steep narrow steps means you have to take turns in small groups going up and down the stairs. Views nice at the top but due to amount of people had to queue to come straight down again. Instead visit Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries) a short walk down the road for much better views and much less crowded.

Very nice promenade close to Lisbon. Only 10 min away from Lisbon from the train station, this small city offers gastronomy,gardens a brand new cultural centre to visit. Street animations are an addtional atraction.

Must-do when visiting Lisbon. Great piece of architecture and history. Nice views towards the city and the river. Buy your tickets in advance and avoid the lines! Or buy a combi-ticket with the monastery and save some money!

Great for pictures. I visited in the evening, so it was already closed, but still, it's a nice place to take pictures. The Torre is beautiful and when surrounded by the river from one side and park from the other, it's a really romantic place.

Interesting(ish). We stopped here on a beautiful sunny day which helped. It doesn't take long to see the tower from several sides and while interesting is just sort of 'there'. We were on a stop with a group so limited time and we didn't go inside and not ever sure if you can go inside. If you are in the are worth looking at but not worth taking a detour for.

Pasteis de Belém. You can get to Belém from Cais do Sodre train station by tram no. 15. It can be full but you can see the sea coast. There are several sights worths visiting - the Belém tower with nicely decorated battlements, Monument to the Discoveries and mainly Pasteis de Belém which started in 1837 and serves delicious "pasteis".

Very, Very Long Line If You Don't Have a Ticket Already!!!. We had the Lisbon Card and went to the Torre de Belem after seeing the awesome monastary. There was a very, very long line. Since we had the Lisbon Card we decided to go on the small line for those with tickets - mistake! The ticket office sent us back to the end of the very long line. It barely moved and we finally gave up and went to the Monument of Disovery instead. It was easy to get in and the view was great - probable as good, if not better, than the Torre de Belem. You can also see the beautiful fountain from the Discovery Monument. Of couse the Torre of Belem had better architecture on the outside.

Romantic, amazing view. An ancient watchtower located right on the water. The view from the top is amazing.The stairs are steep, so the visit is not recommended for old people or very young children. We spent half a day in Belem (we also visited Mosteiro dos Jeronimos).The walk from the monastery to the tower is very romantic.You can buy a combined ticket to both attractions for 12 Euro (6 Euro for students).The only drawback is that there is no metro station nearby (we used the bus).
Must see. You must see Belem..... The Belem castle is magical next to the sea also if you go to the centre of Belem you could go to the famous Pasteis de Belem and eat pasteis de nata enjoy!

Romantic. We have seen pictures of Belem but could not believe how big it really is. We stayed out of the tower and enjoyed it from the outside; spectavular view and a possibility to imagine the past.. The park on the way is also enormous and worth observing.
average. I was not impressed by the monument and the view. It is not a place where to be. it is just touristic.

A little piece of Lisbon history. I like to visit historical buildings so this suited me. Climb to the top to have full views over the river and out to sea. The stairs are very narrow and there is a sort of traffic light system so only one way traffic at a time. Only have to wait a couple of minutes but then you get those that jump the lights and cause a bit of a ruck with others who wait patiently.. Lol..read up on its history before visiting to get full enjoyment. Then pop over the road to Pasteis de Belem for their lovely home baked custard tart!

Iconic. The Torrre is pretty much the go to image in any travel guide for Lisbon. It falls into the must see category. There is a line to get in on the weekends. The line has no shade and is very hot. Inside the views are outstanding but be aware that the stairs are insanely narrow, hard to navigate and will result in close encounters with people you don't know very well.

Belem - a stunning enclave. Belem, with the Torre, Monastery, Discovery Monument, riverside walks and gardens is a must, shame about the Starbucks.A place to relax, admire and indulge - and if you're luck enough between now and August you can visit the Sebastio Salgado exhibition.

Nice to see. The whole Belen area is beautiful and this tower represents its symbol.this place holds a lot of story and it is nice too see mainly during the afternoon to enjoy the sun down. Nice place to see but not spectacular!

Beautiful building. We opted to buy a ticket that included this when we were at the Monastery, which meant that we avoided the long line. The outside view of the lovely architecture is the very best part of the visit although the inside is somewhat interesting. We did go to the very top but then immediately lined up for the long wait to go down, since there is only one stairway. Hindsight...don't bother going to the very top as the view is not much better than the level below and you will wait a long time. I would NOT bring children up here as the stairwell is narrow with shallow, steep steps. The walk to and around the tower is lovely to enjoy on a nice day.

Not just the tower...... Belem is a good day out. Various sights, museums etc, a good walk along the front, and of course the pastries. Don't take the tram..... Jam packed, takes about 40 minutes, stops about a dozen times, and you'll be forever worrying about pickpockets of you believe all the signs.Go to Cais do Sodre on the Metro and switch to the train. They come every 20 minutes, it's three stops, 10 minutes and you're sat in comfort. By far the better option.Do it on a Lisboa card and the sights and the transport are all included. Except the pastries of course.

Beautiful fortress structure in the river. Read about the tower in a guide book and ventured out from central Lisbon to abeles for the day. Beautiful structure. You can imagine it used to protect the city, but for launching the brave explorer men on their quests for new lands.

The effort is not worth the 6E. We didn't feel this attraction was worth the time and WORK it required to climb a narrow staircase of two directions of people climbing and descending. Although they attempt to limit the number of people in the tower to 150 and to time people ascending and descending the narrow circular stairs, it only works if there is someone at the top also controlling traffic. The people we had the unfortunate experience of being in the tower with did not respect the red/green lights and therefore ended up with a dangerous amount of people in the circular stairs!! The tower views are mediocre and not work the effort and danger involved

Beautiful old tower. Very Nice and old. Be aware that you should climb as there is no elevator.
Nice view. À park around and more to see in the neighbourhood. Also good restaurants near the tower.

While contemplating.... Went just to look at the tour and find out what secret and charm it hides within. Walking by the ocean side you just have the feelong of taking part in a historical movie production. Imagining all the wars where defense of armies took place from behinh the walls of this tour... Amazing experience
Good Photo Opp. I stopped by on a Sunday so the Torre was closed but if you are into photography, you can have some good photos if creative.
Bigger than it looks. Well worth a visit - superb views. It's a good idea to get a combined ticket for here and Monasterio de Jeronimos to avoid having to queue at one of them.
Beautiful monument. Historical place near the river Tejo. Built in 1514 to defend Lisboa against the enemy, Torre de Belem remains a landmark of Discoveries!

Just OK. Recommend you go up in one of the two towers to get a view of the city --- this one would be our preference. When you are at the top look up the hill at the small white church... this is where the explorers would pray before walking down the hill and getting in their ship to explore. This tower is ok overall ... a few cannons and various levels to look out windows or through the fortifications but really nothing else to see within the tower. The spiral staircase to get up the tower is one way ... and it alternates direction every few minutes. We were stuck at the top for 20 minutes or so before our turn to go down. No strollers.
Beautiful place and fantastic surroundings. I had a very good time in this place, it's a wonderful monuments and the ocean is amazing, a little bit annoyed by the people who sell things in the street

Too many people. Belem seems to be where the cruise ships take all (and I mean all) their passengers. Too many people arriving at the same place at the same time. It's not that big, is now right next to the shore and is not as great as it should be, looks interesting though.I can imagine the conversation - " we really needs another gun emplacent", " I totally agree but I think another balcony would look nice, especially one with all that nice stonework you do". "It's a fortress, gun embrasure". "Balcony". "Gun". "Balcony". "You're paying, balcony, but it will cost you".
Pleasant day out. Pay to go to the top of the tower for excellent views - the area is lovely and there are plenty of reasonably priced and good restaurants nearby.

beautiful but long queue to get in. The tower itself is nice to see from outside. very interesting how it is placed. however, the queue to get in is huge. I had a ticket bought beforehand, and i still had to wait in the queue because they do not allow more than 150 people at the time in the tower. I waited for about an hour. Once inside, the queue continues. If you want to go to level 1, you have to wait...to go to level 2, another queue...and so on. overall took me almost 3 hours to visit this, out of which most time i spent waiting in queues. The view from top is nice, but sort of fades once you are tired and frustrated from all that waiting.

Nice stroll by the River Tagus. So convenient taking tram #15 to Belem, had the famous Portuguese egg tart @Pasteis de Belem though had to line up. Strolled by Jerónimos Monastery, Praça Império, Monument to the Discoveries, Torre de Belem... so relaxing, only thing I didn't like was the very ugly cement factories or oil refineries on the other side of the river!

Best view from outside, long queue to get in. The view from the outside is great and worth seeing. The frustrating part is queueing to get in, we waited just over an hour in the end - even the tide came in we waited for so long! There's not too much to see inside either, and even more annoying was having to wait/queue inside too, both going up and down to the next levels.Perhaps we hit a partiucularly busy time but I would suggest this visit is planned for a quiet time. Other attactions nearby can also offer similar or better views of the surroundings.

Must see in Lisboa !. I think this is must see place in Lisbon but I don't think its worth to go inside.Its a stunning piece of work with detailed and precision decorations on the walls and back grounds the river Tajo.. and the vas co de gama bridge !!! Its a great picture on a clear day with a blue sky !Its a lovely walk along the river to end your perfect day in lisbon !!!

Lovely tower. It is so beautiful and also offers a great view of the city if you go up there, especially of the 25th of April Bridge. I did't pay anything, but I am not sure if it was a exceptional day.
Not worth climbing. In my opinion is enough to see the tower from outside. Long line ups, narrow spinal stairs. View from Monument of Discoveries just as good.

Enjoy the views and history. There are very few artifacts in the Tower, so go for the views and the age of this structure. It is quite interesting to consider its past use in military strategy and prison, and we enjoy history so it was worth the few euros and the wait to experience. Be sure to go early in the morning or just before closing. Last entry I believe is 5 pm and closed Mondays.
Nice views on the outside. Beautiful castle providing beautiful views on the outside. You can take good pictures from the beach and also take advantage of it on a sunny day.

Disappointing.. The long line ups for this ancient fortification would suggest that there is something to see there. With the wonderful other sights to see in Lisbon and Sintra, this tower is not worth the wait. You can walk up a spiral stair to the observation deck at the top, but this is really not a very unique experience. I would not visit this attraction again. Spend your time instead at the Monastery and museum nearby.

Very cool. The tower is definitely worth your time to go inside and look around, and even climb up to the top for the views. The architectural style is lovely, and it's fun to imagine at time when the tower was in the middle of the river.

Cool tower, nice views, but not a lot inside. A nifty stone tower that has stood for centuries overlooking the ocean. The tower is one of those places that can transport you back to what it must've been like hundreds of years ago as you stand at the ramparts, imagining what the view would've been like in the 1500s. And the view from the tower is quite nice, giving you a wide vista of the surrounding area.On the downside, the tower itself is largely empty on the inside and can take a bit of time to climb due to crowds; the stairwells are single file, so they use a traffic light system to indicate when you can go up or down. You can get away without going all the way up since, as previously mentioned, there's very little inside and you can get perfectly good views on the lower levels.Keep in mind that the tower has been swallowed up by the city and sits just south of a busy road. There's no real neighborhood around it and it feels cut off and isolated. You'll need to use the train to get out to it from the city, but you can walk to the San Jeronimos Monastery from it.I'd give it a 3.5/5 if I could.

500 years young. The Torre de Belem is situated on the bank of the river in a lovely area. There are spectacular views of the Vasco da Gama bridge etc from the top. There is only one narrow stairway inside & a traffic light system is in place. It is well worth the wait in the queue but if can get your hands on the Lisboa card you can get straight in.
Little beauty. For me it is a symbol of Lisbon. If you go to her in time, you will not have to queue for entry(10 o´clock). It's small, quickly passed, athough worth it.
Nice sight. Kind of "must go" while you are in Lisbon. The architecture and location are really nice and make it kind of "magic" atmosphere.

Queues and stairs, great views. €6 (adult). We took the 15 tram to Belem, use a metro card - touch machine when get on tram - if pay on tram twice the price and need coins. There was quite a queue for the tower even in this quiet season, we didn't get prepaid tickets. There was also a queue to get up the tower. The spiral staircase is v narrow, steep and has a red / green light system to go up and down. On balance we thought the elevator up the monument was better than this. The tower is amazing, but the view from the outside is pretty good! The tram back was super crowded- about 1800.

Good but busy. The tower offers some great views of the river / sea and is situated near the monastery, good restaurants and various other tourist must do's, therefore you can base yourself in this area for the day. I would recommend pre purchasing tickets for entry to the tower as the queues can be bad and you can queue nearly as long as it would take you to walk round the tower

Interesting defensive fortification; buy a combo ticket!!. If you're doing Belem in a day, my best advice would be to buy a combination ticket with the Tower and the Monastery; saves you a LONG wait on line. The tower itself has some information about its history, and has pretty great views of both the city and the sea. Definitely head underground to check out the cells (crouch if you're tall).

Relaxing time, worth going. If you are not in a hurry you can find a parking in vicinity and spend a couple if hours near the tower, in the tower and in the nearby museum of weapons. Be prepare to stand in line to get on top of the tower.
overrated. There are so many nice attractions in Belem that the Tower itself looks average, far away and less interesting.
Do go in!. You an take pictures outside the tower, inside the tower adn at the top of the tower!Lines are so-so but it is worth the wait. Food and water is sold by vendors outside

Iconic Symbol of Explorers. The tower was the last landmark explorers saw as they sailed out of Lisbon to "discover" unknown parts of the world. The small fortification guarding Lisbon is a beauty of stonework with Moorish details. Well worth a visit.

Nice place to visit. if you're in Lisbon it's worth getting the tram or bus to Belem and taking in the tower. It's a basically a tower on the edge of the river that looks great in pictures, the monastery nearby and the cultural centre are also worth a visit.

Old defence tower, Nice location. The location of the tower is great, on the border. View to several directions really nice. The inside of the tower is average. Good area to have à break, bedause there is kuch to see.

A Tower with a View. The Torre de Belem used to control the approaches to Lisbon from the Atlantic Ocean; it boasted several cannon and a prison. Nowadays, located considerably nearer the shore following land reclamation, this is not as evident as it must have been in its heyday.The Tower has a maximum capacity, so you will invariably have to wait in a queue until the previous batch of tourists departs; however, the architecture is decorative and the views stunning. These probably justify a visit alone. It can be cramped inside, and the basement prison is low for anyone who is not accustomed to limbo dancing, but I find the building and its location very attractive.Combine a visit here with one to the nearby Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and to the Padrao dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries), then relax at the nearby Botanic Gardens, eat a famed Pasteis de Belem and stroll along the river. Belem deserves to be visited and provides numerous links to Portugal's proud heritage of seafarers, explorers and spice traders.

Don't go on a weekend.. This site is very beautiful with amazing views, but it was incredibly frustrating. We visited on a Sunday afternoon and were happy to wait in the queue, but we ended up spending most of our time in the tower waiting. I was very frustrated to find that when I got to the top, I could barely move around since it was full of people waiting to descend the staircase. I think the number of people inside at one time needs to be lower than what it currently is. The surrounding area and parks are well worth the visit though!

If you're in Lisbon.... It's a very beautiful building and well worth visiting BUT everyone else in Lisbon thinks the same so the queues were pretty big. Slightly cheating by reviewing this on TripAdvisor as we didn't actually go in but just looked around the outside.Well worth going to see though...a beautiful building

Well worth a visit. Visited Torre de Belem in March and found it interesting and would recommend paying a visit. Was used as a fortress and starting point for navigators. Also has superb views of the river Tagus.
Mini castle packed with turists. Small fortesse or castle built some 500 years ago, but fully restored. Nice to see, but it is a bit crowded, naturally as in all nice sites. Recommened.

Gorgeous Belem Tower on the River Tejo. Beautiful views, cool history. Lines can be long as this is probably the signature stop in Lisbon. Get there early. Take your time to explore all of the levels of the tower. Before you go in or after you leave, take the time to just sit outside the tower and take in the many sights and sounds. Enjoy an ice cream from one of the many vendors or pop open an orange Sumol soft drink.
Beautiful. Very beautiful tower. A must-see when visiting Lissabon. Belém is worth visiting when you're in Lisbon.
Impressive historical site to visit!. We went there on a windy day and the tower still looked spectacular! Definitely go climb up the tower and see the city of Lisbon from the top!

Spectactular Fortress on the river. Beautiful tower like fortress sitting just off the shore in the river. It would have been a prime spot to protect the water approach to Lisbon. Well worth the train trip to see.

Saw from the outside but didn't climb or tour he inside. It was our last day in Portugal after visiting a number of historic cities. While I am sure the admission price was worth it and the views and artifacts inside were wonderful, we decided we had seen and climbed enough similar structures. The Tower is quite an edifice to see and it provides for a pleasent stroll between it and the Explorers Monument

It´s the point of Vasco da Gama's voyage of discovery. Torre de São Vicente is undoubtedly Lisbon's most iconic landmark. On top of the upper floor is terrace, which offers views over Belém, the bridge of April 25th on the Tagus river where fishermen try their luck. In 1983, it was placed on the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites, together with the Monastery of the Hieronymites.Expect a wait of 45 min or more.

The Tower of Vincent - 17 Canon Niches - and originally built on an Island. Commenced in 1516 with the aim of protecting the City of Lisbon. If you look at the Google Wikipedia there is an excellent painting of the 1831 'Battle of the Tagus" with several French ships firing upon the Belem Tower.The 4 storey building contains a circular stair case, dungeons, a Custom House, a fireplace for the 2nd and 3rd floors, and a Chapel on the 4th. There is a statue too of the 'Virgin of Safe Homecoming' In 1998 Belem underwent a substantial restoration - and now is one of the Seven Wonders of Portugal.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.
A MASTERPIECE OF ARCHITECTURE. One of the most beautiful tower i' ve ever seen!Nice view from to top, and a little scary the downstairs dungeon. One of the Portugal trademarks.
Great place to visit in summers. It is an interesting place to visit with children you will find lot of interesting things like Big milk ice cream, Mc donolds joy rides of boats etc

Long queues but well worth a visit. Beautiful castle on the river bank, originally built as a fortress it's a tower like no other. The solid structure is built to last and is very interesting if you like history, naval history or are just curious. Be aware that they only let 150 people in at one time so would be worth pre-paying for a ticket. We waited nearly an hour I'm total to firstly get in and then to be able to climb to the top. Due to the small narrow staircase they have a one way system to go up and down the stairs, but when you get to the top, the views are simply beautiful. Well worth a visit and tickets are only 6 euros.

Great on the outside!. Got there midday on a Tuesday and the queue stretched all the way to the start of the bridge. It was a hot sunny day and when 40 minutes later we had hardly moved we decided to give up. Things were not helped by the fact that people who already had multiple venue tickets kept walking past us bypassing the queue. Judging from the guide book, the inside is interesting and worth a vista, which is why we were there, but not worth 2 hours in a queue. So get there early or get a multiple venue ticket in advance!
A quaint maritime castle. A great little castle stronghold which our daughter loved exploring, it is not to big so she did not get bored, great views.

Small tower. There was a Belem tour but all the tours were expensive so we hopped on and off buses and trams. It didn't look very interesting from the bus so we didn't get off. It seemed small in size as well. Maybe others might have found something there to interest them.

Buy a joint ticket with the monastery to jump the queue.. We had purchased a joint ticket, so after seeing the monastery we were able to walk to the front of the very long queue and get immediate entry. The tour has very narrow winding staircases, but they operate a very good electronic control system so you only climb when the stairs are free. The views from the top are fantastic.
Terrible experience. You don't need to visit the tower inside. It's enough to watch it from the outside. The system to go climb up and down does't work. I'm sorry, my english is bad.

Must see. Belem it's a must see also because it's lisbon most famous monument.
I thought it was closer to the city center so take your time to visit it.
we just saw it from outside

Beautiful. The tower is amazing , if you go upstairs you can have a beautiful view from Lisbon.
Go and visit this marvellous place.

beautiful landmark along the river shore. Beautiful landmark and a must see in Lisbon. You should link it with other places to see around the area, such as the Jerónimos Monastery, the famous Pastéis de Belém pastry shop and Belém Palace. Here is a site with more details, and if the link works, you should be able to buy the tickets online and thus avoid the queue. www.torrebelem.pt/en/index.php

a lovely Tower. In a lovely setting by the sea, in Lisbon, an old beautifully structured edifice both a decorative and inspiring piece of architecture from the glory days in Portugal's history. Lovely restaurants in the area, to have lunch after a walk along the front.

Buy your ticket for monastery here too and enjoy the stairs.. If you visit the tower before the monastery then buy your entrance ticket to both here as the queue may be shorter. We did the opposite and spent a good hour waiting in line in the sun at the monastery when we could have queued here for just moments earlier in the day. A lesson learnt. However, the tower was well worth visiting as the views are wonderful and the traffic light system on the narrow stairs hilarious. My wife was a bit slow coming down and the 'Master of the Stairs' wanted her to go back up as she was travelling against the lights. When you hear the beeping, hurry up, or you will face oncoming traffic and his wrath ! It is of course a terrific idea and should be used everywhere there is a narrow staircase.
Classic beauty. This is just a short stop, but one not to miss if you are going to the nearby monastery and church. Great photo opportunity.

A must see site. A great site to view.The tower served two purposes, namely the entrance point to the city of Lisbon and fortress to defend the river.Go there in the morning when its quiet and before all the buses arrive.The panoramic view is fantastic.
Fun place with historical views. Lot of fun with some great views. Worth while as part of belem in a day. However check out the monastery first.
Stunning From the Outside!. We only viewed it from the outside, the lines were too long to get in, but it's beautiful! We spent our time walking over to the Discovery monument instead.

Nice looking tower. Beautiful tower and it looks like a castle with a moat, it's too bad we came at a time when it was closed so we couldn't go in anymore. However, there's lots to see around the area. It's really off on its own in Lisbon so make sure your hop-on-hop-off tour bus comes by often. The Pasteis de Belem is nearby for some yummy egg custards, the lines may be long but it's worth it! Just make sure to bring it back to eat it and picnic by this Tower, because the river is right there and it's just really peaceful.

Very Interesting. Great old tower that used to be built on rocks in the river until the earthquake in 1700s it's well worth a look not much to see inside so save your money and just view from outside well worth a visit
A must visit. Wonderful old tower in Belem - which is generally worth a visit too. You can explore the Tower and get excellent views - go early before it gets too busy.

It depends on your time. As others say visit it, however paying to entry is not worth it. Go in the first Sunday of the month as entrance if free. Avoid also the busy months of summer, the queue can be long, and the confusion inside even worse. If you visit it in the summer, bring water with you, you will need it. You have got also timed times to go between the floors, going up is not entirely recommended to people with limited capabilities of moving. The view from the up is nice, however going up is not for everybody. Nonetheless, it is a good spot so stroll around, and it is definitively recommended to take time to roam around, have a look from outside, and rest near the river.

New World bound ships once sailed past here. The river upon which New World bound ships once sailed past here. I believe Columbus among others. You can walk all over the structure and sit where watchmen once sat looking out the window for ships hundreds of years ago. Even has a little dungeon. Food is nearby. Bathrooms are difficult.

Custard Tarts!. Take a trip here from the centre of Lisbon. Only 20 minutes on the trolley tram or a few minutes on the train. A place of History wrapped with the modern. Spend a couple if hours seeing the Monastery then cross the road to the beautiful gardens where you can sit and watch the world go by.A visit to Belem is not complete without visiting the world famous custard tart shop! From the outside, this shop looks like any regular shop but when you enter, walk through to the rear of the shop and watch the custard tarts being made. Afterwards sit and enjoy a pie with a cup of the delicious hot chocolate at one of the many tables. This place gets very very busy so be prepared to wait. But it's well worth it!!

not recommended to go inside. we bought a combination ticket for the masteiro dos jeronimos and the tower of belem but it is not worth it to pay to go inside. It is nice to see from the outside but since there is only one stair to go up and down, it is a complicated system to go up and down and you need to wait for a long time when it is your turn. you can also only go one level at a time up or down. since it consists of 5 levels to go all the way up, you give up in the middle:-) because actually the only nice thing about the tower is the fact you have a nice view on the river and the bridge, there is no musea or anything inside. So not recommended.

An interesting visit. I am pretty sure that Torre de Belem will be on everyone's lists of places to see in Lisbon. I don't want to put you off either. But for me I was just a bit underwhelmed. It is worth going to see for its age alone, built around 1520. It is right that it is called a gem because the external walls are certainly very well carved (or should that be chiselled?). The inside I found pretty austere if I am honest. Free with the excellent Lisboa Card.
Nice sightseeing. Nice to take a tourist bus (we took the yellow bus blue line) double decker here and just walk along the waterfront.

Long wait, nice but lots of other things to do. Quite a long wait and to be honest the best thing about it is the view from the outside. The ground floor is a number of old cannons, the basement is an old jail, the subsequent floors vary from mildly interesting (if you think a rhinos head made from stone will make your day) to dull. The best thing is the number of people employed in the place to make sure that the traffic light system in the stairs is observed - funny thing is that it isn't, despite (literally) 4 guys at the bottom only allowing you access on a green light - on all the other floors its stairwell anarchy and every man for himself. There are lots of other great things to see in Lisbon and if time is limited go and see it, take some photos and skip the interior. Sorry to be so unsupportive but really you'll wait for an hour and wonder why you bothered. This of course is my own opinion and probably varies greatly with other views, but life's a balance!
Wonderful. You will want to see this. Wear shoes that can get wet as the tide was rather high on the day I visited.

Wonderful. Such a beautiful place. Lots of people visiting on the day we went. Clear blue skies set off the whole structure beautifully. Take some time to absorb it like so many have done through the years. Wow

Best view of Tajo River. This is a Tower located at the entrance of Belem (by the river). It as used to defend the city. Once you get there be ready to go up 92 steps in a very narrow stair. You go up or down when you have the green light.From Lisbon take the trolley 15E. (The E is for Electric) (Cost is 2.85 euros each way or it is cover by the Viagem card (5 euros per day)

The Portuguese Discoveries. It is really one of the most important moment os Portuguese History - the Discoveries. Built by order of king D. Manuel, the first, this is the guard of river Tagus and its architecture must have a visit. Discover the "Manuelino" style, the Portuguese splendor of Renaissance.

Torre de Belem. We took the tram out to Belem from Rosia Square using the 24 hour ticket we purchased from the Metro. For 6 Euro we could travel by bus, tram or train for 24 hours which was very economical. We had a whistlestop tour around Belem and there was so much to see. We did not have time to actually go into the tower but certainly worth another visit. The sculptures on the outside of the tower are fantastic. We also went to the famous Pasteis de Belem to experience eating one of their fantastic Pastel De Nata pastries. We were spoilt for choice. Belem well worth a visit.
Decorative defence. this decorative former defensive gateway to Lisbon is located next to a military museum and modern war memorial, so a touching reminder of the past and effects of conflict today.

Very good when combined with Jeronimos and cakes from Pastéis de Belém. Out of the three main tourist attractions in Lisbon; Jeronimos monastery, George's Castle and Belem Tower we felt Jeronimos was the most interesting. Belem Tower would come in second and has an impressive architecture.When combining Belem Tower with Jeronimos monastery and cakes from Pastéis de Belém is a great day trip. All are in walking distance from each other (15 min). We would recommend this as the first thing to do in Lisbon.
scenic view. In a magnificent position, breathtaking views. Tower in such good condition. Liked tht there was there was little food and drinks places around too.

Crowded, but well managed. This is a 'must see' site, although not nearly as impressive as it mush have been when the river surrounded it. The queues looked really long when we arrived, but the through flow was well managed, including the narrow one way staircases, and we didn't have to wait that long.
Its ok. This place is ok and it has a great view. There is a tiket combo for this and monastery of san antony

Pasteis and tourism :). Going to Belem is unforgettable ... Just take the tarmway... First you will appreciate the views ( Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, Padrao dos Descobrimmentos and Torre de Belem) ... but you also must taste the "Pasteis de Belem" at the "blue pastry" ;) Easy to find ;)

Best attraction in Lisboa. Belem tower is nicely preserved ,kind of a fort.With an impressive history.The views are scenic from every level.althoug h I liked the view from the base floor.
Got a nice red diary for my daughter from the shop.The bridge and the wind sail boats in the river are a beautiful ,breathtaking sight.

Not worth the entrance fee. The charm of the Torre de Belem can easily be appreciated from the outside; little extra can be gained from paying the six euro entrance fee.
The tower is situated a long distance from the centre and is very poorly served by public transport.

Marvelous!. Everything in the Belem area is a must see. The tower is exemplary of the Manueline style which I personally love and adore. The fact that it's almost 500 years old gives you a sneak peek of how amazing it was in the Age of Discoveries!

Beautiful. Not to be missed, if visiting Lisbon. Beautiful location on the sea front and well worth going up on the inside. It is also quite close to The Explorers Monument, which is also quite impressive. The view of the "Golden Gate Bridge" is not bad either.
Beautiful Tower. Symbol of Lisbon...Stunningly beautiful tower on the shores of theTagus river...misty with 25 de April bridge in the background...picture perfect!

It was okay, but I was expecting more.. I love the outside of this little tower. We went in, and the architecture of the building is amazing. No artifacts other than the little canons. You can take the circular stairs to the top.

Breathtaking view of fine stonework. The fortress is situated in the Lisbon harbor giving a stunning look against the blue water and the blue sky. The stonework is superb... so beautiful. It sure is one of the great tourist attraction; hence quite a crow is expected. Despite the huge amount of tourists, the site is worth visiting.
amazing arhitecture. the tower is in Belem and has nice architecture....fee is 6 euros, and you can buy together with ticket at Monastery of Jeronimos which also is fabulous...
A Great Monument. This tower is quite impressive, especially the carvings on the side. Definitely worth a visit so don't miss it.

Lovely tower that is worth seeing. Belém Tower is a Manuelian Gothic fortress tower in Lisbon. The tower is listed at the beginning of the 1500s to commemorate Vasco da Gama and the patron saint São Vicente

A Quite Beautiful Area. The Belem area is quite beautiful with its large parks and activities. The Torre de Belem is a must see and I think the best time is late in the afternoon when you catch the sun as it begins to set. This makes for beautiful views and photos!

gorgeous but rude staff. I visited the tower with some friends and as we waited for our turn the staff was rude to other visitors as they accidentally went wrong way in the hall. That killed the mood in the line and even though the tower itself was nice to see, we felt like stranges in someone's home after that. No smiles or saying hi. Just annoyed looks for everyone coming in,

Iconic monument. It is a beautiful monument. There's not much to see inside and the steps are narrow and many but the architecture is worth the climb. This is a "Lisbon classic" (although technically it is located in Belém).

Belem. Beautiful, five centuries old tower on the Tagus river bank you must see when you visit Lisbon. I enjoyed watching the river on a sunny spring morning, Cristo Rei and 25th de Abril bridge in the distance, seagulls in the water. Really nice and calming place.

A must see. Very much worth a visit while you are in Portugal. People need to learn to follow the 'traffic lights' on the narrow, one way staircases though! We had an incident with a bunch of people who were going up while you were supposed to go down and they almost threw me off!

Timeless. Well worth a trip. Take the 15 tram from city centre. Go back in time in the Tower. Before heading back to the city, grab som famous pastries from Pastiches de Belem coffee shop across the road from the tram stop.
Worth a trip. We reached it taking a tram and then had to walk for a while, but I'm happy we did it. Once we got there, we were glad to visit it.
Region of Belem. Visit on a sunny Sunday with a lot of tourists as well as locals, a very nice place to visit and for a leisurely stroll.
Living history. Beautiful historical landmark with amazing details and a great view of Lisbon and of the Tagus river.
Definitely worth a visit, amazing building. on your tour of Lisbon this is a must see building. So much history, amazing for photos and lots of history.

Iconic Lisbon. Very iconic building in Lisbon and would have been the first and last thing sailors saw of Lisbon as they headed out into the Atlantic.Unfortunately we went when it was quite busy and had to negotiate quite a long queue as they can only take 150 people at a time. There is quite an 'interesting' one way up and down system which made the visit a bit protracted. The inside was good and the views are great, but if you have been to another monument in the area that offers great views over Belem and Lisbon, and there's a queue, I would suggest enjoying the outside of this building only.When you buy your ticket, you can by a joint ticket with a reduction for some of the other attractions in Belem (we did for the monastery).

What a cool building. The view from the top was amazing.. My son and I spent a lovely day in Belen and the Torre was one of the highlights. It takes a while to get to the top and down again as they have a traffic flow system in place. It works well though and the views are definitely worth the effort.

A Lisbon classic - it's a must. The Belem Tower is such an iconic symbol of Lisbon that it's a must for any visitor, especially as you can include a trip out to Belem (it's a short train ride or drive from the centre) with seeing the Mosteiro de Jeronimos, the Belem Cultural Centre and the Discoveries Monument. Parking was free and rather easier than we expected even on a Saturday. Access to the Tower itself costs 5 euros but you can admire it for free from the riverside path. Note that if you want to walk to the Discoveries Monument you have to detour on to the road as the riverside path is broken up by a harbour.

Wonderful building - but marred by pushy sellers. Enchanting building, unfortunately it was closed to the public when we visited Sunday 8th March 2015. As usual in Lisbon - we had to avoid the hawkers, in this instance they were young women selling scarfs and men selling the usual fake sunglasses - all of which were rather too pushy for our liking

Nice view over Belem. Nice view when reaching the top. You should do it before the monastry of Jeronimo because you will get a discount with combined tickets. You have to walk quite fast if you want to climb the stairs in one ascension only, fortunately, there are rooms where you can rest a bit.

Castle surrounded by water. Amazing! It is totally worth paying a few Euros to enter this historic site. Next to the magnificent view to the bridge and the open water of the Atlantic you can learn a lot about the fortress before the big earth quake. Walk back to the city, see the museum, the docks and the bridge. It is a bit of a walk but we enjoyed it very much.
Go all the way to the top (if you can ). Beautiful tower with an exceptional viewA bit sporty to go to the top ( very narrow staircase )The entrance is included the monestary ticket

amazing............... Guys try visiting this attraction when the weather is fine,you will appreciate it far more............It has great historical value for the Portuguese and was part of their main armoury/look out when the country was threatened by sea faring marauders. It is in great condition and the sights in and around the tower are spectacular to say the least. Just go and enjoy the visit you will not be disappointed guys!( on a hot sunny day the views both down the estuary and to the Atlantic Ocean are amazing)
Amazing views. It is definitely worth visiting it, the Torre de Belem offer an incredible view on the Tagus River and the 25th of April bridge a must see in Lisbon.
A nice place to visit in Lisbon. Generally in Lisbon there is a cold wind coming from the ocean. So, if you visit Torre de Belem during winter, make sure you have enough cloths on you. :)

Worth visit. It's a must to see in Lisbon and is within walking distance from Padrao dos Descobrimentos and Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. The area is full of tourists and can be crowded even during winter. You will need to pay an entrance fee if wanted to go inside the tower.

riverside views worth visiting. Along the riverside, you can walk to the tower or use public transport whilst admiring the clear blue waters. Entry is free to lisbon cardholders and opening times vary depending on season. Lots of stairs to climb so wear decent footwear as about 5 levels in total up winding staircases.

Follow the signal light to go up and down. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This four storey tower was built in the early 16th century as a defence system for River Tagus. The exterior looks so magnificent. We bought tickets to get inside to take a look. First we climbed the narrow staircase all the way to the top to enjoy the view. Because the staircase is narrow, they use the light to signal people to go up and down. On the second floor, there is a terrace. From there you can have a clear look at the "Monument to the Discoveries ", the River Tagus, and the "April 25th bridge”. You also can have a closer look at the facade that you can’t see on the street. The day that we visited was showering in the morning, so not many people, we didn’t have to spend any time waiting in line. But when we left the tower the line was starting.Happy Travelling!

great photo op. Free with the Lisboa Card, I went in the afternoon so there weren't too many people. Lots of places to take photos (and maybe a few fancy/artistic shots). Since the stairway is narrow, they had an light system to indicate who should go up or down., although I didn't realize what it was at first.

great exterior- nothing inside. if you get in free with your Lisbon card- great, otherwise, think twice re going in as there is not much to see- you can walk up to the 2nd level but other than the small area down below where prisoners were held, and some canons at ground floor level- nothing...great exterior tho- nice building

Lovely day in Belem!. Lovely town! You can take the tram there from Lisbon for the day. The monastery was amazing, but there is also a lovely contemporary art museum in town. Don't forget to stop for a custard pastry while you're in Belem.

Go twice. We walked along from the Discoveries Monument up to the Belem Tower at late evening and got some stunning photos of the tower at dusk and sunset. Spectacular. We visited next day after a visit to the monastery: your ticket covers entry to both sites. Definitely worth a visit and night time was stunning. There are A LOT of stairs going up to the top of the tower so it's not disability friendly but for the able bodied it's worth the climb.

Belem one not to miss. You can visit Belem using the hop on hop off Lisbon city tour it is one not to miss very beautiful and down by the river. You will also go under the April 25 Bridge which is very similar to the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco only bigger and more beautiful.

Outside better than in. A very impressive tower from the outside, with great views from the top and overall worth a visit (buy a combined ticket with the monastery to avoid queueing), but slightly underwhelming inside. It's a bit like a stationary battleship bristling with guns but not much else of historical interest. However I enjoyed climbing up the narrow staircases to the top and there's a beautiful statue of Mary and Jesus I wasn't expecting.

Neat architecture. I like this though the "dungeon" and ground floor are pretty basic. We got the pass for the monastery and the tower so it was straight in for us. The tower is surrounded by water so you have to be careful when entering and exiting as you may get wet.

A real surprise. We were walking along the river edge and came across the torre de Belem. We werent sure whether or not to bother to go in. But we are so pleased we did, it was outstanding. The steps to the top would not suit anyone with walking problems. They have a great system to get people up and down the staircase. The views from the top and the inside of the fort were excellent. Lots to look at with English scripts to explain.

Nice view from the Tower.... The Belem Tower is one of the site under the patronage of the Unesco... Is just 6 km from the Lisbon city center and it's easy accessible by the tram nr. 15. The view of the Tejo River is beautiful... the visits worth the money for the sights and views you can have...

Small and nice on the river side. It was smaller than expected, but well positioned on the river side; easy to get there by Hop On Hop Off buses (there is one line Torre de Belem, only 12 EUR the 24 h pass; otherwise all 4 lines for 25EUR for 48h). next to this it's a museam of defence. very nice sidewalk along the river.

Great drive by sight to see. Just stopped quickly since it was right along the when I was doing a seaside tour of the area-everything in Portugal is amazing. This site is good to stop along the way and see but won't long to visit, just take some pics and enjoy the amazing coast and especially strolling Caicais with the wonderful cobble streets.

Outside is better than inside. The approach along the water is the best part of this visit. The outside is superb. Inside is empty. If you are a pensioner,[pensionista], take your passport for a reduction in the entry charge, but still not worth the charge.

View from the outside. It's a lovely walk along the river to get to the tower and once there the building is magnificent. However due to the size of the tower they restrict the number of visitors which can mean a long wait (and we were sixth in line) you can also suddenly find a group tour jumping ahead of you. If you visit the monastery then get the ticket the includes the tower in the price to save money.There is little to see on the ground floor, the first floor views across the river are attractive though. Getting to the higher levels requires going up a steep narrow spiral staircase - something which I cannot do. The staircase also has a traffic light system to ensure that the flow of people is only going up or down at any one time. My husband however made it to the top to enjoy the views.Personally, I don't think I would take my children as the waiting time would not warrant the view in their eyes.

Beautiful but not worth going inside. What a beautiful building!! From the outside. The inside is ok, but unless you've got the Lisboa card, which let's you go in for free, don't bother. There's little history info and there are a lot of small spaces with very little room for the amount of people they let in. ..... and then there's the 1 way traffic light spiral stairway system!!!! Well that's worth a visit for the amusement factor - if you don't mind getting stuck at the top of the tower for an hour or so (no one pays attention to it and then there's grid lock on the stairs).Saying all that, the building is beautiful and it's hard to believe that it used to be a fort before all the land was reclaimed around it.Pick a nice sunny day if using public transport as it's a fair walk away from train/bus/tram stops.
Beautiful. This is one of the most beautiful monuments i have ever seen. You feel like you traveling in time. It's truly impressive but in my opinion a bit too expensive.
long wait to get in. After waiting in line for more than half an hour with hardly any movement my wife and I gave up. Our host said it looks more impressive from the ourside than the inside anyway

Beautiful Building. A really beautiful building in a lovely setting . Had a Lisbon card so it was free. Busy with visitors and would imagine it is a lot busier in Summer. As the staircases are so narrow and only allow 150 in at one time might not be worth the queuing to see inside. Not a whole lot inside apart from cannons jails , except lovely view from on top. Personally think the best view is from outside the building .

Fascinating from the outside. The tower is a great example of Manueline architecture and a key part of Lisbon's history. The exterior is beautiful and very striking against the background of Belém's harbour.Unfortunately, the interior is pretty dull without much information on the tower's history. There was a queue even in low season on a Wednesday, and then queues inside on every floor. The one-way system didn't work effectively leading to swarms of bad-tempered, confused tourists trying to get out. You'd be better off saving your €6 for more pastéis de nata.

Not worth going inside. There is no information or history about the tower. The steps are steep and narrow and not made to cope with the volume of tourists who are allowed in at once. The cells area down below has a very low ceiling and feels claustrophobic. We got stuck in this area due to the numbers of people. If you are going to see the monastery as well you can buy a joint ticket which means your entry to the tower is only 2 euros and you can go straight in without queuing.
Beautiful. When you see the tower of Belem, you can not imagine that is a military post. Probably, the most beautiful of its kind in the world.
A symbol of a destiny. The live memory of the discoveries saga.. A wonderful masterpiece of The manuelin style. Over the Tagus, side by side the navigators memorial and nearby Jeronimos Monastery.

Expensive and nothing much to see!. We queued a long time for the Torre de Belem and paid 6 euros each. Apart from some nice stonework and fairly good views, there's nothing to see in the tower. There's very little explanation about Lisbon's navy or defences, hardly any actual content (a few little culverins), and nothing to explain how the tower was built, who used it etc. It's nice to look at from the outside but don't waste your money going in (go on the first Sunday of the month in the morning when the entrance is apparently free).
The Torre. Seeing it from the sea it makes it more interesting. Mix with a visit to the Monastery Jeronimo & lunch at the jetty & you have a lovely day plus get the tram back

Remarkable but disappointing. This was not the WOW that I was expecting it to be. We were there on a January weekday and did not have to contend with crowds. We went inside only because we had the Lisboa Card and it was free. From here walk down to the Discoverers Monument before you head back towards the other Belem sights. If coming on foot from the tram, beware that there are only two points where you can cross the highway that separates the waterfront from the rest of Belem.

unexpectedly other wordly. The short train journey to Belem was worth it just to see the tower standing imposingly in the water. It reminded me of something out of game of thrones and was a real delight to visit.

Unique landmark but lack of info. Not very much info provided on the history of the tower but it is a very unique landmark and worth viewing from outside at least. Entrance is covered by the Lisboa card so we went in anyway.

it is a must see!. The place and its sourrounding are amazing.
Visiting Belem tower will help you to understand part of Protugal history.
Ontop of that it is located in a pleasant place with lots tof places to visit!
Go there you will not loos your time.

Interesting Tower. Interesting building from where you can see different sides of Lisbon including the Vasco da Gamma bridge. stairs to the tower are a bit too much so try to attempt them by taking rest in each stage of the tower.

The horror of Belem! Wanted my money back!. Visited on a Sunday afternoon in February. Only 150 visitors are allowed in at a time...so waited 45 minutes, on a windy deck, to get in. The visit was spoiled by the fact that there is no proper control over the flow of people going up a series of narrow, spiral stone steps, which you must ascend to get to the top. They only allow for one way traffic. There is meant to be a one way system to stop people ascendeing and descending at the same time. However due to the volume of people and people taking no notice of/ not understanding the system, there is a log jam of people stuck trying to get both up and down the stairs. It's a health and safety hazard, and the staff need to take responsibility (they looked resigned to the impossibility of the situation), and need to be on all floors to manage the flow of people before an accident happens or a riot breaks out. We gave up trying to get to the very top because it was too dangerous to proceed under those conditions. I asked for my money back .!.didn't get it....I wish I spoke Portugese! A shame! If you do go ...buy your ticket in advance to avoid such a long queue.

Remarkable, but no need to pay.... I recommend not paying to enter. The story of the tower itself is pretty remarkable. The tower itself is well preserved. Not as big as you would think, so not necessary to go in.

You will really feel history here.. This is a must see for its fantastic location. It is ancient, though,and has very steep internal spiral stairs with a traffic light system to allow for better movement between floors. Not for those with walking problems.

very nice. the surrounding area are amazing to walk around and relax. The belém gardens receive a lot of diferente peoples during the weekend. the torre de belém is one of the most important points int he area, and one of the most important monuments in lisbon. If you don't want to get in, walk around the area and apreciate the river.

It's a site alright. The tower is not large and it may not be open to the public ... and it's lovely and you get the sense of proportion and what it was like when the tower was an important landmark... a guide and landmark to Lisbon. Visit it and appreciate the time it was important and how that looks in contrast to today.
a beautiful tower by the river. Been at the sunset ,even if clouds were dark,colours were magic.Magical atmosphera.Entrance is not free.
Worth a visit. Pretty cool to walk around but nothing awe inspiring. I preferred the Padrão dos Descobrimentos over the tower.

Visiting Lisbon.. The “Belem Tower” is located on the left shore of the river “TEJO”, and classified as “World Patrimony” by the UNESCO in 1983, and as one of the seven most wonderful places in Lisbon. Who gets daily allot of touristsThey started the building of the Fortified Tower in the year 1514 and concluded in 1520, and used to protect the place from where the boats left for the India. But with the evolution of the possibilities of attack and defence, the tower lost his function and gradually became to be a custom-house, a lighthouse and telegraphic. And later on it served also s prison for political prisoners. The tower became along the centuries several remodulations.
