The tower is divided in 5 floors from which we have the first floor as Governor room, the second floor as Kings Room, the third floor as Audience Room, the fourth floor is the Chapel and finally the fifth floor is kept as the “Tower ~Terrace”. All together is it one of the Monuments to visit when you are on the shore of the river “Tejo” in Lisbon, it is on walking distance of the Convent of Geronimo and the Pedrão dos Descobrimentos.

Torre de Belem. A great place to visit. I really enjoyed this place. All areas were open to tourists and plenty of information panels. Well worth a visit. It is much larger than it appears at first, so allow about 2 hours.

Amazing. Another amazing piece of architecture saved. You can enter free with the Lisboa card. its worth going to the top for the view theres also a fantastic fountain in the gardens where you get off the tram only gos off on the hour so don't miss it there are two cafes at the monument front the Italian on as nice icecream and crepes not over priced.Worth to visit!
Beautiful restaured building. Beautiful historic building, worth a visit. Not far from other "must visits" such as the monastry of jeronimo. Great views on the river Taag and Bellem.
torre de belem. a site worth visiting, lots of history and a wonderful building. We were on a hop on hop off bus and it is where you change routes.

Iconic but limited. It is one of the must see things in Lisbon, but if you lack time and are not interested in checking of things from your "bucket list", you might want to skip it. However...even if the tower is a bit of "outside" the centre of Lisbon there are several interesting things in the area that together makes this a place you want to visit. The "Monument to the discoveries", the "Museu Do Combatente" and the Jerónimos Monastery are very close by. The best way to get to the tower might be the train from centre of Lisbon (8 min travel and 20 min walk). I had the option to go by car but didn't due to travel forum saying that it was hard to find parking in the area. I found fair enough places so car might be an option. Likewise Tram no 15 takes you to the monastery from which it is only a 10 min walk. I think a visit towards the evening might be best for great photos since you can get photos towards Lisbon rather than towards the harbour without aiming straight into the sun.
Wonderful. A wonderful site of one of the most symbolic sites in Portugal. That was the starting point for the great discoveries of the new world. Breathtaking, moving, not to miss!

Beautiful building and amazing views... Torre de Belem is a must view. Beautiful indeed from outside, but a rather expensive 6 euro ticket for the not so great left inside the building. We had a LISBOA card, so free. Good for takings on the top floor, but very steep and swirl stairs, not for old folks to go up and down, no lifts. 1st floor and top floor were worth the views. 1st floor gives good views of the Padrao dos Descobrimentos and sea-view. Nice and cool breeze, for sunny day.Top floor has a view of the Belem city, of houses in rows going up the mountain. good clicks.Nice dungeon and History you can read. Still not worth if you are FULL price entry. 1st sunday is Free so try that. Better Pics from outside and FREE !!Lots of food opportunities around, though we ate at the NOSOLO Italian Belem, good option.
Historical Place. The overall view from the place was very good but nothing significant from the historic perspective. There are better places in Lisbon to see.

beautiful .... the beauty etc etc is all have been mentioned thats why i will suggest sth personal if you can go right before sundown ... and stay a bit later to enjoy the lights and the area thats takes a beautiful color ... you can walk around and eat sth traditional and than go back to the centre .. i loved the place
It was ok. The tower looks much bigger in pictures than in person. We went the first Sunday of the month so the entrance fee was waived.

Free on first Sunday of each month. We was very excited to see that it was free on the first Sunday of every month... but sadly we didn't take this up because there was a large queue, and it was quite a cloudy murky day so we felt the view couldn't be much better.The building itself is beautiful though. A must see and very easy to get too. Great view along the waterfront over to the bridge and Christ statue.

You Have to Go to Take the Selfie. I assume you can go inside but we had just finished the bike tour and had to take the bikes back a few hundred metres and it hardly seemed worth walking back. But if you go to Lisbon this is one of the photo opportunities you have to take.

Outstanding Experience. The Belem Tower was better than we expected. We knew its exterior appearance but were pleasantly surprised at the interior. It was larger than we expected. Equipped with canon, a dungeon, and stairs to the tower, it was a very complete attraction. The view from the roof is outstanding. It is a must visit if in Belem.

Brilliant visit on a quiet day. We visited in January and there were not many people around. We really enjoyed it but I'm not sure we'd have liked it as much if it was busy. We got plenty of time to look around and pick out the best photo opportunities. Even on a quiet day there was still a big queue for tickets. Luckily we bought a combined ticket at the monastery so we were able to walk straight past the queue and go in. My family seem able to spend hours looking at cannons and the sea and this attraction combines both of them. The Tower itself is not huge so it doesn't take too long to visit

Great site. We really enjoyed going to see the Belem Tower. We got there early just after 10 so we didn't have to line up to view, you will only need to allocate 30-60 minutes within the tower as there isn't too much to see but it is a UNESCO world heritage site and is very unique in it's positioning over the water.

Worth a visit. Belem is approximately 20 mins away from Lisbon center. The tram 15 operates between Belem and center. This place has a historical background. It is well worth a visit. Enjoy your time in Belem.

Site to visit for historical reasons.. The Belem tower is nice but not valued by the surroundings. At the entrance of the Tage river, you can imagine the end of life for the prisoniers that were enjailed here. Nevertheless, the Belem tower is part of the portuguese History

Great views. Built in 1515 this is a great part of Portuguese history, so a must see and do!We walked there from Lisbon which took about 2 hours but was a beautiful walk under the bridge and by the river.Don't forget the custard tarts from the cafe down the road delicious with cinnamon.

Good to see the history. We found this tower easily as it is marked on the tram map inside the tram (make sure you get the correct one I think it was 15E) its close to the monastery as well and you can get a joint ticket to visit both. Lots of spiral stairs which became a little bit hairy when the red/green system they have in place (only 1 set of stairs up and down) failed when too many people tried to get through but overall it was lovely and with stunning views over the sea, to the suspension bridge and the most amazing sculpture along by the port. I would recommend this as a place to visit as its so important to Lisbon's history.

Worth seeing but. You don't need to allow much time to visit 20 mins to 30 mins max, and should be combined with a walk along the riverside. It's a tower of great standing and Portuguese heritage. But it's just a tower so don't expect a days outing. The ladies selling scarves and sunglasses are also annoying. So be prepared to say no a lot.
Nice views. It's a really beautiful place but what i enjoyed the most was the view from the top, the river looks beautiful from it :)

An Amazing Naval Installation. A visit to Belem is a real must if you are visiting Lisbon. The tower is one of the most prominent structures in the area. While here I also recommend you try the hot pastries from the Pasteis de Belem and visit the Monastery and Maritime Museums. They are all worth the time.

A must see. The most emblematic monument in Lisboa, from here the navigators from the past leave lisbon to unknown lands.A must see in Lisbon, really near from the train station (Belém), and also near you've Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, Restelo Stadium with a view that you can't loose, and the traditionals "Pasteis de Belém" that you must taste.

Belem is worth visiting. The tower of Belem is actually standing in Water. In the evening it is bathed in a reddish light, quite beautiful. The cultural center of Belem is a modern building and worth seeing as well.
Worth a visit. The Tower of Belem is worth a visit an has some nice panoramic views. With that said, you only need a few minutes at this site.

Awesome landmark to see! . This tower is a beautiful castle right on the waterfront that is a UNESCO world heritage site. It takes you back to a different time when castles littered the Portuguese coast and provided defense for the empire. It is still in excellent condition and the interesting thing is they only allow 150 people in the tower at a time so be prepared to wait a little bit. I had purchased the Lisboa card at the airport so I had free entry to this (I suggest if you're into museums and the sites get the card, it pays for itself in no time). The walk up to the top was unexpectedly hard but it's not too bad once you get up there. Great views of the April 25th bridge etc. it's a must see in Lisbon.

Cool to see- but really not much.. We bought a packaged ticket so I'm not sure how much it is to go in separate- but it's not that much to see. The view doesn't change much once inside and half the rooms on the way to the top have flat screen TV's (what?) but the structure itself is very cool and I recommend at least going to the strip on Belem to see it.

Must visit. A must visit in Lisbon, a historic monument. Ensure to go on top, it offers some great view of vicinity.Be prepared to wait in queue in case visiting in busy tourist period because it allows maximum 150 people inside at one time.

Beautiful landmark. If you go to Lisbon you have to walk around Mosteiro de São Jerônimo, Monumento dos Descobrimentos and Torre de Belém. It is an wonderful area! We got the Elétrico 15 and dropped off in front of the Mosteiro. The tower of Belem is few minutes away. It was magic to see that piece of art! It is a huge monument that looks like a ship. You can pay to go inside (they couldnt accept cards because the power was off that day), bu we didnt have a chance neither the desire to see it. It is for sure an area you must go if you are in Lisbon!

A tropical Lisbon monument. This monument in the Belem area is worth the visit with on a bayside boulevard with chic modern seafood restaurants. It has great views of the bay, 25 April bridge, and close by to the Descobrimentos monument. Even in January this monument gives off a great tropical feel to Lisbon.I do realize it's important history as well, but I enjoyed most it's atmosphere.

Back in the day...imagine. .. A great area to walk all around the river where you can explore Belem. The tower is ornate and an architectural gem to explore.Go inside and imagine the explorers and History.

Symbol of Lisbon and Portugal. The tower of Belem stands for the seafarers of Portgal and has seen 5 centuries of history going by from the discoverers setting out for trips around the world until the celebration of Portugal joining the EU. The tower has really been in use for the defense of the city and you can see how it worked. We enjoyed a fine winter sunset on the Atlantic and combined the visit with the Monastery of the Jeronimos and the Pasteleria do Belem. The Tram 15 is a good connection to town. Palace of Ajuda and National Museum of Ancient Art are on the way.
500 years of history. One of the most significant buildings in Belem area. It is a worthwhile seeing monument. Students and over 65 pay only half entrance fee. That is great.

Great view of the river !. A single ticket to get into the tower was €6 and you could go to the top of the tower. IT was really nice, and it is a must go place in Lisbon, it is about 20 minutes from Cais de Sodre with the tram.
Must see in Lisbon. It is one of the must see items in Lisbon , not much inside but the exterior and location brilliant , tie in with the monastery

Great photo op. This is a 15 minute walk away from the Monestary. You can get some great photos from here but basically it is just a fort. If you are doing an open top bus tour I would go to the memorial first and then walk around to here. From the tower you can then take the bus to the monestary and if you time it right you will not have to walk far. You should be able to buy a ticket that gives you admission to both.

Breathtaking views !!. I went there around 4:30 in the afternoon for the sunset and that was amazing ... I took so many beutiful picture and I have to say than this place is wonderful !!!! definatly Lisbon is so beutiful even in January ..

Not that much info inside.. At the entrance there is a one in, one out rule due to safety regulations (you cannot complain about that). Sure we had to wait in line for a while (about 20 minutes), but on a sunny day this does not bother at all. As a former history student, I was rather disappointed by the lack of information inside. There is the option to buy an information guide at the shop. But apart from some rare explanation boards, there was not much memorable in the interior. Also the electronic system to go up and down on the narrow stairs caused some frustrations with fellow visitors because not always followed up correctly. By experiencing this, you realize people were smaller centuries ago.The views are great though, and the unique massive construction of the tower makes the trip to Belem worth.

Pick a quiet day and it is wonderois. Having read some reviews on here, I feel very privileged to have gone to the tower on a relatively quiet day. We went in the afternoon on a gloriously sunny Wednesday in January. There were no queues to get in and the tower was ours to explore. There is obviously access issues as this is a 15th century fort built in the middle of the river. There is an electronic system to get up and down the hideous tiny and steep stone stairs. If you have mobility issues don't go here. You will not get past the first floor. We were a bit disappointed that we were not given information guides with our ticket... You can buy one from the gift shop but don't bother as each area has bilingual information boards which fill you in on the history of the tower.We really enjoyed our visit and the tower gives really impressive views. I left feeling very sorry for the prisoners kept in the dungeons all those years ago.Chose your time carefully; of you go on a quiet day, you will be rewarded.

Great view.. If you are going to Belem to taste the pastel de Belem, male the trip worth while by walking to the Torre de Belem and a must do is the museum of co tempory art called museum Barota.
Majestic!. A majestic piece of Portuguese history to be appreciated!You should stop here and enjoy the beautiful scenery.

must see in belem. If you don't visit this then you haven't been in belem. Amazing . Those who don't want to wait in long lines to get just sit down and enjoy the view (also great place to have a picnic)

A quaint but interesting relic of imperial spending and, slightly, power. A delightful reworking of an important part of the defence of the city into a pleasure ground for the monarchyWithout doubt the Torre had an important part to play, when defence was needed, but the present building appears to combine pleasure as the more important matter of defenceYes, delightful and watch your head on the lower floor!One of Lisbon's better 'must see' I think, if you've more than a day

Pretty Cool. Good for a quick visit. From the top, you get beautiful views, and it has an interesting history. The architecture is interesting as well. Again, good for a quick visit and photo opportunity.

Horrendous queue. My wife and I had having previously visited the Torre de Belem and really enjoyed wandering around it, enjoying the views, and imagining its history as a vital strategic fort. Our two girls love a good castle, so we were excited to take them, as they were with us on this trip to Lisbon. We wish we hadn't bothered.We had to queue for 1hr 20 mins just to get in. It was so busy, which isn't their fault. There was a one in, one out rule, which is fair enough. But if you buy a ticket to also visit the Jeronimo Monastery you can get to the front of the Torre de Belem queue. We didn't want to visit the Jeronimo Monastery this time - but as soon as four people came out, four more turned up from their Monastery visit, with their fast passes in the their hands, and the 'standard' queue just crawled along. What we really needed was information to help us make a decision earlier, such as sign saying 30 minutes from here, 45 minutes, from here, 60 minutes from here, etc. We would then not have bothered. But when you queue for these things, as you start to invest time, you start to feel obliged to continue.After 1hr 20 min we got to the front of the queue. After waiting another few minutes as more fast pass people from the Monastery took the places of the people leaving, we finally got to the ticket desk. The man was handwriting every ticket, I think due to a technical fault.Once inside, there was more queuing - on every level to get to the next level!All in all, not a good experience.It is an historic and interesting place, but it's not worth queuing for 1hr 20min to get in. So if you go there and there's a big queue, my advice is just don't bother. The queues for the monastery and the Pasteis de Belem, we noticed, were also horrendous. Having been to Belem four times before I've never seen it like this. Perhaps a one off?

Torre de Belem is a Must See Attraction. The Belem tower along the coast is a site you have to see while visiting Lisbon. It’s not close to the city center, but worth the time to get out there. Take the hop on and off bus. As it has a stop right by there. There are also plenty of other stops to stop and see while taking the bus. The tower overlooks the Tagus Estuary. Take time to climb to the top for great views. The staircase to the top is narrow and circular, may be a challenge for some. This is definitely a site you don’t want to miss!
Great place for sunset. Nice for walking along here. The old tower is great and the new monument. we watched the sun go down (winter)

Out of the way but worth it. Belem tower is down the coast a bit and seems far away from the centre of Lisbon but the hop on-hop off bus will get you there - and the sights on the way are worthwhile anyway. The tower is 16th (?) century overlooking the Tagus estuary with great views over the bay and back across Lisbon. Very narrow circular staircase to get to the top - one way traffic controlled by lights! Basement area where they stored the cannon balls has very low ceilings. Amazing history and well worth the visit.
Beautiful monument and views. The monument is lovely, set right on the waters edge. You can take a trip to the top of the monument to gain views out to see and across Lisbon. Well worth a visit!

It is worth seeing. We jumped off a 'hop on - hop off' bus to see this five-storey fortress built around 1520 to guard the approach to the city by water. Apparently any prisoners in the cells got a bath every time there was a high tide ! Originally known as the Castle of St.Vincent. Whenever we have seen it on TV programmes it seems to have lines of visitors waiting to enter the empty rooms and climb to the battlements. On our visit it was a chilly December day, so no lines. It is about 4 miles from the centre of Lisbon, but worth a visit.

A tower, history and pastries. We came out to Belem as part of the Yellow Bus tour and really enjoyed the visit - the tower is very romantic with an interesting history. Once we were there we were pleasantly surprised to discover as well the monument to exploration, the monastery and the store that creates the pasteis de Belem (nata). I learned that nata means egg custard but the pasteis de Belem are the original natas, being invented by a monk from the nearby monastery. I would recommend a trip out to Belem while staying in Lisbon. Either as part of a tour or just take the 15 tram. All monuments are closed for entry on Mondays.
Belem Tower. Nice area to walk around. Go up the skinny staircase to the top of the tower for good photo op. Walk along the waterfront to the Monument of Explorer's.

Good start point to Belem. Take the no. 15 tram from Praca do Figueria through to Belem (other buses also go there) and 1 stop passed the Monasterio Jeronimos. Good view from the top of the tower (entry is free with a Lisbon card which also covers the tram ride). From there it's a pleasant stroll back towards the centre of town and other attractions.

great views and a well restored building.. Torre de Belem is a must see for everyone who travels to Lisbon. It's quite beautiful, even if it has been massively restored and in a sense changed in the 19th century. Great views, especially from the top.

Riverside majesty. The Torre de Belem serves as a monument to Portugal's military and naval past. It's still in excellent condition, and can be thoroughly explored. It's location is quite spectacular, beside the River Tagus, with one tower jutting out into the water.Together with the nearby Monument to the Discoveries, this makes for a worthy spot of sightseeing for a couple of hours in Lisbon.

Amazing Place!. The Belem tower is amazing ! I enjoyed a lot this historical monument. I recommend 'cause it's a place to learn more about Portugal's culture and see so many beautiful landscapes. TIP: if you travel to Belem, do not forget to eat the original 'pastel de Belem' (it's delicious)

Beautiful. Well-preserved, but be ready to wait, because the stairs are narrow and you need to wait to go to the top. Beautiful view. But pay attention to the pass: you can get a pass to Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and the tower too. I asked it in the Mosteiro but they gave me another pass : I payed for something I didn't want and I payed to the tower.

Beautiful Views of the Bay and the Bridge and Adjoining landscape/cityscape. Spectacular views of the city from the tower . Magnificent well preserved architecture inside . very Narrow staircase going up and down the tower might seem a bit claustrophobic to some but the open spaces display amazing architecture and beautiful scenic views . We captured some of our best pictures here. Definitely a must on your tour of Lisbon and worth spending the admission fee.

Belem!!. All the area is very beautiful! it is easy and cheap to go there by train. In this area they produce the famous pastel do nata, you can sit have a coffee and taste this delicious sweet. Also, it would be nice to walk through the area and visit and the the other monuments. The ticket to enter Belem is cheap and its worth to see the view from this tower.

it was great but..... its a lovely place to visit , a tower built on the 15 th century, its very well preserved, but be prepared to pay 6 euros, to wait long time on queues , because the only access to the top levels is made by stairs that are very narrow and dangerous not good for family's with children between 0 to 6 of age..
Medieval tower. Enjoyed so much this tour! Beautiful sunset and weather. Also there was a free concert that spring sunday afternoon.

beautiful & historic tower. beautiful tower holding Portuguese heritage & architecture of 16th century. also very nice walk along side the river Tagus. we went there with our children (age 2 & 4). It's not possible to climb the tower with very young children but could be reachable up to first floor. very narrow stairs and have to wait in queue to go up. However; the view from the top is spectacular.

A typical example of manuelin architecture. Torre de Belem is another trademark of Lisbon. A typical example of manuelin architecture, built in the same period as the Monastery of St. Jerome. Admission is 6 euro, a tour of the city is included only the outside of the tower tour, tickets are paid on the spot.

amazing bit of history!. Well worth a look, especially searching for the first effigy of a rhinoceros in Europe! The information boards along the prom are particularly informative and give you a feel for how things once were!

Green light red light. It was a windy winter day, sun shone brightly. I looked up and saw a display of green and red arrows. Anyway, when it is green, it means it is safe to ascend or descend, red means please wait for another 90 seconds. Climbing up may be tiring, but is worth it if you like the sea view. Strolling along the side of Torre de Belem, it's my first experience.

Nice to see what I have looked at on posters for years.. It seems quite small on the outside but is in fact much larger than you think. Very ornate architecture, The strategic importance for which it was built is unmistakeable. Close your eyes and you can hear the cannon balls skimming across the water.It is a steep climb, in single file up, a tight circular stone stone staircase to each level so you have to wait if someone is already coming in the opposite direction. Well worth it when you get to the top. Entrance fee 6 euros, seniors 3. Take a No 15 tram from Placa Figuera.
Nice history scene. Nice walk along the Taje river. Impressive history. Nice informed by different big billboards along the path to inform you the history of Belem and the Tower of Belem.

Unique and Interesting. There are a lot of attractions in Belem and they are very close together. Of all of them, the Torre de Belem is the most iconic. The best part is probably the outside. We did go inside but the line was not too long so it was fine. Even if you don't go inside you can get pretty close so at least walk up to it.

Astonishing!. The most beautiful and the most photogenic tower I have ever seen..There is some special atmosphere around it, - feels like for a moment you step into a place free of hustle and worries where the time stops for a while, so you can sit in the sun and watch the world passing by..

Quintessential Portugal. We came late morning, and most of the site was empty. The views of the city from the North are magnificent, not to mention the views of the water and the port. It is worth it to explore the Torre for about an hour, as it is the symbol of Lisbon and Portugal at the height of its power and influence.

It makes you think. This beautiful tower on the mouth of the Tagus river marked the starting point of navigation for such famous explorers as Vasco de Gama. The tower itself is a classical late Middle Age fortress offering splendid views on the river and the city. It is definitely worth a visit.
Stunning. Stunning building from the outside. We didnt go in as queues were very long and in fairness it didnt look that exciting to warrant a visit.

Amazing. An incredible building that everyone should go and see. You get the feeling of how the Portugese were defending the entrance to Lisbon with great style. Just like many other places in Lisbon, Torre de Belem is overwhealming. It has prisoner holes, cannons, high tower, and amazing details in the stones, for decoration and symbolism. Go and see it.

old but nice. this construction hows how the old runners of that part of the world controlled the incoming and outgoing vessels. Look at the construction and you may realize that modern builders can learn a lot from the old structures. Nice place to go

Another marvel of LIsbon. Located by the river Tagus and majestic whether viewed from the riverside or from the actual river. Great photo opportunity and the adjacent park has a couple of interesting statues. We had the good luck to view this from the balcony of our cruise ship as well as part of an organized coach tour. Highly recommended and there are loos and souvenir stalls nearby.

Belem Tower and It's Surrounding. “Excuse me…I’d like to by a ticket.”“We are cleaning.”“Oh…so I should come back later?”“No, we are cleaning.”I found myself inside a building, a modern building that had a pristine white interior, and a friendly Lisbonite at the desk - he was the gatekeeper, the key master to this building. To be honest, I wasn’t sure if this building was a botanical garden or it was an opera house. I figured the safest thing to do was to go inside and buy a ticket, and see where it took me. It would be my Lisbon-Narnia adventure.I had noticed the building from the apex of a more traditional Lisbon tourist site: the Belem Tower. The building had the feel of a modern opera house built organically to blend in with the Rio Tejo (Tagus River), but it sure had a lot of plants. I was in the district of Belem, one of the main tourist neighborhoods of Lisbon, and there were many things to see - but I was intrigued by this one building.“When will you be done cleaning?”“No, we are a clinic - a cancer clinic.”“Oh…”Is it my fault that cleaning and clinic sound like each other when spoken with a Portuguese accent? Is it my fault that it really makes no sense to close an opera house or botanical gardens for that matter for “cleaning”? I suppose the short answers are ‘yes’ and ‘yes.’ I tucked my metaphorical tail between my legs and headed on out the door, as this pristine heavily planted cancer clinic really had nothing to offer me.Fortunately there were other things to do in this picturesque section of Portugal’s capital city: things like taking the lift to the top of the Padrão dos Descobrimentos, or the “Monument That Has All Those Explorers.” I’m not sure the latter name has been accepted by the Lisbonian Board of Tourism (or if that committee even exists). In case you were living in an opaque soundproof chamber for the 1500’s, Portugal led the way for Europe in sailing to distant lands, establishing trade for spices, stealing gold from various peoples, and even enslaving other peoples. Nevertheless, we still love to imagine what life was like for Vasco de Gama, Ferdinand Magellan, or Henry the Navigator (who never actually went anywhere!).So the view from atop the tower not only gives spectacular views of the city, but overlooks a compass rose, which on my particular day was populated by a singing slash drumming slash dancing group from East Asia. I also noticed some skilled skateboarders circumnavigating the design from above.Belem is filled with many attractions, including the aforementioned Belem Tower (also providing wonderful scenery including a modern cancer clinic). The Tower itself sits on the Tagus River and was originally built during the Age of Exploration as defense against pesky Spanish and French invaders - the Spanish did in fact sack the tower and turn it into a prison at one point. The tower boasts a wonderful portcullis and is one of those lucky structures left un-crumbled by the Earthquake of 1755.Further Belem exploration took me through the Tropical Garden in hopes of visiting The Museum of Modern Art, an ornate Monastery, the Belem Palace, or even the Maritime Museum (all abutting the park). Alas, I has spent so much time on my quixotic quest to the cancer clinic, the sites had closed. The stroll through the gardens was pleasant however, and included some Asian pagodas and couples looking to steal kisses in the greenery. One issue with this gem of a district is that it is disconnected from the rest of the city. One must take a taxi there as the walk from central Lisbon is too far and not pedestrian friendly.I ended my visit to Belem with a stop at a very local pub. I’m not sure it was a pub, but it sold beer for less that one euro per glass (admittedly these were small glasses), which is unheard of in a major European city. I relaxed for an hour with my pint-sized pints gleefully tipping one hundred per cent on each refill. I would love to give a name of this place, but it was so obscure, that even the local hipsters do not know it exists. Hint: it’s on the road back to the main city.I eventually flagged down a cab and headed back to my hotel for a nap before addressing Lisbon’s vibrant nightlife. Belem really is a must if one goes to Lisbon, especially if you have two days in the city. Get there early, so you can do more than what I reported upon, and avoid a trip to the cancer clinic.

Interesting. Very interesting building. For me, its more beautiful outside and not inside so i wouldn't recommend to pay to get in. Many options for nice photos. Close to Jeronimos monastery so you can visit both then. Take the tram 15E from the city centre.
Loved it!. Very pretty, lots of history if you stop to read the bits. Fun, narrow tunnels into the towers for kids to enjoy. Lots of steps so don't attempt if you have trouble with many steep steps.

The tower was classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983. This is one of the must see sites in Lisbon if you are into discovering monuments, its architecture is stunning, it played a significant role in the Portuguese maritime discoveries of the era of the Age of Discoveries when Portuguese Ships sailed in search of new lands and colonies. The tower was also commissioned by King John II to be part of a defense system at the mouth of the Tagus river and a ceremonial gateway to Lisbon. Great photo opportunities here.

Torre de Belem is a must see in Lisbon, Portugal!. This is a landmark attraction on the outskirts of Lisbon that is easy to get to and quick to see. You only need about an hour to see everything in the tower, but the views are amazing! It costs 6 Euro for adults and 3 Euro for 12+. Children under 12 years are free! We purchased the family ticket that includes 2 adults and 2 children for 12 Euro. Be forewarned that there are many stairs and no elevator. Arrive earlier before it gets too crowded as they only let in about 150 people at a time because it is small and only one way up and down. There is a very small gift shop inside, but outside down the street there are several gift shops, a restaurant, and pay bathrooms (20 or 50 cents).Enjoy!

one of my favorites. I spent 77 days touring France, Spain, and Portugal and yet this small tower was one of the highlights of my trip. It is situated where the River Tejo meets the Atlantic Ocean. It seemed real to me. I could see the explorers sailing off into the unknown from the Tower. As I flew from Lisbon to Madrid, I was fortunate to be on the side of the plane that gave me an aerial view of the Belem Tower. The river flowing into the ocean is a sight I will never forget.

The tower is beautiful.. The tower is beautiful from the outside with ornate carvings and crashing waves at its base. We got some gorgeous sunset photos here although unfortunately, we arrived too late and could not enter the tower. Check when tower is open before visiting.

worth visiting. To get there, take the #15 tram bus from the metro station (Cais do Sodre). not a very large attraction as seen on pictures, but still worth visiting. We got the combined ticket at the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos.

Beautiful tower. I never seen a beautiful tower like this one. The typical tower is tall cylindrical shaped that is either flat on top with gates or has a pointy roof. This one is so beautiful. castel like tower.

Very good tourist stop. If you ae in Lisbon this site should be on your list of sights to see. The stop is very busy with every tourest bus in town visiting the site. Having said that the old fort is very interesting and defiantly wort the stop.

A landmark in Lisbon. Built in the 16th century, the 100' 4-story tower sits in the Tagus River close to shore. The Belem area was the starting point for many of the discovery voyages. Vasco da Gama embarked on his voyage from Portugal to India in 1497 from this area. Christopher Columbus anchored here on his way back to Spain following his discovery of the Americas. The plane monument there honors the first aerial crossing of the South Atlantic in 1922 by Portuguese naval aviators. There was a line to enter the Tower and we did not have time to go inside. But it's an iconic landmark of Lisbon and still worthwhile to see from the outside.

Lisbon icon + Rhino !. Torre de Belem is a historic tower and fortress on the bank of river Tagus that definitely worth visiting, where you can feel the Portugal history. It is the starting point for Vasco de Gama adventures. It's easy to get to by tram 15E from praca de comercio in central Lisbon.The tower from outside is very attractive. Inside at the first and second levels you can see canons that defended the town and fort itself. At the bottom level there are prison cells with very short ceiling.To access upper levels you should climb through narrow spiral steps.There is a traffic light system inside the tower to manage the people going up and down in narrow single stairs.At the top you can see a scenic view of the sea through the stone slits of the tower. Tower Belem has a nice story of a rhino: In 1513 a rhinoceros landed in Lisbon coming from india A description of it that made by a Portuguese was the basis for famous representation of rhino on a corner of tower Belem in 1515.There is a nice maquette of Torre de Belem outside the fort. Also do not forget that it is free to enter on first Sunday of each month!

Make the effort to climb to the top.. This place really captures how much courage it took for those first explorers to leave the mouth of the Tagus and venture out to who knows where. And the trams make getting there super easy.

A must see touristic attraction in Lisbon. Together with the Geronimos Monastery, the Belem Tower is a landmark in Lisbon. There are more, of course, but I think that these two are not to be missed.I really enjoyed the view of the sea in the Belem tower. I could image how would feel the Portuguese wives, mothers and sisters of all those sailors which were departing in the Portuguese caravels from around that area to face all the sea challenges during the discoveries times. I could image also and image of battles between Portuguese soldiers inside the tower and their enemies on their ships firing against each other.The tower was built as part of the defense system of the city in the early 16th century, exactly when Portugal was in the pick of its discoveries all over the world, like arriving at the Brazilian coast. It´s a wonderful piece of architecture done in limestone and going 30 meters high.The tower became really a symbol of Lisbon.
The heart of Lisbon. It's so iconic you simply have to go if you're in Lisbon. It's super small and not exactly breathtaking, but it's historical it's a quick stop when touring the city.

The first place to visit in Lisbon.. Actually this really was the first place I saw in Lisbon. While people on our tour was trying to grab a bite at the cafeteria I decided to see it instead. To be honest I could not see the inside of it because it was late in the afternoon and there was a long line. I am not upset about it because Lisbon is such a nice city that I am sure I will go again and visit Torre de Belém from the inside. Around Belém there is also a huge park where you can lay on the grass and relax. A great first spot.. It's a castle on the water. They attached chains from between the opposite coast and Belém to stop enemy ships. A very interesting place. Try to visit it earlier in the day.

Felt like just gone back in time!. As I walked through the draw bridge, I felt like I have gone back in time as a soldier spotting enemy ships and firing canons at them. I am not a war junkies but the place is just mesmerizing. It is a bit of a climb through narrow spiral steps to the top and you can see the "raging" sea through the stone slit of the tower.

Heart of Belem....the place that launched Vasco da Gama. Belem is where Vasco da Gama launched his exploratory trips and it has a rich history. The tower is a fun way to learn more about it. You can visit for free on Sundays, but be ready for a longer wait. If you can do it later in the week, you have to pay the fee, but it is worth it if you are strapped for time. Belem is easily accessible by the 15 Tram or Bus 714.
A watch tower. Actually smaller than pictured, this is a watch tower on the river bank. Requires a bit of a travel from the city center (10-15 min drive).
special tower. worth the visit, this tower at the borders of river Taag in Belém (Lisbon). looks medieval, with dungeons and canons.
Stunning tower. Another amazing piece of architecture saved. You can enter free with the Lisboa card. It's quite impressive and looks beautiful in the water.

Tower has a lot of History. Can't hardly miss it, sticks out in the water and was the taxing station for ship crossing the strait for many years. Now a museum and a has a plaza which is a haven for pick pockets.

Worth seeing from the outside but not inside. As this is an iconic building, we decided to pay it a visit (hint: you can buy a ticket that grants you entry to the Jeronimos monastery, torre de Belem and the monument to the discoveries in one go at any of the three sights - cheaper and saves you a lot of queuing time). Lovely view from the outside with the sea lapping around the building. However, there is a lack of objects of interest once you are in. There were also many other visitors despite the fact that it wasn't peak tourist season (although we did go on a Sunday) that it was difficult to move around. Going up to the top of the tower provided a nice view - unfortunately this involved a one way system where a timer sets a certain amount of time during which you can only walk up or down a very narrow flight of stairs. However, as some people got tired of waiting to go down, they ignored this system (no one at the top to reinforce it although there are staff at the bottom to do so and prevent the top from being over crowded) which caused absolute chaos with people neither being able to go up or down. It took us about half an hour just to get down a flight of stairs that should only have taken less than 5 minutes.Definitely worth having a look from the outside but I would not be too disappointed if you don't go in.

An Iconic Lisbon Building. If in the Belem area a visit to Torre is a must. The history and the shapes are amazing and you'll find yourself spending longer here than you anticipate but it's well worth it and there a some amazing photo opportunities.
Worth seeing. The Belem tower is close to the jeronimo monastery, coaches museum, and discoveries monument, all can be seen in half a day and worrh seeing.

The outside looks good.. We caught the tram to Belem with our 24hr Lisbon travel ticket early one evening and were impressed with the Torre de Belem as it looks great at dusk, I took some good photos but as the inside was now closed we decided to go back again earlier another day. We did go back but there were so many visitors around that we just took a few photos but then decided not to go inside or stay any longer in the area.

Visit using the Lisbon card. This is a popular tourist spot. There is not much to see when you go in and for the full admission price, 6 Euros, not really worth the admission. If you have a Lisbon card it's included and you may as well take the trip up. The card does not let you skip the queue though! Don't miss the Rhino.The view from the terrace and top are good. Personally, I found the view from the nearby Monument to the Discoveries better (you see more of the nearby sights and get a great perspective on the pavement below). It's also cheaper and not so far to walk, but not free with the Lisbon card!

Lovely building. Only viewed from outside but it was an impressive building. Did not go inside as I read the reviews about it not being worth the 6€ but you decide and also we were short on time. Worth a look.
Great day out. Belem was a great day out ... lots to see ... lots to do. Maybe not the best on a rainy day and try and find a nice place for lunch ... food nearby blow average
Not worth the money. Have a look at the exterior but the inside is basically boring.Yes one gets view of the city and the April 25 bridge(Lisboa's Golden Gate) but nothing special.

afternoon at torrre de belem. worth a short trip on the new tram to belem tram 15 it can get very busy so may have to stand the stairs are hard to get up but its worth going to the top for the view theres also a fantastic fountain in the gardens where you get off the tram only gos off on the hour so don't miss it there are two cafes at the monument front the Italian on as nice icecream and crepes not over priced

Not worth the money. Torre de Belem is a beautiful building and has clearly been well maintained. However the cost to gain access of 6€ I feel is to much for what there actually is to see. Most museums here cost that and they have much more to see and do. Also if you want a guide you have to pay for one!

Interesting to look at.. Definitely worth making the trip down to see (take the bus or tram, don't walk from the city centre!) but only worth paying for entrance if you're happy on narrow stairs! If you are though then there are good views to be had and interesting turrets and balconies.
Interesting tower. Visited on a wet and windy day but still enjoyed wandering around. Good views across the river. Interesting traffic light system in place for going up and down narrow staircase!

Interesting history and construction, good views. Narrow one way stairs to get up and down and mind your head but worth it to see the tower and the views across the Tagus river and back to jeronissimos monastery. Architecture is for show not battle but interesting blend of the exotic with European - very distinctive. Get there by 15e tram from central Lisbon
Interesting. Well wort a visit. However looks better from the outside as there is of little of interest inside. Easy to get to by tram from central Lisbon
Historic and picturesque. Good views, very historic. Traffic light system inside the tower needed for very narrow single stairs!

Nice place but not really safe. Belen is a little far away from the center of lisboa, but you can arrive using the tram. Nice place for the afternoon. But, be aware of pickpockets!!!! We were waiting the tram when we saw a person trying to rob a german guy. My husband was able to jump and stop that. No police there, and none local people helped, so if you go, be careful and take care of your belongs. We mentioned this to the guy at the Tourist Office and he said that they are aware of this situation but the police is not talking any intervention. If you don,t go, you will not loose much.

Saw it just from outside. Must see. Even though only from outside. I haven't been inside because we were leaving for Coimbra and decided to see the Monastery at the opening of visiting hours instead. I believe the views with the tower are lovely, it's a nice photo spot, but we rather didn't bother with the massive queues.

Nice area worth visiting. Torre de Belem is a lovely area and definitely worth visiting, we did not go into the fort but loved sitting by the river drinking coffee while watching the fort and just taking in the atmosphere.

Beautiful but poorly organised. The tower itself is gorgeous. The views are nice but not spectacular. The queue was very long and people got splashed by the waves breaking underneath the bridge (where the queue was) - some people got completely soaked. Inside there is one tiny staircase (one way) and a completely inefficient tragic light system to help people go up and down. The result - a lot of pushing and frustration. You shouldn't be paying for this, it's not worth it. Go to one of the other museums around.

In to-do list. For me it's one of the sights, associated with Lisbon. Didn't go inside, but enjoyed nice views outside. Appr. 15 minutes walk from local train station ( 3 stops from Lisbon ), mainly by river promenade, passing monument for discoveries and marina. As it was very nice warm day - a lot of tourists and locals as well.

Watch your head on the low door arches!. This tower was used in the 16th century to defend the city from attacks up the Tagus River and looks an impressive structure from the outside. It can only be accessed via the wooden foot bridge across the water.It was chaos queuing to get in on the bridge. People were jumping the queue as there was no one to sort out the mess. In the end it required some verbal exchanges to force people in to line.Be careful when crossing the footbridge as the wave washes on to the wall splashes up onto the bridge before entering the tower.This attraction was free with the LisboaCard otherwise it’s 6€ each for adults.There are a series of spiral staircases to get up and down the various levels and to the top outside viewing level. There wasn’t enough room for people to travel in both directions on the stairs and an amusing traffic light system with sound was used to prevent a gridlock. Once at the top there are some great views.Remember that most museums are closed on Mondays including this one.Certainly worth a visit on your Lisbon trip.
Worth the trek. Very interesting historic fortification with fantastic views of the river, a bit of a far walk, but worth it once you're there.
Must see. Cute little tower built to defend the city. Get in early to tour as they limit the amount of visitors in the tower at one time.

An interesting monument honoring explorers. The Belem Tower is a monument situated on the north bank of the river Tagus approximately 10 minute ride from central Lisbon. The tower once sat in the midst of the river Tagus defending the city of Lisbon but earthquakes changed the coarse of the river so the tower now rests on the north side of the Tagus. Whether seen from a cruise ship in the river Tagus or up close and personal, the tower is an impressive sight.

Incredible view of the city . The view of the city from the terrace is magnificent at night where everything is lit. The ride with the elevator is a must but the waiting line is sometimes not worth it. The best thing a visitor must do is to buy the green 24 hour ticket that gives him free rides on every public transportation and free access at some sites. Be very careful of your belongings because of pocket lifting in crowded places.
Its OK. It's a nice tower, it's OK but we didn't love it. This is, in my opinion, something you could avoid in your visit if you are short of time and you would not be missing nothing very special

Interesting though limited information to explain what's what. Free for those with a Lisbon Card - otherwise about EUR6 pp. There is a main area showing the small guns which helped defend the city and a tower of about 4 floors. A single spiral staircase is the only access so it operates a 'stop/go' traffic light system and numbers in the tower at any one time are limited to about 150.

A must see in Lisbon. We really did enjoy our day trip to Belem.. I do recommend going early as to not have to fight for space on the local tram. It was so crowded for 15 minutes, it made us a bit nervous. Other than that, what a nice place to see if the weather is cooperating.

The fantastic Torre de Belem. The Torre de Belem is located in Lisbon, the capital of Portugal. It has been built on the mouth of the river Tage, to protect the Hieronymite monastery, but it hasn't been very useful, so it became a jail and a payment place. It is a very famous attraction because of the view that it offers. I really recommend you to climb the staircases until the summit of the tour ! You will have the pleasure to admire the boats, navigating on the river ! The most beautiful is to look at the water, reflecting the sunshines ! Furthermore, there is a renowned pastry shop near the tour, where you can purchase delicious pasteis de nata !

wortwhile. 20 minutes travel outside of Liboa center. easy to reach by public transportation. here the sailors left on there voyages. impressive view on Taag river and Atlantic ocean. also very nice monastery nearby.

Highly decorated fort on River. Closed by the time we arrived, but popular tourist spot. Interesting architecture in commanding position and views of the Vasco da Gama bridge and the Cristo Rei on the south bank. Great at sunset.
quick stopover for picture. The line to get in was too long so we just took pictures from outside. You can see the golden red bridge from background so it makes a really pretty photo stop.
Worth seeing. The Tower is worth seeing but getting to the top through the one way staircase is a challenge. Great view. Afterwards grab a sandwich and beer at the cafe that overlooks the Tower.

A XVI century jewel. Built in 1514, during the reign of D. Manuel I, this fortification was part of the defensive plan of the Tagus river bar.National monument since the beginning ot the XXth century is an ex-libris of Lisbon, situated in one of the most pleasant places in town, by the river.This visit is an encounter with the history of Europe. In the XVI century, in front of Belém Tower passed the ships of the Portuguese navigators discovering new cultures and peoples in other continents.Try: http://www.torrebelem.pt/

One of the ex-libris of Lisbon. If you are visiting Lisbon this is one the monumentos compulsory to visit! Belém Tower (Portuguese: Torre de Belém, pronounced: [ˈtoʁ(ɨ) dɨ bɨˈlɐ̃ȷ̃]) or the Tower of St Vincent is a fortified tower located in the civil parish of Santa Maria de Belém in the municipality of Lisbon, Portugal. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site (along with the nearby Jerónimos Monastery) because of the significant role it played in the Portuguese maritime discoveries of the era of the Age of Discoveries.[3] The tower was commissioned by King John II to be part of a defense system at the mouth of the Tagus river and a ceremonial gateway to Lisbon (wikipedia).It is near the Tagus River and it is has beautiful gardens in front of it. Next to it you have the monument dedicated to all those who have fight in the Portugueses Colonial War in the 60s/70s.The price of the ticket is 6,00 and can be bought online here https://bilhetes.igespar.pt/Default.aspx

Once fabulous, now really hard work.. We visited the Torre de Belem for the second time with a friend of ours visiting Lisbon for the first time. Our last experience was wonderful and we had no hesitation recommending it...however! There is now a limit on the number of people who can enter the monument, ok I understand that but it does mean lengthy queues and delays. The recent installation of turnstiles at the bottom of the stairs to the main tower however leads to immense frustration both going up and down. A red and green lighting system is meant to allow fair travel, this doesn't really do that as there are stopping points when going both up and down the tower. This led to an immense queue forming on the roof waiting to descend, in baking hot sunshine. Add some tourists with walking difficulties and it became one almighty traffic jam on the narrow circular uneven surfaced stairs. Not helped by an elderly man employed in the tower to attend to such occurrences...who promptly made things an awful lot worse. A shame because the views from all levels of the tower are quite spectacular, but perhaps not quite worth the entrance fee or the hassle.

Very impressive Fortress. The Belém Tower is a Beautiful Fortress from the XVl Century. It survived the 1755 Earthquake. It alies Beauty with military purposes, it's Unique in the world. YOU have to see it !!

Neat little tower but better from the outside. Lovely location but not really an island any more. Restricted numbers and one-way system for climbing up and down makes this only worthwhile on a quiet day. Otherwise you spend more time queuing than seeing the views or reading the history.

Romantic tower. Although we did not have the time to enter the monument, the feeling just standing in front of it was amazing. Situated in a beautiful spot, it offers the opportunity for a lot of activities besides the amazing view, the most interesting of which being concert organization.
Interesting, but do your history homework first. Impressive structure, however, not particularly meaningful unless you study the royal implications and the connections to global exlorations.

An iconic symbol of Lisbon. It was a bit of a walk from the Discovery Monument to the Torre.There was a bit of a line to enter so we decided against it and walked around it instead. It was a beautiful day so we just sat down and admired the structure. You can take great pictures from nearly every angle.
One of the key sites to see in Belem. You have to see this 16th century fortified tower overlooking the water and couple this with the really cool discoveries monument nearby

Great bit of history. A great bit of history, gets the imagination going. Really well maintained. The views from the tower are fantastic, but only accessible by a single tall, spiral staircase (there are rooms available to take a breather). This single staircase means groups take turns walking up and down, this led to a build-up of people at the top.
Big queues.. Big queues at this place from the moment that you join the hopeful throng hoping to be lucky enough to be admitted.

Part of the Area's Long History Dating from the Early 1500's. Nice spot for photos, and maybe we short-changed this site by not waiting in line to go up into the tower. It has historical significance but wasn’t one of the most interesting attractions that we saw in this area.Belém Tower (or the Tower of St. Vincent) is a fortified tower in the municipality of Lisbon. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site (along with the nearby Jerónimos Monastery) because of the significant role it played in the Portuguese maritime discoveries. The tower was commissioned by King John II to be part of a defense system at the mouth of the Tagus river and a ceremonial gateway to Lisbon. The tower was built in the early 16th century and is a prominent example of the Portuguese Manueline style. The structure is composed of a bastion and the 100 foot four storey tower.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Another Must See. You can do this and the monastery in one day with a delightful lunch by the river. Start at the Monastery and buy your ticket for entry to both sites. Then proceed across the street to the monument where Henry the Navigator points the way out to sea. Stroll down the walk by the river stopping to grab some lunch (there are a lot of places so lunch can be grab and go, light or hearty). Finally approach the Tower which is a beautiful example of Manueline architecture. Great for some photos and you came climb the steps inside for some great views of the river and Belem
Not much to see. It's nice, but there's not much your can really do here. Nice area to take photos tho. They also had a couple of guys dressed up, we had a photo taken with the pirate!

Great views. We visited Belem to see the monastery and luckily bought a combination ticket which enabled us to dodge the extremely long queue here. It's a great building, great narrow spiral staircase up to the top.....if you hear beeping its the one way system - as the staircase is so narrow you're only meant to go one way at a time, so they have a red/green system. Unfortunately people don't always realise this or try their luck and keep on going meaning more and more people get stuck at the top. Minor annoyance, but it meant the top was very busy with people and you had to queue to get out. Amazing views though and worth the effort of the climb up there!

Do the Tour to do it justice. we got off the bus about 1km ahead of the tower and walked past the Navigators Monument so maybe by the time we arrived we were underwhelmed, esp seeing the long queues to get in. Stil, a unique emplacement and worth the trek out there

One continuous queue. First you queue for a ticket, then you join the queue to climb the tower. Once at the top, you immediately join the queue to go back down. On the plus side, the views are quite nice, but in my opinion, it's not worth the hassle if it's busy. They should put a slide to go down :)
worth the long queue. The line here was extremely long... so better get a combo ticket from the Belem Church and Kloister.

Ancient tower on the sea side. This has some history to say - this tower is located near the place from where vasco da gama is believed to have sailed off for his discovery of land. This is in a very serene place. May was of course best time to visit.

Beautiful. We enjoyed spending some time in that little tower. Nice views, well maintained and nice staff.
you should definitely go there!

beautiful views. It was a cloudy overcast morning and just as we got in the rain came down! We toured the first floor and waited out the rain. When we went outside, the weather had cleared and we had sunshine! Beautiful views of the water and the bridges. This is one of the sights that should been seen!

Worth seeing especially from the top. Magnificent view
Clean
Well maintained
Charged to visit €6 per person, for 65+ €2
Hop on blue line tour connection

Historical and magnificent. We arrived there early to be greeted by busloads of German and Japanese retirees. They weren't in the way but the tower was still closed and we were hungry, not having breakfast yet and decided not to wait for the tower to open. Since we didn't get to visit inside the tower I'm unsure of the fees and the other features provided inside. In hindsight, the purpose of the tower was to look beyond and outside to the sea so I guess we completed that objective.Wandering around the area and enjoying the views, the fishermen, the changing of the guards beyond the tower were all enveloped by great weather, a marathon race in progress and promise of other nearby attractions within walking distance.

Must see while in Lisbon. We went to visit these beautiful monuments in Lisbon on our first night there. Even though most tours here are not available on Monday, we decided it would be nice to visit at sunset for a romantic stroll (we also noticed it’s perfect for a jogging destination). The Torre couldn’t have been more beautiful. We just kept taking photos. We took photos of the Monument to the Discoveries a little later when twilight was already upon us, as the blue sky, the moon, and the color of the Monument was a perfect contrast. It’s a nice balance of the modern and historical, but both represent huge contributions of Portuguese history. Not to miss while you’re in Lisbon.

Unique white tower. It's a tower from the discoveries time build like a stone ship standing in the middle of the river Tagus (not nowadays).It's a beautiful all in white piece of Manuelino style. Along History served as a prison and as a fortress to protect Lisbon from pirates attacks and traditional enemies of the Portuguese (Spain, France...).Worth well the €6 paid for the ticket.
Belem Antique Market. We combined the Sunday with a trip to the antique market in Belem and to see the monuments on the waterfront.Check to see when the markets are on because they are not always on.

Great Views!. I really wanted to see this place, and convinced the rest of my group they should too! We did not buy tickets in advance and did not really have to wait real long. I believe they do only allow so many people in at once. We also bought the combo pass for this and the monastery. So you can really see why they built this there. From the top you can see quite far. The only way to get to the top is to go up the tiny spiral staircase. It's interesting how they meter the people. There's a timer of 2 minutes for people going up. You get a warning tone, and you need to get off on the next floor. Then the down people go, and they get 2 minutes. Etc. etc. Pretty clever system, and makes more sense when you realize you don't have to climb all the way in the 2 minutes!You can also go into the basement and see the prison area. I'm a tall fellow, and the ceilings are quite short. Worth a look, though.It is a good place to see the city, the bridge, and the river. Definitely a nice photo taking place. Highly recommended!
Interesting visit. This is a very busy place to visit. We had enjoyed a long walk from 25th April Bridge (where our ship was docked) to get here but it was worth the walk.

Best Thing in Belem. This was my first stop in Belem and waiting in line could not damper my excitement about seeing this old defense tower. It has been well taken care of or very well restored. They limit the number of people allowed in and they have a system set up to regulate people going up the single file spiral staircase. The views are lovely and it is worth the money to get in

Really interesting place. This tower constructed in the XVI century (open in 1519) is a beauty of an architectural feat, also a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a not to be missed place in Lisbon, which by the way is a beautiful city with lots of great places to visit.If you are there don't miss it!!!

Excellent monument to visit. Very interesting, with good views from the top. Only 150 people can be inside at a time so either go early, or buy your ticket in advance and save yourself from queuing (we arrived at 11.00 and waited about 45 minutes).

No need to go inside. Actually the beauty of the tower is already seen from the outside. There is no need to go inside the tower because there is not much to see. It is not so high to get a breathtaking view. And the most disturbing thing - you have to stand in very long queue to get on the tower and even longer to get down. The first thing I did when I got on the tower was getting in the line to get down. :) It is beautiful place but as I said, you don't need to go up there to see it.

Worth the visit despite the staff. The tower is both beautiful and interesting, with great views from the tops. However the staff we encountered were grumpy and unfriendly. Make sure they don't deliberately try to overcharge you.

A historical landmark. Such a beautiful tower in the Tajo River, it is historic and located near the Monastery or Jeronimos, the Presidentail Palace and near the famous Pasteis of Belem...all this is a must even if you are in Lisbon for only 24 hours !
Only Worth an Outside Look. Nice and worth photos from the outside, but inside is nothing but a stair climb to the landing above for the view. Save your entry fee.

Very beautiful but not worth visiting. If you are in Lisbon / Belem, you really have to visit this tower.Why? Because its beautiful & full of history.Only don't go inside; Queues are very very long & there is nothing to see. The tower is really not high!

Nice place to visit. At a walking distance from the Monastery of Jeronimos entrance is 6 Euros. Going up the stairs requires minding a semaphore system on each story. It is interesting to imagine soldiers going up and down these narrow stairs and passages in the days the fort was used to defend the city from ships entering the Tejo River.

Historic but a poor experience. I tend to agree with some previous reviewers. It is such an integral part of Belem and Lisbon that it would be silly to miss it. But the visitor experience is poor. Staff are supremely uninterested and the traffic light system for the narrow stairs is just like roadworks in the UK. Some idiot (and there were many) will try to beat the system and screw it up for the rest of us. Also joining the queue from the Middle levels requires the average tourist to have the brains to realise that if you are going up you wait until people on the stairs are going up and vice versa.

Beautiful Views. The tower has good views but only 150 people can enter at a time so you will queue. There is a traffic light system for climbing the tower and as it is single file so you will also queue once inside. Very little information an narrative.

Nice, but Don't expert too much. The tower looks great, but the area is quite small and gets crowded quickly even though there is a maximum number of visitors. People do not follow the signs for the stairwell (you are supposed to stay no longer on the stairs than 1 minute going up or down) even though there is a good system that shows you when you can go up or down. The view from the tower is good but that is about it.
Nice view. I really enjoyed this place, the view was spectacular! It was a bit of a walk, but totally worth it!

cool place to photograph. The place was closed when we went but I think all you need to see is the outside. Nice place to take a relaxing stroll. Great place to take photos as mementos for visiting Portugal as this is a place that is easily recognizable as a Portuguese landmark. Not sure if there are facilities inside, but there is a restaurant nearby where we had coffee and ice cream and we were able to use the facilities.
Great but don't go inside. Just view and take photos from outside, don't pay for the tickets to go inside, there is nothing there and the view is not particularly good.

Beautiful Castle. Went to Torre de Belem during daytime, so we didnt get to see the place all light up with candles, but it was still a beautiful sight. It was closed when we arrived, and we couldnt see any information on when it opened. There was a restaurant close by, wich was a nice place to sit and watch the castle, and a great spot for people watching. The taxi driver warned us about pickpockets, wich I think is good to be aware of. Lost my silk scarf, and when I turned around to pick it up it was already gone.
unique. it was a unique experience. A castle on the sea. \Such a great place to see and meditate. full of inspiration

Waiting in the queues. We bought double ticket with Jeronimos Monastery to avoid the queue to Torre de Belem. In fact we had to wait for entrance 15 minutes instead 1 hour like the people who wanted to buy the ticket at Torre de Belem. Despite the fact that there is an automated system inside which should manage people going up and down on very narrow stairs, all the visitors were steered by three guys who in my opinion made a chaos. Instead of enjoying views and architecture I had to stay in queues and wait for the guy who let me enter the stairs. Definitely I don't recomend to enter Torre de Belem - everything you can see is outside.

Very interesting. The tower is not a huge one when compared to other similar structures around Europe, but its position beside the river and its style makes it very interesting. The interior is relatively small too, serving its original purpose as a defensive structure.To get to the top, you will need to climb some flights of stairs (not recommended for some people), but the view is worth it! You will have amazing pictures from there.

Beautiful & Historic. This beautiful tower is even prettier in person. Thankfully had a gorgeous day and got some great photos. I love that there's only one staircase to go up or come down so they devised a red light/green light system, not that it's strictly observed.... Definitely worth a visit, then you can go see the nearby monastery and get the best Pastel de Nata!

Do not make this the top of your to-do list. Myself and my partner wanted to visit the Jeronimos Monastery in Belem first, and at the ticket counter to the Monastery, had the option of buying a kind of tour ticket, which cost €16 per person, which included the Jeronimos Monastery, the National Archaeological Museum situated inside the Monastery, and also the Torre de Belem. If you're buying a ticket to just go into the Torre de Belem, it isn't worth it. Turn around.Basically, I can sum up the site in a paragraph for you. It is a fortress which has roughly 5 levels. only accessible via one very narrow staircase. Each level you stop off at has the same view of the same sea and land. The only difference was at the bottom level, it had several canons in place in front of windows. The levels above, had absolutely nothing in them, but the same windows in the same positions, with the same view. There was a red and green light system, whereby single file queues going up or down each level were made on timer. A very long time was spent queuing up and looking at the screens, waiting until it was our turn to go back down the tower down the narrow staircase. There was not much enjoyment or anything interesting to look at apart from being impatient in getting out of the tower. Just take a look at the tower from the outside, because I guarantee you will think of it as a waste of time getting in and wishing you were out.
Nice site.. I expected to be bigger, you can see everythig in 1/2 hour. It has a nice view on the town and vasco da gama bridge from the top.
OK but not great. The outside is nice but it is a hassle to get to the inside and no many people are allowed in at the same time. The only good thing about the inside is the view.

Must See. This is the place everyone associates with Lisbon. Unfortunately, we didnt get to visit inside, arrived at the same time as several coach tours and queues were too long. However, took plenty of photos and had walk around, it's a nice area. Maybe get to visit another time.

Lisbon's Nr. 1 post card!. It is not possible to visit Lisbon and not going to the "Belém" area. In this área, you'll find many important attractions, but "Torre de Belém" is certainly the most iconic one. The image of this 16th century fortress is a strong symbol of Lisbon and of the brave Portuguese navigators. Its has been appointed a National Monument in 1910 and Unesco also awarded it as World Heritage in 1983! And that is amazing! Along the centuries, the old fortress has endured earthquakes and many renovations. The actual building is indeed a masterpiece of the manueline (impressive stone sculpted façades) and gothic (beautiful interiors) styles. Take your time and stroll along its five floors, visit every single room and enjoy the incredible views of the Tejo River and the nearby historical buildings and monuments. After it, nice pictures and fond memories to take home. Enjoy!

Love it. You really mustn't miss this one. The stonework is amazing, and you get to walk through nearly the whole place. Wonderful views from the towers.Very impressive. This has to be a "must do" on any Lisbon visit. Stand in the footsteps of Vasco de Gama!

Could be so much more. The main attraction of the tower can be viewed from the outside, the stone work. Inside is pretty empty and arguable not worth the time. My advise would be to go in but stick to the first floor the climb to the top is a bit of a waste. A bit more effort would turn this into a no1 attraction.

Torre de Belem is terrific!. Visited this site recently and it was worthwhile. It sits right on the river along the beautiful river side pathway so you can dine in the area, visit this and other sites. We enjoyed taking pics of the structure but did not climb to the top due to long waiting lines.

Love it! one of my favourite places in Lisbon. I love Torre de Bélem and the other monuments around. This area is so beautiful. The view is amazing with the river and the bridges. Definitely a must go if you are in Lisbon. And don't forget to eat the pasteis de Belém across the street! :)

A small tower to explore. It is a small tower located at the mouth of the river. The stairs are very steep and narrow. People walking up or down have to wait for the light signal before they can start walking otherwise there will be traffic jam and no one is going anywhere. The stairs are so narrow that it only allows one person to move at a time. So be patient. If you ask me whether it is worth the money or time I would say no. But if you want to go and check it out do buy the combo ticket with the visit to the Monastery of Jeronimos to save you a couple of euros. Enjoy.....
Nice place to visit. It has a great view of the city and it's a nice place to walk. Try to use comfortable shoes (no highheels for women!) considering the difficulties of the ancient streets.

Visit if you have time.. We had to line up for tickets and admittance was restricted to a limited number. Seniors over 65 years get a discount. The wait depended on how many people came out. The castle has 3 or 4 storeys and the steps up were quite steep. Traffic is one way at a time. Wardens will control the flow and the numbers as well.From the castle windows, one gets a fantastic view of the bridge over the Rio Tejo and the river.
Castle on the river. We've visited it at night, so we couldn't get inside, but it looks very romantic and historic. There are some other places to see near by.
Beautiful. Stupidly of us we went on a Monday when it's actually closed! However it was lovely to walk round and enjoy from the outside, must see if you go to Belem!
It was worth it. Very historic place which is to great walk around , great view. Definitely recomend it for anybody traveling to Lisbon.

great views. there where long queues the day i was there, it was August so I expected this. I would advise the tourist ticket where you can queue jump.Once inside great views, the stone work is very impressive.
Very historic. Well worth a visit, but you queue to get a ticket without any shade, so make sure you have your hat. The numbers allowed inside at any one time are limited.
Monuments. Very interesting place with some of the most typical monuments in Lisbon. It's a must see for all visitors! The only downside is that it's not in the center and you must go by tram.

Tasty Food and Great Touristic Places. You should have Pasteis Nata in Pasteis De Belem. It is totally different from other you may have in other places. The neighborhood is great and a lot to discover.

impressive sight. well wort a visit as theres quite a bit to see around this part of Lisbons coast. catch one of the little yellow trams number 15 from the centre to the large monastery and you are close by. head past the fountains to the coast to the tower and and the monument of discoveries. also very good for restaurants right across from the tram stop.

Worth a visit. Interesting sight to see if you are visiting Belem. One of the hallmarks of the Age of Discovery. I would definitely suggest visiting the Tower along with other well known sites in the area to make the visit to Belem more worthwhile. The Belem district has much to offer and the tower is just one piece of the puzzle.
Nice visit. Have. Have not been on the top. But nice to rest and have a look. Nothing special to do here. A lot of tourist. So you don't want to miss it

region with classical building and atmosphere. Belem is the place with classical Potuguese atmosphere and full of the feeling of "age of discovery in 15 century." Near the coast, you could see the classical sailing boat driving along the sea shore just like going back to the old time. Enjoy the leisure time in the traditional coffee shop, Of course, don't forget to taste some potuguese pastries with potuguese coffee. The best relaxation I have in Lisbon.

Little castle in the sea. This is a lovely surprise, it does not look that big from the outside but its deceptive because its built in the sea and use to be a lot further from land! Watch out for the weird light system for the stairs!

Beautiful, historic and nice to visit. If you are visiting Belem, you should, at least, visit the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and the Torre de Belem (12 euros for both if you buy a bundled ticket). The most interesting views of Torre de Belem come from the outside and the top of the tower.
