Difficult to get up and down the staircase as many people want to go up as go down, The guys at the tower do their best with a traffic light mechanism. A lot of history for this tower as it has been a witness of many ships looking for "new" worlds and coming back with riches. In an extreme, you could save the visit of the inside and just enjoy the view from the outside.

Avoid sundays. The tower has long lines on Sundays. The tower has a system which controls the movement up and down the narrow stairs which is good , but this means waiting in line to move up or down once you are inside the tower. Once at the top the views up and down the river are fantastic.Best to visit Belem on a weekday if possible. You can also visit the famous pastry shop , the monastery and the Maritime museum. You can take Tram 15 from city centre to Belem or train if you are short on time.

Belem landmark. Belem is easily reached by tram number 15 from the city center. The whole area can be easily walked. The tower is impressive and the whole waterfront area is nice to visit. Also not to be missed is the monastery of Jeronimos close by with its outstanding architecture. There are also in the area nice parks with water ponds and ducks, fountains, nice green and restful places to stop for a picnic.

Unique. From this beautiful Tower the Portuguese discovered a great part of the world. It is situated in a beautiful area with parks, monuments, museums and restaurants. It is, indeed, a very nice place to be.

Very picturesque but learn to skip the line. It is totally worth visiting this site. But to avoid the long line if you have your Lisboa Card, when you visit the Monastery ensure to ask them for tickets for Belem too. Once you have your tickets you can bypass the lines and go right in. Also note that this site is free if you have Lisboa card.

Nice way to view history. First thing, this place is incredibly busy! You need a bit of patience but it is rewarded. The tower isn't just impressive to look at, its also interesting inside. The commanding views of the Tagus and the architecture inside are worth the queue.

A sight to see.... This is a breathtaking tower. It is a bit far out and can be a bit difficult to get to but you must see. The views are breathtaking and worth the trip. I saw it from a tour bus that we took and we jumped off to see it. We didn't go in because of time but still understood the wonder of this.

Great Views. Enjoyable with great viewed of the Tagus, well worth a visit. Reasonably priced and if you get a combination ticket with the Monastery and the architecture museum you can get fast track entry to all the attractions.
Awesome. It is very beautiful but the line could be long. I recommend that you buy tickets online or somewhere else because otherwise you wait in line for 1 hour or longer.

It's a tower with a nive view. It's a defense tower with a very nice view and a little historic background of Lisbon. It worth going to and in, but it's not as magnificent as all the books tell you.Go there! But don't expect more then a tower.
Great view. Nice day in Belem and a trip into the Torre de Belem offers great views of the area. Buy your ticket ahead of time. The lines can get long. The spiral staircase can be tricky.

Better from the outside. It's a beautiful looking building from the outside and great history but unless it's free as part of your Visit Lisboa card I wouldn't go inside.It's got little of interest in there in terms of displays or information and their traffic light system on the spiral stairs is chaotic. Everyone pushes past each other and it's not pleasant. The nearby monument to the marine explorers offers far better views and is much more interesting.

Lisbon Benchmark. Portuguese for tower of Bethlehem, it stands proud for centuries in very good shape. Lucky i got there early morning, the place gets very crowdy when tourist buses arrive. A must stop while in Lisbon!

A beautiful building with a lot of history. It looks fantastic and the camera did a lot of clicking while waiting in the queue to get tickets. If you are visiting Belem you will almost certainly visit both here and the Monastery so get a combined ticket and not only save some Euro but also save time queueing at both sights.Inside there is not a lot to see, but the views make it worthwhile and it would be such a shame to come all the way here and not have a look.

Good combo with Belem. Saw this and the monastery with the same ticket. Not a bad walk from Belem. Saw it right before a rain storm, which kept the crowds down. Staircase was annoying with people ignoring the lights. It is a pretty basic set up, no major displays, just good views. If you are on a budget, the explorers monument is only a 1/2 a kilometer away and is only 3€ with almost identical views and an elevator. Restroom at the cafe out front is a pay restroom, but you can reuse the ticket, or get a pass if you buy something.

Commercial historical artefact. Was not as impressed with this building as others in Lisbon. It's cramped and very busy (they do only let 150 people in at one time but I still think that is too many). There is a traffic light system to manage the single spiral staircase but these lights are often ignored by the visitors and I saw some clashes between people who had forgotten basic courtesies.

Nice, Expensive and badly organized. beautifull monument!Splendid environment!But they are not able to control the movement up and down from the tower. they tried to automize it with green and red lights but they do not know that a lot of people do not care at all about them. bid chaos as a result. A mass of people on the top in the killing sunshine, people waiting for each other in the stairs.

Great views. The Tower was included in our Lisboa card so we took advantage of going. The exterior is quite impressive and views are great from the different decks/rooms, but there isn't much to see inside. I would say it's not worth a long line waiting, but it's worth a visit if you're nearby and have free entrance.

romantic tower. So,we bought Lisboa card which gives you free access or discount to a lot of sights&monuments&museums, so this attraction was free for us (also, you have free public transport). This tower is simply stunning!!Very romantic architecture but it was built to protect Lisabon from raids from the ocean/river. You have to wait to get in, and also when you climb the tower,to get to different levels. There's actually a sort of traffic light on the stairs since they are very tight, so that people don't fall over each other cause somebody is trying to go down while others want to go up, so this system they have is clever and prevents such things. For some reason, a small shop on the lower floor (where the cannons are) was closed. It's a nice view from the top too. Also, the tower of Belem is a short walk from the monument of discoveries and the Jeronimos monastery.

Not really worth the effort. Visited the Belem Tower after going to Jerronimos Monetary, which is probably what most tourists do, as the Monetary is nearer to the tram line. Its a good 20 minute walk to get there, and although it is quite an impressive building from the outside, once you get inside you realise that there just isn't very much to see. Because it is such an old building the (one) interior staircase is very narrow and only allows transit in one direction at a time. To combat this, an electronic signage system has been installed which informs visitors when they can transit up or down from each floor. Unfortunately this is ignored (either deliberately or due to low intelligence) by a large number of visitors leading to people pushing past each other on a very steep & extremely narrow circular stone staircase. Once you get to the top the views aren't special - only saving grace was it only cost 2 Euros to visit. In my opinion it isn't worth going out of your way for. It goes without saying that if you have any sort of disability then you will struggle at the Belem Tower.

You just can't skip it. It's one of the World's UNESCO site so you can't miss it. Beautiful from the outside but you don't miss anything much if you do not get inside the building because of the long line. Narrow stairs and you can go one way (up or down) at a time. The view from the roof top is not as beautiful as what you see from Padrao dos Descobrimentos which is near by.
absolutely to see. tower worth to see, and worth to climbe up to see beautiful view from the top. Near to the amaizing Jeronimo`s Monastery. Both are absolutely number 1.
nice. a must on your fist visit to Lisbon...nearby the map of the world is also intersting...beware of women pickpockets trying to sell scarves¡

Lisbon's Defensive Tower. Visit early in the morning as it opens or around 13.30 when people having lunch to avoid the queues. Not too much to see in terms of artefacts but great views from this fort..The one way system up and down the steep stairs was a bit random and didn't work all the time.

can skip it. It's ok but nothing extraordinary, nice views. Quite long line to enter and you also take much time to go up and down as staircaise is norrow and lights regulate which way when goes. Much greater is monasterio de Jerónimo.
Lovely tower with view over the river. Great to visit and take photo's although we didn't go inside, worth it just to walk along the promenade to the Monument of Discoveries.
Well worth a visit. Lots to see in Belem. This was just one of the many super sights. Thought Belem was well worth a full day and throughly recommend lunch on the river front.

typical tourist attraction. but lovely in itself. We spent a long time looking for it because it's behind the train tracks and we were on the other side, a long way away from any crossing bridges..
Beautiful views over the Rio de tejo though
must see when you go to Lisbon!

One of the Seven Wonders of Portugal. The Torre de Belém is one of the most significant monuments of the city of Lisbon. Is located on the right bank of the Tagus river, in the town of Belém, where once existed the beach of Belém. Initially surrounded by water on all its perimeter, was progressively involved the beach, even today incorporate ashore. The monument stands out for implicit nationalism, since it is all surrounded by decorations Coat of arms of Portugal, including entries from crosses of the Order of Christ in windows bulwark; such characteristics refer primarily to the typical architecture of a time when the country was a global power (the beginning of the Modern Age). Classified as World Heritage by UNESCO since 1983, was elected as one of the Seven Wonders of Portugal on July 7, 2007.
Awesome. A must for those who enjoy absorbing the history of Portugal. Take a bus or taxi and spend time viewing this landmark
Well worth a visit. One of the must-do sights in Lisbon. Combine with visits to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and Monument to the Discoveries. Go early or late to avoid the crowds.

Really nice. This is a nice tower completely surrounded by water. It would be an even nicer experience if it didn't rain cats and dogs when we arrived there, but was still a nice trip to Belem though.

Different type of fort/castle/tower. First off, this is a must see in Lisbon. It is pocket-sized, separated from the shore and close to two other major sights in Belem - Monasterio and Monument to discoveries. It does require some walking from them, but it is worth it. Several floors of rooms, at least a dozen of mini towers for you to go into and look out, a great view of the Tejo estuary, an acceptable price, ... Really, a lot of interesting sides to it. However, I advise not to visit if its rainy like me and my girlfriend did, since the stones might be slippery and you wont be able to get the most of its potential for great pictures!

beautiful spot. we did not have a tour inside the tower, but it is worth taking a bus to have a look. the view is just magnificent. you can see the 25th of April bridge, which is very pretty as well. it is not too far from the city centre and they have some cafes where you can grab some delicious belem cakes.
Good photo opportunity!. Just another tower but it is along the river so you can get a good photo. It is near a number of other tourist attractions - coach museum is nice.

Interesting. Interesting example of typical Portuguese architecture from 1500.Two things people do not know is that the tower was situated 500 meters in the river, and was used as a warehouse at the time, where the ships loaded their supplies before sailing away on their discovery travels.
Historic Landmark. You really must see it, but be patient because the line to enter it is very long. But is is worth while.

Beautiful but busy. We went here beginning of September. It's a great old building to see. Inside is just stones to be honest.
And to get up there's a traffic light system so you can easily go up and down on the narrow stairs. Unfortunately most tourists don't follow this system and you get up stuck on the stairs.
Excellent. Worth a visit, but avoid a visit in the afternoon at peak hour because it's very crowded and it can take a long time to get on the roof and to get back / The entrance is free some days

Badly managed queue. There is only one staircase up the tower & no attempts were made to control people going up or down the two floors. Consequence, chaos on a hot afternoon. We gave up &, as we left, they had stopped entry to the whole complex.

Stunning views. The history of the tower is worth investigating, and so are the winding stair cases leading up. There are beautiful views of the river and Lisbon landmarks. This is definitely worth seeing!

one of Lisbon's beautiful sight. Went there during high season. The area has a lot see. On your way to the area, you walk along the blue water and there are so many buildings from old days that you could see. There is an easy way to get there with trams and you just need to walk like 5 minutes from the stop.

dissapointing. we didn't go in, just did a look from the outside as this is one of the unesco heritage sites; there was some scaffolding that did take away but I don't really get why this is reported as above average by anyone. good news is that it is just in front of the Jeronimo convent which was indeed truly wonderful

Beautiful old tower on the river. Well worth a visit, but pick your time of day if you want to go up the tower -early morning is best. It is on the open top bus route, so you can drop off & on ayour convenience
Pretty. We didn't go inside, but it's a nice site and a beautiful spot to walk along the river. There is a little park in front of it and it's just down the way from the Discoverers Statue.

Must visit place in Lisboa. All the area can be visited in just one afternoon: Torre de Belém, Monumento aos Descobrimentos and Mosteiro de Jerônimo. It's incredible to imagine how the portuguese used to leave that area to cross the Atlantic Ocean centuries ago.

Good for day trip. This is good place for a daytrip. We started with tasting the "pastel de nata" pastery at a bakery cafe, then went on to the Jerónimos Monastery, then we went up to "Monument to the Discoveries tower" and ended with walk to the tower of belem.
Another must see. This beautiful tower, which used to serve as a fortress is located in Belem, just a little west from Lisbon centre. You can easily get there by bus or tram. It's a must see.

Something different. The Tower of Belem is something pretty rare these days: a defensive tower built in the shore of a big city. In the Tejo river, this place is a little bit claustrophobic but a good tip, specially to take your kids. They will be really joyous with this medieval film scenario and have lots of fun running up and down the numerous and endless staircases all over it.

Belem Tower. The Tower is beautiful and interesting, but visitor numbers are a serious problem. Numbers allowed in at any time are limited to 150, but even then they have to work a system of traffic control on the stairs to the upper floors, which doesn't always work very well and which significantly increases the time of the visit.

Beautiful view. I really like my trip to Belem .we took the 15 e tramway nice ride,we really like the church beautiful .The monastery I should have skip specially at 24 euro .The nice surprise was the tower ,92 steps to get up there but the view is beautiful and the breeze from the bay refreshing .
Like a boat, part of the river.. Turn back into history discovering the portuguese discoveries. This tower works as a reference for everyone visiting Lisbon and the river. Be part of it!

Outstanding historical building. Because of the movement of the river, this last castle which formerly guarded the entrance to the river inland is a most impressive moated medieval castle well worth a visit though long lines to enter.

Peaceful. Belem is a delightful area a 20 minute tram ride away from Lisbon. And the Tower of Belem is a beautiful monument where one truly gets the sense of those brave adventurers who left Portugal in search of the new world. Just sit on the steps and take in the sights and sea.
A must see. Beautifully set on the estuary, it is well worth visiting and enjoying the views from the top, especially on a sunny evening

History revives in front of you. It used to be an island from where the explorers used to begin their voyages. Now it is next to the coast waiting for you to visit it and teach you the Vasco da Gama & all other explorers way for living!

Beautiful site along the river in Lisbon. Located at the bank of the river in Lisbon this is a greaat place to visit. It is also surrounded by other beautiful monuments and buildings at walking distance.

Great views from the top. We visited this attraction using our Lisbon card. The Torre de Belem was defence tower built between 1514 – 1520. It was fairly busy when we went but well worth the climb to the top to see over the water and back towards the city of Lisbon. After visiting the tower it is worth taking a short walk away from the tower to visit the naval war memorial - beautiful sculpture with an eternal flame, guarded by sentries.

The Belem Tower.. A well preserved historical monument of the Portuguese Age of Discovery. When you visit, you feel you have taken a step back in time.The surrounding parks have many good sites to see and food to try.

Perfect view over Lisbon and Belem. A really amazing tower! It has a perfect view over Belem and Lisbon. On Sundays there is a free entrance in all the museums from 9 or 10 until 14h30. It worth the visit and you simply can't miss it since it's one of the most classic and most visited places in Belem

Nice to Stay. Torre de Belem is a great place to visit. If you are in Lisbon you must be there. Has the same importance than Torre Eiffel in Paris. You should go and will see history, tradition and beauty.
great place to explore. Wonderful place to explore, great location and cues not too bad. Lots of stairs so make sure you have good walking shoes.

Overrated .... We have visited Torre de Belem as it is one of the main Lisbon attractions. All in all, it is worth to pass by & take a photo but I would not recommend anyone to enter inside (as we did). Beside the view, there is nothing more ...

Nice but small. Luckily we entered before a hord of tourists came (the queues were rather long). I would say it is worth the visit. The view from the top is quite nice and you get an idea of what this tour or fort was used for back in the day. It is rather small so don't expect too much. I think we paid something like 20 euros per person to get in the tour including a visit of another attraction in Belem. So it is definitely not cheap.

Very nice place to visit . It is nice to climb and see the ocean from the tower. If you go, buy the ticket at the Jeronimo monastery (they have the monastery and tower visit for 12e) where only the monastery is 10e and tower is 5-6. This way you also skip a massive line at the tower, which was about 150 ppl when we were there. We were able to walk by with our tickets and get in right away.

Nice tower. The tower was very small and the queue was long,had to wait like half an hour.Once I got in I had to wait inside as well to go up on the tiny staircase as it was really busy with tourists.The view is amazing from the top but such a shame they were renovating this as well-could not take nice pictures.Worth getting the lisbon card so no need to pay the entrance fee but still have to queue.
Free bathrooms. Beautiful place to visit. The only bad thing is that it cost .50 euros to use the bathroom. It's time to provide free bathrooms and get rid of the stench in the bushes.

Beautiful!. We bought a combined ticket to visit the Belem Tower and the Mosteiros dos Jeronimos for 12 euros. The tower is located by the river Tejo and once you get up the tower you get an amazing view of Lisbon by the river.

Worth queuing for. Although we had to queue for some 20 minutes or so it was well worth the wait just for the views from the top of the tower. The winding staircase is steep so I wouldn't advise anyone with hip or knee problems to attempt it. As with all the attractions in Lisbon the entrance fee for the over 65s is very, very reasonable - only 3 euros.

Lots of tourists, not much to see.. I have to say, I only spent like half an hour there and I did not enter the Torre de Belem, because there were a lot of tourists queuing up for going to the top. The architecture of the tower is pretty picturesque, though, and the view of the bridge from the ground is quite nice.
Great view. very nice site to have a view on 25th april bridge. If you buy the ticket for the tower while visiting Jeronimos monastery you save time and money!
Not bad. The Torre is nice and interesting but was not my fave part of Belem. I could've skipped it but would not know that unless I had seen it! See for yourself and decide.

Impressive tower, so-so view. I must admit that I enjoyed Belem Tower more from the ground and the lower level than I did from the top. I was expecting to be blown away by the amazing view, but the tower honestly just isn't tall enough to see much from it. Yes, the 25th of April Bridge looks cool, but it looks just as cool from the ground. I was hoping for a different perspective on the Jeronimos Monastery, but again, the tower just wasn't tall enough. The building, however, is really cool - like other buildings in Belem, it was built in the Manueline architectural style not seen in other parts of Lisbon, or even Europe. Though if you're looking for an easy tower to climb, this is a good one - I did it while 7 months pregnant and it wasn't too bad. Definitely the first and last tower I climbed on our trip, though! You can get a combo pass for this tower with the Monastery, but if you can get the student rate at either, it's cheaper than the combo. I'll be using my student ID until that thing turns to shreds!* If you like my review, I appreciate you clicking the 'helpful' button; those of us who take the time to write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more :) *

Should be higher on the list. While it's simple and there isn't much to explore, the view is wonderful and the tower itself is truly iconic, one of the things you associate most with Lisbon. Was a pleasure to grab an ice cream and sit in the neighbouring waterfront cafe and just watch the bay. Highly recommend for a tranquil, beautiful experience.

Very bad organisation. As we were waiting we noticied that alot of people got to skip the que. We went in an it was a nice tower but again the organisation was terrible.As you get towards the top the stairs organisation was poor abd disappointing after all our waiting.

A must of Lisboa. Belém must be part of your Lisboa experience.The Jeronimos cloister is really the place to learn about and see the unique Manueline style. . The inner courtyard is so nice to overlook and to meditate about the great history of Portugal.After this, do the walk to the discoveries monument (what a grandeur) and then to the tower of Belèm. Combined ticket for 12 euros. And end with the Pasteis de Belèm. I have eaten 5 pieces. Slightly warm and very crispy. A real great moment.

Lisbon's icon & symbol. We didn't go up the tower but was satisfied to view the tower from the outside. As the icon/symbol of Lisbon, it certainly was a must go-to site in Lisbon. The only thing was that it was walkable, but quite a far walk from the other attractions in Belem. Upon reaching Belem, we visited Casa Pasteis de Belem first, followed by Jeronimos Monastery, then Monument to the Discoveries and then to Belem Tower. Tip: wear comfortable walking shoes & be prepared to do lots of walking
Fabulous. Portuguese Maritime Construction at its best. Some brilliant views of the river Tejo and towards the statue of Christ the King.

A very different Castle. Our first mistake was not buying a ticket for this attraction when we visited the Mosteiro dos Jerinimos - you can buy tickets to all the attractions in Belem at each of the attractions; this is not particularly clear when you arrive at the ticket booths. As a result we spent an hour queuing to get in. Admission is limited to about 150 people at one time and to walk around the place takes about an hour.Once inside it was very much a castle experience; the architecture was quite interesting. But the real fun began when we tried to ascend the spiral staircase; there is a "traffic light" system that broke down and the results were a bit chaotic - people passing on a spiral staircase is not ideal.There is little inside - but if you spend the time to read the information boards you will understand the history.The views were worth the trip to the top.

Quite a landmark!. Torre de Belem situated in the Belem district a short train ride from central Lisbon is stunning to look at. Built in the 16th century as a defensive fortification it is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.The queues to visit inside the tower were so long that we decided nt to go in. We did however have lunch at Café do Forte, which when facing the tower from the shoreline is situated just to the right. Here, we enjoyed freshly prepared food at a very reasonable price. If you go to Belem by train as we did, be prepared for the km walk from the station to the tower. Whilst in Belem do visit the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos and see the tomb of Vasco da Gama.
Wow nice. I went there with my family and friend,, really vary nice place for capturing good pic and sea view is awesome ,, I spend some time there ,, I enjoyed too much ,,,I love that,,,

More Impressive From The Outside. There's really not that much to see on the inside. It's your basic, unfurnished castle. The only highlight I can point out is the ornate spires on the main terrace of the castle. The view isn't that impressive. What I actually enjoyed most when I was there was the stormy weather. The waves crashing up against the stone walls of the tower made me think of how the first explorers setting out West would have felt when they ran into similar storms and would have loved the refuge of the castle. The rains also scared away most of the people in line, so many of the rooms were empty, which left me with plenty of space to wander around and watch the stormy waves from various little alcoves around the tower.
A must see. We visit the Torre de Bellem by taxi but public transport can be used. Free entrance. Lovely place to take photos. Must visit if you go to Lisbon.

Remarcable symbol. As the historic meaning of this monument it is a must to go place ins Lisbon. Great view from the top and great surroundings. Even for locals it is nice to go there!! Read about the portuguese history and find this fantastic landmark

Don't go to the top!. Great site. Yet you will be trapped! The number ov visitors on the stairs is strictly controlled and only one direction of travel is allowed. I got to the top of the tower and found a massive line waiting to come down. There is was stuck lining up to come down! The view was ok but not worth the wait. Observe the tower from the shore and save your time!

To do only because it's famous. some days free entrance. If you go to Lisbon, you have to visit the Belem Tower in Belem district even if it will not be the best visit of your life.if you don't read further, just know that some days the entrance is free (like Sundays or specials days that you have to check on the website)get your tickets on internet before to avoid the massive queue and look for combined tickets with other visits to save a few euros.ok about the visit itself now...the inside is quite poor for such a monument and only some panels will fill the empty walls and tell you a story about each room but nothing very spectacular.the more you climb the stairs, the best view you will get from the Targus river and the surroundings. you can make some serious panoramic pictures there. About the stairs, they installed a system of stop lights (red/green) to help tourists go in only one direction at the time but many don't respect it and you will end up blocked by a fat old lady and she will be angry at you for pointing out her mistake (or no respect of others)there is also a maximum number of visitors in the tower so if there is 2-3 tourists groups in front of you, you will have to wait for them to get out before they let you in.
Beautiful Tower - Get There Early. One of the top tourist attractions in Lisbon, that is well worth a visit. Just remember to get there earlier before the tour buses and hoards of tourists show up!

Quaint architecture.. Worth visiting it, a number of other landmark monuments in the Belem district. Right on the river with a huge park along the river. Great place to visit with small kids. Some restaurants along the river for food. Excellent seafood and lamb chops. House wine is fantastic every where you go if on a budget. Catch a nice view of the Vasco bridge and the Christ monument from the river side. The historic navigators monument is further up in that road with and amazing marina along the way. Don't miss the royal palace gates with the famous pastry shop further up the street. If you are interested in sailing and navigation, there is a whole museum at the end of the Abby/church.

Belem. Santa Maria de Belém is a suburb and civil parish of Lisbon. You can go to the tower de Belem, have some good Belem Pasteis. There are many other places/ buildings to visit. Take the Belem Tour Bus and enjoy your day.

Beautiful but crowded. Beautiful historical tower from 16 century situated on perfect location where other attractions are near by. Only remark are crowds and long lines for entering the tower which are oftenly not respected by many visitors. When you get inside you can not enjoy it as much as you would like again because of the crowds. Best to visit early in the morning or late afternoon.
Very very nice....a must see. The experience of going up is really fun doing...going don not always efficient with the "light system"!

Mixed feeling. I don't know how to rate this place as there are up side and down side:- Really easy to get there. You can take tram 15. Note: don't get off at station named "Belém". That name is very misleading. A lot of people got down there because of that name. You'll have to walk a lot. We prepared beforehand so we know that the station to get off should be "...da Princesa..." or "Pedrouços".- The overall scene is very beautiful. You have a river, fresh air, breeze, a fortress, a bridge that looks like the Golden gate from far away and a restaurant nearby, where they have glass wall and excellent view.- Things get stupid as it comes to queue and ticket. Same old story as for all attractions in Lisbon, it takes forever to get to the ticket booth! Seems that they only care for the money from tourists, but not the organizing. After 45 min in the queue, we gave up. Seems that we were lucky because a family which went out from the tower expressed their disappointment as they say "7.5€ each person for litteraly nothing". We believed her from our experience in Sintra.So the take away: You really should go to this place. Very nice landscape but just skip getting in the tower. Recharge your viagem ticket beforehand (best choice is full day ticket) otherwise it's 2.85€/single trip if you buy it on board.

Due to overwhelming tourism, plan well or it won't be fun. The torre of Belem as such is worth visiting. However, in high season it is so busy in Belem that you have to plan your trip well, or you will be stuck outside the torre for a long time (literally hours). Prices are also going up pretty steep, and really, it is not worth paying 6 euro's for it. However, follow this advice and all looks way better: Combine it with the fantastic Jeronimos Monastery. Then it is only 12 euro together instead of 6 for the torre or 10 (!) for the monastery. Moreover, go first to Jeronimos as the ticket line there is often less than 10 minutes, while we had to wait more than an hour in line for the Torre de Belem. Also, avoid the tourist bus hours. Go as early as possible, or very very late. Otherwise you will have to wait also a very long time to be able to go up the very small stairway inside the Tower. Don't expect a marvelous view either from on top of the Tower. If you'd like that, than the Vasco da Gama tower is way cheaper and higher.
A must see historic monument. This magnificent historic monument is a must see! Beautiful view on the Tejo river and other side of the coast and monument Christo Rei.

Historic Tower.. The Tower of Belem gives a significant historical & cultural reference point to Portugal`s past glory in its adventurious voyages of discoveries.It is a fortified tower built in the 16th century for the defence of system at the mouth of the Tagus river & a ceremonial gateway to the entry in to Lisbon!it consists of 4 floors with artillery guns positioned to allow for long distance gun firing.Climbing to the top of the tower you can have a lovely seacape view of the whole surroundings.considering its past association with Portugal`s history it has been declared as a UNESCO Heritage Monument.

Beautiful Scenery. Although it was a bit crowded, the tower is situated right on the ocean, and the scenery is quite beautiful. Belem is a short train ride away (15-20 min) from Lisbon, and worth the trip.
One of most beautiful places to visit in Lisbon. A palce to visit, with a magnificent, look to the Tejo, where always a mind wind is blowing. Why not to relax and take a tea at a bar close by.

Poorly organised, and a bit empty. As per other reviews, the queing system here is pretty stupid, as is the lack of information on offer about what's happening. Basically there'll be a long queue at any time of day, and it'll barely move because people will come up with tickets they've bought elsewhere. They'll use the exit line and that means the queue to enter for people without tickets simply doesn't move. When you get in, well, there's next to nothing in there. A row of cannon, a basement that's being painted (with no room to put anything in either), and then the tower itself. There's only one way up and down, on the same staircase, and using a traffic light system that everyone ignores which means more waiting. The view from the top is ok. Not as good as from the newer tower further down the coast though, so in all honesty, read about this place in a book, maybe look at it from the outside if you're in the area, but don't bother to go in.

Love it. The tower was supposed to serve a defensive purpose, but as with the monastery, they just couldn't stop piling on the details. Fun to walk around inside and out. There are at least three levels.

The Towers Okay but Don't Plan a Quick Visit. This is a nice tower and in places relatively interesting, however the middle floors don't have a lot to offer, other than some decent views over the river. The issue I have however with the Belem Tower is the dreadful organisation of people inside, we visited on a Saturday (so in some part we are to blame). However they have a traffic light system that people ignore and staff don't pay it much attention either. In total it took us about half an hour to climb the tower only to get the top to join a cue of about 200ish people and spend 45 minutes to descend including prolonged periods balancing on very small step in the tower. All this was on top of about a half hour cue to get in. All in all I wouldn't bother.
long lines. The tower looks nice and is also very interesting inside. The only problem is that they have very long waiting lines.

Worth a look.. Visited here at night after a long day sight seeing. Handsome tower in the water reached by a wooden bridge. Lovely spot to sit. Slipway down to the water is very slippery sometimes! Worth a look.

Beautiful tower, great views but horribly run. I actually felt sorry for the tower. It is so beautiful a place to visit and go into, with lovely views. However, the queues were crazy... I don't mind places being busy, especially in August, but the way the queues were handled was awful. A few days before I visited a place with a little tower and had a photo taken as a 'princess in a tower', but in belém I actually felt trapped in the tower. They have a timed system to go up and down the spiral staircase to get to the top and green and red (stop and go) lights to control the flow of people. In theory, this maybe should work, but it didn't, not the day I visited anyway. Something working in theory is fine, but it assumes the visitors, (actually humans :p) are robots... That no one will be slower, or feel a little shaky/nervous in the narrow stairwell... Or God forbid fall (there'd be no time for that!!!) It also assumes that everyone will follow this system, which you'd hope would be the case, but remember humans...Anyway, it was an absolute nightmare. There were people not following the system because they either got aggravated or panicked by being stuck in a room off the stairwell for longer than the timer said and missing their chance to go... Or because initially one lot took that little bitlonger to ascend/descend than the timer allowed... On my ascent, through to the stairwell when it went green for go, when we were nearing the top a loud alarm started beeping at us... But we didn't know what this meant. When we got to the top, a man at the top of his queue to descend was shouting at us that we must stop coming up as it was their turn to come down, but there was nothing we could do at that stage... This was obviously what the alarm was about. This man was just another visitor who was aggravated by the system... There was nobody at each level to explain or facilitate this system which would definitely have helped, even if just for a sense of calm and knowing what the was going on.On my descent, after queuing awhile for this, I quickly realised that I was behind an older lady who was a little slower on her feet, but who had, fair play to her, managed to get up to the top (and why shouldn't she, if she wanted to and was able?). This made our descent slower naturally andwe essentially ran out of time to all get down before the people downstairs were given the green light to ascend, which led to chaos and arguments and us being forced into a small room... This led further to people getting irrate and suggesting that we all just go anyway without the green light, having already miss one turn to go because there were still people going up and down the stairs... Obviously, I could understand this man's frustration but was also having visions of a terrible accident on the stairwell if we proceeded with his plan. Eventually someone who worked in the tower came up and sorted the situation but as a visitor, on my own, I was very near a panic attack and was never so relieved to be out of a place. There has to be a better way of doing things to prevent this sort of situation developing again. Perhaps it was a one off and maybe it works very well most of the time but there needs to be allowances for the fact that people are people and don't always act predictability. Some people don't follow the system, probably more likely when this system is not explained or facilitated at all, or because people all move at different paces for a variety of legitimate reasons...Newgrange in Ireland has only one way in and out and is quite tight, so they just also a certain amount of people in at a time at allocated times, with a guide. Perhaps something similar should be in place here, or at least clear instructions and explanations upon entering the tower, when your ticketsare validated, along with a person working there at each level to ensure everything runs smoothly.Was extremely disappointed with my visit, as well as quite stressed and angry.
Impressive. Nice to look at.We did not enter the Tower as we came with a tour group.There is a tree with lots of white flowers just outside the Tower.

Great from the outside, doesn't offer much inside. We bought a joint ticket for this at the Jeronimos Monastery, saving a few euros. It also meant we could skip the queue for this attraction and walk in the 'exit' line, going straight up to the security guard with our ticket, and he scanned it and let us in (cue grumblings from the queue :-) ).Inside was not, however, all that impressive. A few cannons, a dungeon, and a very narrow winding staircase to the roof, with a traffic light system for up/down that mostly failed to control the flow of people at all as a) there were so many people who just ignored it, and b) it didn't allow enough time for the last person of the previous group to get up/down before changing the direction. So the queue to get off the roof went round and round the roof in a spiral formation, with a 15 minute wait to get down. The Torre de Belem is quite interesting from the outside, and reading about its history on the information boards makes for a moderately interesting visit, but overall I was left just a little underwhelmed by it. Especially when the views from the top are nowhere near as impressive as from the much cheaper Discoveries Monument a couple of hundred metres away.
Beautiful, but Busy. The tower is worth seeing, but the queue to get in was too long. I would recommend going very early, between 2 and 3 or late.

Gate-Keeper into Lisbon via the Tagus River. Being a World Heritage Site it is a must see. The construction of the building is impressive. We particularly enjoyed watching the tourists navigate the lighting system setup for the spiral staircase. Some got it and some didn't which created some entertainment. This was one of my must see's in Lisbon and I wasn't disappointed.

Not to be missed. Watch out for the gypsies out front who are very harassing and intimidating.
The tower is a real feat of engineering, with great views if you persevere to the top.
Tips: avoid when parties of tour buses are around; buy combination tickets here to skip queues elsewhere.

queues, queues. okay so we didn't actually go in...big queues in the sun. ..but was great to look at and the kids loved the parkland around. We stopped by the nearby café for lunch which was perfectly acceptable.

Beautiful district. About 15 minutes by tram from the center of Lisbon (Tram n°15), you can visit Belem, which is really touristic for the typical pasteleria (you have to taste one of these specialties : Casa Pasteis De Belem) and for the Gold Tower.At the waterfront, the tower is beautiful, but the context more. Sunny walk to the Belem Tower. This is one of the must see sights of Lisbon. Beautiful Architecture!. This is a unique place, beautiful! There is a green square around the tower where you can sit relax and enjoy the view. Best pictures are from the left side of it, with no tourists there.

Baking in the Midday Sun. The exterior of the tower is beautiful, as is its location, and the inside is worth a short visit (there is no furniture) if you don't mind standing in the midday sun outside for 90 minutes! My husband and I and our two sons arrived at 11.15am and there was a long queue down as far as the end of the bridge (approx 100 people). The sun was strong and there was no shade. However, we expected the queue to move at a reasonable pace and estimated we would get in to the tower in about 30 minutes once those who had gone in at the 10am opening time were finished with their visit. But after 30 minutes queueing we realised that some new people arriving were bypassing the queue and going straight in. We wondered why. When this continued, we asked a very nice young man working at the tower and he explained that these were people who had purchased a dual ticket over at the nearby Jeronimo Monastery and they were therefore allowed to skip the queue. However, when a flood of people came streaming up the line past us over the next 30 minutes, we, and some other people in the queue, were not at all pleased and protested strongly. We felt we had little hope of getting in at all if this continued and we should have been made aware of this when we started queueing. We were also baking under the midday sun. The person in charge of the tower that day apologised but said these people were entitled to bypass the queue. Having spent one hour already in the queue, we were reluctant to walk away, as some did. When we got to the top of the queue after 90 minutes queueing we saw a notice inside at the ticket desk saying that the maximum number allowed in the tower at any one time is 150 people and that people with dual tickets were priority visitors, as are pre-booked groups and groups with vouchers. Other priority visitors include pregnant women, families with small children, disabled persons and elderly people – these exceptions are acceptable. If the tower can only take 150 people inside, then this should be stated on a notice down at the bridge, not just at the ticket desk inside. This notice should also give the list of those who can bypass the queue so that those queueing can make an informed decision as to whether or not they wish to stand outside in the hot sun for a long time. It would also be helpful if those in the queue were given an estimate of how long they might be standing in the heat outside. Umbrellas to offer shade should also be made available as there is no canopy to escape the sun. The dual ticket system for this tower is not a good idea, nor the fact that groups can bypass the queue. Is there a limit to the size of groups who can bypass? You can purchase a dual ticket at the Belem Tower for the Jeronimo Monastery – that building can take far more people at any one time so the queue moves much faster than at the tower and the queue is mostly shaded by the building. If those who are in charge of the entrance system at the tower do not change the policy regarding queueing, then I would advise visitors to think carefully before they join the queue at this site.

Impressing historical monument. Good location, impressing tower near the San Jeronimo monastry and the great portughese sailors monument. This old tower is much more impressing than the neglected new nearby monument.

The tower of Belem surprises!. The immersion is spectacular, but the Tower of Belem surprises.It is worth visiting this monument, but I recommend you take a friend or even a professional guide, because the whole of the richness of this structure is hidden details of architectural and historical.
Obligatory place in Lisbon?. Place of tourist's pilgrim ("Look, I have been here!"). It is nice and stylish but its hard to imagine somebody goes to Belem only for this place.

Most beautiful and exquisite landmark in Lisbon. The most beautiful Military fort with exquisite stone carvings and sculptures a world class landmark .
Unmissable Manueline tower.
Great architecture. Cannot believe we did this on the second to last day there....that's what happens when you rush. Next time we will take our time. Beautiful structure.
great views. Be there either early in the morning or late in the afternoon due to big queues. They only let a certain number of people in at a time so it's never crowded.

Lovely. It's not the visiting,it's the view.You will climb thousand of stairs until you reach the top,but once you are up you will be overwhelmed by the beauty of the ocean!Outside of the torre de Belem it's like a small beach where you can walk barefoot through the ocean.

Beautiful architecture. We arrived around 11 today, and the line was massive. That wasn't the problem as much as the fact that it was moving inches at a time. External beauty & internal shambles. Really beautiful location with a great landscape. Really poor organization for the huge amount of people coming here every day. Unacceptable caos of lines in every floor and at the entrance.

Sensational views. From memory this place is free on Sundays but that meant there were significant queues. Once you get up though its all worthwhile. Great views over the bay and towards the city. Wonderful history and perspective.
Wonderful view. I loved the view from the tower. At 3 Euros the price was reasonable and I got to take fantastic photos of the plaza mosaic and the monastery.

Beautiful to see but overrated for what it is. The good: As this structure is one of Lisbon's top sites to see we had bought a combined ticket with entry to the tower and the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. The building itself is beautiful and gives you a little bit a time travel experience how the city used to be protected from the seaside.The bad: Unfortunately it is a big miss when it comes to detailed explanation how certain floors within the tower have been used and the rooms are all blank and empty. As only a small staircase connects all floors the visitor flow is managed by traffic lights on each level which could work if people would pay attention to them. So basically you end up waiting on each level to go up or down, which can lead to sunburn on the rooftop level as you eventually arrive on top of the tower just to immediately go back in line to head down and there is no shade to protect you from the burning sun.The conclusion: Although the building itself is impressive to see and gives you a slight idea how the city defended itself against intruders from the sea it isn't really worth the wait in line to get in. You easily can enjoy the building sitting in a nearby seaside cafe or sitting on the steps leading down to the Atlantic Ocean.
Don't miss. One of the most important sites in Lisbon. Helps you understand the history of the city. Doesn't take long, but very important.

Worth a miss. This was listed as the #1 site to visit in Lisbon, so we dutifully headed there, having first visited the beautiful Monasterio dos jeronimos (definitely a must see, if your heart is set on the tower then get the joint ticket). Having waited in a queue for 30 minutes, we were admitted to the tower - there is very little in the way of explanations for why the tower is there or what it was so if you don't have a guide book you'll be a bit lost. There is a second floor terrace and from there a spiral staircase leading to upper levels and the roof. There's only one spiral staircase to go up and down, controlled by a traffic light system. One 'set" of lights was broken while we were there meaning people were heading up and down simultaneously, which felt very claustrophobic and pretty unsafe. Once we arrived at the top, we found that we just had to join a lengthy queue to head back down - seeing the view during your queuing time. The view itself was underwhelming. I really don't feel I'd have missed much If I'd come back from Lisbon without visiting the Torre.

Do yourself a favour...go to the monastery first . There is a combined ticket you can purchase at the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos for €12 or €6 if you are a student. Lovely views of the Rio Tagus and the Torre. We arrived at the Torre late in the afternoon so we weren't able to go inside and ascend to the top. From the top of the tower, terrific view of the Tagus River. Belem, a suburb of Lisbon, has many interesting sites (all within easy walking distance of one another), including Jeronimos Monastery (listed separately on its own Trip Advisor site), the Maritime Museum, the National Archaeological Museum, the Naval Museum, the Discoveries Monument and Belem Tower.The Belem Tower - always very popular with tourists - is a UNESCO World Heritage site.It's a fairly challenging climb up a narrow circular staircase to reach the top level of the tower, but the view from the top is superb.The earlier one gets there, the better: fewer tourists jostling about and cluttering up one's pictures.A very interesting and unusual structure.

Built for the posterity. First King John II in the 16th century recognised, that the defences of Lisbon were insufficient. He wanted some sufficient fortification along the mouth of the Tagus River, but he died, and only 20 years later on King Manuel I of Portugal ordered the construction of a military fortification around the beach of Belem.The rectangular Bastion was a later addition, when some years later on the king was advised that the Belém Tower "should be strengthened, repaired and completed...”Despite these efforts, just some years after the Tower was finished, in 1580, after a short combat, the garrison defending the Tower surrendered to Spanish forces.Reading the history of Belem Tower put a question mark into my mind. Was it worthwhile all the effort and expenses to build it?Oh, yes! For the posterity it was. This very powerful rectangular tower, floating surprisingly graciously in the water, catches your eyes from some distance. The finesse of the building,and the interesting details are inviting you to get closer, and closer.Never mind the crowd and the queuing; it is definitely some of the MUST SEE places in Lisbon. Better start with the Jeronimos Monastery and buy there the double ticket; it makes your waiting shorter. We used the No 15 tram to get there. It was overcrowded and hot, but we had worse experiences already, and it was only a minor problem.After the visit I had only one dilemma. We couldn't decide, that it was more beautiful from outside, or in.
Good view,nice walk in Belem. It's nice to view, even with all of the tourists. Wouldn't sure I'd spend much time there, but it's in the Belem area which is well worth the time.

Don't miss it. The tower is a landmark of Lisbon. Be sure to visit.Located on the board of the Tejo River and cross the bridge that connects the mainland to the Tower. You will be entering in a world of a past adventures and navigation histories.

Pretty to look at. With all the hype there is on Belem we were of course not surprised to be met by an enormous crowd of human beings attempting to go into the tower itself. It is basically a harbor, tourist restaurants and a nice building. However, I do believe it would have been a more interesting experience if the crowd had not discouraged us from going into the tower :-)

A tower to see. its a tower with about 7 floor, we went on monday and it was closed so make sure you check its opening timings as we didnt get the chance to enter it so we had to see it from outside only.If you are going makesure you visit the monastery as well.
Impressive Monument. Very impressive monument with a great location. So much to see in just one location. The river and background monuments are great to experience as well.

Worth the queue!. We chose to visit here on the hottest day of our holiday, great for views, terrible for queuing - there is no cover so you are exposed to the elements. This queue was huge and took over an hour, a tip we found out after though - you can buy a joint ticket at the monestary which is close by, this not only offers you discount, it also lets you push to the front of the queue past fools like us. This is key, as due to the size of the tower they only let a fixed number of people in at once.note there are loads of stairs - not suitable if you are likely to struggle!Hope this helps as this is a must see sight and well worth the effort! Where the caravels sailed to explore the world.. This place is simply magical.. Where Vasco Da Gama & his sailors set sail and found the new trade route to India for spices.A must see in Lisbon! No question.

The gate to the ocean. Belem is a very exciting area to spend a day in. Alle the parks and very interesting statues/monuments to visit. The Torre de Belem was avery interesting and informative place to visit. A lot of history to get known to.
Amazing building. Discovered a whole new style of architecture in this stunning building from the height of Lisbon's power. Quite a walk from the station though.

Nice monument. Nice monument located in a very nice place, Tejo river sideplace. It is far from the main city but there are a lot of public transportation. It's worth to visit Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and Padrão dos Descobrimentos nearby.

A tower to meet sailors. Far from the center of the city. It's open only until 19:00. So, if you wanna visit inside be aware of it. We would be able to enter :-( Some nice restaurants nearby. Please take into account that after 22:00 you will have problems with public transport.

Not as big as we expected. We had taken a tram and then walked out here as it was highly recommended. However, when we got there, there was a big and very slow moving queue. We decided just to admire it from the outside. It is in a great location and there is lots more to see in Belem

Lovely area. Torre de Belem is one of the cites to see in this area by the water. So it is really a day trip. must to go. very interest place, the castle to defense the Tejo access the the airplane to cross the Atlantic with 2 crazy portuguese pilots aboard a unbeliever airplane

Worth a visit.... Long way from city but with a variety of tranport methods available. Can get busy but we were lucky and there was a short queue so we decided to pay the money - 6 Euro. It is an astounding building with great views to the river. Interesting system in place for getting up and down as the stairs are too narrow for 2 way traffic. But then have to wait for the green light again!There are other attractions nearby and makes the visit to the area well worth it.

Spectacular ancient tower on the glittering Rio Tejo. This 16th century tower is a stunning piece of architecture and beautifully situated on the Rio Tejo. Climb to the top to take in stunning views; walk around the plaza and the riverfront below. Nearby is a superb Museum of Contemporary Art (maybe 10 minutes walk from the Tower, on your way to or from the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos). The museum, Museu Colleccao Berardo, is free, and offers a world-class collection of modern art plus welcome air conditioning and shade on a hot day - not to be missed!
Sightseeing Belem. The area is a must to see for Lissabon visitors. There are so many sights but the tram ride was really hot!

Interesting Moorish tower. The architecture of this tower is breathtaking but avoid visiting when it's crowded with tourists. There is a one-way system on the narrow and winding staircases and sightseeing may a bit dissapointing.

Interesting. The tower itself is really interesting not only from the point of view of history but as a piece of old architecture as well. The winding staircase inside is really breathtaking, so steep and narrow that they have lights showing the direction you can go - a great idea by the way. Do not go inside if you suffer from claustrophobia or are afraid of heights. There is a lot of visitors so during the high season be prepared to spent an important amount of time waiting (I spent about an hour waiting for tickets). If you go to Belem and plan to visit more attractions (monastery, museums etc.) it is definitly worth buying the Lisbon card.

Gret view from outside. This structure served as a Customs Building in its past, as well as offering protection, too. It exhibits Moorish influence and Knights Templar influence (shield motif).As far as spending money for a tour, the tower is empty and costs 5 Euros to go inside. There is a staircase to climb. It sits on the water and there is so much to see and do in this park-like setting besides waiting in line.A really interesting statue monument (or maybe it's more like a tower) depicts Lisbon in its Golden Age. Built in about 1960, Prince Henry the Navigator and a whole slew of supporting characters make their way up and to the top most focal point of this parade. The woman on her knees on the monument is the Queen of Portugal (Philipia of Lancaster), mother of Prince Henry.The cross and sword shown as going around the world represents the spread of Christianity. The tower of Belem is the symbol of Lisbon and the 13 year war between Portugal and its colonies. This monument is a memorial to the "colonial national" war. The park near the water and these delightful structures offers a separate show daily. While we were there, we saw the Catalunyan Human Tower prepare for their attention-getting sash-wrapping show. In time, it would be a really big stack of people. The wrapping of the sashes (to keep their intestines in one place under pressure? I can only surmise this is the purpose) was all we witnessed. Sadly, the tour bus keeps rolling along and so (not so sadly) does this Catalonyan spirit of independence.

Lisbon Belem Tower. It`s fantastic, because all the ships to discovery the south Americas departured here. The tower is about 12 metres (39 ft) wide and 30 metres (98 ft) tall. On the first floor interior of the Tower is the Sala do Governador (Governors Hall), an octagonal space that opens into the cistern, while in the north-east and north-west corners there are corridors that link to the bartizans. A small door provides access via a spiral staircase to the subsequent floors. On the second floor, the Sala dos Reis (King's Hall) opens to the loggia (to overlook the river), while a small corner fireplace extends from this floor to the third floor fireplace in the Sala das Audiências (Audience Hall). All three floor ceilings are covered in hollow concrete slabs. The fourth floor chapel is covered in a vaulted rib ceiling with niches emblematic of the Manueline style, supported by carved corbels.

Visit later in the day.. A nice stop but not as old as some of the other tourist monuments in Lisbon. Full of tourists so mostly you get lots of tourists in your photos. Good to visit late in the day after the cruise ship passengers leave.

Iconic and historic - great visit. The iconic Lisbon tower is well worth a visit. Closed on Mondays!! If you go, be sure to try the famous Lisbon pastries down the street at Pasteis de Belem

Neat structure. This is a neat old piece of Portuguese history - a fort that helped protect the city. Get there when it opens and buy the ticket that gets you into the other attractions to avoid all lines for the day.
amazing. It was our third day in Lisbon.Now we made a plan to visit Belem.We tried here Pastel De nata ,the famous dish of Portugal.We visited the famous church of here, was amazing.

Worth the wait. While we had to wait in the hot sun to enter this world heritage site, it was worth it. Great exhibit with clearly marked stairways to the top. We had to buy the guide for one Euro, but it definitely helped us understand the space better. My husband is an architect and he thoroughly enjoyed seeing this monument.

Great Views and Nice Short Visit. I visited early in the morning haveing gone in the middle of the afternoon to find it busy and as the queue is in the hot sun we didnt want to wait too long so i would recommend going in the morning. The tower itself is lovely to visit, lots of open space and tons of views over the tagus and of lisbon city. The only draw back is the climb up the one flight of narrow stairs to the top of the tower as if it had been busier there will be some small waits to allow and even amount of people go up and down but its definitely worth going to the top to look over the city and see the rooms and little nooks all the way up!! Even if you dont go up to the tower there can be planty of photos take from outside and around the area which has some little stalls and cafes to grab something to eat.

INTERESTING HISTORY AND ARCHITECTURE. It was constructed in the early 1500s, of limestone, and now sits on the northern bank of the Tagus River. There's a bastion and a tower of four stories. Guard posts. Wide interior archways. Small balconies. Period canons on carriages in position. It's a trip back in time that's well worth a visit. Come early as access to this historical site is limited to a certain number of visitors at a time.
Nice monument. It's not amazing until you stand right next to that tower, it makes you feel as if you're back in time, great location, good for pictures...

Long wait but definitely worth it.. We waited at least an hour and after a while it got old when five adults with a kid in a stroller got preferential treatment. A very pregnant women even stood on line....she should have gotten in straight away. Adult ticket is 6 euros. Free first Sunday of the month. Since only 150 are let in at one time the tower wasn't crowded and no jostling for views. Go early and be prepared to wait. It's worth it.
history. so much that to learn, beautiful, not to expensive to get in, location is just absolutely amazing, very close to the water. also few attraction around the area.

Gorgeous. One of the best pieces of Portuguese Manueline architecture in Lisbon, it definitely deserves a place on your list if you're in town. An easy walk from the Jerónimos Monastery you can purchase tickets to see both there. Make sure to climb to the top to see views of the 25 de Abril Bridge.
Lovely area. This is where you can find great art and architecture as well as the best Pasteis de Natal in Lisbon.

so nice view. Nice place for visiting. i had the opportunity to take great pictures in this tower. the water, the sunset! nice monument. i went by myself and i really spent a good time. Sunny day its perfect for going there

Small, Crowded and Worth IT!. Amazing landmark dating for the 1200's. You can go all the way to the top but because the staircase is small you have to wait for the buzzer to tell you up and down every 2-3mins. Go early as this gets crowded and the line can get long. UNESCO worthy, but.... Didn't go into the tower itself, just walked around it taking pictures and that was enough for me to get a glimpse of the past. Also, if you take the tram no. 15, you might wait a while, since I waited for 20 minutes when going there and around 30 minutes when going back.
old fortress - great old building. Enjoyed this fortress. Was a good old building with great detail in the stone work.A good spot to view parts of the city.
Nice monument. Nice monument honoring the great Portuguese explorers. Beautiful views from the top of the surrounding area and the bridge.

Good views but meh. Not much to see really. If it weren't so cheap to enter, I would have recommended that you skip it and just take photos from the outside. Lots of stairs to climb to get to the top, from which you do get some nice views but nowhere close to the best viewpoints in Lisbon. The building has an interesting history, anyway. Careful for low head spaces at times.

Excellent place!. Located at the modern part of the city, it is very impressive and in a very good condition. Don't miss the chance to have a coffe or snack at the nearby cafe, having a great view to the Torre. It worths a visit, because apart from the monument itself , you can walk to the Jeronymos Monastery, Padrão dos Descobrimentos and a lot of museums!

A beautiful white tower between blue sky & sea. All the reviews do this place justice. Definitely spend a day wandering around Belem. In a previous review someone mentioned getting to Monasterio de Los Jeronimos before the tour buses - very good advice! It is a beautiful place. You can go into the church for free but buy your ticket in the ticket office on left- hand side for entrance to the monastery and take in the wonderful architecture. Loved this area, take time to savour it. From Rossio take the 15e tram to the monastery and have €2.85 in change if you don't have a travel card....there are ticket machines on board.

Take the No. 15 canary yellow old tram from near Rossio metro. I see the "official" description suggests 2-3 hours - under one hour for me was plenty and fulfilling. Here's a tip. Visit the Jerome Monastery first. There are long queues always - but buy a multi-entry pass - mine cost 12 Euros (including a small discount). Then march to the top of the Tower queue waiting to buy their ticket and get in without waiting! Bonus. It takes about 10-15 minutes to walk from the monastery to the tower. If you are staying near Rossio metro you could also find the tram stop for the No. 15 retro wooden tram (the canary yellow one featured on all the tourism products) - [look for the queues of tourists!] I bought my ticket in the subway with the help of one of the marvellous English speaking staff [3.30 Euro return - including REUSABLE transport card]. I thought I was to travel Rossio-Belen via subway - but he steered me to the charming historic tram instead. To get home via the same route several air conditioned buses or the No.15 modern yellow tram were available. No old tram - don't know why.

Living history. There's nothing I can add to the thousands of positive and well deserved reviews this place has received except this... we are all fortunate that the City of Lisbon has managed to keep this marvellous place in such good condition. It's an absolute thrill to be able to walk across the same stone floors, climb the same stone stairs, hold the same stone columns for support that the inhabitants of this place did 500 years ago. For us, a highlight of our trip to Lisbon.

Beautiful. Go by tranvia. You can spend there whole the morming visiting Torre de Belem, Monasterio de los Jeronimos and Monumento de los Descubridores. You can taste the pastel of Belem. Relax walking along the river and the parks.

Fairytale white tower on water. A pretty white stone fairytale fort and tower stuck into the water with water on all four sides at high tides.You can enter - there’s a fee - when it’s open, do check, and morning city coach tours seem to time it to arrive before it opens in the morning – presumably so passengers can’t delayed inside.Can get very crowded.

Wonderfull place. Just Been there makes you go to the back to those days of kings and princess it's just astonishing place, on the beach, who had a castle with a private beach...? Incredible place, we loved it and want to go back again, believe or not, we spend the whole day the first day, and half day the second, on top of that makes you feel better listening the Latin music form and street artist, makes things better... The guy it's incredible play his music and sell CDs... Also close to the momument of war and museum, simply... astonishing...!! The best place I highly recommend.... Take water, lunch, because the restaurant close by is quite expensive..... And after that... Enjoy..!!!

The symbol of Lisbon. The Torre de Belem, Discovery Monument and Jeronimos monastery can be covered in a day. We were a little underwhelmed with the Torre de Belem after seeing the Jeronimos monsatery. So try and keep Jeronimos for last to enjoy the Torre. The views are lovely!

Must see. The Tower of Belem is one of the best-known historical landmarks of Portugal. The tower seen from outside is beautiful, huge, and really impressive. A must visit when in Lisbon along with the Jeronimos monastry. Also we enjoy to take the historical tram 28 while we are in Lisbon. We discovered also a big market hall which is not used any more and when coming closer there was a senior dancing competition on the 1st floor.
Historic and beautiful. Fantastic views! Picturesque and lots of opportunities for photos. Located next to the water. Great place to get the feel of a tower and castle.

interesting site. It was an interesting trip by train and we visited a convent also that was very interesting for us and includes 2 more museums-the maritime museum that is also interesting if you have time.After this visit we had a nice walked to the tower
interesting. when we were there it was closed so we couldn't go in. the area around it is also worth seeing: the park . statue and the mosaic
Impressive Sight. Very impressive guard towert with lovely views over the Tagus river . Pleasant place for a seaside stroll.

One of the Seven Wonders of Portugal. When this tower was first built it was meant to be a defensive platform for Lisbon and it was surrounded by water. Currently it is mostly part of land. It has had several different uses including as a prison for political prisoners during the reign of Filipe of Spain. It was named one of the seven wonders of Portugal and it is a known landmark representing Lisbon. The stairs up to the terrace are one way only (look for the red and green light that lets you know if anyone else is climbing them in opposite direction before starting your journey up to the terrace), but once on the terrace you can take amazing photo shots, specially if you are there close to sunset.

See it from outside. We didn't bother going into the tower, as it's only 3 floors tall, and you can get equally fantastic views from the footbridge (which goes across the railway lines) a few yards away!Don't bother going in, but rather soak up the views from the waterfront walkway. There is also a little cheap café with outdoor seating on the river. It is just across from the Torre - that way you can enjoy both the river views AND the views of the tower :)

Interesting...great views...can be crowded. We were there on the first Sunday of the month which was free admittance. It was crowded, but the weather was wonderful also, so that brought many people out. Interesting history and narrow stairways create a touch of Portugal past. I would recommend this site as a must-do in Lisbon.

Loved the Torre de Belem. Great time - just remember it is closed on Monday's.... cause we almost forgot. There is a red light / green light system so you know when you can go up or down the stairs since it is one way. Unfortunately people didn't quite realize this and many who did ignored it. Works really smoothly if we all play together .
Historical. Ok it's a centuries old tower . If you are in Belem stay here 10 minutes & go find the bakery that makes the cheese tarts!
Totally worth it!. It was beautiful and I got some gorgeous photos. Sometimes I'm all about the interesting architecture. This did not disappoint.
A beautiful site!. An excellent example of the Manuelista style of architecture! Very beautiful site on the Tagus River! A MUST SEE for Lisbon!
Nice views and history. Enjoyed a wander up the towerBit crowded and some people who were selfish caused jams by not following the rules on one way systemThe place is worth a visit

An impressive monument. Although we did not go inside this monument (previously a guard position to safeguard the city) it is worth a stop just to walk around and look at the historical figures on this piece. See if you can guess the famous explorers on this monument.
Gorgeous fantasy beauty spot. So lovely and peaceful part to visit. Stunning photo oppurtunityDon't go on a Monday as you cannot get inside the Tower

Nice place to visit. NIce place to visit but I think that should have something more inside. After the second floor everything was the same, a big empty room made of stone. But on the last floor you have an excellent view.

Not worth the hassle.. While the building was pretty, I wouldn't stay the views from the top - equivalent to 3 stories or so - are all that spectacular for the entrance fee and the annoying stair- climbing experience. Traffic on the 1.5 foot wide circular staircase is controlled by a timed video screen with arrows that no one follows, which sometimes resulted in shouting to those frustrated with others who didn't wait their turn. Human attendants could probably have solved this.

Small, but worth it. The Tower of Belem is one of the best-known historical landmarks of Portugal, and it oozes with tales from the past. It is very close to the Jeronimos Monastery, and you will be able to enjoy a nice view over the river or sit down at the green gardens nearby.

U can not enter after 18h. And u need to buy the tickets even earlier. The man guarding the entrance as it would still be a fortress is not friendly. The tower is way smaller then expected. But also nice to watch from the outside

A nice day out. Set of the banks of the river, it is about a 12 minutes walk from the monastery. It's a very picturesque setting, and worth the walk. It's not terribly impressive in side, but is quite old and ornate.
Not enough information. What a great place , great views and lots to see inside , thought this is somewhat spoiled by there being Very little information in English as to what room had what purpose.

Interesting and worth a visit. Although small, the tower is interesting historically and from an architectural point of view. Plenty of English translations so you can enjoy the history. Fascinating to understand that the tower, when built, was in the middle of the river and is now on the bank, such has been the movement of the river over 500 years. Good views are provided from the top of the tower.Queues can be long.A tip: We caught the red line Hop On Hop Off bus to the tower (as well as having purchased online from home, the Lisboa Card), allowing us to explore the area and entry into the tower, Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, Museu de Marinha and the Museu Nacional dos Coches. The Padros dos Descobrimentos (Discoveries Monument) is also a short walk from the tower and worth seeing, but not included on the Card. Don't forget the Pasteis de Belem for your custard tart fix, which is also in the general area.
Just a tower.... To clarify: at this stage we were getting sick of paying into attractions. So, we didn't go in. Took some lovely photos, enjoyed the park and walked around the area.

Wonderful little tower. This is one of my favourite attractions in Lisbon. It is quite small and does not take too long to see, but it is lovely to simply sit and enjoy the view, the architecture and the sea breeze from the tower. It is a mixture of styles and everywhere you look, there is something else to see. The tower has a set of circular stairs, but very cleverly there is a traffic light system (which unfortunately some chose to ignore) to try to minimise any clashes in travel direction. This is such a lovely site to see and is an absolute must while in Lisbon.Of note, you can buy a combined ticket to the tower and to Jeronimos which will save you some money

Amazing "Little Castle" On The Water. After having been down the street at Padrao dos Descobrimentos monument, we told our taxi driver to take us to Torre De Belem. It such a cool little castle on the water - although much bigger when you stand in front of it. Great touristy pictures are easily had from 3 sides. Worth the time to get over here and see it.(To Travel Is To Live)

Haven't been inside. I haven't been inside, but the whole thing seen from outside is beautiful, huge, and really impressive.
The architecture, the size, the power that it transmits is amazing.
It's possible to be seen from many spots, but it's also worth it walk until there. Very easy to get there from the city center.
