A tower with beautiful surroundings. It is a must visit when in Lisbon along with the Jeronimos monastry. The walk from Age of Discovery monument in front of the monastry to Belem tower is a must do. Offers great views of the 25th April bridge as well!
Unique structure. A 'one-of-a-kind' structure. It's an old fort set at the mouth of the river and have many unique architectural features. Well worth a quick visit.

Get there early, long queues. Try to get there early to avoid queues. We went in the last week of May and it was busy, can't imagine what it must be like in July. Bring a hat, there isn't much shade around.

Climb the tower!. Its a very interesting historical tower with very scenic views of the river. However, if you are a bit claustrophobic you may find the narrow staircase a little daunt. All together very good fun to visit for not much money.

Torre de Belem, Lisbon, Portugal spectacular. We went to Torre de Belem in Lisbon! Portugal recently. We bought a original water color from the artist. We saw the suspension bridge and the Christ the redeemer statue we saw the Geronimo cathedral and the river as well as the park, the Monument to the Discoveries are close by. This is not to be missed. We had a Belem pastry. Delicious

Average tour. It really amounted to a tour of the monastery and chapel, which was good but extremely crowded, and entrance to the museum of modern art which was not my thing. It was more a museum to the mediocrity of 20th century non-artists. Just my opinion.Think I would just see the chapel on my own.

Great views. The tower is easy to get to from the train station. If you want to go directly there, stay on the side of the tracks where you get out. The tower is about a 8 minute walk from the train. Make sure you take the stairs to the top of the tower. Great views of the bridge and the monument. Loved the 'stop and go' lights to climb the tower!

A UNESCO World Heritage Site. Tip: visit early on Sunday before noon for free entry and to avoid dense crowds. Belem is a town west of the Lisbon city center so you have to take a 10-minute train ride to arrive here, but it's worth a visit if you have a hour or two to kill. This tower served as a fortress at the mouth of the river to protect the city during the Middle Ages, so you'll get quite a history lesson when you visit. It's an interesting experience, but isn't a must-see if you have a packed schedule. It does offer a good view of the bay when you get to the top, although the tiny spiral staircase leading you there is very inefficient considering the volume of visitors it must accommodate. Bottom line is that you should visit if you have time, but forego if you don't.

getting there is half the fun. Growing up in Johannesburg's East suburbs we had a chain of coffee shops called Belem with a logo of a white tower - it had always intrigued me as to what this place was and why it was so important to the Portuguese community. Belem tower is right on the river Tagus (although it was originally on an island in the river) and is one of the few major buildings to survive the earthquake of 1755. I suppose it represents the golden era of Portuguese navigation / trade / exploration and conquest. Getting there is really fantastic as you can catch the metro to Cais do sodre (end of the Green line) and then a tram / train to Belem Station. Then you can walk along the Tagus river taking in a view of the 25th April Bridge and marinas as well as a number of museums in the area and the fascist Padro dos Descobrimentos. Worth a half a day if the weather is good
Beautiful sight. The main attraction of Lisbon and did not fail. Highly recommen just waking around and taking it in. Dip your feet in the river to cool down!!

Postcard perfect. Visited this in Mayb of 2012 and was in total awwwww...its exactly how it looks in a postcard in real life. Perfect to sit and look at, the little sculpture is cute too. Exactly a way to end a nice walk is taking a moment to look at the Torre de Belem.

Beautiful View. The Tower of Belem is worth visiting for the view and for the history that the river has in Lisbon. It is a steep climb up very narrow stairs but there are several levels for the view. Try to visit on the first Sunday of the month. It is more crowded but admission is free.

Pleasant. This was a nice spot to see, we walked from downtown, very long walk! I would advise a bus or train, much easier. Train is only 2 euro each, easy to find your way around. There is also an old military museum there. Each has a cost to enter. We also went in to the military one, I was not really interested in it but my husband enjoyed it. I was very surprised at the garbage on site for a tourist attraction? You would not spend more than 2 hours tops here, unless you ate, but food much better in other spots. There is also a washroom here for a cost of .50 euros.

Pleasant walk along the river. The Tower of Belem is a short walk from the Jeronimo Monastery. Both should be one anyone's list of Lisbon sights. The Tower is a medieval fortress that once guarded the river. Today, it's a tourist attraction but not very crowded. Well worth a visit if you're in the neighborhood.

Only touristic spot. It doesn't worth your walk and not at all your money or climbing up narrow stairs...it's nice from outside but there are more interesting places in Lisbon... I would rather skip this attraction due to hot weather it totally squeezed our whole energy that day...

Need a guide. This sure is a piece of art..which comes alive with a good guide.Do not miss the floor chart of Vasco da Gama's voyages and if you are lucky ..you will see the bus getting into the water.A must see with a guide.

Worth a visit. We arrived in Belem by taking one of the yellow bus tours costing just €15 each. The Torre is well worth a visit and costs €6 each to go in. Like most places there is a small charge but it does offer good views from the top and is interesting. It isn't massive and can get busy but if you're in the area then take time to visit.

Interesting tower. Interesting Place for the views and sense of the entry into Lisbon by ships in the distant past. Rooms are empty but as you go up each level gives a slightly different view from the windows. The narrow single lane stone stairs have a traffic light system on each level to allow only one way climb/descent at a time so make sure you follow it strictly.

Not to be missed.... This landmark is bit of a walking distance from tram / bus stand, so in a hot day - it may be advisable to go there in the morning. The structure is made of stone and remains amazingly cool during the hot afternoon. The view is fantastic and limestone structure with blue water view looks beautiful. Near by garden area is frequented by families on picnic.
Worth the climb!. Narrow, steep stairs to get to all levels, but do climb them all. Very interesting site-- great views--in an area with other things close. Should be on your "to see in Lisbon" list.

Great Exterior, no need to go inside.. While some people may be disappointed when they arrive to see that the tower is small and located on the edge of a wharf. The tower itself is a work of art but not ancient as some of the other places in the city. There is a charge to go inside but it was not really worth for me to see the interior. There are many other places around the city that afford better views. There are cafes around the tower.There is a tram station "Belem" for transport.
to many People on Sunday. The Torre de Belém is a popular destination on weekends, hence many people. On Sunday an antiques market takes place there. Easily accessible by tram and by bus.
Interesting outing... ...from Lisbon city on the modern tram. Good place to relax in the sun nearby with a drink. But the main draw I have to admit was the 'nata' ( custard tart) bakery 5 10min away!

Iconic landmark. This iconic landmark is fun to explore and offers lovely views of Belem and the river. Expect to walk a distance to reach it if you don't take a Hop On Hop Off bus from the city center.

A lovely attraction. The Torre de Belem is really easy to find, in a picturesque location next to the River Tejo. It's cheap to enter and has a nice view and it's really near the pasteleria which sells the delicious pasteis de belem! I'd highly recommend this attraction.
Historic landmark of Lisbon. We took a cab over to this Lisbon tourist site from our hotel. Nice historic building with great views of the river. The area around the tower is well worth the trip.

Beautiful building. Try to get to the Torre de Belem before the crowds: only a limited number of people are allowed inside at any time, and there is a flow-management system in operation on the (steep and twisty) stairs. The building is very beautiful from the outside, though the climb to the top doesn't add much. Be aware that with a combined ticket from the Jeronimos, you don't need to queue to get in but can go straight to the front of the line.

very good view. it is not close to the city center, but if you go there, you could have a great view at lisbon, for only 3 euros (2euros for students) you could go up and enjoy the view. I do not think it is a must do in lisbon, but if you have the time for it, then why not!
Tower of Lisbon. Not quite the size of its London namesake, but just as steeped in history. Quite simply, don't leave Lisbon without seeing it.

It was closed when we arrived. Arrived too late after 1800 so it was closed. It's a small ancient building on the river bank. The whole area of the river bank is just like a park so you can ride, walk dog or even lying there and do nothing.
Must visit. The area around this tower is so beautiful, you'll instantly fall in love. Right next to the river Tejo, this one is a must visit.

A must see in Lisbon, such a historical landmark!. A tower built in the middle of Tagus in-1514-20. Closed Mondays. Easy accessible by train Belem, Streetcar 15 or buses 28, 727, 729 and 751. The architectural structure is simply breathtaking and beautiful on lower and higher levels of the tower. A true history landmark. You can also purchase a combo ticket to also visit the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, highly recommended. Taxi transportation also is affordable in Lisbon.

Very nice . The view of the tower and the view from the tower are super! They implemented a new traffic light system for the stairs and control number of people in the tower made the visit nicer and safer. This also means you might need to wait longer if you are not early bird.
torre de Belem. it is interesting to take pictures inside and on the roof too - the view is nice. Around Belem (seaside) you can walk for hours

The Impressive Architecture of the Belem Tower. This is an an outstanding and impressive tower done in the Manueline syle of architecture. It is situated on the Tagus River in Lisbon. We got here via tour bus. It is also near the statue to the explorers who are commemorated for their naval explorations during the Age of Discovery.
Beautiful Tower. Really pretty tower, loved the little sandy area. Amazing that it is still standing as the base is in the water.

Belem visit. Delightful architecture, must see in Lisbon. Structure was vitally important as a defensive fort on the Tagus river 16th century (I think). Across the street is the Jeronimos monastery, making for a good morning tour.

Torre de Belém. While in Lisbon make sure you take the time to walk along the river to see some of Lisbon's famous landmarks including Torre de Belém . As from http://a-perfect-escape.com/torre-de-belem/:Torre de Belém also known as the Tower of St Vincent is a tower located on the bank of the Tagus River in Lisbon, Portugal. This tower was named a UNESCO World Heritage site for its role in the Portuguese maritime discovers and as it served as the gateway to Lisbon. The tower itself has been standing since the early 16th century and its four story tower is made from limestone.Visit Tuesday – Sunday (Closed Mondays) 10 AM – 5 PM for 5 Euros or have free admission with the Lisboa Card. From here there are many museums and parks to explore.

Must visit place. The adress is not correct on this app. Torre de belem is located at the river. Its located close to the monastery. From torre de belem you have an amazing view of the 25th of April bridge.

Best Scenic Spot after St George Castle. It has views of the river, and across is the lesser known cousin of the famous Brazilian Christ the Redeemer, known as Christo-Rei. It has a nice waterfront for a casual stroll, and it is in the vicinity of other cultural treasures like the ornate monastery on the other side of the highway, and probably the most famous place to have an egg tart.But being Lisbon, the quality of their attractions aren't nearly on par with normal European standards, with a bygone era transportation system, although the upside is that it's cheaper compared to other European capitals.

A small but historic Tower. This sixteenth century tower on the main city side of Tagus river is small but impressive. It provide a great view of the river and great photo opportunity. Initially we wanted to avoid it because of crowd but finally when we went we realized it was worth the wait.

History. This place is well known as the most beautiful to visit when in Lisbon.Lots of history from the war of the pass and kings of Portugal.Lots to see and learn inside,the construction is extraordinary beautiful,difficult ti image how it was built,Should not be missed when in Belem.
Unavoidable choice for Lisbon. In Rome, go see the Pope.In Lisbon, must prove "pasteis de Belem", near the tower.The tower itself is small, with noyhing "plus" but its bucolic

Nice Monument. City tour bus stops here but it is not close enough to see inside or take pictures so if you want to see this it is quite a hike to get there. OK monument that is quite a walk from the Monastery which is really very nice to tour.

Beautiful. Buy the combo ticket!. LovelyWe had almost no que and bought a combo ticket allowing us to skip the long que at the monastry completely!It allows only 150 people in at once and due to the narrow stairs allows people either only up or down at once on a timer system.You will find it slightly further on from the monument.No. 15 tram took 40 minutes at 9/10ish there but only 20 back to Lisbon at 3

Beautiful fortress - closed on Mondays!. This ancient tower is stunning, with its waterside viewpoint. Even though it was closed on the day we were there (it is closed every Monday!), it was well worth the trip out to Belem to see the Torre de Belem. I suspect the photos of the tower are far better on days when it is closed, as the ramparts are not crammed full of tourists!

Nice architecture. It's smaller than you may think but it's very curious and different from all the other buildings. It's made of stone and it's on the river, we had to cross a small brudge to enter. Totally worth it!

View from outside, not worth it to go in. This tower is great to view from the outside, but the cost to enter and climb the top is prohibitive and not worth it compared to other options in the city for a view. Definitely a must visit while in Lisbon due to the historical significance and majesty of the tower, but stick to checking out from the riverside.

nice view up there. be ready to climb those circular steps to the top of the tower. if claustrophobic and get dizzy easily, it's quite a challenge. get the monastery and tower tickets at once and save.

One of the great symbols of lisbon. There is no wonder that most people admire this site. It shows Portugal in it's best powerful days. Whatever you think about Portugal today (I find it among the loveliest in Europe) we shall take 100 years that she was the No. 1 country in the world.
Torre de belem can represent proudly this era.

Loved it!. So glad I got the chance to see the Belem tower. It was very pretty and you can take some lovely photos there. I didn't have time to go inside but it was nice to walk along the waters edge.

Beautiful!. Again, we were confronted with very long lines and the scorching sun overhead. We passed on going inside. The Tower from the outside is very impressive and we loved the history and the fact that at one time it was right in the middle of the river and now the water has receded to leave it on land on the banks of the river instead.

Well worth Your Time. This is a very well preserved attraction that has great views from the top. They have a green light, red light system to get up and down the very narrow spiral stairs to get up to the different levels.

Worth the effort. Walk out from Cais de Sodres to the Torre de Belem. The walk along the front is worth it. However, it'll take a while, you might be better getting a bus. The bus stops everywhere and it's quite a way out in West Lisbon,.

Average. If it were not historic you would be disappointed, it's a very small little castle tower, there is nothing to really see except imaging what went on there back in time, no doubt you have to see it as we did but I don't think your going to be wowed .

Beautiful and historic. We toured the tower one bright sunny day and really enjoyed it. The views are amazing - you can't miss going to the top to soak it all in. It was also quite interesting from a historical perspective. Also, we didn't know until we got there that you can buy a pass to also see the monastery and save a few Euros. Both are worth seeing so plan on it and buy the combo pass. I think you can use it another day but you can easily see both the tower and monastery in the same day, and have lunch in between,

FABULOUS VIEWS. Entry 5€ Only 150 people can go up to top at any one time. One way up, same way down. System for this is a little confusing as the stairwell is dark and quite narrow with many steps to climb. It's an impressive piece of Portuguese history and well worth the visit. We didn't find much of a wait for entry on the day we went and we did arrive around 1pm. There were many little cafes and a couple of larger waterfront restaurants on the walk to the tower as well as the monument to discoveries which you can also climb to top for 3€. The number 15 tram will get you there and back but it us very very crowded, hot and stuffy.
Beautiful Architecutre. This is a very beautiful tower and a very historic place in Lisbon that should not be missed.Tip: Arrive early to beat the crowds!

Great tower but too busy. If you want to visit this do it first thing in a morning or last thing at night - other than that there a big queues and it is almost impossible to get to the top as the 'in/out' turn style system doesn't really work that well. If you want a good view of the area go to the monument of the discoveries half a mile down the sea front.

BELEM TOWER (TORRE BELEM). We went to the cafeteria between the Tower and the Combat Museum and bought a couple of cappuccinos, then headed to the Belem Tower. Come to find out, the entrance is free on Sundays, from 10am until 2pm, so we got in for free. They only allow 100 people in the tower at a time, so it was a bit slow going. When we reached the first staging area, and finally go a glimpse of the stairs up, Manoli decided she didn't want to climb up the tight spiral stairs, so I went up alone. If it hadn't been free, I'd say it wasn't worth the trouble! There were four flights of tight winding stairs with landings at each floor. They installed a system that was supposed to allow people to go up or down in a systematic way, using red and green arrows to indicate when you were supposed to go up or down, but so many people ignored the signals that it made for general mayhem! When I finally reached the top floor terrace with the great views, I discovered that I'd have to wait in a line of 40 or 50 other folks for the chance to go back down. So, after a minute or two of taking good photos from various points, I waited in line for something like 20 minutes just to be able to leave. Not a very satisfactory system, without any enforcement! The Torre Belem is quite beautiful, but most of that beauty is outside, with a few rooms and some great views from inside. If the crowds are small, I guess going inside would be worthwhile, but if its crowded, I'd just take some good photos from outside and move on.

A Must Visit. Stroll along the Rio Tajo waterfront through the well maintained park, enjoying the view of the Jeronimos Monastery in the background and the magnificent 25th of April Bridge leading across to the Statue of Cristo Rei overlooking a grateful Lisbon, to the Belem Tower. It is a beautiful monument of special significance to all residents of the New World. This visit can easily be included with a visit to the Museum of Navigation and Jeronimos Monastery, they are all musts

Small and busy. We went on a Sunday morning, which is the day that it is free to get in. If you do the same, go "early"! We were one of the lucky ones but the ones behind us were not so lucky. The waiting time to get in ir around 45 mins and this is because the stairs to go in and out are the same.No matter how much time you wait, you have to go and see this stunning architectural and historical piece.
Beautiful small fort. Beautiful,white fort,close to Jeronimo monastery,well known land mark.was busy,nice park and steps close by to relax on

Torre de Belem - lovely view from the top.. The stairs next to the water/tower are great for relaxing and you can climb the tower, and look around, see the Mosteiro dos Geronimos. A timer for the stairway to prevent congestion when climbing.

ecape from the city. Belem is just a wondurful place just outside the city. this monument is the central of belém, we didn't go in there, but that wasn't necesaary. the little beach, the terrace, the park, this is just the place if you want a relaxing afternoon in lisbon.

Another place is Lisbon to sit and relax in the sun. The tower is 5 euros. It is fun to explore and the views from the windows and from the top are lovely. The stairs next to the water/tower are great for relaxing in the sun. In the tower, the prison quarters below and the tiny staircase were crazy to behold. There is a timer for the stairway to prevent congestion - for 1.5 minutes, visitors are allowed to descend the stairs and then for another 1.5 minutes, visitors are allowed to ascend. It gets hot in the stairwell. In a May 2014 weekday, there was no 'crazy line' mentioned previously.

The tower of discoveries. TheTower of Belém, built to commemorate Vasco da Gama's expedition, is a reminder of the great maritime discoveries that laid the foundations of the modern world.You can climb the tower, and look around, see the Mosteiro dos Geronimos, and other places, the river Tejo and the south part of Lisbon..... So much to see....

Torre de Belem. As most of people know , Portugal was 700 years ago, together with Spain , had the best know how in sailing. In small boats, went along African coast till they reach Japan. To crew the boats, there would be a big party just in front of Belem tower, where people could eat and special drink all the wine.... and next day they will be on board a caravel sailing maybe to India....

Nice walk and nothing more. Yes, the Tower of Belem is nice. But I would never take the huge line to get inside, it is not really worthwhile. Take a walk, and enjoy the view, instead...Almost forgot to mention: during the summer, there is music and beer and a lot (really a lot) of people in the park in front of it.

Masterpiece of manueline architecture. The Tower of Belém is one of Lisbon's best known monuments. It rests in a beautiful setting, in the Tagus River mouth. It's a manueline-style (a portuguese subgenre of gothic architecture) pearl, well worth a visit. It's interior is a bit empty, although it's well worth a visit. Any visit to Lisbon, and particularly to Belém, isn't completed without at least a walk next to this monument.Don't miss other nearby attractions - the Monastery of the Hieronymites, the Discoveries Monument (Padrão dos Descobrimentos), the "Pastéis de Belém" café, the Tropical Garden, the riverside gardens and the small but historical Belém quarter.
Used to be in the middle of the river. Classic Lisbon site . A must see but make sure you get there before closing to explore the inside. Typical Lisbon

Lisbon hallmark. This Manueline tower dates back from the 16th century. It was built there to defend the entry to the Tagus estuary. It is a unique and picturesque tower that can easily be perceived as Lisbon landmark. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, like the nearby Geronimo Monastery. It is about 2km away from downtown but no visit to Lisbon can escape this monument that stands as a memory of the Portuguese age of discovery.

Beautiful monastery in Belem. This monastery in Belem was a highlight of our visit to Lisbon. We took a bus - the 728 - from historic Lisbon to Belem - where we waited in line for half hour to get tickets to the monastery cloister. The architecture is interesting and worth seeing. Somewhat mannerist and decorative, it's a beautiful respite from a busy city.A small fee for the monastery cloister but not for the church.

Such A Cool Sight. I recommend visiting the Torre de Belem as its quite a unique sight. The entrance fee is reasonable and the views from the top are pretty nice. Its in a good location where you see quite a few other sights including the monastery and the monument to the explorers. Definitely do not miss this sight.
Unique. Think kind of architecture is quite unique and it's in the river, we had to go by a bridge to enter!
the monastery is incredable. you HAVE to go to Belem. The monastery is not to be missed. It was really beautiful. It is also close to the museum that houses old carriages. Well worth a visit also.
Didnt Climb the Tower. Great site to visit. Didnt pay the money to go inside the tower, Im sure the view is amazing, but it was nice to go and see the tower.

Worth seeing. They have a one-way system with timers for the stairs letting people go up or down for a few minutes at a time which is great - the stairs are steep and claustrophobic though and I imagine on a busy day you could wait a while. 5 euros per person. 20 minutes visit.

Stunning. You really mustn't miss this one. The stonework is amazing, and you get to walk through nearly the whole place. Wonderful views from the towers, too! Go on a weekday if you can, to avoid the crowds.

better than the photo's. I have been disappointed in the past by 'iconic' attractions but this is one 'must do' that is worth the trip. It is beautiful little gem. Cross the bridge and pay 5 euros to explore inside. They have a one-way system with timers for the stairs letting people go up or down for a few minutes at a time which is great - the stairs are steep and claustrophobic though and I imagine on a busy day you could wait a while. The views are fab and look out for the rhino and his amusingly incorrect translation!
Beautiful tower by the sea. Very interesting historical tower with excelent views over the Tajo river. 5 euros per person. 20 minutes visit.
Impressive. Worth a visit if you are in Belem although the elevator was closed when we were there- still nice for a walk around.

Beautiful building and great setting. This is one of the sights you'll see if you go to Belem. It's a great setting but not much else. The crowds were large so we couldn't wander inside without getting claustrophobic. Taking pictures from outside should be good enough.

Quite a steep climb to the top of the tower. we bought a combined ticket to beat the crowd at the monastery and we saved some time there. Going to the top requires climbing 5 flights of stairs with each flight having 15 to 20 steps and the area is very narrow , spiral and steep. The views from the top are great and specially from the 3rd floor where you get to go to a small balcony . you almost get the feeling of hanging above water and can get some really good pictures from there

Extremely Busy.. Plan your visit when no cruise ships are in port. The lineup to tour the Torre de Belem was extremely long which precluded us from taking the inside tour. The cruise shippers all flock to the same place and make it a hell for the casual tourist.

Unavoidable.. Although this will probably not be the most memorable building you ever see in your life, it remains very pretty and an unavoidable symbol of Lisbon.Easily combined into a half-day trip with the Monument of the Discoveries and the Jerónimos Monastery (all within walking distance). You can get to the area by taking the 15E tram from Lisbon's Cais do Sodre‎ train station.Note that extremely long lines form to enter the tower (5€) and quite honestly, unless you are studying Manueline architecture, the interior of the tower is not worth the trouble. As locals say: "it's the same four walls, but from the inside, and with a higher view."

Unexpectedly interesting. A tower in the river Tagus built for defence. Not too big but impressively carved stonework and interesting explanations of its use and features. Great views up and down river. It is on most tourist itineraries so it gets v. crowded, though once inside its much better, until you come to climb the narrow and steep stairs to the upper floors. Note there is no concession to the less able (or just unfit!) in the stairs. However, the flow of people is controlled for safety purposes. Small but good shop. For refreshments, go to the cafe outside the nearby Museum of Combatants and sit in the shade by the river.

A recommended place to go. I went there on Sunday that was free for visitors to go inside the castle (such benefit was even known afterwards). You can also visit the nearby attractions such as the Jeronimos Monastery and The Discoveries Monument

Belem tower in Lisbon - Amazing!. My husband and I arrived here on May 11th of 2014. We were in for a rare treat, as admission to the castle was free since it was Sunday. We absolutely fell in love. A must see if you come to visit Lisbon and just steps from Jeronimos Monastery and The Discoveries Monument.

free on sunday!. we went over to the torre de belem on a sunday and it was free entry between 10-2pm. This meant that the line for entry was quite long but worth the wait. Great views over the river and a great little tower to climb. Not everyone seems to follow the red/green lighting system for the single person wide spiral staircase up to the top of the tower but persevere for the views!
A must visit. A little different to what I had expected, but still very impressive. This has to be a "must do" on any Lisbon visit. Stand in the footsteps of Vasco de Gama!

If you are in the area and after seeing the other sites.... I got the combined ticket when I got to the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos - the line there was so long that I thought, I might as well get the combined to save time.I got to the Tower and it was unique but for the cost I didn't think it was worth it as I had already gotten photos of the area from the museum. All the great shots are from the outside so just take your photos outside of it.A tip tho if you do want to go in, wear comfortable shoes as there is no elevator to the top. Some people had to be helped up as it's a lot of stairs.If you have it as part of a package like I heard, then OK, might as well. Otherwise spend your time in the area to see other things especially if you are on a limited schedule like I was.

A fortification which is beautiful. It is a bit of a walk to get here and queue for a ticket, but it's quite delightful to enjoy the outside views and appreciate the strategic position of the tower. Interesting that an artillery position resembles a wedding cake. We came here before the Jeronimos monastery and bought the combined ticket which meant we could bypass the monastery queue (and save2euros).

Must see if you are in Lisbon. If you are in Lisbon dont miss to visit Torre de Belem, an very old tower at the waterfront close to Lisbon, and its build that it looks like as a stone ship standing in the sea. There is a fee of 5 Euro to enter the Torre de Belem. Go down to doungeon, and climb up on the tower from where you have a realy nice view. Take care about the signs above the entrace to the steps. There are signgs which show in wich direction can you go, up or down, because the steps are realy small, and the bidirectionl walking on the staris is not possible. So you got to wait that the sign for your direction turns to green. After you have visited the tower, take some time to walk through a very nice park around the tower, and spend some time there enjoying the sea and the nature.

You must visit. Tower of Belem was built to protect Lisbon port at 16. century.The tower is example of late Portuguese Gothic art and also in UNESCO World Heritage List. We have spent so much time in Belem and Ajuda, soTorre de Belem was closed unfortunately. But even at the outside it was so gorgeous  Admission is free with lisbon card. Openning hours: 10AM-5PM (Oct.-April), 10AM-6:30PM (May-Sept.).
Worth the hassle. When going up and down the stairs inside the tower - plan your steps. Despite the red and green light system there will be confusion. Nice view from the top.

This superb defensive tower is a kicker. The late afternoon kicker for us was this superb tower built as a fortress. it became the beacon for the discovery-tour of navigators. But our entry into this real beauty lies first in the decoration of the exterior. Adorned with rope carved in stone,it has openwork balconies,Moorish-style watchtowers and distinctive battlements in the shape of shields. the gothic interior below the terrace was used as a storeroom for arms and a prison,is very austere but the loggia provides a panorama not to be missed. the loggia inspired by italian architecture gives a light touch to the defensive battlements.

Picturesque. It was really something to see this impressive tower right on the waterfront. The surrounding park is quite lively, and the evening I was there happened to coincide with a jazz festival. I wasn't aware these grounds existed, but many people were enjoying picnics and just soaking in the atmosphere. There are also plenty of cafes to sit and take in the scenery.I was surprised that the Belem train stop is actually quite a walk from the Torre de Belem. It's an easy ~10-15 minute stroll along the water, but at the end of a long day of walking it felt like an eternity.

Go late afternoon. This is a must see structure, but packs of cruise tourists invade and swarm almost all day. Wait, be patient, go at the end of the day (buy dual tickets before 4 pm at the Monastery)--the sun will favor your photos then and the hordes may have thinned. It is a timed staircase up and down - narrow spiral stairs -- not for the infirm or claustrophobic. But it is very cool.

Nice. Using a quantity of stairs (standard ones and carrusel ones) you can have beautiful panoramic views of the city from several stages (floors). Inside the tower you can see rooms and rests of the previous equipments.
Great Views. Great Views - lots of spiral stairs to climb to make the most of visit/views, however, apart from guns there is little to see within the tower
Map location. The location and guidance otTorre de Belem is completly wrog and missleading its position is on the river bank west of Padrao dos Descobrimentatos about 300 meters.

Easy to walk around, many thing to see.. Do not miss the Monastery Dos Jeronimos, it is absolutely wonderful in its airy construction, details sculpted on the columns and the walls. The cloister is particularly beautiful.

Nice spot. A nice spot to take in on a walk along the River Tagus. Didn't go inside (it was closed anyway) but lots of photo opps. Walk further on to see the tomb of the unknown warrior in a reflecting pool. See also the dancing fountains over the road in the park.
Better from the outside. Not worth queueing to get in then up & down the stairs. The best views are from the outside. Views over the river are a good from quayside

Check it from outside. Torre de Belem is a wonderfully beautiful building but going inside will not enrich you with anything. Some nice shots of the building and a lovely view over the river, however both can be achieved from outside as well. By all means go there (Belem in general is lovely), there is a nice cafe/restaurant with a perfect view just next to the tower but for me the wait in the crowd on a Sunday when there is a free entrance was a waste of time. If I'd paid for the entrance I'd be hugely disappointed.

beauty... the line was ridiculous, needless to say, I didn't wait.. however, from the outside it looks amazing.. I love all the architecture here in Portugal.. the history is beautiful.. if you have time to wait, I can only assume it's a must... if not, definitely a must to go see it from the outside... it's beautiful..

Our third trip here!. Read about all the figures that are curved on the sides of this wonderful monument to the navigators...with Henry the Navigator up in front. Be sure to take the elevator up to see the beautiful view on the top...

Not to be missed.... Belem is an excellent place to spend a day... and the belem tower is not be missed... tower looks good from outside... not much to do inside... but worth visiting the top of the tower... if you have the combined ticket then I guess you can jump the queue as at times the queue can be pretty long...

A pleasant stop. After seeing the Geronimo Monastery with its many museums, this was pretty tame, but it is a nice stop on the hop on, hop off tours. Cafeteria at the stop is affordable and has free wifi, and the tower can be visited in a reasonable amount of time, allowing foe lots of photos of the river and bridge. Fairly sparse in terms of the attraction itself. You might just want to take pictures, eat ice cream, and walk down to the monument of the discoveries rather than going inside.

Nice monument, Lisbon landmark, but windy and cold the day we visited. Its a mandatory visit in Lisbon. Smaller than I imagined. Couldn't visit inside because the tide was rising at the end of the afternoon and in fact some guys that were leaving got soaky wet at the access because of the waves. Very near the 'Padrão dos Descobrimentos', another landmark

Lisbon must see. If you are going to go to the Monasterio san Jeronimo and the Torre de Belem you can buy a combined ticket for 10 euros which means that you can jump the queue at the 2nd site, so don't do what we did and stand in the queue at the Torre, when you already have your ticket you can just walk straight in. If you are scared of confined spaces I would not recommend climbing the tower as you have to climb several very narrow spiral staircases. There is only one set of stairs so they work a clever red and green light system allowing people to climb up and down, which works well as long as everyone abides by the lights. That said you don't have to climb the tower to enjoy the Torre de Belem you can stay on the lower level and still enjoy the views. Allow 30 to 45 mins to see this attraction.
Good view. Very relaxing, very cool, romantic place, nice for photo shoot, nice architecture, good experience . Liked the location, eateries

The pastries!. We thought we'd be prudent and just get three tarts for two people.Yeah. Right.We ended up splitting more like seven... and it wasn't easy to stop at that.The area around is nice too. Absolutely worth the visit.

Pretty, long line, worth the climb with Lisboa Card. I love a view, so since the Torre de Belem was included with the lisboa card, my friends and I opted to climb it. It's very lovely and picturesque, but there's not much too it. I wouldn't pay to climb it, but I very much enjoyed it.

Cool Building, Not much to see inside. The Tower is cool to look at and you get to climb to the top. There is a 1 way electronic control system that is nice for the stairs. There is not very much to see on the inside though.
Beautiful. Very lovely - we hired bikes and had a nice ride from the city centre along designated cycle paths about 8k

Great architecture. We go there by walk from Miradouro Sao Pedro de Alcantara and this is the best place on the bay. It's worth to go there because it's a great piece of architecture. Beside good view the tower is important in Portugal's history so you can lern few things from there.

Didn't go in!. We didn't go in as we'd gone up the other monument - but it's really interesting and beautiful so we sat in front of it for a bit and had a look around the area. There's a cafe in the nearby Army museum (or something), and it was great to have a jug of sangria and a panini looking at the Tower.

Interesting site. Worth going to see, at least on the outside, but the site doesn't offer much more to see on the inside. It's got some decent views from on top the tower, but be prepared to wait a long time to go up, and even longer to come back down! There's only 1 staircase, so it switches directions for a few mins each way.
Great place on the bay. Beautiful old fort right on the bay. We had a tour host took us by this place and it is beautiful. Well worth the visit.
Not what we expected.. Long lines for something that was not impressive. The monsteiro dos Jeronimos and discovery monument was much better.
history lesson. Well worth the busy tram journey along the coast to see the gardens, monuments and churches. Although it was busy lots of space to sit and walk

Great Belem Tower. This majestic tower was the gateway to Lisbon and also the defence. System at the entrance to the Tagus River. The hop on hop off bus stopped here after the Jeronimas Monastery. It is designed as a UNESCO world heritage site.

What a great structure!. This structure is one of the most pure "Manueline" structures in Portugal. The views from the tower are great. There is a bit of a line to get in but it's much shorter than the Monastery O Jeronimos -buy your ticket for the monastery here and skip the line at the monastery which is REALLY long. Don't skip this site- you'll be missing one of the most beautiful buildings in Portugal.
Torre de Belem. Great view, not really worth it for the price. Lots of very narrow stairs and people but there is a good system to let people know whether or not it is safe to go up or down.

Nice bit of history. It's pretty awe inspiring to think that Vasco da Gama sailed past this and knew he was home.. It's right on the river, close locale to several other major sights so it's convenient sightseeing. The tower was closed for the Easter holiday when we were there but there's a nice area around it to relax and take a load off for a bit.

Take this as last stop after monastery etc. After Monastry and this sea going Discoveries monument, this Unesco world heritage listed tower is worth for short stop. It has small bridge to it, during my visit, tide was so low that you were able to go next to the tower. Visit also "Museu dos Combatente" military museum next to tower. There is military memorial, similar to Vietnam memorial wall in DC, honouring those abroad fallen soldiers.If you can not take a ferry cross the river, my tip is that leaving with a tram 15, walk bit direction to west as all tourists come from tram stops of tower and monastery, most cases leaving people at stops.
nice castle...and on the water. very interesting castle...great views of the water..and tour tape was interesting to hear about life in the olden days...

Famous but just OK. The Torre is pretty and historical but there are many other things to see in and near Lisbon that are far better. It's famous and we felt we had to see it; so we saw it and left. Nothing really special. The best view was from the ferry (just East of the Torre) that we took to the other side of the Tagus River. The ferry ride was the high point of our trip to Belem after a very disappointing wait, wait, and more wait at the Monastery.

Excellent heritage site. Liked the site but REALLY disliked the lack of communication to guests about the alternate timing schedule used to coordinate people going either up or down the tower staircase. The mature man that was to be supervising the process did little but grumble at guests and certainly did not attempt to explain the process to guests. Very disappointing experience due to staffing.
Great sight. Lovely tower built in the water with a little bridge out to it. Looks like something out of a fairy tale. Great for photos. Lots a space- queues to get in but well worth a visit.

Can't miss it when visiting Lisbon!. This area of town has some of the main attractions of Lisbon, as the Tower of Belem and the Monasteiro dos Jerónimos.You have to reach it either by taxi or by bus/tram, if you're staying in the center.Here you can also find the best pastries in town!

Must see when in Belem. Took the commuter train from Commerce Square to Belem and visited the Tower along with the other sites in Belem. The tower was very cool. While visiting it started raining, so ended up waiting out the rain at the cafe next door. After the rain, it cleared up with nice blue skies. There is also the Museum of the Army next door.

Pretty from the outside, not worth going in. We were here during the week before Easter, so there were tons of crowds. The wait to get into the tower was about 40 minutes, even though we had already bought tickets. Once inside, there wasn't much to see. You can ascend to the top of the tower, but there is yet another wait. There is only one staircase to go up and down, so once you're at the top you have to wait again to go down. I recommend seeing the tower from the outside, but not paying the fee to go inside unless there is no wait. There is another monument nearby, Padrão dos Descobrimentos, which you can ascend to get a similar view.
Beautiful building. Great construction by the sea. Try getting there by sunset just before it closes in order to get the best pictures. Very near to the Two Geronimos Monastery.

Take a picture and pretend you're leaving for the Americas. This little tower is important in Portugal's history since it was usually the last thing Portuguese explorers saw after they confessed their sins at St. Jerome prior to leaving for explorations in the far east or Americas. If you feel underwhelmed, it helps to remember that the Tower used to be in the middle of the river until the banks moved away from St. Jerome and the main part of Lisbon.

little shade on a hot day. bothered by tourists in droves and immigrants selling tat. The area is charming but the queue for San Geronimos was over an hour long standing in the sun. Did not go up the tower but sat by the river watching boats.
Historical. Lovely to visit if you like history. View of the river and surrounding area great for kids to cycle, play and picnic. Easy to get to on the train from Cascais or Lisbon.

Did not disappoint.. Was looking forward to the tower for the whole trip. I like old buildings, castles and such, so for me it was great. Yes there was a little wait to get in, a little crowded inside, but the only place we had to be after, was afternoon cappuccino. The tower was impressive inside and out, great views from the top of the tower and a great place for pictures. My wife is not so impressed by old buildings, so for her she might give it 3 stars, except for the stair traffic lights, she thought those were great!

Great monument. I didn't get into the Tower because it was to late, but in return I could appreciate and astonishing sunset behind the Tower.Interestingly, there was a miniature of the tower so that you can touch it! Very good for those who are not able to see it with their eyes, but also for those who can.There were other attractions nearby make it even worthier to visit, without mentioning the delicious Pastéis the Belém.
Fine monument. Very nice and interesting place to visit. Bad thing is that there are too many tourists. But anyway, it is must place in Belem

Wonderfull example of 1500 architecture!. It is an architectural jewel, situated in the margins of the Tagus River. The surroundings are perfect to walk around, Very peaceful. Nearby other attractions make this spot part of a perfect day.
Torre de Belém. Very Nice and interesting monument located In Belém close to Lisbon and to Tagus river. Not to be missed!

Wedding cake. A must-go in the Belém area - and if you are visiting Lisbon, you HAVE TO go to Belém!Historical place in a beautiful surrounding, some locals say the tower looks like a wedding cake as it is white and tall. After going up, you can sit outside overlooking the river or take a break in a cafe/snack bar on the right side, also with a great view to the river.Then, continue to explore Belém: Centro cultural de Belém (with exhibitions and also a great view), Padrão dos Descobrimentos, Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, Presidential palace (changing of the guard on sundays, 11am), Museums (dos Coches, da Electricidade - free -, da Presidência, de Arte Popular, de Arqueologia), gardens, restaurants and the famous pastéis de Belém - everything in walking distance!

Definitely worth checking out while in Belem. A very attractive and historically relevant site in Lisbon and worth going into during your stay. Not too expensive and gives some nice views from the top. Recommended.
i loved this tower. Belem the complete area of Lisbon is my favourite. and the Belem Tower ahhh!! beautiful.. Great view..

Very nice spot!. From the outside Torre de Belem looks very picturesque, but relatively small. Once inside it is much bigger with wonderful views allaround. Great piece of architecture, nice stone carvings and you can explore several levels. The view of the bay, the bridge, the monastery and museums is very nice. In good weather you can just sit on the wall or near one of the windows and enjoy the view! Short walk from the Monument of Discoveries. You can buy a joint ticket for the Torre and Jeronimos monastery.

A must visit. Historically relevant, aesthetically attractive. Set riverside with other must-visit sites within a pedestrian area and easily accessible by city tour buses. Go on a sunny day and take your best camera!

Well worth a visit and good views from the top. We enjoyed our visit to the tower built in the river with a wooden walkway and drawbridge entry. With the Lisboa card it's free as well, we would recoomed all visitors here for a few days to look at buying one as it covers most forms of travel as well as free/discounted entry to attractions. Built in the era of Portugal's explorers and empire, it is and interesting and quite decorative building. It is worth a visit on your Lisbon trip.

One of a few big attractions in Belem. If you are in Lisbon, it is worth heading out to Belem for half a day. The Torre de Belem is worth checking out. Entry is €5 but if you are also going to the nearby monastery (which is also recommended), think of buying the combined ticket for €10 which will save you €2. The Monument of Discoveries is a leisurely 5/10 minutes walk away from the Torre de Belem.
Torre de Belém. better known as the "Torre de Belém". Nice little castle build to protect the harbor. We didn't go inside but enjoyed the view.

great view. we really liked the Belem area, there are a lot of places to see in this area. I would recommend to go early and maybe spend the day there.If you go on Sunday then entry to Belem tower and the monastry are free until 2pm, but get there early as there are huge queues to get in.Torre de Belem and Padaro dos descobrimentos are located almost next to each other, so if you choose to climb up one of them i would recommend torre de belem as this had more to offer than the great views.

Not to be Missed!. Another 'must see' if visiting Lisbon! We travelled out from the City using our 6 euro a day bus/tram/train tickets (much cheaper than the many tour busses) The tower is sited right on the river and provides both fantastic views and great photo opportunities. I would recommend going early in the day as it does get busy later on and the narrow stairwells can be very congested.

excellent starting place for tour of Lisbon. If you get there early, there's free parking at the Torre. It's a bit out of the city centre but there's a few essential sights out there and it's a really easy place to find by car. It's also on the Hop-on, Hop-off bus tour route, so we left the car there and toured by bus the rest of the day.

A must-see in Belem. Beware of rainy/windy days : the wooden pathway that goes to the tower itself (which stands in water) can get VERY wet if you're caught by a sudden wave. We were drenched in Tagus+seawater but enjoyed our visit nonetheless.
Lots of things to see. Within 100 meters you will find a beautiful medieval castle, the tomb of Vasco de Gama, Jeronimos' Monastery and Enoteca de Belem - Portugal's best wine and dining out.

Belem. Lots to see in Belem ... the Navy museum, the St. Jeronemo Monastary with the tomb of Vasco da Gama inside and pieces of his ship used in the ceiling, the map of Portugal discoveries and best of all was eating the Pastries de Belem custard tarts.
15 minutes aways from Lisbon. Located outside of the city this attraction is one of a kind ( you can acces it via the tourist bus)

Worth it. I've been here several times with friends and family that visit. I've only been up on top once and that is a cool view of the city. But it's also fun just to go walk around it and marvel at the sculptures of the explorers.

Surrounded By Beauty. Torre de Belem was beautiful, surrounded by the water, paths to stroll around and the the Monument down the road. The inside of the tower was cool and offered great views but I would suggest if it crazy crowded to skip the inside.

Torre-ble Tower. It's a long walk from the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. The enrty is conufusing - if you bought a combo ticket at the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos you already have a ticket but have to stand in the line with people buying them and that wastes a lot of time. When you do go up the tower there is a green light red light system for when it's okay to go UP and when its okay to go DOWN. The stairwell only allows for one directions and people ignore the system and you could be stuck forever to go wither direction. The view is a non view - just the water and you can get that from so many other vantage points in Lisboa. And then the long trek back to grab a tram back to Lisboa......total waste of a few hours when all was said and done. SKIP
A bit claustrophobic. It was pouring down with rain when we went so quite crowded. there is a traffic light system to go up and down because it is narrow but people don't obey the signs.

Beautiful scenery. Went to Belem on tourist bus, really is a picturesque area located on a port bordering the river. There are beautiful statues to take pictures with, the weather was lovely, the sea was bright blue and it is a place you can stay and enjoy the views for hours on end

worth a visit. lisbon has a lot of towers and hills which allow the tourists to enjoy the natural and beautiful scenery from different angles and heights. belem tower is one of them. it is worthwhile to pay it a visit.

Lovely old tower. It is located at the sea shore in Belem, very close to Lisbon. First you can visit Jeronimos Monastry, Maritime Museum and have a very tasteful pastel de nata (Custard tart) in Pastais de Belem (foundation1837)(Rua Belém 84-92, 1300-085 Lisboa, Portugal +351 21 363 7423) then go to the sea shore for this lovely old tower (UNESCO World Heritage) build in 1519
Well worth a visit. Visited on a lovely day, the tower is a beautiful building at the end of Belem and well worth a visit

Great to visit but getting to the top is a trial!. Sure, go see the Torre de Belem - wander the battlements but if you want to get up to the top of the tower - good luck! There is only one way up AND down and it's a tiny shared winding stair case. There is a bell system to let you know when you can climb up or down but it was confusing and there had to be at least 80 people in line on any given level trying to get further up or climbing down. It took us 1/2 an hour just to get to the 2nd level and we finally gave up and headed back down again. Better just view the tower from below and save the 5 Euros.

Pretty, free on some Sundays. I'd recommend this if it's free. Or perhaps if you have younger children. Otherwise, it's pretty from the outside, and you get the jist. Tour the whole area with gardens and the Discoveries monument and don't miss the Jeronimos monastery across the street. We walked several blocks behind the monastery to track down those little tarts and we weren't disappointed!

A little bit of a trip to get here but worth the view. If traveling without a car, you'll need to take the bus 15E to get out here, but it's worth the trip. The monastery and maritime museum are also nearby so make sure to visit these as well. There isn't much to see in the tower, but the view around it and from the top is quite nice. Also, walk back beyond the monastery to have a custard pie and lunch--you won't be sorry!

Okay but don't go up the tower when busy!. Looks great from the outside but be warned there is a very narrow spiral staircase up the tower controlled by a 'traffic light' system. What we found was the timings weren't great and we had 100 plus people at the top of tower who wanted to get down but stairs we full with people coming up. People were getting aggravated and wasn't worth the 5euros for this.

Sign of Lisbon. Belem is quite a nice place to visit, see the tower, the monestry and enjoy one of the cafes\restaurants in the small streets around. easily reached from th parco comercio with the 15 tram
A perspective from outside of Belem. I didnt enter, but I enjoy from outside. Is really beatiful. You can get there by metro and its really near of other monuments.

Ok, but not if you have any physical impairment.. Impressive tower with good architecture ,and nice view over the Tagus. However, stairs to ascend tower are very narrow and could be dangerous particularly if you have any physical impairment. Badly needs a member of staff to regulate visitor flow, basement room used as a dungeon has extremely low ceiling, so also not accessible for lots of people.Overall this attraction is ok, but don't worry if you miss it.

A must visit in Lisbon!. Very impressive peace of architecture and beautiful stonework! Fantastic views from everywhere. Be careful going downstairs - the ceiling is very low. Can by joint ticker for the tower and the Jeronimos monastery.
Chaos. Chaos, they need a better stair system, spoilt the visit.....I would not recommend just because of that.

Unmissable. You can't miss this. Get a tram or bus from the central square and go along the sea front to this beautiful tower, right in front of the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. When you are there do not miss the "Pasteis de Belem", they're sold in this historic shop cum restaurant , just to the right of the monastery,which makes about 40thousand of these delightful little cream cakes every day.

A Must See!. Beautiful tower guarding Belem, I love the bridge that leads to the tower, something about walking over water. Did not enter because I was too taken with the view of the sea and the surrounding area.

Attractive 16th century architecture belies its true role. The Belem Tower is an attractive 16th century piece of architecture that appears to contradict its role as a fortress. You must also see the Forte do Bom Sucesso close by to fully appreciate its significance.
Torre de Belem. Well worth a visit. Great views of the river and the Belem area. There's a small café next door which is also quite nice with outdoor seating area.
So beatiful!. If you are in Lisbon, you really need to go to Belém and visit all the touristics points there, especially "torre de belém".

epic place!. The Belém Tower is probably the most famous landmark of Portugal and it truly lives to its reputation!
You can visit it from the inside and check what a place it is! What was a fortress at the early 16th and is now an open air museum.

If you are in the area or passing through. The Torre is beautiful, but not big so 1/2 - 1 hour is enough to go in (entrance fee) and up and take beautiful photos. We decided to pass through here from Sintra to Lisbon. The wind was quite strong so hold on to your hats. Parking is free.

Outside view. The Torre is quite a stunning structure. Located a bit far from the other tourist attractions you can walk it or tram it there. The structure looks like a giant castle piece from a chess set and is quite good to see from an architectural perspective. However we never went inside so I cannot comment on that but it's worth going to have a look at and great for pics as well.

Well Worth the Trip. Torre is, simply put, freaking awesome. You can walk the whole thing from the basement to the top. The views are fantastic and when you think of the history of the tower, well - wow! It's a great thing to see when in Lisbon.

Pretty on the outside. The Torre is beautiful from the outside. It cost 5euro per person to go in.....and I don't think it's worth that. A lot of it is quite an empty shell. The views are nice, but nothing compared to the view you'll get at the Castle in Lisbon. I'd recommend walking around this area and enjoying the view of the Torre and the marina.

Very historic and beautiful building. Formally in the river on the way to Lisbon, The tower was the last structure the voyagers saw on their way out of Lisbon and the first structure they saw on their way back in.Incredible architecture. Spectacular views.
Beautiful!. Even more beautiful in person. Lots of floors to explore. So neat how it juts out into the water. It is almost too pretty to have been a fort!

Great photograph opportunity. We did not go inside the Tower as we did not feel it was worth it. However, the views from the outside are very impressive and we took the opportunity of taking many photographs. I wouldn't recommend taking a trip here especially to see the Tower, but, if you are in the area then have a look outside as we did.

a classic place to visit. Visiting the tower you can understand how Lisbon protected themselves and see where they kept their prisioners. A lot of History in this building. You can take wonderful pictures and take in the spectacular view of the river from the top floor.
Riverside castle. On a clear day there are excellent views from the top of the tower, but inside there isn't much else to see. It's location makes this an amazing location to take pictures.

Just a good landscape. This is just a good landscape in Lisbon.
There is nothing to see inside the tower! So, do not spend 5 euros to go up there.

A picturesque attraction in a splendid city. I have now visited Lisbon twice, each time being as a port call during a cruise vacation.There is so much to do and see in this huge city that it is a good idea to take the sight-seeing bus tour, where one can hop on and hop off at the various attractions.On the bank of the River Tagus, not far from the 25 April suspension bridge can be found the Belem Tower, one of the city's ancient defences from invading forces. It is situated in beautiful surroundings, and affords endless photo opportunities because of its architecture and location. Considering the Tower is many centuries old, it is remarkably well preserved, This attraction is a must-see during any visit to Lisbon.

Excellent Tower. During our third day in Lisbon we visited Torre de Belém ( Belém Tower ), during our walking in the area. We went to the top and take excellent pictures from Jerónimos Monastery, Tagus River and surroundings. I felt that i was back to the past, with sailers, cannons surrounding me on the first floor.

Good enough from the Outside. This is a fabulous place to wander around, but inside it is small with very narrow steps and walkways which makes it a bit frustrating with so many tourists. But if you go on Sundays it is free entry. Otherwise cost is 5Euros to go inside. Frankly it photographs much better from the outside.

A must see. Easy to reach with public transport from the center of Lisbon.Very nice views and packed with history.Disadvantage: there is only one small staircase to go up and down in the tower. When it's busy (and it was when we were there), you have to queue quite a long time to go up and to come back down.

A must see on a short trip to Lisbon. I traveled to Lisbon with a friend and this was on both of our must see's! We weren't disappointed. Great views and well organised well worth the 5euro entrance fee.

Nice but a bit underwhelming. The tower is a nicely restored stone structure. Unfortunately there is only one narrow staircase access with a series of direction flow lights for alternating assent and descent. Or that's the way it is timed to work. People take very young children and those with limited mobility take much longer using small narrow stairs and it becomes a mediated disaster. Save you Euros and take photos of the exterior and give the tower itself a pass.

Belem area is a good visit. The Torre de Belem is sometimes the ‘face’ of Lisbon. It may be the most recognizable architecture though it is actually not in Lisbon but in Belem about 10-15 minutes west. It's reachable to subway, trolley, and tour bus. It is a unique castle jutting out into the river. We decided not to go inside based on the reviews. I think in general the Monumento a los Descubridores, the Cloister of Jeronimos Monastery, and here makes for a good 2-3 hour visit to this area. They are all within walking distance.

A little disappointing. After reading other reviews I was looking forward to our visit. It wasn't the best day weather wise and without the view there really wasn't much else. It's quite empty and not really worth the entrance fee.

Better on the outside. This is quite an architectural gem and looks fabulous from the outside although the impact is lessened somewhat by the adjoining car / coach park. Luckily the entrance fee for us was waived as we had a Lisbon Card as I don't think we would have got good value had we paid. We climbed up to the first level ok but then would have had to pass through two turnstiles to get to the next level. After waiting in a queue for around 10 minutes we abandoned the attempt and headed for the exit. Fascinating maybe but I don't think we would have gained much more from our visit.
Well worth a visit. Good views from the top of the fort, also a sense of the maritime and colonial history of Portugal which is reinforced by the fact that the fort is actually in the sea.

Not worth the entry fee. After reading about the attraction in Belem, we arrived at the tower. I enjoyed the history and architectural qualities, however I was unpleasantly surprised by the entrance fee in relation to the value of this place. If only they could have enhanced the visitor experience. Now the place felt to empty.

Alright. The tower has a very peaceful surrounding with the sea breeze for company. The tower is a beauty, but only on the outside. Inside there is nothing to look at so the entry fee is a bit of a waste. However if you love the peace and the quiet, do visit. There was not a big crowd here when we came and hence, we enjoyed our visit in peace.

History and Tarts. We visited Belem on a beautiful sunny day and were immediately attracted to the phenomenal structure honouring the Portuguese explorers. A short walk down the sea wall was the Torre de Belem. An interesting defensive structure, very well planned for effective cannon use. Our visit was completed by the leisurely consumption of pastis de Belem (custard tarts).

Don't waste your time. We visited on a Sunday when it is free. Bad mistake. Huge lines to get up the tower. Once we finally got up, we had to wait over an hour to get down. View was ok but Monument of the Discoveries was much superior. Really nothing extraordinary about the Torre de Belem - frankly it was more impressive from the shore.

This is a must see along with the nearby Monastery.. The Belem Tower is an amazing defensive tower that protected Lisbon from attack 500 years ago. It is beautiful to look at, set in an amazing location and still contains the cannons that allowed it to be so effective.In busy times the wait to climb or descend the steps of the Tower can be quite long as it is controlled by a system of traffic lights in one direction at a time. The view from the top on a clear day is however spectacular.
Manueline style. Well... There are a lot of persons who wait from this monument more then it can gives to you .... I personaly was impresed with the amazing architectural style it got...

Worth the trek out of the centre. This area is out of the centre, but defintely worth visiting. It has some beautiful monuments. If you have time, do go up the discovery monument. And of course, try the pasteis de Belem, delicious custard tarts, from the famous bakery!!! The monastery is also stunning, but watch out for pickpockets, when we went I noticed lots of them about asking for money and approaching tourists!!

small but beautiful. This popular and iconic tower in Belem is well worth a visit. just a few Euros or free with the lisbon card. Situated on the river bank. There is information on its history inside.

Well worth a visit. The tower of Belem is iconic and very popular at weekends. It is free to go in and the views from the top are worthwhile. The downside is the narrow stairways which are controlled by traffic lights. However the system does not work too well and jams on the stairs were common

Por mares nunca dantes navegados.... Absolutly breath taking location right on the bank of the river Tejo
Tagus in english opposite another place you must also visit the JERONIMOS MONASTRY
Close on Mondays. Have been here on a previous visited but wanted to take friends there. Unfortunately on the Monday we visited the monument was closed. Never mind. We'll be back

Dramatic Monument. Sits out on the water, which makes it quite striking. I don't necessarily think this one merits paying the price to go up for the view. But tourist attractions in Lisbon are so inexpensive that its not really a splurge. We went offseason so it wasn't wall to wall tourists. If the season is in full swing, don't to kick yourself for not paying the entry fee to climb the stairs for the view.
amazing view. It's only 20' from lisbon and you can get there by tram n15 from comercio square. the ticket is only 5 euros and after that you can go to the archeological museum or the monastery

Tower not so interesting but historic. The town itself seems important because of the link with Columbus and the explorers leaving from here. The tower itself was not particularly interesting and is a distance from the monastery and pastry shop, both of which are worth visiting. The tower is on the list of "must see" spots, but it's important to see all the sights in Belem, not only the tower.

Many steps so wear good shoes. There were alot of steep steps to climb in order to get to the top of the tower. They have an electronic system which tells you when you can go up and when you can go down the various parts of the tower. It didn't work too well as many people weren't obeying the lights so be prepared to be stuck on different levels for a while especially if it is busy. Great views of the city from the tower.

Lots of steps. The weather was miserable, but we had a nice visit to this Tower. The steps up and different levels were a hit. Not a lot of information on site about the Tower? But a nice enough visit.

Nice historical monument. We didn't stop for a tour here, but it's in a nice wide open park with views of the Tagus river estuary.The tower itself is weathered and it appears that it's possible to take a tour all the way to the top turrets and look out over the city and harbour.

Don't get stranded on the roof. Free before 2pm on Sundays, this attraction can get pretty busy. When we visited we ended up stranded on the roof for ages. The roof and upper floors of the tower are reached by one thin spiral stairwell: I don't think the 15th Century builders were planning for thousands of tourists traipsing up and down all day. The stairs are so narrow only one person can safely walk up, or down, at a time. They've implemented a traffic light system so that, in theory, people going up won't bump into people coming down. Unfortunately a lot of people were ignoring it, so by the time we got to the roof more people were flooding up and nobody was getting a chance to go down. It was quite funny seeing the puzzled look on people's face when they reached the top and had to immediately join the queue to get back down because the roof was so crowded. It was also funny seeing how many people bumped their heads on the small doorframe- watch out for that, btw.The Torre de Belem is a beautiful building, but I'd recommend just staying outside and taking your photos from there. Unless you have a deep interest in medieval Portuguese history, in which case get inside, take a look around the cellar prisons and try to be patient with people who don't understand that green means go and red means stop.
The great Torre de Belém. The famous monument in Lisbon and perhaps in Portugal, the photos speak for it´s self. If you come to Lisbon you can not go away with out visit it. Very romantic as well.

Pretending to be a soldier. The mind boggles when you think this used to be in the middle of the river - but it makes a lot more sense that that's where it was designed for. The prison cells downstairs are tiny (wouldn't like to have been a pirate!) and the views over the river are beautiful - we could see back as far as the 25 April bridge. A fair way from the city centre but with the Lisboa card we got the bus journey and entry included, then decided to walk back as far as the docks under our own steam.
Must visit. This was slightly out of the way of the main bit of town but is pretty cool to see and definitely one of the must-see sights of the city. Offers great views from the top.

very nice. Historic landmark, very beautiful construction and close to other magnificent historic placesI visited in December 2013 , so wind was blowing throughout all the tours but beautiful view otherwise. Very narrow passages so be patient with others

Best from the outside. This is a lovely tower right on the waterfront. While we enjoyed viewing it, we did not feel compelled to pay to enter. It is not very high so would not offer an amazing view. Well worth visiting though because it is located in Belem, near the other attractions there.
Nice View. The view from above was amazing, the bridge, the monastery, the river, Belem Tower. I was there is much wet and fog, about 11am.. no line to speak of.
Day visit. Made our own way to Belem and had a great time. Maritime museum is brilliant.Wouldn't recommend queuing at the pattisserie - you can get just as good pastries at any pattisserie in Lisbon!

Not on a Sunday. On a Sunday it is free up to 2pm and I think half of Lisbon was there. Very narrow stairs working on a traffic light system which lots of people ingored causing chaos on the stairs!! Better views fom the Discoveries monument 2 euros for lift to top.
One stop on our excursion. We were on a cruise and Lisbon was one of our ports. This was one of the sights we saw on our tour (arranged independently) and it was certainly impressive close up.

Better view with no crowd at Padroa dos Descobrimentos. This was not worth it after visiting the monument to Henry the Navigator just a block away. The cost is half and there are fewer people and there is an elevator. Either way the view is great. You see a side of the city not seen from the castle or other hills within city center.
Nice at sunset.. It's just a small tower with antique architecture. We couldn't get in because it was closed for visits. Nice view at sunset.

500 year old Protector. At the point where the Tagus opens out to enter the sea stands this fine example of pure Manueline style architecture. Belem, short for Bethlehem, Tower was built to protect the harbour of Restelo at the entrance to the Tagus. It stands alone looking out over the incoming and outgoing tide. We were there at low tide and the mud flats shimmered at its feet like black satin. There is a fine view from the tower platform over Belem and the Tagus.

Everyone must see that Little tower. It's little and beautiful that Lisbon monument. If you go to Lisbon you better see the tower. View from the place is nice and we didn't took the stairs . We saw the river view with the tower from the yellow bus at Alfama neigbourhood. It's a beatiful view.
Watchable, visit inside isn't necessary. Looks great, is famous so worth to see. If Y need nice view from Tower - go inside. But truly? It isn't necessary to enthuse the edifice.

Where the Tag river goes to Atlantic Ocean. Monument Padrão dos Descobrimentos for Henry the Sailor, impressive vie for gate: copy of Golden Gate. Step to Mosteiro dos Jerónimos (monastery) and to Belem Tower and Belem Palce. Must see!

Iconic monument. You must go and visit this when you go to Lisbon. Set on its own against the delta. Views are great from the top but be prepared for a long climb up a narrow stone circular staircase and then a scary climb down as the one way system fails!Top tip; go on Sundays and it's free, otherwise it's €5.

Very cool historical structure and beautiful architecture but way too many people. I think this is a must visit if you're in the Belem area which is probably what makes it so incredibly frustrating. The architecture is extraordinary but be prepared for long waits crammed against a staircase. I was alone and had plenty of time so I didn't mind but there were multiple instances where 50+ people would be coming down a staircase while 50 more were waiting to go up. They either need to have some traffic directors or admit fewer people per block of time. I'm glad I visited it but the better views are had from the outside. If you don't like being trapped and shoved stay away from this attraction.

Very nice monument with great views. A very nice tower in the district of Belem, in Lisbon, a shame it was so rainy when we visited but still worth it. It is cheaper to visit with a combined ticket to the monastery of Jeronimos.
Iconic site, a must see. A morning here from Lisbon to see the sites. Really great fortress / prison. I really iconic site in this great city. We look the tram here.Some great pictures of the area.

Magical. We went in the evening. The river was quiet and the air was still. The light playing off of the water and the clouds made the place magical and fun. We were one of the last to go through before it closed, giving us less of a crowd and more room to move around! It was the high light of our short trip to Lisbon.
Excellent from outside - Poor inside. Perfect shot for sunset photography. The inside was poor enough. Five (5) euros for nothing? Don't visit this tower. Just stay outside.
Worth a visit!. Lovely place and quay leading towards this tower... nothing particular exciting inside, but a view over the water is nice... We were on Sun - entrance was free free charge ))

Impressive landmark. Along the river just outside the city is this impressive tower. We visited in the late afternoon and it looked marvelous in the light. Not much to see or do besides the tower, but if you are into great architecture and historical buildings, this is one tower you should see. Or just relax after a city walk and enjoy the view over the river and the ships passing by.
