Beautiful view!. It's a reminder of Portuguese glory, with a gorgeous view from the top. It's worth climbing 3 stories up some very narrow stairs. It also has an underground floor (a dungeon, in the old days). Since we visited in January, there was no line to wait in..The entrance is free of charge from Lisboa Card holders, like most other places in Belem (not the Museo da Marinha though!)

Symbol of great times. This is truly a landmark of Lisbon. It's an old 15th century little fortress at the mouth of Tagus river joining the Atlantic ocean, in the Belem part of town. It was built as a defensive fort and as a landmark for famous Portuguese sailors, when coming back from their great expeditions.It is very rich in architecture, very ornamental, in the Manueline style. The style of the rich 15th cent.Portugal from overseas trade and robbery.It looks greater from the outside. Inside it is a little bit dissappointing, except the first terrace which is marvelous.Don't wait the line to climb the top. It takes double time, for up and down, and the view is nothing special (better opt for the top of the Navigators monument, which is close by, higher, and has a lift).Buy the combined ticket, for Belem tower and The Jeronimo monastery (it is cheaper).

Interesting to see. This was a really interesting site to see because it has a lot of cool history. It's also right on the river, which is nice. I would go with a guide of some sort to let you know the significance of the place, though, or else it will just look like a random tower on the water.

Not a must see. This is an interesting little place to visit and if you have bought a lisbon card worth the effort to cue however you only really paying for a view from the top, which isn't that high. its most impressive from the outside as there isn't really much inside and the cue to go up and down the stairs in this confined space a bit of a pain

Great historic site. There is a fee to visit and there are usually lines but the wait is worth it to see this historic site. There is not much inside other then some old cannons and narrow spiral stair cases. there are 4 levels to get to and you have to watch the traffic signals and only go when the arrow and green light are going in the direction you are going. The views are beautiful and there are great picture opportunities on all levels. Worth the visit.
Lisbon symbol. It's one of the Lisbon's symbols and it really is pretty. Too bad we only saw it from the outside :(

Good walk from the Pasteleria de Belem. Unfortunately as I was there on January 1st (due to work) the tower was closed. It was extremely windy and starting to drizzle, but the walk was still enjoyable from the monastery down the monument of the discoveries, over to the tower. I found it to be nice neat piece of architecture, but of all the things to do in Lisbon, this is a hour stop at best. It is difficult to get to considering how easy everything else in Lisbon is walk or use the metro, but considering how much is in Belem, it is an easy stop to combine with the other Belem sights.

A Lisbon Icon. A very interesting tower on the banks of a river. Apparently a great example of Manueline architectural style. I was more drawn to the details on its facade - a mixture of different architecture influences. Im not an expert but the Moorish influence is evident. A must to see, located in an area where other Lisbon attractions are.

Quirky place to visit. The Torre de Belem is an interesting building but has some narrow staircases and low ceilings in places, so isn't for everyone. There are information boards on each floor explaining how the tower was built and what each room/floor was used for. These are worth reading as there is not much in the rooms themselves to indicate what part they played. There is only one, steep, narrow stone staircase to access the floors and this is operated on a timer system, with only 120 people allowed in the tower at a time. Do leave yourself enough time to get back down the tower as you might have to wait on one of the floors if lots of people are trying to leave at the same time.The architecture on the outside is more noteworthy and includes one of the first, if not the first, depictions of a rhinoceros in the country! You can visit it for free if you have a Lisboa card, otherwise it is 5 Euros (early 2014 prices).
Beautiful. Even if you don't feel up to climbing all those steps, it is a beautiful building in a stunning location.

Must see in Lisbon!. Very nice tower with lots of information. Worth a visit. There is just a little issue. Since the stairs are really small, there is only on way to go at the time. When going up, you have to wait upstairs. There is a sound and a display that tells you if you can walk or not. That sound was REALLY ANNOYING! It's like a horn. I heard the horn still when I had dinner a few hours later. I don't know why they have not installed a better (calmer) system...

beautiful but not outstanding. I liked torre de belem,one of the most historical landmark in portugal but i cant imagine an old person or disabled one to go up the tower. small stairs with a complicated control for going up and down, only one person trying to organize many tourist at the same time.don't miss the pastel de belem fabric.

If windy, hold on to your hat. It is near St.Jerome's Monastery and the Monument of Henry the Navigator. Good walk if the weather allows. In our case (January 1), it was rather windy with a bit of rain, so we held onto our hats good. However, the Tower is magnificent, even more so in this kind of weather. Nearby there is the actual plane which first flew across the Atlantic southward.highly recommended.

Tower of Belem. This is located close to the Monument to the Discoveries and Jeronimo's Monastery, so most tourists would visit all 3 highlights. The other two highlights are more interesting than this (a mere tower). When we were here, entry to the top of the tower was closed (for whatever unknown reason).

A gem of architecture. Touring the tower offers a close up look at the beauty unique to Manueline style. From below the stone carving looks almost delicate, but by climbing and viewing the balconies close up reveal the strength of well worked stone.
cute cute cute. Very cute place... Go in the midle of the week.Enjoy the view from the top of the tower.It is a special event when it is windy.

Not worth the time. I was disappointed with Belem in general. While the monastario do jeronimo is worth seeing, the tour really wasn't worth it. I regretted not spending more time in Sintra instead of going to Belem.

Not a major stop for me, but hey it's History!. This fortress tower from the early 1500s is not much to "see" but it's right near the Jeronimos monastery, easy to stop by and take a look. There is no charge to walk up to the tower, but I did not go inside, and there may be a charge for entry. It's right on the edge of the river Tagus, with a beautiful concrete walkway that goes quite a way along the river. The tower is well preserved, there's a sailboat marina nearby - the sailboats were more interesting to me :) And there's a cute little tent-shop kiosk area at the walkway, with actual handmade embroidery articles and lots of tourist trinkets.

Old World Portugal. This fortress like lookout post brings back images and ideas of those seafaring explorers who left Portugal to discover the new world over 500 years ago. This has got to be the number one piece of history to see in the city of lisbon
Must See in Portugal. In spite of awful weather it was worth to take time and visit at Belem the historical Torre de Bellem. The only minus was water next it was full of trash.

Not worth the time you spent queuing. This tower is nice to see from outside. But there is nothing special inside .The interior of the tower as well as the view from its top are not worth the time you spent queuing to get inside/climbing upstairs. It took us healthy 30 mins to get inside the Tower, just to realize that there is nothing special there on the first 2 levels, and if you want to get on the upper level of the tower it will take you 30-40 more minutes, first, to queue up and then to queue down. If you still want to take a glance at the river from the side of Belem, this can better be done from the top of the Monument to the Discoveries.

Amazing View. The view from the top is spectacular! The moment itself is very interesting and the map of the world that is located in front of the monument is great. There is nothing inside but the elevator to go up. Very short time to view this if time is an issue. Definitely worth seeing.

very pretty and a good laugh. this is a very beautiful building and worth the qeue to get in (if you already have the combined ticket don't wait in the qeue go in the exit and there is someone there to scan your ticket but there is no sign to tell you this) inside, the staircase to get up and down the three stories is VERY narrow and so they have made a kind of traffic flow system to get people up and down safely its very simple, two arrows one pointing up one pointing down when the up arrow is green you are allowed to move UP the staircase, when the down arrow is green you are allowed to move down the stair case, how simple you are thinking but be prepared to have a good laugh at the ammount of people that cannot get to grips with this, its hilarious, but you can be trapped on the roof for awhile till there is a big enough gap for you to run down the stairs

Not for the high-season. We were there in November, so the place was left pretty much for ourselves. However, in the high-season it ca get crowded. A very interesting (low) tower with narrow staricases and low-ceiling underground rooms. Impressive stone-work all over.
Nice views!. There wasn't a lot to see here, but some nice views from the top! Very narrow staircases to the top, so be careful when heading up to the top, can't also be very busy.
Nice place. Take the tour of Lisboa which will take to Torre de Belem, the Monastery and other sites near by the Tower. If you go in the winter my recomendation is to do the morning tour.

Amazing castle/tower, and pleasant stoll in the park. After days of cobblestone streets and climbing the hills of the city it was fun to join the other families of Lisbon for a leisurely walk in the area around the tower.

Great looking tower. Great looking tower with good photo opportunities. The inside can get crowded and there can be long waits to go up the tower. May not be worth the price to see the inside, but the outside is great.
It is fantastic. the architecture style manuelino is like a disney princess castles It is very beautiful especially in sunshine

Gorgeous iconic little castle. This really is one of those must see sights - and one which does live up to it's billing.We came on a Sunday and entry was free - arriving at 10.30 there was no queue and we were straight into the tower it's self. (Standard miserable Portugese ticketing staff - where do they get these morose people ?!). It's certainly not a large attraction but it's very ornate.Getting up and down the tower one has to enter a room at the bottom via some turnstiles (They limit the number of people in the tower) and obey some traffic lights to go up / down the stairs. This seemed a really good idea as the stairway is v narrow. Either the timing was all wrong or people were ignoring the green / red arrows but it seemed to cause no end of trouble.There's not a lot to see inside - the view from the top of the tower is impressive though.We passed the tower later - mid afternoon and there were huge queues to get in - so get here early.The attractions main selling point is simply viewing it from outside. It really is, on a fine day, spectacular.

Stairway to heaven - not!. While the tower, perched on the Lisbon harbor entrance, is a beautiful medieval design, the trip to the top is quite an ordeal. There is a system of red/green lights to keep some level of organization navigating the narrow spiral staircase. If you have the patience to withstand the queue, the view from the top is worth it.

Interesting monument that is all. The Tower of Belem is an interesting constrution, but there isn´t much to see in it. Its main attraction is the main tower, but climbing it is troublesome. The stairs allow only one person per turn. People frequently get jammed in a very cloustrofobic place. The view up there is good, but not great.

Don't bother - see it from the outside if you must. This is a historic monument, no doubt about that. However, it is devoid of any of its internal history, it is just a continuum of empty rooms. The overwhelming memory I will take away from this experience is the amount of queuing we had to do, and the danger we were placed in, to commit to this opportunity to queue.This monument has a single stone spiral staircase up and down the building. On the day we went we had torrential rain, so the staircase was wet. Whilst a sign said a max. of 120 people in the tower there were actually far more than this. I would have thought they may have noticed that hundreds of people were entering but no one seemed to be leaving, but apparently not. The spiral staircase was managed by a traffic light system, which may have well been semaphore, because either people didn't understand the difference between green and red, or they didn't care. Anyway, the result was that by the time we got to the top we had to queue for an hour to get down. When we did finally get the green light to go down we had to climb across thousands of people trying to get up, and all on a 600cm wide wet stone spiral staircase. All in all not a great advertisement for Portuguese tourism, or indeed for humanity itself!

Worth passing by, but not that much to see inside. An interesing building with a fascinating past, but not really worth the admission price to look around inside. More could have been done with the ground floor space to tell the story of the building's past. You do get some interesting views from the upper floors, but there are plenty of places for free views in Lisbon

Great Tower. Although you have to wait to climb up the tower once inside (using a traffic light system) it is worth the effort. Amazing views considering you are only a few floors up. Not a lot to see inside, this is for looking out. You do have to bend double in the dungeons.
Nice from the outside. We did not go inside, we were a bit tired. It is a tower used in the past to watch the sea for protection. There must be a great view!

Pretty sight. The tower is a lovely sight and if you're lucky to be here on a nice day you'll have beautiful views over the water in the sun. I didn't go inside since it was very crowded and I heard a lot of people complain that it was too dark. It's just nice to look at from the outside, sit a while and take in the views.You can easily get here by tram or bus from Praça do Comércio and visit the other attractions around the Belém area. The tram tends to get more crowded, I opted for a bus ride back to the city center and it was great. Most tour buses stop here as well.The area between the tower and the monument of discoveries is nice for a walk and you will find souvenirs and restaurants.
old glory days. one of the essential attractions of lisbon representing the old glory days of portugal. nice view too out to the river tego.
Beautiful and historical. For us brazilian Portugal is very important, and walk around this very beautiful monument is a good chance to know about this country´s history.

Torre de Belem: Amazing. The tower takes a while to walk to from the "Belem" bus stop but it's an absolutely gorgeous walk along the river under a beautiful sky they say is blue 300 days of the year. Even in December the weather was gorgeous and the tower itself is an impressive monument to the explorers who left from Portugal to discover the world. Well worth a visit!

Tall. It's very tall. And very narrow. And you have to wait your turn in order to ascend or descend flights of stairs. And it is a long way from the monastery and the discoveries monument. But it does have a nice feel to it and there's nothing like a view of the River Tagus to settle one's spirit. Worth visiting even just for completion's sake.
Sunset is the best time. Get great photos with a sky full of radiant colours at sunset. Not to be missed. Highly recommended.
Beautiful and peacefull!. The place tells a lot about the history of Portugal and must be seen! The view from the tower to the River Tejo is wonderful.
Fantastic. A must see, really amazing its a tardis much bigger inside than it looks, there is a charge but worth it,

This and many other Lisbon attractions close by. It is a lovely walk along the Tagus river side. Seeing the various touristy places along the river is a lovely way to spend some time in Lisbon if you want to see something in Lisbon when you are there on business. The castle stood magnificiently on river and has stood the times. Across the castle is a very modern looking building - a cancer research center. The contrast is quite appealing. Enjoy the castle and views around here.

Nice location on river Tagus. Belem tower is a world heritage site located in the banks of River Tagus. The tower played a significant role in the Portuguese maritime discoveries of the era of the Age of Discoveries.The tower was commissioned by King John II to be part of a defense system at the mouth of the Tagus river and a ceremonial gateway to Lisbon

Magnificent View. On the same port of call day I went there once again a memorable place for the great explorer on the western side of the Lisbon town centre. To reach there we took a tram, running parrellel to train tracks but equally faster. The long unending white facade of the monasetry Jeroimos comes in view with a park opposite. Vaso da Gama's tomb is there but I didn't pay Euro 5 for the previlege and instead went towards the river bank to apprecaite the tower. Worth a detailed visit next time

A lovely tower.. This 500 years old impressive tower is built on the bank of the Tagus river.It has withstood centuries of harsh winds and tides, yet it still remained beautiful.The tower has 6 floors to be visited, although the upper floors can only be accessed via a VERY narrow staircase (not recommended for claustrophobic folks). There's a traffic light that signals when people can go up the stairs or down the stairs, as it is literally impossible for people to go on both directions simultaneously.The tower's top terrace offers a stunning view of the river the the 25th of April bridge.Free entrance with the LisboaCard.

A fairy castle. This gothic castle is like something out of a fairy tale perched on the edge of the river. Unfortunately we could not visit the interior as there was some works beign carried out. Would love to see inside - maybe next time.

Medieval Fort. Jutting out into the river, and resembling a 16th century ship with a high qusrterdeck, this castle was built to defend the river approach to Lisbon.With narrow, winding stairways, and small cannon suitable for stopping a small ships, it gives an insight into the time period.Amuse yourself by reading the English translation about a rhinoceros that arrived as a gift from India. Never stint on translations!

Worth seeing.... Stopping to see the Tower of Belem is worth it for the great views right on the water. If you like taking photos, you won't be disappointed of the various views this location provides!

A historical tower. We made three trips to Belem and the first time we went to see the tower. Unfortunately we spent a lot of time walking to it as our tram/light rail broke down way before our stop and we had to walk quite a bit to get to the Belem tower.It was fairly nondescript to look at,even though it is of historical significance

Remarkable Historical Tower- Must See. The Tower is reached by a small gangplank- it was once further out in the river but evidently the Tagus has receded over time. This is the place where the voyages of discovery embarked, the Armada assembled and Columbus stopped on his return to Europe. It is a beautiful tower with many medieval embellishments. The outer part is the best but we did take the very tight stairs to explore inside as well. We were lucky to visit on a bright sunny day and the river views from the Tower were spectacular. It is definitely a highlight and should not be missed.
A window over the river. Pray God to offer you a shiny day and you'll enjoy all the magic of this place, where from Portuguese set sail to give "new worlds to the world"
Worth a Visit. Such a pretty building right on the river. Admission was very reasonable and the views were lovely. Lowest level has really nothing to see, but the rest of the building is interesting.

A little jewel on the Tagus bank. It is rather small but superbly preserved. We went there in late november so not too many people at the same place at the same moment (luckily). Only 120 people are allowed in the tower at the same time and you have to respect the traffic lights to take the stairs (up or down)

A "must see" while in Lisbon. Interesting fort built on the river. Beautiful views of other nearby attractions.The steps up are narrow and spiral. They are timed so that foot traffic is either up or down, never both at the same time. Many nearby attractions - Military museum, carriage museum, Discovery monument, and other museums.Buy the Lisboa card at any news stand - Then you use that one card for the tram, trolley, museum entry (some free, some discounted).
a must in Lisbon. Torre de Belem is a must in Lisbon. Fee - 5 Euro. On sunny days there are plenty of visitors and you will need to queue for a few minutes to get in and out.

Beautiful Sight, But Didn't Go Inside. I can't remember what the cost was to go inside the Tower, but I decided that it wasn't worth it. I would certainly suggest seeing it, but you can decide whether to pay to tour it or not. Also, there is minor construction going on there right now- building a new foot bridge to the Tower- not a real inconvenience.

Interesting Monument. Despite the wind and rain we enjoyed a late afternoon visit here. We had purchased a Lisboa card and entrance was included in the price. I think otherwise it was about 6 euros. The spiral stairs are very narrow but they have a one way system and timer in place so luckily you don't meet people coming the other way which is a really good idea!

Torre de Belem. A really beautiful building, well worth the visit. It can be seen by taxi, walking or the best way is hop on hop off tour bus, where you can take your time to explore and then hop on the next tour bus
Beautiful monument. Spectacular place. One of the most beautiful Portuguese monuments. Magical place when your imagination goes way back to the discovery times.

Lisbon 1st monument. The Belém tour is, in my opinion, the mainly monument of the beautiful city of Lisbon. Building on the 16th century, originaly completely sorrounded by the water, the monument is a really expression of the portuguese sea discovers. You must see also the Jerónimos church (near the Belem tour, in the other side of the avenue) and the Pastéis de Belém, the best cake of Lisbon

Interesting and good views. Well it's a bit of a way out from the city but well worth it. The number 15 tram is a good way of getting there, either stop at the Monastery and its about a 600m walk or go to the next stop and cross the footbridge.Good views from the battlements, not a lot to view unless you are into the Manueline architectural style.
Nice tower. Lovely tower. We didn't go inside as we wanted to save some time but it's nice to go there even just for the walk.

the most visited attraction in lisbon. It is the most visited attraction in Lisbon. You will take many pictyres. The outside of the tower is very nice as the manuelino rythm is very nice. Inside there is nothing special besides the eciting wiew. Children will love to climb to the top.

it is the most popular monument. It is the most popular monument of lisbon. If you have seen photos of Lisbon you have seen it. The monument is very nice at the exterior as you can see the manuelino art. Inside it doeshnt have something to see besides the terrific wiew. It is a nice place to go with your children as they will love to climb in the tower.

beautiful. This is a beautiful piece of architecture that is worth visiting. We did not line up to go inside as the line was long and we put the rest of our time to visiting other sites in Belem. That being said, just viewing the outside is fairly gob-smackingly wonderful as we sat on the steps for a long time soaking it up.

Beautiful set for pictures.. The tower at sunset is a very romantic setting. it is a very nice place for pictures and just imagine that navigators used to set sail from this tower... Souvenir shop in this area are a little bit cheaper than in the center of Lisbon.

Very nice building. Very nice building full of history, there is no great need to pay for the visit inside the building. Tip: Souvenir merchants outside the tower are amongst the cheapest we encountered in Lisbon.

My dream place.... Phenomenal tower with a wonderful view of the ocean and Vasco da Gama Bridge in nice old part of the city where you can also visit a famous bakery Pasteis de Belem...Ticket is also not so expensive. Tower has a few different levels. It's very old, built for the defense of Lisbon, also used as a prison, but today such a nice attraction!

Beautiful Lookout Point. Located close to the Jeronimos monastery and delicious bakery known for making pasteis de nata, the three together make a great day in Lisbon! The Torre de Belem was pretty crowded (during the summer) but definitely worth it. The views from the top are beautiful and the architecture is intriguing and whimsical. Prisoners were kept in the creepy but interesting basements. Don't miss this!

Good Views for Photographs. Worth taking the cheap public transport options of tram/bus/train to Belem and to snap some impressive photos across the river. Not worth going inside the Torre but great walk along the front.

Superb. Fabulous architecture, incredible to see what was built by hand. One tip though, go early as it gets very busy, and obey the traffic light system on the stairs! Free admision on Sunday until 2 pm
Oddity. This monument is a bit of a trek from Lisbon city centre, but worth a visit. The nearby Discoveries monument and Jeronimoes monastrery are nearby and within walking distance.

Busy but very nice. We were delighted to find the attraction was free on Sundays! It is a tight squeeze walking up and not for those with poor mobility, balance, or a fear of close spaces. It did however offer beautiful views of the Tagus river and too is a historical place that is great to see!

Belem. Loved it with the sea and the sun and a lovely park. It could do with better public transport links however, and maybe some direction boards so we knew what we were looking at. The actual building was fascinating, as was the history and the views. Don't miss the harbour close by, with hundreds of fish and jellyfish swimming around, but watch the traffic on the walk back to the town centre, unless you have a car or have come by tour bus.

Worth a visit. We went to Belem on a beautiful sunny day and enjoyed walking by the river and having a drink watching the boats go by. We did not go in the Torre but loved taking photos of it and the monument to the discoverers. There is a lot to visit here and you could spent a day.We went by tram but it was very crowded and we had to stand all the way being pushed against. We thought we would catch the train back but there is only a ticket machine at the station and you needed a special card to get a ticket from it which we did not have! So we got a taxi back which cost us about 1 euro more for 2 than the tram had cost and was a very pleasant journey.
Interesting Tower. Visited the Tower as part of a day trip to Belem. Entry was free with the Lisboa card and it also allowed you to skip the queue. Good views over the area from the top of the tower.

Nice design. Looks quite good as you enter Lisbon and brings Portugal's past into the present. Can be visited by the various types of tourist transportation in Lisbon and is close enough from the centre to visit.

Quick visit.. If planning visit the Belem area of Lisbon by train, be careful which train you take because not all of them actually stop here. Look at the front of the train before you get on to make sure it says "todo". The tower is a quick stop of attractions in this area. The climb to the top is not difficult and there are signal lights telling you when to go up or down so it is safer. There is a discount with the Lisboa Card. After the tower, walk along the water toward the sculpture. There are also some nice spots for lunch near here.

Wonderful sight surrounded by a great park. It was so amazing to think of all the sailors going and coming from this spot for so many years. It has a fantastic view of the river and onto the ocean. Beautiful sunset and view of the 25 de Abril Bridge also.

Proud to have Portugal share in history. Seeing Belem Tower and the waterfront of Lisbon made one realize what an important part Portugal played in the founding of America. Impressive how much pride the Portuguese take in the contribution of their country to the discoveries made in the 1400's and 1500's.
loved that area and the Cafe De Belem.. Loved the history and the photo opts in this area of Lisbon. Especially loved the special treats at Cafe De Belem.

Well preserved olde worlde Tower / Fortress. Saw this place as we walked along the boulevard and had a wander around ..... and up and down the ramparts. Saw the prisoner cells where the poor souls must have had a twice daily wake up bath as they appear to be below the high water mark. We had bought the 'Lisboa' card for train / tram journeys and I think entry was free with the card. Interesting to think of the people who lived and died there over the centuries and certainly worth the visit .... followed by coffee and a Pasteis de nata in a cafe ........... yum !

The Belem Tower - "Good Bye" Tower. The Belem Tower is the place from where most of the well-known expeditions in quest of far-away lands were launched. And, as such it can be called the "Good Bye" Tower and/or the Tower of Tears. The location is right near the confluence of the river and Atlantic ocean.

Belem Tower. Great area to walk around in. The Tower itself is very picturesque right on the water front and the area is altogether a nice place to spend a morning. We couldn't go in the Tower as it was being renovated. Don't forget to sample the famous custard tarts from the bakery just across from the Tower. Good way to visit is on the Red or Yellow Bus tours. If you time this right, (we waited until our last day), the 24 hour bus ticket also enables you to ride on the local trams and entitles you to a free ride to the Airport on the Airport Bus all for about 15 Euros.

Go on a Sunday. On a lovely Sunday in October we went to Belem. It is a great place, vibrant, and full of history. We walked along the promenade to Torre de Belem. On a Sunday many attractions are free including the Torre de Belem. There was a queue but it didn't take long to get inside. The structure is very photogenic both inside and out and it is great way to spend an hour. Traffic lights inside mean only a certain amount of people are in any one area at a given time, so it is never overpacked.
Out of a fairytale. Short stop here to see this wonderful old tower - not to be missed! We didn't go inside as we didn't have time, but the tower itself is so magical, that was enough.

Nice building, nice view. We decided to climb all the stairs in the tower, hoping we would enjoy the view. It paid off, climbing the stairs was very exciting for my children (we pretended we were knights:)), we had lots of fun with "traffic lights" - there are traffic light on the stairs, making the traffic one way in order to avoid jams (the staircase is very narrow). The surrounding area is nice as well. There is a little bar near by (where I had the most expensive coffee in Lisbon - but still cheap compared to my home country). Overall I recommend the visit, provided that you have time for it.
Great setting. Fantastic building in great setting, though we decided not to pay to go inside. Nice walks along riverside to and from village centre

Great views. The Torre is found in the Belem neighbourhood (west Lisbon) and can be reached on the tram, by train or by bus. The tram is the most expensive - so check out the bus. Although the guide books indicated that you could not climb up to the top level - this was not the case - and the view was incredible. The circular staircase is very steep and narrow - so consider this before going to the top. Check out the gargoyles - they are great. There is a fee to go into the bottom level but they did not check for tickets to go up to the top. You can save about 3 Euro a person if you buy a ticket for the monastery in Belem at the same time as the Torre.

Surrond by the sea. Built in 1515 as a fortress to guard the entrance to Lisbon's harbor,You can by torre de belem + Mosterio dos jeronimos for 10,00 (best value).Be prepared for so many steps to see the view upstairs.
Pretty average. The tower architecture was interesting enough to visit. The little posters with information about the tower were helpful.
Super attraction. A commanding vista for this fortress. Many great photo opportunities at this site. It was windy, so bring a light jacket, just in case!

Impressive tower by the sea. Placed at the end of the sea wall walkway right at the end of Belem the Torre stands out as a great view from a long distance away. Renovations being done but doesn't impair the history or significance of this structure.

Well worth seeing. We visited to Belem Tower on what turned out to be a very rainy afternoon. However, we did go up to the top of it - not for the faint hearted as there are a lot of steps! Very interesting place and great view from the top.

Take a tour of the Torre!. Was really lucky with this one. The attraction is free between 10am and 2pm on Sundays. I arrived at 1.55pm. The walk along the river towards the Tower is very scenic and is an escape from the throngs in Belem. You cross a wooden bridge to get to it with the waves splashing. The tower allows great views of Lisbon and the surrounding areas. It is worth climbing the steep and narrow stairs to the top for the views. The traffic light system for allowing people up and down the steps is a little funky but necessary. Well worth the stroll.
Nice spot. Pretty spot on the water, there wasn't much to see in terms of the tower itself, pretty small and sparse- but it's a nice little spot to walk around

Tourist Stop. Located near the military museum this is in a area for tourists who like history and being hustled by roma's selling scarves & sunglasses.Too far to walk to pasteis de belem but it is an interesting place.

Must see on any Lisbon trip. Belem is probably the most noteworthy part of Lisbon with a dense ensemble of sights in walking distance. Important to notice is to not go on Mondays (which we did), as everything will be closed and you have to return to see things from 'the inside' - also avoid weekends when cues are a mile long to buy one of the famous Pasteis de Belem (if there is no choice but to wait, then wait anyway, it is indeed worth it)

History under your feet. Like those pasteis de nata, if you come to Portugal you have to come and 'try' each one of these monuments, there's an interesting atmosphere in Torre de Belem, worth a visit. The steps to the top can be scary, it's a very small space with people going up and down the steps at the same time and no room to pass, but it's fun.
Lovely building. Just had to get to Belem to see this, lovely building, was disappointed to see a lot of rubbish floating in the sea by the shore near this. Great photo opportunities.

Free on Sunday. Not sure if it's every Sunday, but when we went it was free on Sunday, as was Jeronimo's Monastery - we went early to beat the crowds not realising it was free, and it was well worth it, so worth checking out before you travel. Worth a visit.
Belem Tower. An interesting Tower and worth a few minutes off the tour bus to see. If you see a group make sure you tale your photos before the group is in the way.

An interesting place, with great views of the river.. its in a nice part of town, with lots of other things to see within walking distance. its only small and no where near it says it is on the map on here strangely. we didnt go inside but there are nice photos to be taken here.

Surrounded by water. It had so many nooks and crannies, balconies and terraces. It's relatively small , so you don't need a lot of time there. About one hour, including pictures. The stairway up and down only allows room for people to go in one direction, so you have to wait your turn for the green light . Well worth the visit, and then you are in the right spot to take a nice stroll on the waterfront.

It is what the pictures show. The tower is one of the tourist sights of Lisbon and it is what it is. Its old and historic and the walk to it from the tram stop is pleasant.Not sure why they built this opposit all the oil & gas storage facilities though!

Old and new blended. The Belem Cultural Centre ,a contemporary touch, across the road from th Monastery, is well worth a visit. The Berardo Collection of Modern and Contemporary art is tempting for art lovers and a snack at the cafè on the top floor of the Conference Centre (open until 8 p.m.)can be enjoyed together with a panoramic view of the Talgo and a chance to see young Lisboners intent on their studies while sipping a coffee.

It's okay. It was okay to visit, but not as spectacular ad we expected. Please make sure you ask for the combi ticket for the Tower and the Monastry. This saves you some money. We visited the Tower first and did not know about the combi ticket. After the Tower we went to the Monastry and saw there was a combi ticket possibility. We asked if we could get a discount because we already visited the Tower, but we got a No on that.

Great from outside but poor management –long wait to go down!. The tower is great to walk around and to see from the ground. The view from the top does not seem so very different from the the view from the ground and I am not sure it's worth EUR 5 per person.The provisions would probably not pass the UK health and safety regulations. There is only one way up/down which is a very narrow stairwell that can only accommodate one flow of traffic at a time. This is timed by simple traffic lights. But the timing does not work well as we got stuck up there for a long while, unable to leave and had to wait for a long time. There was no attendant to manage the crowd or to call. Standing on the top of the tower in sunny weather, in a crowd, with no way to get out or call for attendant is not OK. I will be contacting the tourist board about this. The staff on site would not take a note of my complaint and all they could say was “sorry”.

worth a visit but very expensive. we spend half a day in Belem and it was enough to see the major sights. Too many tourists at some, but very beautiful. Be aware that there are entrance fees EVERYWHERE

Visiting Lisbon, go here. This was a beacon for navigators returning from the Indies and the new world. This is situated in the in the historical area of Belem and the tower is just of shore. Spectacular views over the river, fabulous wharf side walks and the magnificent 16th century monastery of Jeronimos is close by. If you are on a tour bus route of Lisbon you will also stop buy the museum of royal coaches which again is very close to this location. Well worth the visit as part of your stay in Lisbon.
Not worth the money. Too expensive, missing the historical feel to it - you can get a much better view from the Discoveries Monument for a lot less money.

Traffic Light System!. It's an quaint-looking tower, built offshore and sitting some metres away in the shallow waters. It won't take you that long to see it, so make you also factor this into your planning.The basement is not advised for anyone tall with back problems as the ceilings are extremely low and will have to stoop quite severely down there. Try to arrive early to beat the crowds as the thin, winding main staircase can become sardine-like and the traffic light system controlling which direction (up or down) you can travel at a specific time is effective in preventing chaos, but also makes you feel like part of a herd of cows. If you're visiting the monastery you can buy a dual ticket for both there and the Torre, which saves you money and time queuing. Worth seeing for sure, but certainly not earth shattering.
Gateway to Lisbon. Nice building on the entrance to the Tagus river. It's at the end of a long promenade walk from the centre. Probably best visited as part of a hop on & off bus tour

Interesting, but very difficult steps. The interior did not offer much, and the steps to the prison below were VERY steep & the rooms there required stooping to enter. To get to the upper levels of the tower required more very steep stairs without railings & also waiting in a line to be able to climb up. Not sure I would have paid to go inside again...looking at it from the outside would have been just about as good.

location is not correct!. First of all, i don't know who is the smart guy who put this mark in the middle of park!tower is on the seaside, 6-7 km down... So if your trying to find torre the belem, try it near belem monastery de jeronimos, it's 15 min from here...
Worth checking out. I love these kinds of things. Unfortunately My visit here was too early to be able to go inside but even just viewing the outside of it and surrounding area is neat.

Dont go inside. The tower looks great from the outside and this is it. If you go inside there is relay not much to see. First you have to pay a fee of 5,00€. In the lover part is a sort of exhibition (you need max 5 min to see everything). Than there is the tower. Well I almost loose my mind because of the staircase to the top. It is so narrow that people can either go up or down. You have a traffic light showing you what to do. But people ignore this and the staff doesn't care! it is horrible!! Once you managed to get to the top you can only stand in the line and wait do get down. It has taken 20 minutes for me to get into the staircase again. Don't recommend this for older people and people with some kind of disability.

An Historic Site to be Visited for the Experience. The tower is not huge, but a unique experience. The view at the top of the tower is great, but to get there you have to go through a winding staircase that is only big enough for a single flow of people either up or down. They have a unique light traffic system for people with red and green arrows indicating who goes when and where.Tips: For all attractions check opening & closing times to avoid disappointment. The Lisbon Card is very useful especially if you are in Lisbon for a few days. We purchased the 72 hour card and is was so convenient for all forms of transports as well as providing free or discounted entry into attractions. It paid for itself and we ended up marking significant savings overall.

Belem - interesting and enjoyable. The tower deserves a visit for its own sake (it is in the UNESCO cultural sites list) and for the views across the river from its top. We took a taxi to the tower from Rossio area (~8-10 euros). There is a fee for the tower, but it is free on Sundays. After visiting the tower walked on the river bank towards the city all the way to Ponte 25 de Abril. It was a very pleasant walk on a hot day. On the way, on the opposite side of the avenida there is Mosteiro dos Jeronimos - another beautiful Manueline building worth visiting. Under the Ponte there is a marina with many restaurants in it. We had dinner there, then took taxi to the hotel. That was a very nice day - culture, fresh air, a bit of exercise and great food.

Dont miss pastries belem!. Quaint, very busy pastry shop is devine! Try codfish, beef pastry and custard tarts they are famous for! Catch the tram no 15 from outside the pastry shop to get into lisbon central. Buy your transport green card and top up its good for trams and trains, easy transport around lisbon and beyond and cheap!
Worth a visit. Very cool tower that is well preserved. Worth a visit, especially when paired with other sights in Belem. Make sure to climb to the top for a great view!

A view from the shore. Torre de Belem is an architectural wonder on the shore of the city of Lisbon with alot of history surrounding it. You really get a good picture of what the ancient explorers like Vasco de Gama saw as they left Lisbon and moved into unknown waters. The whole area at the shore is very picturesque and worth visiting. Take your camera for sure.

they shut the door in our faces!. after the yellow tour bus passed us by, and we trudged all the way to this site, they shut the door in our faces, 20 minutes before it was scheduled to close. 'come back tomorrow!'
Belem tour. The trips we took where with the City Red bus which is hop on hop off 16 Euro for 48 hours the best way to tour any city
Tower and surroundings. Nice area for tourists, with a number of museums, monastery, cathedral and restaurants. Nautical Monument of Portuguese Exploration special.
Historic Landmark. The tower of Belem, played a major part in the discoveries of the new world by the Portuguese sailors under the auspices of Vasco da Gama (a must).

Nice building but nothing inside. The tower looks great sitting on the shoreline and once inside there are a number of empty rooms leading up to the top of the tower from where there are some good views of the river. There are no artifacts to view and little information about the history of the tower which made it slightly disappointing for me. Still worth a visit though. You can get a combined ticket for the Monastery of Jeronimos at 10 euros for both so it is not that expensive.

Small staircase. The Torre de Belem is a defense tower next to the Tagus river.It is a beautiful building with moorish accents and great views.Do go upstairs, but be aware that the staircase is very narrow, so don't do this when you are claustrophobic.

A Lisbon icon.. Combined with the monastery, monument and pastry shop the tower makes for a good excursion from Lisbon. Unfortunately the wooden walkway to the tower crosses a muddy 'moat' rather than an expanse of water.The women selling scarves nearby were a bit persistent.
Beauty & old. Great tower in the water. We enjoyed the city iof Belem. The coach museam is close and very nice. Wales through the city and then took the tram. Nice sights

Gorgeous. Well worth the trip. Must climb to the top. Loved the lights that allow people to travel either up or down so that you don't crash into people going the opposite direction. Wish more places would adapt this idea.

Small Outpost - Not a Huge Castle. The Tower is a small outpost that guarded the entrance to Lisbon. Originally it was located in the middle of the river which has receded over the years. It is a interesting piece of architecture and history, but by no means as interesting as the Monastery. The stairwells and the doorways give you an idea of just how small the people were in the 15th c. It's a little out of the way from the city, although a bus takes you to the Monastery and you have to walk along the waterfront to get to it. It's a nice walk if it's a nice sunny day.

We didn't even get in and it was great!. Ok, so honestly we spent a lot of money in the Modern Art shop, so we were thinking in skiping Belem Tower, but we though we should go even if we were not getting in (there's a fee for the entrance), but you know what, the beautiful view, getting into the door and appreciating this tower closely made it a very special visit.There was a sunny and windy day, we were able to seat in the park in front of the tower, get an icecream and just enjoy the view of the tower melting with the ocean while getting the sunlight.We took a lot of pictures, some people got closer and even get their feet in the water.So there you have, very nice experience, we only pay 1 euro for the ice cream, we have the nicest pics ever and we enjoyed a lot staring at the Tower.
Great. It's nice jus to walk around. There's a great sight. And yoy can also walk a little bit more and visit the others sightseens nearby.

History, architecture and culture. So many have written so much about Belem, there's not much left to say, so I'll be short and give some practical advice. Belem is, to my opinion, well worth a visit. If you're interested in history, architecture and culture you can easily spend at least half the day out there.First tip: Don't come early! From the morning until about lunchtime, the place is very busy with tourists coming in groups with hundreds of buses. After lunch the pressure is normally much less.Second tip: The city tram # 15 is the straight forward way to get there, but it is often quite busy. And if you are two or more people, and don't have a Lisboa Card or a Day Ticket to go for free, you will be better off taking a Taxi. From Rossio to Belem is about 7€.
Historical. Our visit was only in outside! Very nice! We saw persons on the top of tower, but we did not had courage to climb there!
stunning. this was part of our tour,lovely right beside the sea,the army had a display of army vehicles on the day we were here
Beautiful. It's a very simple place to visit, just a tower on the water. But it is beautiful inside and out, with gorgeous views of the water, and amazing architecture. I would highly recommend it.

a jewel of the MANUELINO. a genuine portuguese architectural style, the Manuelino is a kind of late gothic style with a lot of see and nautical decorative elements. You cannot miss it and in the surroundings you can find a even more beautiful site the Monastery of Belem also a monument of the Manuelino.

Piece of Navigators History. While a bit isolated from the other sights in the area this tower is a key part of the Portuguese Navigators history. The tower itself doesn't have a lot to see internally - mainly a cluster of small cannons. The original decorations and furniture seem to long gone. You can get cheap entry 3E vs 5E by buying a combo ticket as part of the Jerome Monastery ticket package.

Lovely tower in the river. You just have to go there. Not too big, entrance is 5 euro which gives you good value for money.The surrounding is fantastic and the history is briefly and well documented.Have been here 12 years ago, went no again and would go here again when in the neighbourhood.Thumbs up!
One of the reason. Why I wanted to see Lisbon. It didn't disappointed , except the tower is closed for , what I believe some reconstruction. But still amazing piece of art and architecture.
"Must See". It is well worth the visit. Interesting architecture, fascinating history. Does not require a great deal of time and should be included in every Lisbon itinerary.

Nicer from outside. Well, Torre de Belem is really nice from outside. Visiting it you spend most of your time waiting to get access to the next floor (5 in total) – or to get down again. The authorities try to be very organized, but as the time to climb or descend the stairs is too short – it ends up in total chaos. And in fact there is not that much to really be seen, the best are the views of Lisbon or the sea. As money is missing, painting is falling off the walls and the building seems to need some maintenance...Save the money & time to get in, take some nice photos from outside and buy some "pasteis de nata" in Belem instead!

Great monument, but not imperative to visit inside. It's a landmark of Lisbon and Portugal. Interesting architecture, view and historic interest, however, visiting its insides is not imperative. It is interesting, but a bit poor. The tower itself is an historical place but it hasn't a lot of stories to tell.

Belem Tower- historical site on the waterfront.. Fascinating piece of history worth seeing in a nice waterfront park setting. On the day we went there was free entry. We went there on one of the hop on-hop off busses. Afterwards we hopped off at the docks where there were many places to choose from for eating and drinking.
Fabulous building. Loved the traffic lights controlling access to the upper floors. Great views of the river and surrounds.

A must See in Lisbon. We walked from Lisbon center by the water down to the "Torre de Belem". We was a beautiful day and well worth it. You have a great view to the bridge and the Christo statue. I had no idea Lisbon had one too. By the bridge are a number of restaurants and you walk past a number of people fishing from the peer. It was really lovely. The Torre itself looks as if you have taken it out of a history book. The Portuguese played a big role in the discovery of the world. The Belem area has a lot of other places to see as well - I would suggest to definitely make a day trip. We ended up waling back and catching the sunset at one of the great spots in Lisbon.
Wonderful. One of the greatest spots to visit in Lisbon!The great Manueline style tower on Tagus River is an unforgettable landmark in Lisbon!

The River. This reminds us all about those brave people that left land and reached other places. If I think about it, though people existed in the other places, I was here in Lisbon admiring those that left from this river, during those times. It does take a lot of courage

A Symbol of Portuguese Age of Discovery. The Torre de Belem is one of the first things I saw when I reached the Lisbon. It stands proud in the Tagus River as it has since 1515 when first built. The gleaming white monument in the Moorish taste is accessed via a small foot bridge. You can enter the tower and climb to the top. Inside is a dungeon, sentry posts, a chapel, and private quarters in the tower. The building served as an armory and as a prison and is really interesting to visit.When visiting the Belem area, you will want to visit the monument to the Voyages of Discovery next door as well as the Monastery of Jeronimos. You could easily spend the entire day in this district alone. Enjoy.

Historic. Found this area of Lisbon well worth a visit there are at least five places to see.1, Monastrey and church (Has the tomb of Vasco da Gama in)2, Maritime museum located at the end of the monastery3, The coach museum next to the Palace where you will see soldiers on guard duty4, The navigator monument5, The Belem tower To get to Belem take the number 15 tram always rather full, best way is by train (Do not forget to get the bus card like the oyster card just top up with money , also can use the Lisboa card this card also gives free or discounted admission to museums etc

A must see in Lisbon!. The Torre de Belem was easy to get to via public transportation. A well maintained attraction. I was surprised how small it was - looks bigger in photos. Well worth the walk up the very narrow stairway to get to the top.
A must do. Visit Portugal and not visit the cloisters, monument to discovery and torre? What a waste. And a tram ride to boot ( or rent a bike from BikeIberia and ride the waterfront.)
Beautiful!. It is worth it going to the top of the tower, stopping in each floor and admiring the views. Of course it is very windy, but very beautiful. Save at least two hours to visit it.

Under construction. When we went there in September 2013, the tower was under construction. It wasn't possible tot go in. We took some pictures on the outside. Overall it is a nice tower to watch. Especially combined with the other things to see in the area of Belém. Take your time to go there by train (from city center) or pay 10 euro for a taxi.

Nice area to spend an afternoon. The area of the Torre de Belem is beautiful, with big parks and several restaurants, although touristic, the food is delicious. The Torre itself is beautiful and you can have beautiful views of the city and the river from there.
Great sense of Portuguese History. Marvellous monument and very easy to photograph, great position alongside the river, but a nightmare to try and find somewhere to park

"Back home" at one of the most beautiful manmade area's. In one branch of my family we pass on from generation to generation that one of our ancestors was a Portuguese soldier in the army of the Spanish king who besieged Antwerp from 1582 to 1585 until the city surrendered. The guy liked it here and fell in love with a local beauty (It is not known what came first, his love for the country or for the girl). The first time I walked from the cathedral to the Torre de Belem and back to the old city, I had a once in a lifetime experience to immediately feel 'back home'. Weird and beautiful at the very same moment, do our roots indeed go that far? Anyone else had this type of experience?Apart from this very personal comment : This is one of the most beautiful manmade area's I have visited. The city is a work of art and one can almost still feel the cataclysm of the earthquake that in some way was a pivotal point in European history.
Tower of Belem. Very nice and cheap to tour inside. We went at the end of sept so there was no line. A must see but you do not need to go inside.
A mini-masterpiece. The intricately carved exterior of this 16c tower is worthy of a close-up view and the climb to the roof is well worth the effort.

Great visit while in Belem. If you are in Belem please add this to your itinerary. While in Belem go here, the monastery the monument of the discoveries and the coach museum. So much to see in this part of town, could spend half a day and worth the trip. Part of the area was under construction while I was here this week and it was raining but is was still worth it. You have the water and the bridge in the back ground and makes for such a wonderful picture!
A great monument to visit and see. A great monument to visit and see but expensive to enter It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site along with the nearby Jerónimos Monaster

Great views. Interesting and great views...cost 5euros each...probably a bit steep for the short time one is in the tower. However, it is quite beautiful and one can see the history of the city from the tower...over the historic landscape to the new April 25 bridge and the city...old and new

A wonderful sight on a sunny afternoon!. The tower is truly beautiful to look at and it is combined with the pleasure of a walk by the river in the sunshine and the possibility of a coffee and little local custard tart or a glass of cool white portugese wine in one of the many cafes nearby. it's a must-see if in Lisbon.
Worth a visit!. Impressive tower in the sea coast, worth to see! Beaware that it's all close on Mondays, so please check your time schedule before going there.
Loved it :). I liked its architecture, the way the river and the city look like from above. I found the traffic lights a bit annoying and I saw some people who hadn't noticed them and went up.
a touristic attraction. weather was amazing and sky so clear ... beautiful view of the city and river ... there was a lot of tourists but enough space for all of us...

Impressive and imposing on the shoreline. Great historical architecture and a must see when visiting Belem. Nice lawns and pathways to walk around it as far as possible. Reminiscent of the Golden Tower in Seville.
Best view in Libon. This is an old tower which history is just amazing. Preserved, just looking at it makes you travel back 500 years. A must-go place in Lisbon.

Ok if you have the time. We visited on a Sunday early afternoon and had to queue to get in and then found out why, it is free entry on Sundays before 2pm. This caused a lot of delays and queuing as there was only one narrow stairway up and down and they use a traffic light system to control pedestrian flow which does not always work!On a good day you will see everything in under 30 minutes as there is not much to see inside so quite glad i didn't pay to get in

WATCH YOUR HEAD~!. This trip on the yellow bus was well worth the $ but sitting on top you really have to watch your head as I was almost struck by trees on several occasions and had something very hard (plastic) hit me in the head (very windy this day)

Marvellous example of ancient defensive architecture. Husband and self visited the Belem Tower in June 2013. Take the bus or tram to Belem, and walk the mile of so through formal gardens, past the Vasco da Gama monument, (and maybe visit the Joachim Monastery which survived the earthquake - great example of Manolian architecture).The promenade is alongside the waterfront, and gives a great vista out to sea, and it is easy to imagine the centuries of seafaring which happened right there. The ancient Tower itself is white and profusely decorated with plumes and patterns, so it quite resembles a wedding cake! There are displays and staff, but generally you can wander over several floors, giving interesting views and photo opportunities. Don't miss the Belem pie shop - the custard flans are famous, but I would thoroughly recommend the duck pies - YUM!

Nice but not worth a que. We went on a Monday and most of the attractions are closed that means you arent inundated with hordes of tours. The tower is lovely set on the river.Not many people about meant able to take puctures etc without being jostled. Went past on tuesday on way to Cascais by train the place was heaving.So not sure if worth paying to go in but if your not that bothered go on mondays.
Beautiful tower and area. It is an amazing tower and the surrounding area. Dont forget to try the pastry de belem. Easy acces with the tram15.

Worth a visit!. Entrance is not very expensive, and the fort is very cool! Views from the top are amazing, and you learn a lot about the history of Lisbon and Belem while you're there. Well worth a visit!
Wow!. A must-see in Lisbon. There is a fee to go to the top (5 euros) which is well, well worth it. Great view of the river and beyond.

Nice but crowed. Nice view on the new bridge and the Belem area but too many people! The place was very crowded even at the first our in the moorning! Maybe because it was during the week-end.Free on sunday from 10 to 14!

One small place in Portugal's history. And one of the many things to see in Belem.Don't limit yourself in just watching it from outside. Go inside and imagine yourself as part of the glory days of the tower.

special view of tejo. sunny days and belem. all was special in this location. one of the most carachteristic structure in the town with a beautiful view of tejo. a real jump in old times with charme and full of history
Nice tower and history. The tower was nice to see, and gives good views on Portugal. The up and down system on the stairs was poor, and is isn't signposted very well imho.

A jewel, but not much inside. See the Gago Coutinho aeroplane. Seen from the road, especially from a slight distance when the sun is low in the sky, the Torre de Belem is a jewel, a bleached-white, fairy-tale castle floating on the water. Inside there isn't a lot to see though, and it can feel claustrophobic. So if there are a lot of people, it may be wise not to bother with the inside of the tower at all, but to walk back a few yards and see the aeroplane-monument nearby, commemorating the first Portuguese flight across the Atlantic, in 1922. (The aeroplane is a replica of the one that made the flight.) There's a grassy area where children can play, and a cafe / restaurant just across the path.

Torre de Belen. Ar 5 euros overpriced for scuttling up & down some stone stairs. The history is brilliant but it is absolutely not value for money! Go,go, go to the Maritime museum nearby which has shedloads of history, is wonderfully curated, great for kids & worth every penny.
A must see. We only saw the tower from the outside as we were short on time but this is an impressive site to see. Plus being on the WHS list makes it a must to see.

Must watch. Excellent the total area of Belem is both informative about history of Portugal and entertaining.First we thought of waste of time and just passed through the area in car twice and we ended up almost spending whole two days exploring this area. Especially this Tower of Belem is fascinating and very organised way of climbing the 5 floors with single spiral staircase. Views from the different levels are fantastic. The restaurant near this tower serves nice coffee and snacks. We enjoyed the whole evening here with family. Nice place for people who is intrested in Photography

Worth seeing. We visited with our teenage kids and although we did walk there from the Mosteiro dos Geronimos...it was hot and they did not appreciate the walk.. we enjoyed the site. We bought a combination ticket with the Mosteiro and there isn't much to see inside but if you like the history of the country it is worth seeing.

Well-managed spiral staircase. Great views from the top, right on the water, just gorgeous. But the best part? They have a great system for managing one-way traffic on the very narrow spiral staircase. I've been to a lot of spiral staircases in Europe and it's always a mess trying to see if someone else is coming down while you're going up. Belem has a system and it was great! It's the little things that count.

Trapped in the Tower of Belem. I love Portugal. I love Lisbon and I love Belem. I even love the Tower of Belem. I find it a fascinating little quirky architectural gem. However, I'd never been IN the tower until this visit to Portugal. From the outside, it's hard to see that the tower has about 5 different floors. These are connected by a single spiral staircase made of stone and made when people were much smaller. It wasn't made to have 500 hefty and pushy tourists on it at the same time. And especially, it was never intended to be the Tower of Babel with Japanese, German, Chinese, Spanish, French and English all being shouted at the same time. The problem with the Tower of Belem is the "traffic system". Each floor consists of a room. In theory, as you go up you should only go up one level and pop into that room... thus allowing the people from the room above to come down..... but it is not clearly explained and the screens indicating what people should be doing (coming down or going up) are inside the rooms... so they people on the stairs have no idea what they should be doing. While I was there it got incredibly ugly with people trying to move in all directions on this tiny staircase. People were screaming at each other in different languages and nobody was doing anything to try to solve the impasse. I got stuck on one floor for 15 minutes because it was impossible to move down. The room filled up with others like me... and we all got fairly frustrated. I don't ever want to be INSIDE the Tower of Belem again.

A glimpse of history. A nice spot in Belem to soak the atmosphere of great travellers.Even if not going up to the tower (it can get very crowded) it is very good place to start your morning tour.Go and eat a few pasteles de nata in Casa Pasteis De Belem afterwards.

impressive. The point is impressive to see. Its out by itself so be ready to walk. Its about a 20 minute walk from the Jeronimo Monetary. I would actually not recommend going into the building but enjoy its facade and the park.

A visit to Belem Tower. Located in the western end of Belem district we visited this Unesco heritage site on a hot summer day on 6 July 2013. After viewing some canons in the ground floor we used the only narrow winding staircase for 4-5 fllghts to go up to the roof. We had to wait at the landings as the same staircase was being used by peolple to come down and go up. You had to wait for approximately 2 minutes at each landing with the red light flashing until the green signal comes on indicating that it is your turn to go. Once at the top we enjoyed a nice view of the Tagus river, 25th April Bridge and the Discoveries Monument.There is nothing much to see and the entry fee of 5 Euros is not worth it. We might not have entered inside if we did not have with us the Lisboa Card which entitled us to a free entry to Belem Tower with the card.

Well worth a visit. Entry to the tower was very reasonable - about 4 or 5 euros each. The tower is lovely and great views of the sea. The stairs up to the top are quite hard going and I wasn't to keen on the way down but well worth the effort. Can get busy but doesn't feel overcrowded. Belem itself is worth visiting and had a lovely feel to the town..

Far better in person. Before my trip to Lisbon (as with any vacation trip I take), the first thing I did was to look through the TripAdvisor's list of the best rated attractions in the area, among which was Belem, of course. Honestly, it did not look that much impressive on the photos but it looked interesting enough to visit, and since it was also one of the landmarks of the city, I of course went to see it. And boy would I have been sorry to have missed it - it was truly beautiful, and looked much better than on the photos, which is often not the case.

Like something from Gormenghast!!!!. I found the Tower of Belem to be fascinating. It looked like something from Mervyn Peake's "Gormenghast" with it's Gothic aspects, and seemed to be floating just off the land. There was also a really good system for ascending and descending the narrow spiral staircase to the top of the tower. Lovely view and interesting display in the lower area.

Impressive monument over the Tejo river. Full of history, its history is connected with the Portuguese navigations in the XV century on. If you want to visit inside be careful because its schedule is:October to AprilFrom 10.00 to 17.30 (last entry 17.00)May to SeptemberFrom 10.00 to 18.30 (last entry at 18:00)Closed: Mondays and on January 1st, Easter Sunday, 1 May and 25 December

beautiful. It`s a beautiful monument but not much to see, once inside. You do have beautiful views of the see and all the surrounding area. I had the Lisbon Card, which gives me free entry and I didn`t have to wait in the queue to get in, I just walked in, and for that a lot of dirty looks. the Lisbon card also gives you free entry to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, and no waiting in the queue either.

Must see!. Very much worth the visit. Torre de Belem and the monastery of Jeronimos are enchanting places to visit. Easy to reach through bus from the Figueira Square bus stop. Our best pictures were taken there! Also, don't forget to taste the popular Portuguese sweets (Pastel de Belem) at the famous pastry just near the monastery.

Nice to see from the outside.... ... but overcrowded.If you want to go up to the tower, be prepared to wait in line, as the stairs are very narrow and allow the traffic only in one way - either up or down. Therefore everything is very organized with traffic lights (red/green), but it may take up to one hour to get to the top and then come back down.I believe that it is an attraction nice to see and photograph from the outside.

Where are safety railings?. Providing you do not plunge into water, lovely ship like recreation of the brave pathfinders who sailed to expand Portugal's global holdings. Nice dock nearby but limited shade
More than beautiful!. Really worth visiting and not expensive (there is student discount). Beautiful little tower with beautiful view.
Overrated. It's just a small tower close the shore, beautiful, but nothing special and the surroundings are just ok. There more interesting and beautiful things to do and see in Belem.
Great experience. Fabulous view, really liked it. Great for sightseers, and wonderful to read up about the origins etc. of the tower

Simple. We did this as part of the city bus tour. It is worth stopping at this tower as it is near other attractions to see in Lisbon but don't go for the tower alone as it will only take 10 minutes to view

Belem Tower. Very nice view and excellent surroundings. The traffic light at the staircase are very useful, but sometimes people do not understand it. The "museum" part could have little more things to show.

7 Wonders of Portugal. The Torre de Belem is so surreal looking surrounded by water. Another great place to visit and do not hesitate to visit the 'Pastels de Belem' that is only about a 15 minute walk from the Torre de Belem.

Amazing scenery. Great view and very interesting tower, it brings you back to medieval period!
You can make great photos, enjoy the view of the river and city! Walking from one floor to another is adventurous since the stairs are narrow and pretty high and in dark halls!

Worth seeing. It is a quite interesting piece of history of Lisbon and Portugal. Do not forget that is is closed on Monday. There is a nice cafe next to it: just sit there, drink espresso and enjoy and nice view.

Unique Tower affording Excellante Views ! ! !. This unique piece of architecture offers excellante views up and down the waterway ! To avoid too many bodies go earlier in the day. Well worth visiting but does not need to be time consuming. Usually, the Hop-on Hop-off Buses will bring you here

Nice place to visit. We went to Torre de Belem and started in the basement. Than first floor by the rotating stairs. There was a "traffic light" for "one way traffic" during a certain time, but that didi work. So we had to climb the small rotating stairs and other people came down. This problem occured every floor (four times) and downstairs again. I'm not claustrofobic, but it was a terrible experience.There should be employees to help and organize "one way traffic" every five minutes or so.In spite of that, the Torre is worthwhile to visit. Very nice views oevr the river and interesting things inside.

Charming but limited. The setting is lovely, the tower itself is a gem but there is almost nothing inside it. There are a few information panels about its history on the walls but not much of it is translated into anything other than Portuguese. You get some super views of the bridge, the statue of the Saviour, the hideous war memorial and the estuary but it is not worth the trip out to Belem on its own. The war museum next door is similar in that it is a lovely building in an attractive setting but there is very little worth seeing inside. The Portuguese armed forces have not been very significant internationally in recent centuries and this is obvious. The first exhibition is of some local enthusiast's collection of Airfix models...
Worth seeing. There's no need to go to the top/inside, but it is definitely worth checking out if you are in Lisbon.

Belem. This is a very interesting Piece of History in Lisbon. It has moved closer to the main land due to the great quake. Do go and see it and if you go on Free Sunday remember there are a million tourists trying to get in. Be patient it is a great view. They have traffic lights on the stairs as they are very narrow. Be prepared many do not adhere to the method of maintaining a good flow. take the tram but it will drop you off infront you will have to walk a little.

Beautiful monument with a rich history. A must see attraction in Lisbon, the Torre de Belem is beautiful from the outside, but well worth the price of admission (buy the combined ticket if also visiting the Monsteiro dos Jeronimos) to view the Tower from within. Passage from floor to floor can take some time as there is only a single, circular staircase leading both up and down. A unique timed system would work quite well if the crowds would simply obey the signs...be prepared for some waits to pass between floors if there is a crowd. Well worth the trip!
Unique tower. This is a must see as it is unique however getting up and down the spiral stair is slow and the information on the tower is lacking.
Interesting. This attraction should be seen early in the day before it gets too busy. We went around 9:30am and just beat the crowds.
