History around every corner. The Belém quarter is arguably one of the most pleasant and interesting areas in Lisbon. Once a beach, the shore line reaching to the Monastery of Saint Jerome, Belem has tremendous historical significance for Lisbon and Portugal. It was here that the sailors came to pray at the small Restelo Chapel and later at the Monastery before setting off in their voyages of trade and discovery, in the 15th and 16th centuries, the time when Lisbon was the capital of the largest empire in the World.It was also here that the most significant examples of the very Portuguese Gothic Manuelin style were built: the Monastery of Saint Jerome and the Belém watchtower.It is the birthplace of one of the icons of Portuguese gasfronomy: the portuguese custard tart, the Pastel de Belém.Finally, it houses many museums and one of the most important modern art collections in Europe, the Berardo collection at Belem Cultural CentreTheres enough to see in Belem to keep you busy for a whole day, so plan your trip ahead.Here's my suggested itinerary:You can reach Belém from central Lisbon by tram (take nr.15, starting at Figueira Square), by train from Cais do Sodré station (check the timetables as not all trains stop at Belém) or by bus. Of course, you can always take a taxi.Your starting point is Belém Garden just opposite the Palace of Belém, or Pink House, once a royal palace and now the President of the Republic's seat and office.The first stop is the Carriages Museum (Museu dos Coches). The museum is currently (August 2013) at the Palace of Belém, its main entrance next to the Palace's main gate. However, the museum will soon be transferred to a huge white modern building close to palace. The carriages museum houses a collection of carriages used by the Portuguese Royal Families, the Clergy and some other noble families, since the 16th century up to early 20th century. Pay particular attention to the amazing 18th century carriages and the one used for Queen Maria I's coronation.Upon leaving, walk towards the huge monastery of Saint Jerome, easily visible from the museum. On your way, stop for a mid-morning snack at the Real Fábrica Dos Pastéis De Belém. This apparently small and traditional pastry shop is actually a maze of rooms, as you'll discover when you enter. However, the room where the main counter is is the original one. This shop was the birthplace of the portuguese Pastel de Belém in the 18th century and it gained the informal status of monument over the years. It's a must see attraction in Belém. You can buy packs of six to take out, but my suggestion is that you do it the Portuguese way: have a seat and ask for a coffee and a Belém custard tart (say "um café e um pastel de Belém"). Remember that you'll get an expresso when you ask for a coffee in Portugal. Also, you can find custard tarts everywhere in Portugal and in some places abroad, but only these ones can bare the name "pastel de Belém" (Belém custard tart); everything else is just "pastel de nata" (custard tart). Make sure you sprinkle your tarts with lots of cinnamon and icing sugar.After your snack, it's time to visit the World Heritage Site of the Monastery of Saint Jerome (Mosteiro de Belém or Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, in Portuguese). Entrance is paid but worth every cent. See the decoration that incorporates sea inspired motifs, typical of the Manuelin Style; have fun spotting ship ropes, compasses, anchors, etc. Check also the tombs of Vasco da Gama and of Camões (Portugal's national poet), the amazing church, the cloister (where Portugal's accession to the EU, in 1985, and the Lisbon Treaty, in 2007, were signed), the refectory, the choir and the Fernando Pessoa's memorial. If you have the time and interest, check the Archaeological Museum, at the monastery's building and/or the Maritime Museum, further down.It should be lunch time when you finish your visit to the monastery. There are plenty of options to choose from in Belém, but I suggest you grab a bite to eat at the Cultural Centre's cafeteria and then visit the Berardo Collection (free entrance).After a dive into modern art it's time to go back to the 16th century. I suggest you walk to the Belém Watchtower, an ex-libris of Portugal, which is about 10 minutes walk from the Cultural Centre. The tower was built on the 16th century to guard the entrance to the very rich port of Lisbon. It doubled also as a siniter jail. The tower is a stereotype of the Manuelin style, built during the Discoveries golden age and it stands now as the country's memorial to those days. The tower sat on the shore of a beach right until the 1940's; the river's eroding effect and urban works have turned the area into what it is today.There are other things to do around the Tower:- you can visit the Colonial War Memorial, a 2-3 minutes walk from the tower- the Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown, a state-of-the-art research centre dedicated to brain diseases and cancer research. The Centre is an architectural jewel, with interesting details such as the Pillars of Heaven, two concrete columns with the top painted in blue that seem to connect with the sky on clear days, or the Window of Hope, from where patients being admitted to the Centre can see the scientists working to save them. Do bare into consideration that one of the buildings is the research and treatment area, with patients with terminal diseases walking in and out; do show some restraint, this is not a monument. On the other hand you can walk around the common area or visit the Darwin restaurant at the Administration building. Also, an extension of the Guggenheim museum is scheduled to open soon here;- in the Summer months you can take a cruise in the Tagus starting from a quay close to the tower;- just stroll around or have a picnic on the grassFrom the Tower, walk back towards the Cultural Centre, but don't cross the railroad, stay on the side closer to the river.I suggest you stop for a drink at the Mensagem bar of the amazing Altis Belém Hotel and enjoy the view of the river, the 25th of April suspension bridge and the Monument to the Discoveries, your next destination.On your way to the Monument you'll see the only two surviving buildings of the 1940 Portuguese World Expo, a huge exhibition undertaken by the fascist regime to celebrate the 800th anniversary of Portugal's foundation that turned the Belém quarter into what it is today.The Monument to the Discoveries is a ship shaped building, built for the 1940 Expo, which main feature are the statues of all the historical figures who were related to the Discoveries. Of course, the leading figure is Prince Henry, the Navigator.The main attraction of the monument is the rooftop terrace. The view from the top is a must and it is definitely the best vantage point to see Empire Square and the huge marble World map set on the square in front of the Monument, a gift from the Republic of South Africa for the 1940 Expo. The map shows the ports of call and dates when they were reached by the Portuguese.Your day should be finishing by now. I suggest you take tram 15 back to Lisbon or stroll around the area and have dinner at one of the restaurants close to Empire Square.Enjoy!

Great opportunities for budding photographers, set within a nice area.... We visited Belem late-morning whilst staying at Estoril and Cascais. We stopped off first for a famous Belem custard tart, known as 'Pastéis de Belém', which proved delicious with a coffee. From there we headed to the tower.The Torre de Belem is a real architectural treasure and I found it a good opportunity to practise my photography skills, not just of the tower itself but of the stunning backdrop which includes the Portuguese monument to explorers, the huge suspension bridge and in the distance, the Christ the Redeemer imitation.There were long queues for the inside of the tower, which we decided not to brave, but I'm sure this would be as equally interesting for those interested in both the architecture and history of this amazing relic.
Fantastic place. Great place to visit. Fantastic view on the river. Marvelous Mosteiro dos Jerónimos. Nice place to vistit.

Such a lovely way to spend a day.. Belem has so much to see & do. Catch the No 15 tram, it's a local fare from Lisbons Figuero Square, €1.40, takes around 20 mins, get off the tram @ Belem Tower & the eternal flame, have your photo taken with a guard, they dont mind, then walk back to Discoverers monument. Across the main road is Jeronimos Monastery, & if you are so inclined a steep walk up the hill to the Castle. Their is also gardens & coach house. Check before you go some things are closed on different days.Pasteis de Belem is a must for their Portugese tarts.
Worth a day trip. Jeronimos Monastery, Tower of Belem and definitely Pasteis De Belem...all must sees during the trip. Only a 20 minute tram ride from Lisbon.

Loved it. Belem is my favourite part of Lisbon. I loved the Tower and the Monastery, everything. There are a couple of museum in that area too.It is perfect for a nice walk on a sunny day. If you ever get too hot you can paddle in the river part in front of the Tower of Belem (the water is shallow enough so you can walk to the tower without getting wet above the knees)

Best place in Lisbon. Loved Belem, great restaurants (Enoteca de Belem), great pastries, amazing architecture & everything is within walking distance. The monastery and the Tower are well worth paying in to see, and it's nice just to stroll along by the sea. Highly recommend going here when in Lisbon, so easy to get to by train also.

Get there early. Make sure you get there early before it gets crowded. The views of the river were really worth it, but there is only one winding staircase up and down about 4 flights. There were supposed to be green/red lights signaling people traffic, but they were broken on our day. This resulted in a some real pushiness trying to get up and down. Would recommend to any Lisbon traveler, but don't go it if there's already a line.

Great part of the city. Belem is home to the famous pasteis and has a great waterfront and nice museums to visit! The contemporary arts centre is worth a visit and the waterfront is great for jogging.

A jewelbox on the river.. We did not pay admission to go in, you can only see so many castles. But just looking at it from up close is good enough. It seems like an ornamental building but was a real defensive castle and was further out in the river before they filled in behind it. Park near and take a gander on your way to the other attractions in the area. Drive to the others, it is quite a walk for old Americans.

A must see on a visit to Lisbon.. There are several attractions so close, come on Sunday, park free on the streets and visit several sites for free until 2 PM. Mariners Museum is a good one, Coach is so so, but free on Sunday, Tower is something we just looked at and did not go in, but it is pretty, and the Navigators monument on the river is interesting.

The soul of the Discoveries Lisbon. When you visit Lisbon you visit history. History of thousands of years, since the Phenician founded the city and Romans and Arabs left their footprint.And if you want to know about the Lisbon of the Discoveries, then you must go to Belem area. It is where you can find historical buildings like the Tower of Belem, Jeronimos Monastery, the Monument to the Discoveries, Ajuda Palace and Memoria Church. But also Museu dos Coches (Coaches Musuem) and the President of the Republic official residence (with the Presidency's Museum) and is well served with several other museums near by, such as Maritime Museum, Planetarium, Berardo Museum of modern art (at CCB), the Electricity Museum (an old electricity power plant of the begining of the XX century). And it is a great place to stay, although not much accomodation is available (2 hotels, and some hostel/private short rentals). Transportation is great. You can easily take the bus to central town or the typical tram to nightlife central areas, or just walk around to the docks nightlife restaurants and bars. The train to Estoril or downtown is also only a 3 minutes walking, as it is also the ferry boat to river Tagus left bank, where you can find great beaches and beach bars (day or night).

Just for the picture. Yeah, is a cool area but beside two or three buildings you have nothing to see here. For the pictures is fine, but bring a cap because the sun is VERY heavy and you don't have where to hide. Eat some famous cupcakes also.The monastery is wheelchair friendly, the tower doesn't.

Avoid when many tourists. It's an interesting tower (rather small) with quite a history but it can't handle crowds: as mentioned in other reviews, there is a stay/go (red/green) traffic signal system on each floor for each direction.Enough people are ignoring it to easily get stuck or too cosy on a very narrow circular staircase; or long waits until a reasonable number of people are using their brains.Go inside in (very) low season only.
Excellent short trip from Lisbon centre. Lots to do here - went up the famous tour and saw other great statues. Pleasant atmosphere. Crowded trams to get to Belem!
Definitely worth a visit. I would have missed this if we didn't stay in Belem. The monastery in Belem was the highlight of our trip to Lisbon and a nice place to stay as well.

Don't miss this!. Going to Lisboa means visiting Belem. Go to the monastry of Jeronimo: not only the church (which is impressive), but take the tour in the monstry itself too! Visit the museum of modern arts: you'll see great permanent exhibitions. Cross the street (there is underground passage) and discover the map of the world: to see it better: go up the monument. And don't forget to get the famous "patisseries" of Belem: the "pasteis de belem'! http://www.pasteisdebelem.pt/

Five Centuries Heritage Near the River. Highlighting: the diversity of styles, the armour collection, medieval / renaissance Portuguese space, but also mix of mystery and romanticism, a privileged view on the banks of the Tagus, a unique look on the latest building adjacent. Around, other icons of Lisbon monumentality, as Jerónimos Monastery, Belém Cultural Centre, Discoveries Monument.
Very nice sight.. Excellent sight. great history. Glad to have seen it.Before it became attraction it used to guard the entrance of the Lisboa harbor, afterwards it was a prison and a lighthouse.

Great, could be better organized. We went there around 11am with tram 15, there was a huge line to buy tickets to San Jeronimo and Tower, we waited around 40min, so buying tickets online is advisable. The cloister in San Jeronimo is incredibly beautiful and well preserved, the best part of this huge complex of buildings. Absolutely recommendable. Belem Tower is a great place to see, very beautiful and nicely preserved. The only problem: it is badly organized, there is a huge line to go upstairs, stairs are pretty narrow and people go upstairs and downstairs in turns, with the help of red and green lights, this system does not work well, and waiting time upstairs can be pretty long.
Wonderful. Segway ride around along the river front from the monument to the castle. The views from the monument, well worth a visit. The custards from the pastry shop,and the general atmosphere.
Monument is great, explanation to be improved. The tower is a pearl on the Tage. It is certainly a must see. Some more historical background in the tower would have been interesting.

a masterpiece of architecture and pastry!. With its astonishing church and monastery, Belém ranks as one of the top sites in all of Portugal. Easy to reach by tram from central Lisbon, it makes an easy, culturally required day trip. The ecclesiastical buildings are masterpieces of Portuguese art.The Torre and the nearby statue tribute to Portuguese explorers are nothing special.Foodies ans those with a sweet tooth will not leave the town without sampling the pasteis de Belém, one of the wonders of the pastry world.

Queues. A Unesco World Heritage site but not a pleasant experience. Waited 30 minutes in the hot sun to get in. Then walked around the ground and lower floors. Very little to see. Up to the next to find another long queue in the hot sun. Into the tower and yes another queue to go up. You then really needed to stop at each level with an odd system where you go up at times and down at others, but of course some people are going up when they should be going down and vice versa. I never made it to the top but stopped one level from the top and tried to watch a video - pretty impossible with people talking about the up down system. My daughter did get to the top and after looking at the views was stuck there queuing again for 30 minutes. After that we finally got down and out. Time taken there was 2.5hours and it wasn't worth it

Must see. When in Lisbon you must go to Belem. The coach museum is beautiful and very interesting not to mention educational. A little history lesson. Pastes de Belem, definely the best and you mt go to this pastry shop. If you don't your tip to Lisbon isnt complete

Not worth going inside.. I went here in August and it was relatively quick to get in. It costs 5 euros to get inside and on the ground floor you have canons facing out the windows. You then get the pleasure of going up the stairs. Be prepared to queue! They have a 'system' where you have to wait 2 minutes each time to get up or go back down. However, people don't always stick to this causing problems on the narrow staircase.When you get to the top you realise that you may as well join the queue to get back down ASAP as the process is so slow. People's faces as they realised this was pretty priceless but not worth the 5 euros. Take pictures from the outside instead and save yourself the pain.

Great part of Lisbon. Its a place of historical interest and a must when visiting Lisbon.Torre de Belem , Padrao dos Descobrimentos and Mosteiro dos Jeronimos are all within a short walk. And don't forget to pop into the old ''Pastelaria de Belem '' and try the freshly baked pasteis de Belem - they are delicious!
Scaffolding. No-one going inside as it's under renovation, but it is worth the walk. Watch out for the foot-bridge to get back across the road and rail tracks!

Nice.. Went here after having walked all of Jeronimos Monastery and from the Discoveries Monument (about a mile walk from Discoveries Monument to Tower. Not much shade). Maybe I was a little tired, but I wasn't awed by it. Regardless, it is very historical and nice.

Must Do in Lisbon. Very Impressive place. The Monasterio of San Jeronimo is especially incredible. The Torre de Belem has a great history. On the other hand, the Discoveries Monument did not impress me. The outside is very interesting. The tower was plain at best. Was not worth the cheap price to get in. Pasteis de Belem are a must!!!! YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT!

The monastery of St Jeronomo is well worth a visite. Walk by the sea from the seafarer monument to the Belem tower. There is also a culture center with a big modern museum - and a lot of small, charming places to eat.

Historical. We went to Belem Tower. Unfortunately hours of operation shows 6:30pm closing but they close at 6:00pm. We arrived at 6:05pm and were not allowed in. Other visitors were upset as well. Be sure to be there before 6pm. Did not get to see the inside. Disappointed.

The most beautiful area in Lisbon. Located just along the river Tagus, this is the most beautiful area in Lisbon. Wide green grass gardens, the highest number of historical monuments (Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, Torre de Belem, ...) is where you must go to learn about the great Portuguese sea adventures in the XV and XVI centuries.If this is not enough, Belem is the home of the world famous "Pastéis de Belem" factory. These world famous cakes are worth the visit just by themselves.

Interesting. Surely a must-see district of Lisbon, but doesn't live up to all the hype. Famous Belem cookies are the least reason to visit Belem. Better spend more time in the Monastery and its grounds.

Great architecture. Belem is a very attractive area on the river front. There is no metro nearby, but it can be reached by bus or tram 15. A taxi from the centre cost us less than eu10.On Sunday a lot of attractions in Lisbon are free, and if you don't mind crowds, then Belem is a good visit on a Sunday morning because you can go the cloisters in the monastery and the Belem tower.The Mosterio dos Jeronimos has a wonderful frontage, most of it is a museum, the church is attractive, but for me the cloisters (entrance fee) were very beautiful. The area around has attractive gardens but unfortunately our time was limited.There is a walk of up to half an hour to the Torre de Belem, (passing the monumument of the discoverers) which sits in the river and you cross a drawbridge to enter. The exterior is ornate, the interior has a traffic light system for going up and down, but you may still meet people on the narrow stairs. The view down the river is very good from the top of the tower.

a good site but overcrowded. The site is close to the monument and the monastery so if you go to Belem you will pass or see this site. The issue is that it is a poor substitute compared with the other sites and buildings. It seems to contrived and is packed with backpack tourists and sightseers, all clambering to pay their 6 Euros to walk a few steps to look over a small battlement. Not worth the prices or frustration.

Changing of the guard. Short distance from Lisbon and well worth the visit. Happened to be changing the guard at 11 on a Sunday which was an interesting experience, but felt for the poor alsatian dogs.

Tourist draw, apparently. Far too many tourists, hordes outside the food shops and monastery. Made for an unpleasant experience.
If you've spent much time in Europe (and seen your fair share of palaces and churches), I wouldn't bother.

Lovely walk!. We were in Lisbon on a Monday which happens to be when most everything (museums etc.) is closed. However it was very enjoyable just walking around next to the water and taking pictures of the sights. Definitely gives you a taste of how Portugal was in its prime! It is quite a hike from the historic center of Lisbon...I recommend taking a bus/tram to get down there.
Lovely historic place. Great reminder of portugugese discoveries dating from 14th century. Nice place for photos and views of Lisbon.
gorgeous area. very nice area near the sea. nice monastery and famous for belem cake. It is only 20 minutes avay from Lisbon center and there is tram 15 from the square of commerce
Nice spot. This place is near the seaside and so its a great walk ..also close by are other sights like the jeronimas monastery so you can spend atleast half a day in this area

Walking tour with Discover Walks. I discovered that Discover Walks is now in Lisbon too and i immediately booked a free tour with them! The Belém tour was great and João, the guide, did an amazing job and teaching us all about the area in a really fun and easygoing way! And we even tried out the famous portuguese custard cake! Check www.discoverwalks.com and click Lisbon

Amazing Belem. What a great place to visit, the architecture is amazing and it just catches your eye. You can pay a small fee to go inside but you can also just walk around the fort for free, its a must see if your planning a trip to Lisbon
Tour of Belem a must see. Great views from different levels of the tower. Loved easy access and well organized control of up and downs in stairs.

Where the empire can be seen. When Portugal was the leader of navigation and world discover, the richness of the discoveries in Africa and Brasil allow the construction of beautiful and unique buildings. In Belém you can discover the more "imperial" Lisbon, in places like Praça do Império (with Mosteiro dos Jerónimos) or Torre de Belém. But you also will find a place of culture and leisure. Art and culture can be seen in CCB (Centro Cultural de Belém) and Museu Berardo. And you may also take a long walk alongside the river. It's quite beautiful. And of course taste the famous "pasteis de belém".

Lots to see in Belem. From Praca do Comercio in Lisbon take Tram 15 all the way to Belem. Plan to spend a couple of hours as there is lots to see. Visit the Torre de Belem, walk around the Monumento dos Descob rimentos, cross the street via the tunnel and visit the Monasterio dos Jeronimos and the Cathedral, really impressive! Not far from there, go to the pastry shop to buy the famous Pasteis de Belem!
Belem. This is amazing architecture, well worth going to see. Brilliant detail and history. Juts out in the river and is iconic.

BELEM. When arriving to Belem, don´t get misunderstood! There are three most significant marks of Portuguese and World culture you can't miss.First, we take the Jeronimo's Monastery (from the Jeronimos catholic monks (under the rule of Saint Geronimo, not the great indian chief), a great achievement taking elements from both the gothic style and the so-called Manuelin Style, a portuguese architectural style, (XV-XVI centuries), which combined the elements of gothic with a sort of specified elements from sailing (ropes, sea creatures, waves, and so on). The whole result is a masterpiece of religious monument, classified as a World Heritage.The Nave and de South Portal are amongst some of the world masterpieces of architecture and religious significance, considering the years when it was build.Next to it, don't miss Torre de Belém, a once XVIII century fortress, placed in river Tejo, those days ago, and now in its margins. It's a perfect example of war architecture of those days, defending the entrance of river Tejo.Nowadays it can be visited without the fears of tiding waves. The whole construction, specially its tower, is a magnificent example that must be explored by tourists.And you can't miss the Centro Cultural de Belém, a huge complex where you attend to a several kind of shows, from opera to theatre, permanent and temporary exhibits, jazz and photo hapennings, music performances, and the wholesome Berardo's Collection of modern art, which includes paintings of Warhol and Liechtenstein. Among some great portuguese paintors of the last and present centuries.Oh, and when leaving, don't forget to go to Pasteis de Belém, where you can taste the best world cake of the World. Yeah! No foolin' around!

Visit History. This tower marks the local from where boats roam away to what we portuguese know as "Descobrimentos". So, when you go see it, try to feel all the simbolism that it conceals within the walls. This maks the beggining of one of the most extraordinary adventures in human kind. Just imagine travel to the unknow sea where it was told that monsters and sea creatures would kill humans that ever dare to cross them, without maps or ports. That's Torre de Belem.

Belem in Lisbon. I live in Lisbon. For me Belem is the best place in Lisbon. You can visit very important monuments and museums: Belem Tower, Jerónimos church, Marine Museum, Coches Museum, CCB cultural centre and eat the genuine Pastel de Belém.
Belem. Interesting little tower although not a lot to see really. The area along the river has been nicely developed now.

Lovely views if you don't mind the climb.. We visited on a joint ticket with the Jeronimo Monastery as this was the best value for visiting both attractions. As other reviewers have said a lot of the beautiful stonework is on the outside of the building, which you can view for free, but there is also some nice architecture that you can only view from the cannon deck and courtyard. The information boards inside the tower are very informative and well placed around the tower, the most interesting thing for me was being able to visit the cells at the bottom of the tower. The stairs in the tower are narrow and on a spiral but each flight is not too onerous. I suffer from knee conditions and managed two flights without a break. The view from the top of the Tower is stunning and I felt worth the climb to get it.

Beautiful tower next to the sea. A bit away from the city centre, Belem and Jeronimos monastery - in the UNESCO World Heritage list - are a place of retreat for a good walk. The Tower is on of the symbols of Lisbon!

Pastiche de Belem. Tower and Monument of Discovery are interesting but the Pastiche de Belen are to die for. Here, they are the best in Portugal, much better than Pastiche de Nata. Don't just buy one, get the six pack.

Must visit. Great area to spend the day! One can visit the Torre Belem, the Monument of Discoveries, and the Cathedral. They are splendid buildings, so even if you dont go inside it is worth the visit. I would also recommend to visit the Pasteis de Belem, which has a very yummy tart!

Beautiful part of Lisbon. Catch the 728 which goes along th coast. Easy to get to. The best portuguese tarts can be found here. Bring a hat if its sunny, there's not much shelter along the coastal walkway to the tower. Electricity museum was great as well if youre a nerd.

Modern seaside. If you pay a visit to the Monumento do Descobrimento and Torre de Belém you will see people walking, riding their bikes, jogging and sitting by the terrace of a restaurante/café, facing the Tejo River. Beautiful and restful place to be. It has adapted to the modern life, contrasting the historical monuments there.

Outstanding exterior. Can get to it via the train to Cascais (3 stops from Cais do Sodre station). Entrance is free with the Lisboa Card.There is not much to see inside. The real beauty of the Tower is in the exterior decoration. It is adorned with rope carved in stone and has many Moorish-style watchtowers. There is a statue of the Virgin and Child and with a little imagination you can picture a long away explorer like Vasco da Gama being comforted by sight of it upon his return. The views from the top of the tower are well worth the challenging climb up a very narrow staircase. They use a stopégo light system and if it is busy, it can take some time to go up and get down. All part of the fun!

great historical sites. The Torre Belem, the Monument of Discoveries, and the Cathedral are all located in this area. The walk along the Tagus river between the sites was nice and safe. Very calm and peaceful area.

Green light means you can go. Red - you have to wait!. Tower of Belem is a small object with narrow stairs. In order to make your visit nice and safe there is a system of signalization that controls (in theory) peoples movement. When the arrow showing the direktion you are taking is green: you go. When it's red: you don't. That is it. They even took it two steps ahead and provide you with a timer that shows how much time you have to go up or down (depends on which direktion is green) and about 20 second before the time is up it will bip, loud (!).If you fallow the system it will make both yours and others visit much nicer. So please do!

Lovely town, but touristy.. There are many great views here, along with restaurants and shops. But, we went on a Sunday and it was very busy. A lot of tour buses and tourists. I would suggest going during the week.

excursion of Spain and Portugal. Took a Trafalgar tour in early May - absolutely a wonderful experience. Learned so much about early civilization, discoveries, navigation, palaces, cathedrals, etc etc. The history of the Moors, the Christians, the royal rulers, the architecture and the formation of cities around ports - all fascinating. Belem Tower was just one of those places that captured the story of sea faring expeditions and early discoveries. Loved it all - the old, the new, the people, the tour, the companions we met, etc
Belem in the rain. Getting to Belem is a bit tricky, but once you have arrived, it is an excellent trip back in history.
Historical landmark. Beautiful, well preserved monument, kinda of a far away, need to get a red or yellow tour bus to get there
Worth taking the time to go here. This area has some don't miss sites, such as the monastery and coach museum, and is well worth the time to get there. Take the trolley for a nice trip.

Beautiful Belem. Absolutely loved The Royal Monastery of Santa Maria de Belem also known as the Monastery of Jeronimos, with its breath taking peaceful Cloister, best visited late afternoon when all the tours guides have left. So much to see for a reasonable 7 euro's. The Torre de Belem on the river is also worth a visit, along with the Padrao Dos Descobrimentos a monument dedicated to all the Portuguese explorers. Both have fantastic views of the area including the marina, the 25th of April Bridge, the Royal Palace the botanical gardens to name a few. You could easily spend a full day here as there is so much to see, ensure you wear comfortable footwear.

Great place to travel and have lunch. We took a hop in and out your bus to Belem, we ate the famous pastries of Belem, we saw the fort, the museum and had a great and inexpensive seafood lunch in Belem. There is a lot of hills so get comfortable shoes.

Great afternoon touring this part of Lisbon. Spent 2 weeks in Barcelona nd Lisbon and knew that Belem was a must see. Best part was - went on a Sunday morning and most of the sights are free on Sunday till 2pm! We took a taxi for about 8euro from Chiada. Started at the tower, walked to the monument, then to the Monestary and then Royal Coach Museum. All very interesting and lovely sights. Lunch at a local restaurant filled most of our day. Not to be missed when in Lisbon!
Interesting and pleasantly situated. Worth reading about in a guide book - we learned quite a lot and noticed detail on the tower which we would have missed.Busy, though.
A very interesting area. Many things to see and do here, and good to be by the waterside for some of them - the only problem being that it is cut in half by the main road and railway!

good walk. we took tram 15e to get to belem. the tram can get very crowded. it was nice to walk along the water and see the various monuments. the pastry place has long lines but they move quickly and the famous pastry itself was good. across the street behind the stores is a nice park to relax.
The Belem tower. Very crowded...the sonor system doesn't work so well and you are traped up to the tower with a loooot of tourists. But it has a nice view and that's it!

Very touristy. If you are into the wonderful history of Lisboa and the inteprid Portuguese travellers, then a trip here is very interesting and there is a cool breeze from the water. Both the Tower and the Monument are good photographical material. However it is a way from town and will take a while to get there. We got the taxi to take us because it was so hot but you could get a train.

Ok tower, great cakes. The best part was the famous cace Place where everybody was crazy about buying their cakes. We asked the lady for recommendations besides their famous cake. That gave us several tasty alternatives in addition to that famous nata cake. delicious.And stop by Enoteca do Belem - impeccable dining and great service!
Carriage Museum was the best.. Went to Belem for the Monastery and the tower but the most fun was the carriage museum. Beautiful and very evocative of Portugal history.

Absolutely Beautiful. Belem is one of the coolest places to visit in Lisbon. With all the monuments and museums, it's hard to see it all in one day. My husband and I visited Jeronimos Monastery and its beautiful gardens, the Tower of Belem, and the Monument to the Discoveries. Both the Tower of Belem and the Monument are located next to the Tagus River. it's very relaxing to spend time along the water. Each of these sites had its own spectacular charm. The architecture of the Monastery and the Tower are breathtakingly beautiful. The Monument was also a treat with a nice view of the city at the top.

Belem is fascinating.... There are many interesting things to see in Belem. The most interesting was the Museo de Coches. The tower de Belem was very nice to see. The Jeronimos Monastery was fantastic.
Tower and cakes. The belem tower is the must beautiful and impressive building I've seen in Lisbon. And I tried the pastries in all kinds of places but the ones from belem are really the best.
place full of history. walking along the river, The Tower of Belem, the national confectionery, where you can eat the best pastel de Belem in Portugal

Pasteil and Piety. Belem has the gorgeous Geronimos Cathedral, built in the 14th century and funded by sea farers trading with India. It is also famous for the Pasteil De Belem - the famous custard pastry made by the convent nuns, the recipe for which is closely guarded.It is very breezy and can get cold even in summers so remember to take your windcheater.

Beautiful. Nice place to visit, specially the Jerónimos Monastery and the gardens in front of it. Check also the Discovers Tower and the map on the floor from the top. This area is beautiful, you are very near from the Tagus River.

Beautiful friezes. Belem was fascinating, particularly the friezes at the entrance.i saw Belem both from the water and the land. If you don't do both, you are missing out. Be sure to climb all the way to the top.
Do visit. A nice authentic area that must be visited. Don't miss out on trying the famous Portuguese dessert (best prepared by Pastis De Belem)
Calm and Beautiful. Located on the waterfront, it is really nice to walk between the differebt attractions of the area. Nice and not expensive restaurants.

It was nice to say we'd been there!. The outside is so interesting that it begs you to come inside! Once inside you can see the cannons that once protected the harbor. Then you get to go up the VERY narrow staircase. That was literally the smallest staircase imaginable! Its the only one to the top, so it is also the only one to the bottom. There were people going up as people were coming down, so it took almost 20 minutes to go up. Down was much faster for some reason. The view is okay. It started to rain so my pictures were few.
Historical area. The Pastries are not to be missed,they are great.Monastery and church is really worth a visit.Very relaxing to walk through the parks and visit the museums.

Nothing that inspiring. The tower and a couple museums and 1 monestary. Far from the center and just not that impressive. The walk around the area is not that nice and all the parks were very sad and dirty.

FOUR outstanding sites within a few metres. You can get there by tram but we went with the coach tour organised by Newmarket travel for day 2 (3 since leaving from U.K). We had already tried out the delights of the Portuguese pastry shops the day we arrived and on our exploration by hire care to lovely little Batahla. And number one pastry is the crunchy flaky custard tart - NOTHING LIKE the one at 2 for £1 at Tesco! The one you get with superb coffee is at the Pastry Factory at Belem. This Pastry shop at Belem is to Lisbon as Harry Ramsden's chippie was to West Yorkshire (before it spread its brand to every motorway service station). The front of the place is a work of art in traditional blue tiles. Only a few metres from the Pasteleria is the monumental Abbey of St Gerome with its wonderful carved façade stretching for over one hundred metres along the flower- decked park that once was the quayside of Belem in the time of the great navigators. Vasco da Gama's ornate tomb is within. Then across the park you can reach the river Tagus riverside and pass the seaplane that was the one that made the first flight from Portugal to Brasil. From here one reaches the Tower of Belem -a lovely limestone richly carved fortress that once was set on an island in the river. Finally there is the monument to the navigators erected almost five hundred years after the Belem tower but now THE landmark on the riverbank It is built like a ship's prow crowded with all the historic figures looking out to the sea.

Very turistic, few stuff to see, go to PASTELERIA DE BELEM. There are 4 main attraction to see there: the tower of belem; the monument; the monastery; the pasteleria de belem where eat delicious typical cake
Great neighborhood. Has several great things to see: the monument for the discoveries, the tower of Belem, the national coach museum and the gorgeous Jerónimos monastery.
Worth seeing but don't go inside. Nice tower from the outside but not worth paying 5? to go inside. Really nothing to see apart from the view over the bridge.

Excellent National Coach Museum. Who would think you could learn so much about history by looking at the development of the coach as a mode of transportation? Fascinating and elaborate museum. Once you get there be sure to download the free iPhone app -- fun tour with videos and quizzes.

half day trip. A nice enough for a trip for a few hours en route to cascaiss but very touristy. Of course we had a pastsi de Belem. Delicious indeed. The marina is pretty and looking out over the water is very tranquil with fishermen and sailing boats
Belem custard tarts. The famous Belem custard Tarts were delicious!The pastry just melts in your mouth and the custard is absolutely divine!Worth the wait!
Belem Cakes :)). You must try these wonderful cakes. Early in the morning you may have to wait at the take away que. There is a very large sitting place at the back of the shop.
Facinating. One of the most beautiful and interesting Cathedrals we have ever seen. The attached Cloisters was also outstanding and equally beautiful.

Half a day of history. This is definitely worth a visit when in Lisbon. It's a good half day trip west to the suburbs of Lisbon but there are so many things to do and see, all within walking distance of each other. Nice riverside vibe too.
Worth seeing. Pictoresque. Go to the pastry there down from the monastery. Delicious and fun to watch bakers. The monastery is outstanding but it is closed on Mondays so plan your trip wisely.

Historic Lisbon. Take tram 15 or a hop on - hop off bus to visit the beautiful Belem Tower. You can buy a dual ticket for admission to the tower and the monastery. Tour the tower levels, then walk back along the waterfront to the discoverers' monument. From there, you can cross under the road to the monastery. The chapel is free to enter, but the monastery, which now houses a museum, requires a ticket. Open 10-6, and early is best. Allow 2-3 hours total for the visit. There are restaurants and shops in the area next to the monastery.

Nice for a stroll. Try and avoid arriving with the tourist buses! There are some lovely shady walks through the park towards the river. This was where they invented the custard tarts which are very tasty and should therefore be sampled here.
Historic site. In the hot weather this is a breezy spot. The tower was a highlight. The monastery is somewhat crowded. There are plenty of bars and restaurants along the river.
interesting. One of the main attractions in Lisbon. I was skeptical to spend 5 euros to get in but it was worth it. Very interesting to go in and climb the stairs to the top...nice views..

This suburb deserves a day trip. This suburb of Lisbon was one of my favorite parts of my visit. Easily worth a whole day leisurely visit and easily accessible by tram or bus. It was really beautiful and I'm really glad I took the time to go.

Not to miss. Belem is a must visit in Lisbon, for its museum, as well as the river-side walk. Tram 15 might get a bit crowded on times, as metro doesn't connect Belem from the city centre. However, it is worth the visit, and also can be reached using the Yellow Bus (Hop on Hop off).
Popular place. Surprised at the number of tourists there, most had come on tourist buses. We went to Belem from Lisbon city by public transport which was easy.

Well worth the trip from town center.. The monastery, park, river walk and Belem Tower made for a perfect 1/2 to 3/4 day excursion. With the metro tickets also good on the trams, the connection was easy and the brief trolley trip to Belem, going under the big bridge was fun in itself.

Worth visiting. Beautiful architecture and vistas of the sea. A stop at the monastery and the Tower of Belem are worth it even if you're only in Lisbon for a few days. The Carriage Museum was also surprisingly interesting.

much to see. This area includes Jeronimos Monastery and museums and Belem Tower and also other monuments. Definitely worth visiting. You can take the hop on hop off bus that services Belem, or you can take tram.

Pleasant, not on a Sunday though!. Yesterday (a Sunday) was the only date we could go to Belem. it seems every other tourist in Portugal was also going there. We then found out that museums are free between 10am - 2pm and so the transport was packed and impossible to get on. Once there Belem was nice, but would have been better to visit on any other day that a Sunday. Make sure you visit the monastery and Maritime museum. Both very good.

Lots to see. Easily reached by tram 15, the monastery and maritime museum provide an engaging respite from the heat. If you want to escape the crowds, the botanical gardens are recommended; they are a bit run down but still interesting and a good space to relax. The monument to the navigators is awesome, and Belem tower a beautiful landmark, a great chance to paddle and have a sangria by the waterfront.

Unmissable. The monastery is extraordinary - the front door to the church, the quad, the tombs (including Camoes and Vasco da Gama), and the elephant statues. Don't miss the custard tart shop and the tower!

A must. If you're in Lisbon for more than just a day, you have to go out to Belém. Don't bother going up the Tower or up the Discoveries monument, but you must see the interior of the Jeronimos church (it's free - you only have to pay to see the monastery cloisters). If you have an interest in modern art, see the free Berardo Collection at the Belém Cultural Center.

A must see. Of great historical importance and a pure delight to the eye. Lovely views of the Tage river and the 25th of April bridge. Buy the combined ticket with the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos down the road and walk there. On e way check out the free contemporary art museum

Atmospheric and good views. Worth a visit for the history and culture with some great views across the water. It provided an insight into Portugal's former great power status in its ambition and style beyond its initial defensive purpose.
Great couple of hours. Monastery and the Tower are very much worth visiting. Easy transportation on the #15 tram, highly recommend 3-4 hours.
Beautiful but closed Mondays. I only got to see the outside, which is beautiful, but I didn't know when signing up for the tour it was closed on Mondays.

I Loved Walking Along the River.. I decided to do a quick visit to Belém to see the tower. I took the funicular and was dropped off about .3 miles before the tower becaus of a car accident. I strolled down the street and happened upon Pastéis de Belém. I walked across (actually under) the street to reach the Discovery Monument,and while taking in the views I saw a host from a popular reality show. He was kind enough to take a picture with me. There were men fishing and people bike riding. Whenever I travel, I try to find a place to run. Before Belém the hills of Lisbon were not part of a route I felt like running- especially after walking up and down them many times. But the path along the river in Belém is perfect; it's flat, paved, and the views are great. It was a great way to spend an evening.

Well worth the tram ride!. Take the no. 15 tram out of Lisbon to Belem and you won't be disappointed. The beautiful, ornate monastery of Jeronimos, the magnificent statue of the discoverers and the pasteis de nata make this journey really enjoyable, as well as the tram ride itself.Only problem is, that so many other tourists were also doing the same thing ( read about it on Tripadvisor!!) that the tram was very full and we waited nearly 45 minutes for the next one to come along. Worth it in the end though.TIP.- get the day ticket which enables you to travel on the local transport (6.50€ pp) includes buses, metro and funicular cable cars and includes trams so makes the trip to Belem quite cheap!

Tower of Belem. One of the landmark building, symbol the great sea voyage and discovery age building. It is interest no just shot from outside, but go inside.The experience for got to wait for the people up and then take turn to climb up the stair floor by floor is interesting. Once inside different floor can get different view.Heritage building and landmark. Do not forgot the nearby Discovery Monument as well, nice landmark.

Scenic. It was a short ride away from downtown Lisbon and a clear day when I went. It is one tram ride away from the downtown area. Walking around was very easy and there were enough spots where one could put their feet up and relax a bit and may be have a pasteis de nata or two. Belem is believed to have some of the best. I tried some and I have to agree they were tasty, especially with the cinnamon! Take a stroll by the Belem Tower, the monastery and go by the bridge that looks like San Francisco's Gold Gate bridge. You won't regret spending a day there!

Good outing. Various places to see around. We liked the church though we missed the tasting of the local pastry. The river is excellant walk right to the end. The gardens opposite the church is good for a short break and lunch to eat.

pasteis de Belem : must visit. if you lve custard tarts... you have to get them at their origin at Pasteis de Belem . Fresh , diretly out of the oven, still warm and crispy, everything you could wish for. And the Espresso under 1 Euro.

Cute detour outside of Lisbon. Did the typical trip to Belem. Took the bus/trolly (we purchased tickets at the post office) and spent a couple hours looking at the historic sights and getting a pastry. The weather was not in our favor on our visit but it was well worth the trip.
Custard Cakes. The locals all said don't miss the custard cakes in Belem.We stopped to see the Cathedral and got some warm cakes.They are great

Interesting waterfront full of historical aspects. Take the train from Cais de Sodré or other public transport- it's very close to the centre of Lisbon. The Jeronimos monastery is a fabulous site with several museums in it as well as the church. The whole history of the Portuguese exploeres is fascinating. It's the place to eat Pasteis de Nata (Portuguese custard tarts) and easy to get fat on them

Trip end of May. We took the tram 15 to get there and once there we walked around, visiting : Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, nice!! The monument to Columbus, the Tower of Belem......be aware there are lots-lots-lots of narrow stairs.... :) . But after that you can go to the Pastelaria and eat a packet of pasteis de Belem, to be eaten in the garden opposite the pastelaria.I also suggest a pop-in in pao-pao/queijo-queijo

THE TORRE DE BELEM. The Torre de Belem was built as a fortress in 1514 to defend the mouth of Lisabon river Tejo. Its rich decoration includes the Manueline symbols-cables encircling the building and ending in elegant knots, armillary spheres crossees of the Military Order of Christ, and elements from nature such as the rhinocerors (the first representation in stone known in Europe). Classified by UNESCO in 1983 as a World Heritage Site, the tower is now one of Lisbons most popular tourist attractions.

So much to see in Belém. The 15 Tram goes to Belém, The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos a must to see, The Monument of Discoveries Rivers edge, Also the Torre de Belém, The Coach Museum (Museu Nacional dos Coches), everyone must go for a Pastry and Coffee at Pasteis de Belém, thats if you can get in the door, Known locally as the bank of Lisbon, Much much more to see gardens and promenades too.

Gotta love Belem. Belem is a great little area with some nice cafes, restaurants, and interesting sites. It's definitely worth the trip outside the city "center" and should not be missed by anyone visiting Lisbon.
Belem. The Monastery dos Jeronimos is amazing, also the Torre de Belem - within walking distance of each other.

Things to do on the Tagus river in Lisbon. Spent a nice morning on a beautiful day enjoying the sights along the Tagus river in Lisbon. Visited the Jerónimos Monastery and Church of St Mary (worth seeing for its fascinating Manuelline architecture), the Torre de Belém, a fortification built in the 16th century on the banks of the river, and the Monument to the Discoverers, a monument to the early explorers in the Portugese Age of Exploration. It was built in 1960 on the 500th anniversary of the death of Prince Henry the Navigator. The whole riverfront area is very picturesque and kept me busy taking photos. Be sure to have one of the famous custard tarts... they're delicious!

Lisabon day 2 ... or 3.... When your done with your "course A" i Lisabon, take the tram out to Belem. The tower and foremost the world heritage "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos" is a great experience from the bustle of Lisboa.
Gironiomo and the pasteis. nice view, Gironimo, discoverers monument wth the Padreo at the background - delightful - and the pasateis of Belem are a must

A day full of positive experience and emotions. We spent a whole day in Belem, starting with the ride on tram 15 from Praca do Comercio to Monasterio de los Jeronimos. Arquitecture of the Monastery is amazing. Naval Museum is located in the same building on the left if you are facing the Monastery. Good collection of models of ships, no wonder Portugal was a big naval empire once. We have also visited Belem Tower and Discoveries Monument. As it was Sunday we visited all these 4 places of interest just for free! A good tip: on Sundays until 14:00 a lot of places in Belem is free entry. And of course we finished the day with delicious pasties de Belem (custard tarts). A great day to remember.

Beautiful only from outside. I once paid to go inside the tower but got my self disappointed since it offers almost nothing new to see - no new sight seeing, no new architecture.So from the outside anyone can take pictures to this beautiful historical building. It's close to other Lisbon attractions so it would be worthwhile take some photos.
Good Pastries!. I only saw the monastery and art museum. But Belem pastries are great and I enjoyed my visit to Belem.

Staff unhelpful. It was busy which was expected,the staff talking amongst themselves and brusque,and giftshop attendant wouldn't take a 5euro note for a 1euro guide.
Views really good,and not bad for 5euro entry

Home to some of Lisbon's most famous attractions - and snacks!. The day that we went to Belem, we of course had to stop and get some of the famous Pasteis de Belem, the little custard tarts that, legend has it, came about because the monastery had all these egg yolks left after using the whites to starch the nun's vestments.We also visited the monumental Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, the monastery with its Renaissance sumptuous decorations. Breathtaking - we loved the cloister most of all.We passed on the area's two other draws, the Torre de Belem and the monument to the Discoveries. After coming out of the Mosteiro, we were ready for a big lunch, and once we had eaten, we were ready to head back to Alfama, where we were staying, for a little rest before going out to dinner.
open and old. the view from the tower, the botanic garden a bit dated and not well kept. Food excellent and most important the pastry shop.

Belem. Just spent the day in Belem after doing the centre of Lisbon yesterday. It is a more relaxed environment by the water, although it is still quite busy. It was nice to wander along the waterfront, visiting the Belem Tower and other sights. The Jeronimos Monastery is worth a visit.

nice. I liked the Tower Of Belem, but for me it wasn't the best of the trip. It's quite nice but it was way too crowed and very windy, so we didn't really want to wait to climb the whole tower. The reason that it was very crowed, was because we went on a sundaymorning when it's free.

Pasties de Belem a must do!!. Quick service, lots of tables and plenty of seating.costs the same to eat in and take away, so grab a coffee and some tarts and enjoy!!! Have a few because they are the best ones you will ever taste!!!!

A place to spend a day.. A really good place to spend a day visiting the neighborhood. There are nice restaurants, cafés and the most famous Pastéis de Belém.....also great places to visit , Torre de Belém, and others historical places.
tower. Belem tower is like a castle-boat and a view from the top is very nice.You can take a tram n.15 from the center of Lisabon.

Over hyped. It looks beautiful from outside, inside it is waste of money. Common! we have better and larger castles in the UK, why see one if Lisbon which is so small and totally not worth money. All i can say is just look from outside, click some pics ,relax and come back. I was totally sad to go there inside and I wish I had used that money somewhere else :)

fantastic area full of things to see. Definitely worth visiting the Tower of Belem and the Monastery and other attractions. Monastery is quite spectacular and stunning. Stunning views from Tower of Belem and ingenious traffic system.

Must go to Belem. Belem has brilliant sights: the monastery is so large and so awe-inspiring that it absorbs crowds effortlessly. In Lisbon it is definitely the most impressive sight to be seen. But the maritime museum with its collection of ship models and ornate ceremonial barges has a great deal of fascination. Not many people bother to walk the distance to that end of the monastery building so it is a pleasantly reflective experience to visit the maritime section. And even fewer bother to call at the coach museum down the road. Maybe that will change when it moves to a fine new building. The coaches are old, evocative, and strange. They range from monstrous gilded coaches built to impress (one feels sorry for the horses) through fast, elegant vehicles to sedan chairs. Delightful and a bit strange as a museum ought to be.Finally: the pasticceria which is the source of the custard tarts. They are DEFINITELY the best. I sampled dozens during 4 weeks in Portugal and these were up to the travel book description. It is worth sitting down in the busy restaurant to savour them with coffee. Belem is great fun.

Worth visiting. If you're in Lisbon you have to go to Belem. You can get the tram number 15 from the city centre. The Monastery, the tower and the monument are the main things to visit. You have to try the Belem pastry as well! Very traditional and so delicious!!

Well worth a visit. This historic tower was built as a defence for the mouth of the River Tagus, and Lisbon, and is well worth a visit. It has narrow, claustrophobic passages, but there is a well organised one way system in place, and the views from the upper stories are extensive. Recommended, but people with mobility difficulties would be advised to restrict their visit to the lower battery, with its cannon and displays.

Belem. We went to Belem on the Hop On Hop Off bus. Saw the Belem Tower and the Palace there. There is usually a lineup for their famous Belem tarts but they are absolutely worth it. Lovely gardens nearby.

Betlihem. A restful beautiful part of the city with the statue of Prince Henry the navigator,, The majestic tower of Belem (castle of St Vincent Lisbon official patron saint), Maritime museum. Lots of history Fantastic white marble buildings and gardens
Welcoming Lisbon. This majestic Tower guarding the entrance to Lisbon on the Tagus river since 1515 seeing it from the river and the land was an amazing sight.

Lovely part of town. Lots to see here in a compact area, MUST have a Pasteis de Belem straight from the oven. We found Sunday was packed, but Saturday afternoon, we walked straight to the front of the queue.

Transportation Delights in Belem. Both the Maritime Museum and the National Coach Museum provide excellent exhibits on two key forms of transportation for Portugal. The ship models in the Martime Museum were incredibly detailed and many of the coachs and carriages in the Coach Museum were truly over the top!
Age of Discovery/Imperialism. Beautiful sights/sites. A bit too much glorification of the "discoverers," with no mention of the slave trade, the consequences of imperialism.

Pretty and historical. Absolute must Belem egg tartes!! See the Belem Tower and the Discovery Monument, and Cathedral. Watch changing of guard in front of military museum. Not far from Lisbon proper and can be done on any of the hop on hop off bus routes.

Just beautiful!. Built in 1515 as a fortress to guard the entrance to Lisbon's harbor, the Belem Tower was the starting point for many of the voyages of discovery, and for the sailors it was the last sight of their homeland. It is a monument to Portugal's Age of Discovery, often serving as a symbol of the country, and UNESCO has listed it as a World Heritage monument. Built in the Manueline style, it incorporates many stonework motifs of the Discoveries, sculptures depicting historical figures such as St. Vincent, the Tower is on all the tourist guides as a "must see" and you just can't go to Lisbon and not check it out. I suggest you go in the morning and see it in daylight, and also tour the inside - the 5 euro ticket is absolutely worth it!

easy to put in a relaxing day. I like Belem. It has a nice open feel, less crowding by tourists and touts, less panhandlers and more park space than most of the rest of Lisbon. I find it easy to put in a full, laid-back, day here. The waterfront is lovely and the walking is nice along the front. There are a number of good restaurants. Beautiful ancient city on the water. Took the bus to Belem from Lisbon but took a cab back. The bus is very crowded and hot. Belem is a cute town right on the water...well worth the trip. You have to visit the pastry shop right off the main square..just look for the long line!,,

Very interesting tourist area in Lisbon. Fancy statues and buildings with little in between.
