a nice area. A nice little area just outside the city, about 10 mins max by train. The harbour area is beautiful. There are plenty of nice places to stop for a drink... try the converted tram car banana cafe. Nice novelty bar in a good location with plenty of shade!
Along the water. We loved our time in Belem. The monuments were impressive and the pastries were delicious. Easy to access from Lisbon via public transportation.

Most interesting part of Lisbon. Belem is located where the Tagus River empties in the Atlantic. It is very scenic, with views of a red bridge that reminded me of the Golden Gate, and a large statue of Jesus, second only to the one in Rio. We visited the Carriage Museum, walked past the Jeronimo Convent, and took in the huge sculpture created as a tribute to Portugal's sea faring explorers. It's a great place to take a break and have a drink while watching the activity on the river.

A must when visiting Lisbon.. Along with seeing the monastery there and the Torre de Belem... a must is visiting the famous pastry shop that sells the best custard cups in Portugal called "Pasteis de Belem" established in 1837!

Amazing Monastary. I could have spent the entire day at the monastary looking at the detail of the building.Pastries were amazing and probably something I would love to have in America since I devolped a craving for them daily since visiting.

Historical. If you're a fan of world history this place reminds you how Portugal conquered half of the world. From St. Francis Xavier to Henry the Navigator, the monument represents and commemorates important personalities through out Portugal's history. I highly suggest you have a guide as you won't be able to appreciate these by yourself. The Cathedral nearby was also memorable. But for a cool experience the pasterlia beside the Church/Monastery serves delicious tarts that crumble in your mouth.

The Essential Trip from Lisbon. Both the Jeronimos Monastery (plus the Tower – buy the joint ticket) and the Berardo Collection exceed the highest expectations – take a day out here. (The Berardo is as good as MOMA or Tate Modern and better displayed than either.) Oh and be sure to sample the custard tarts at the cafe in the main street – they really are by far the best, as we ascertained by a serious comparative tasting at the fanciest Lisbon cafes!

Overrated. Sadly we were there round 11 am and we weren't alone. It might be nicer later in the day with less people. There is not much in the tower so you don't have to go in. Have a pastry or two and visit the monestary. Oh and the maritime museum might be interesting if that's your thing!

Fabulous example of the Portuguese Manueline style!. Belem Tower, built in 1515 at the mouth of the Tagus river as a fortress to guard the entrance to Lisbon's harbor and as a ceremonial gateway to Lisbon was once located on an island near the shore of the Tagus River. Today is sits on the northern bank of the river.The 4 storyTower, about 98 feet tall by 39 feet wide, is an excellent example of the Manueline architectural style. The interior will take you via narrow circular staircase to the top. The ground floor bastion still has the cannons in the niches. On the first floor interior of the Tower is the Governors Hall (Sala do Governador) which opens into the cistern. .On the second floor, the King's Hall (Sala dos Reis) opens to the loggia (overlookig the river) and features a small corner fireplace, The third floor is the Audience Hall (Sala das Audiências). The fourth floor features a chapel.We especially enjoyed seeing the gargoyle facets & the watchtower cupolas.Location: Avenida da India, Belem. (Tram 15E)Open: 10AM-6:30PM - Closed Mondays Admission: €5 (free with Lisboa Card) NOTE: You can purchase a combined ticket that includes admission to both Belem Tower & Jerónimos Monastery for €10 OR you can purchase the Lisboa Monumental (includes Jerónimos Monastery,Tower of Belém and Ajuda Palace - €13) Senior discount (65+) = 50% discount

Belem: Lisbon's most historical & monumental area is a "must see"!. Located along the River Tagus where the river meets the Atlantic, Belem is the place from which the great Portugese explorers (Henry the Navigator, Vasco da Gama, Ferdinand Magellan, Bartholomeu Dias) embarked on their voyages of discovery. Columbus, after discovering America, stopped in Belem on his way home.This area, rich in history, contains such wonders as the Belem Tower, the Monument to the Discoveries, the Jeronimos Monastery with it's amazing cloisters, the Ajuda Palace, and the Coaches Museum, Belem is where you can admire the intrcate details of Manueline architecture.Don't miss treating yourself to a delicious custard tart at the famous "Pasteis de Belem".Getting here: Public transportaion in Lisbon is very easy to use. We took tram 15E to Jeronimos Monastery. You can find all public transportation options at the Carris site at: http://www.carris.pt/en/home/

Gotta See. This is a suburb/area down river from the city, The feature of the area is the Torro Belem which appears on most tourist material. It is striking and worth the visit but in the area there are a number of museums that you should consider. Firstly the Museu Nacional Dos Coaches, this sounds tame but these coaches were collected in the later part of the 19th century by the Queen. It is amazing to see these coaches at close hand, they ornate, large and opulent. The Museu Nacional De Arqueologia has a number of collections from the earliest times to later Roman and subsequent civilisations. The best has to be the Maritime Museum with models and artifacts that trace the history of Portugal that was once a great maritime power.There is a hop on hop off bus that tours this area and it is well worth while as it also tours the area away from the river area and museums. The houses and views from the suburb are well worth the effort.

Beatiful Belem. We caught the train from Lisbon to Belem which worked well. The monastery of Jeronimos is a wonderful example of Manuline architecture although rather busy with bus-tours even in May. Definitely worth visiting the cloisters followed by the impressive Monument to the Discoveries and a stroll along the river bank to the Belem Tower, pausing for lunch or refreshments along the way.

Oh Belem. You don't heard much about Belem on the traveling books But is so much to do the museums theTorre the Belem the river activities so Mny people go to eat pastais de Belem, what agreat area you have it all at Belem restaurnat wow so many sea food restaurants food is all good the walk around for hours you need few days to do the whole are summer nice and sunny
Nice little city. If you are in Lisbon you defo have to visit Torre de Belem, in Belem as well as Jeronimo. Its a nice little city and has got so many things to do.

Don't miss Belem!. There's so much to see in Belem, you'd need two days to cover everything - so these were my reactions:Mosteiro dos Jeronimos - a must-see for the amazing carved stonework in the cloisters, which has much in common with that in Rosslyn chapel (of Dan Brown fame), down to the green men, roses and thistles(?) or maybe pomegranates, and ropes - which were made locally. The cloister is ringed with an astonishing collection of 'meat and two veg' (phalluses) which sometimes morph into skulls - pretty obvious if you look carefully, but can be overlooked if not! The church is OK (nice carved pillars) but far less interesting to me.The Tower of Belem has much of the same stone carving themes (minus phalluses) and is well worth a visit - excellent view from the top. The stairs are steep and narrow, and so a one-way timer system is in operation - this works fine except when some twits choose to ignore it. Don't miss the carved rhinoceros, which can be seen from a narrow passage just before the start of the spiral staircase.Padrao dos Descombrimentos - a large modern tower with carvings of Portugese explorers and notables, this was built during the lengthy reign of autocratic prime minister Salazar, so it's not surprisingly rather fascistic in style - worth seeing from the outside, and maybe for the view (there's a lift) if you can't manage the steps in the old Tower.National coach museum - great if you like coaches, OK if not - muted lighting to prevent the colours fading. There are three massive coaches which were presented to a pope - completely OTT with their carved figures, one has recently been restored. Most interesting (to me) was the coach in which the Portugese king Carlos 1 and his son Prince Royal Luis Filipe were assassinated in 1908 - the bullet holes are visible. Ironically, the coach museum was inaugurated by the queen and king in 1905.You can catch a snack in the famous Pasteleria de Belem - easier if you go through the LH door to the back rooms and get waiter service. There is a lovely view from the cafe (NOT restaurant) in the modern cultural centre - not easy to find - follow signs for the Berardo collection and the cafe is on the left (river side).
Imposing Tower. Belem tower is situated at the mouth of the Tagus river and was intended as a fortress to defend Lisbon against invaders.

Go in the evening. ... and watch the sunset. The surrounding park has great views and people watching at the end of the day. Access is easy via bus or tram (bus is more frequent). Belem refers to the maritime tower. The Belem district itself has many sights, listed separately.

Great day out from Lisbon. Loved the monastery visit, and the Pasteis in the old pastry shop. If the pastry shop looks crowded in the front, make your way to the back as there is HEAPS of space further in. Table service is faster than queuing up at the counter too. Went to the tropical gardens, and although it was relaxing sitting in the shade and reading, there wasn't much tropical about it, and all the buildings were so run down, many were in a state of ruin. Sad to see.If you get the 15 tram out there (an overrated experience) be prepared for sardine simulation! Better to get it from the start point if you can, rather than along the way. Would be a nightmare on hot days!The Belem tower was OK, but if you want something special, head further out (150m) past the amazing war memorial to the very modern looking Cancer research building and have lunch at the Darwin Cafe there, looking out over the water. Not crowded, and great and innovative food.

Lisbon's museum and monument district definitely worth a visit. It was a gorgeous blue sky, sunny day in the low 70's. We took public transportation to Belem and walked over to the Jeronimos Monastery, founded in 1500s, and today it is an archeological museum. It is a marvel of Manueline style of architecture. Many important historical figures are buried here, among them, Vasco da Gama. We walked over to the Tower of Belem, a monument to Portugal's Age of Discovery. It is a classic landmark, a Unesco site. This monument from the 1500 stands on the spot where the explorers set out to see. If you go in and climb to the top, you can enjoy a beautiful view of the river with its sailboats, as well as pastel rooftops in the hills nearby. We also visited the modern stone sculpture, the Monument to the Discoveries -- shaped like a giant ship with explorers, crusaders, monks, etc. looking beyond, led by Henry the Navigator. A very impressive monument at the foot of which is a map of the world in multicolored marble, showing the places Portuguese explorers landed, and the dates. After having lunch at a water's edge restaurant, we stopped at the famous pastry shop, Pasteis de Belem, where they've been making the ubiquitous Portuguese custard cream tarts since 1837 or so. After having tasted it at breakfast, I wasn't jumping up and down to taste it, but our Frommer's suggested it not be missed. All I can say, is that it was heavenly!!!

A beautiful sunny day. We went out by train on a beautiful sunny day Well worth the trip It was Sunday and there was lots of people around with basketball tournaments being held There had been a womens marathon on before we arrived and there was women everywhere with pink tshirts on Lovely walk along by the water Saw Torre da Belem and the Monument with all the figures on it Went to see St Jeronimos monastery which was superb
Worth a trip out east of the city. Worth getting the red line bus route out to Belem for a half day trip no more, see the Torre and visit the Pastry shop, the tarts really are good.
lovely area. It is on the river Tagus and beautiful to walk along the side of it. We loved the tower, the Henry the Navigator monument and the Jeronimos monastery
Enjoyed the food, the view and Maritime museum.. The Belem pastry is worth the wait, and the restaurant next to the famous pastry shop was really good. Fresh, fresh seafood.

Nice tower. You'll get great views of the river, the bridge and across the Belem district.Try to avoid any school children trips as we had 2 and it was a nightmare.There are rather tight steps to the top so take care if you are a tad infirm.

A wonderful memorial of times gone by!. Built in the early XVIth century as a tribute to the navigators and ships sailing from Lisbon to discover the world, the Tower of Belém is situated at one of the most beautiful corners of the Tagus' estuary in Lisbon. Built in a Portuguese Renaissance style (Manuelino), the building overlooks the river and the city, and is a wonderful remembrance of times gone by, when Portugal was one of the powers of the world. Culturally it still is for sure. You can climb up onto the roof and watch the wonderful blue sky!
Nice day out. The food was fantastic, just a tram ride from the centre of Lisbon. A few things to see and do there, well worth it

Quirky, history and great views all rolled into one neighbourhood!. Try the Pasteis de Belem, check out the amazing views from the Torre de Belem and the Great Discoveries Monument. Make sure to also go to the Alcantara Docks and the LX Factory.
Beautiful Architecture. Great-looking tower by the river. Didn't go in as we were told there is nothing inside the tower. The monastery is across the road as is that famous pastry shop!

Amazing place, unfortunately closed. Belem is amazing place in Lisbon. It's must if you go to Lisbon. You can get there with tram number 15 or follow Hop on HOp off. I follow the Yellow Bus! I think it's Recomended. Unfortunately when I went there, the castle is closed.
Good for a half day. Really just a little tourist enclave with about a half day's worth of activities. The monastery, the tower, maritime museum and the pastries if that's your thing.
Beautiful!. We spent whole Sunday morning visiting Belem, the Monastery, Belem tower, museums and all for free!! I loved it all!!

get there early to avoid the tourist busses. lovely short trip (15 minutes?) from Lisbon - easily accessible by train. Pity Macdonalds sign over the famous pastry shop. Lots to see - monastery, discovery monument, modern art museum etc. Scout around and try out the different pasteis de bata and other sweet delights. But hords of tourists if you get there mid morning

Compact, interesting area of Lisbon. Belem is a great area to visit as there are so many World Heritage sites in a compact area - not to mention the most famous restaurant to try the local pastry - pastel de nata. We parked our car between the Tower of Belem and the Discovery Monument - no charge to park. Walked to the Geronimo Monastery - about 6 blocks away and across the street from the Pasteis de Belem restaurant, where we visited for a reasonably priced brunch. The monuments were in a beautiful location on the Tagus River. You could see the Christ Statue across the river beyond the red 25th of April Bridge (looks like the Golden Gate). The Monastery was built of a beautiful golden stone, with interesting carvings and tile. I highly recommend a day in this more laid-back area outside the Lisbon city center.

Loved it! You had to be small to work here!. I loved this example of Lisbon architecture. An interesting little defensive placement overlooking the Tagus river, but be aware that to see it all you have to climb a narrow spiral staircase to the top of the tower. Also, you can also get discounted entrance if you buy a joint ticket at the Monastery.
Amazing!. This is a tiny castle... although it has very narrow and winding staircases its well worth it. the views from the top are spectacular
A morning well spent. The monastery is incredible, the monuments interesting, and the custard tarts a must! Jump on a no 15 tram as early as you can, as they get very crowded.

Nice area with lots to see and do. Belem is a great little area just out of the centre of Lisbon - take the 15 tram or 714/726 bus from any of the maon squares to reach it in about 15 minutes but be warned that the trams get very busy and crowded. I would recommend visiting the area and stopping off for one of their famous cakes :)

Unmissable landmarks. You can reach Belem on public transportation by changing from subway to rail at the Cais do Sodrè station on Lisbon Metro's Green Line (Linha Verde). The roundtrip ticket costs 3 Euro and trains normally run at 20-minute intervals. Unfortunately, the train stops half a mile (800 meters) from the marble monument known as Padrão dos Descobrimentos (dedicated to Portuguese explorers and navigators) and a full mile (1700 meters) from the Belem tower. Still, it's a pleasant walk to those Lisbon landmarks (on a sunny day) as it offers great views of the Tagus extuary. "Kodak moments" abound all along the way and you can even take shots of the Belem tower leaving out the pesky tourist crowds if you walk a couple of minutes west of it, in the direction of the old fort. Don't eat at the Café do Forte, though, where indifferent food and unexcusable service ruin an otherwise superb location.

Should be visited. The cloisters in the Jeronimos monastry are the finest I have seen. The Jeronimos church is interesting and the Belem tower (not really high) is nice from the outside. In my opinion, it is not worse going into the tower and climbing it.

Nice tower!. It is a must to see. Great architecture and you can visit inside and outside and you can climb to the roof. It is worth to spend the time and if it is a sunny day, you'll have nice pictures!
Great place to take pictures.. Located at estuary of Tagus river. Old building that looks unique. Save at least 1 hour for it. Take a lot of pictures. Enjoy. Very crowded on weekends.
there is not much to see. Not bad place, but there is not much to see: museum, small tower, garden..The place is very crowded. One thing you shouldn`t miss- Belem pastry

A must see. Just a short walk from the Discoveries Monument, the Tower is a must. Can be difficult walking up and down the narrow, winding staircase with so many people visiting at the same time. Not too much to see when climbing higher so don't feel bad if you can't do it.

You MUST go here and look around. We were on a tour with a large tour group and this was the first stop. The tour guide suggested 20 minutes for photos and a quick look. She was insane!!!!!! We ditched the tour (wasting £120) and stayed and were so glad we did. Amazing to see this place and picture how it was used over 700 years ago. And it is so much bigger than you initially think, with several floors, each with a specific purpose. Beautiful for photos of the lovely blue Lisbon sky as well.

Tower of Belem. The Tower at Belem was a surprise! I is bigger than it looks and has some great views from the top. I took a picture of one of the balcony/terrace stonework, and then a week later saw the exact same picture on the cover of a travel magazine. Beautiful stonework and architecture. Easy tram ride from Lisbon for just a few Euros. Around the tower is the monestery, maritime monument and bakeries that sell a famous pastrey dish (forgot what they are called). A nice area with multiple things to walk around and see.
Afternoon of exploration. Nice area to walk around. Take the tram to the tower and then walk back towards the monastery for a nice half day of exploration.
Belem. Interesting Fort with a spectacular view of the bay. Very near other attractions. Nice facilities are near by for reasonably priced good food. It is a must stop if you are visiting Lisbon.
Torree de Belem. This is an amazing small fort in a commanding position overlooking the entrance to Lisbon Harbour. It is very well preserved and well worth a visit.
Very interesting. That's a very interesting building. All the area around is a beautiful one. Belem's tower is a dive into the kind of 16th century atmosphere. To do.
Museums & Old Buildings. Belem is full of Old Buildings some of which have been converted to Museums. The place is packed with tourist buses, so go early and beat the rush.
Amazing architecture. Wonderful old architecture in a lovely setting. There is lots to see in the area within easy walking distance and the Belem Tower is a great starting point.

Belem beautiful. Amazing architecture in the cathedral. The general area is worth a trip out on the 15 tram (prepare to be squashed and mind your bag). It has gardens, bridge-views, a few restaurants.... Well worth a trip.
Feel like in kings and queens era. This also a wonderful monument of Lisbon. You will like to klimb the towers in a very straight strairway and feel like you were in medieval times.
worth it to see. I enjoyed the view from Padrao dos Descobrimentos and the ticket cost me only 3 euro. Everything was reachable within walking distance-for me preferable than public transport.
Crowded. Too crowded by tourists. Many many lines everywhere, a bit too tourist oriented and losing authenticity.

Nicest neighborhood, great sites. Took one of the tourist buses. Don't miss the Maritime Museum and boats and the early airplanes. Excellent cafe at the end, good food, eat outside if weather permits. Then went to the monastery itself and briefly the cathedral. Great cloister, good local exhibits, everything translated into English.

A must see. It is the most beautiful place in Lisbon with the monastery, the gardens and the banks of the Tagus river. On a good sunny day it is lovely to stroll in the gardens in the area.
Several of the tourist attractions are in this place and it is flooded with tourists.

A stroll in the sun. The Pasteis de Belem cafe/ patisserie is not to be missed either for take-away or table seating. If the tables in the front room are full, just keep going through the rooms at the back.

World Heritage Bonanza. When I travel I like to visit as many World Heritage sites as I can. I enjoyed three when I visited this area of Lisbon! Talk about history! Wish I'd studied more careful when in school!
Great place to visit for many reasons. Great sights and UNESCO world heritage buildings, good modern art museum and the best custard tarts in the world. Do not miss it.

Classical neighbourhood. Belem is a great and very touristy neighbourhood. Lots of great museums and you can walk along the shore. Look for the restaurants near the cathedral for some decent outdoor dining and look into purchasing a Lisboa Card before you good for free and discounted entrance to the historic sites in Belem. A great afternoon adventure.
Very historical, I liked jerom Monastry, tower and the river from where voyag. Tour guide did not give history and more info about the place. Before I go on holiday I always do read about the place.

Torre de Belem excellent - in a lovely area too. Take the tram or bus to Belem, though if they are packed, a taxi from central Lisbon was only 10 euros. Torre de Belem, in the picture, was charming and it was free to visit (at least it was on the Sunday we went!) Charming tower on five different levels, with lots of information on the history inside, in English. Great views from the higher levels, though try to avoid peak periods of visitors as there is just one narrow spiral staircase inside to get up the tower, and its very tight when it gets busy!Belem has a real "seaside" feel with lots of open spaces, parkland, a marina, gardens, great architecture and buildings to visit, plus the giant Monastery of course. Not to forget the Pasteis de Belem for great pastries and custard tarts!

Belem. Nice to just relax around and feel the sea breeze. Didn't go into the Belem itself though as the fees was 5euros which i felt was a little pricey. Nevertheless, the Belem area is scenic so half a day can be spent here

Pleasantly surprised. Looking at the decription before our trip, we didn't think we'd like this place. We were pleasantly surprised when we did visit on a whim. The tower itself is very ornate and pretty with good views over the water. The inside is larger than you would think- there are many levels with narrow, steep, and winding staircases, so be aware if that sounds like a problem for you. Definitely worth the stop if you are in Lisbon.

Not on Mondays. Great sights/vistas across the river, and fabulous pasteis de nata (egg custards made with rough puff/flaky pastry) but all the visitor attractions especially museums are CLOSED ON MONDAYS.

Great place for a stroll. Belém is a great central point to see a number of great sites. If you go by car, you can park for a reasonable price at the Belém Cultural Center. We were there for about three hours and it was well worth the four and a half Euros for parking. From the Cultural Center, you can head toward the river to see the Monument to the Discoveries. After visiting the monument, you can head back toward the main street for lunch on the terrasse at Nosolo Italia. Good pizzas etc, with a great view of the monument. You can stroll down the river to the Tower of Belém and its gardens, where they have special events from time to time. Back towards the Cultural Center, you can visit the monastery and then finish it off with some Pastel de Nada from the famous Pastéis de Belém. Makes for a great afternoon!

Definitely worth a visit when in Lisboa.. Belem is about 30 minutes by tram or bus from Lisboa. The tram or bus ride is enjoyable. Belem itself has a couple of visiting sites that are worth the visit. The Monastery (for sure), the Belem Tower, the coach museum, And of course: Casa Pasteis De Belem, where you will enjoy the best Pasteis.

ok. This was ok we stopped for a photo shoot.You could go inside the Belem tower,but there was a big queue so i didnt go in. the thing liked the best was the Belem tower was on the edge of the beautiful sea
Belem, Lisbona. The cathedral of Jeronimos is not to be missed. As well the 'Pasteles de Belem' a traditional confectionary where you shall see people queuing up in the street!
Fun area. Lovely on a sunny day to walk along the sea front and see the famous landmarks and museums, wouldn't want to stay in a hotel here though as its very touristy.
fantastic place - must see!. It is one of the nicest places in Lisbon in my opinion. The monastery and the tower are fantastic. I took 500 pictures there!
Beautiful Monastery. Beautiful monastery, fabulous sculpture of caravelle on the waterfront, but the world famous pastries may be a bit over rated

Lots to see. This is a nice place to go for a few hours, check out the Monastery, Belem Tower, Monument of the Discoveries & go for a pastry at the famous Pasteis de Belem (make sure you go in to the place to see how large it actually is, amazing). The maritime museum is also great, but not if you are pressed for time (unless that is your thing, of course.) This is good for everyone. Be advised, everything is closed on Monday.

Lovely village feel. Belem was a great spot to visit. On the weekend it was very busy with a second hand market and lots of shops to explore. We came back during the week and it was much quieter, easy to get a delicious tart and freshly squeezed orange juice.

worth the trip. This is another area near Lisbon. It is on the water with views of a bridge that is the brother or sister to our Golden Gate Bridge! The fortress is interesting as is the Monument to the Discoveries. There are some good museums near by & a special pastry shop near where the tram lets you off. It can get crowded in the afternoon in the summer so go early or late.
belem. lovely day out walking by the river, having a boat trip, getting a meal and a drink at the many resturants by the water. The tram gets very full , better to take the bus.
a little disappointing. the only reason to go to Belem is for Pasteis de Belem... so good. otherwise, walking through the park and along the water is nice with good weather, but nothing spectacular.

Not worth making a specific trip for.... Belem is ok if you're tying it in with other surrounding places but certainly not worth trekking for alone.Like most of Lisbon, it's quite pretty, monopolises on the views and tells of Lisbon's nautical rich history. You have to see. This is the place to see if you are in Lisboa. Do not skip it! Wonderful tower of very Portugal specific architecture located just on the river / sea shore. Easily accessible by train from Lisbon city center. Try to get there early to see mist lifting from the river. Next stop is nearby Monastery

Like "dragons fortress". The best experience is when you walk towards the tower, and like in our case, it was windy and the waves were large. It was extreme. The tower it self is beautiful, but not a lot to see. On Sundays, you have free entrance.

One of the most beautiful parts of Lisbon. If you are thinking of going to Belém you have to consider visiting a place that I'm not sure a lot of people know: that place is Museu Nacional dos Coches. If you take de 727 bus of Carris (the yellow ones, that you can use if you charge your Viva Lisboa green card with a daily pass for 24 hours, in any machine of the subway - that pass will provide you 24 hours of transportation in the subway, the Carris buses and the so famous elétricos and elevators) you can stop right at the entrance, and if it is a Sunday and you're able to get there before 2pm you will make a free visit.After that I recomend the restaurants nearby (you will see them right away, just by crossing the street to the other side) and, for desert, of course, the so famous Pastéis de Belém. They are really delicious and the cafe where they are sold is such an interesting place! After that you can go to the church of Jerónimos (that part is free but if you want to go further in Jerónimos you will have to pay) and Padrão dos Descobrimentos (to get there you only have to cross the park that is in front of Jerónimos, and then a tunel. From there you ca walk to Torre de Belém just by following the river.

Pastries of Belem. Pastries at the Pasterias de Belem was great, but be prepared to line up. better still sit inside it's huge.Monastery de Jeronimo where Vasco de Gama is buried is awesome; better value still when you have the 3 day tourist pass; known as the Lisbon Card available from the tourist office.Belem tower is a must see and very nice, small but worth seeing; again use the Lisbon Pass.

Head for this area - best tourist sights. We took one of the tour buses (try the Yellow bus tour as they seem to have the most buses) and headed for Belem. In this area you can find the wonderful Monastery which shelters the tomb of Vasco da Gama, the Carriage Museum, and the Belem Tower. They are all really worth seeing. The carriage museum was the biggest surprise and we would strongly recommend if you have any appreciation of history. it was free, and inside amongst dozens of vintage carriages they had the carriage used by Philip the Second in the Sixteenth century. That really took our breath away and I spent a long time just gazing and imagining it in use at that time. It's really worth looking inside the Monastery and the Tower As you walk from the Monastery along the waterfront to the Tower you pass a very nice cafe where we had a fantastic lunch in the sunshine. Also, don't miss the Pastelleria near the Monastery for the "pastel nata" pastries. You can't miss it as there is usually a queue outside. Don't be put off - they are probably queueuing for the shop to buy pastel nata's, and you should be able to walk past and go inside to the cavernous cafe and get a tea of coffee while you watch these delicacies being made.

Maritime Belem. As A retired Master Mariner Belem was a must visit for me with its great Nautical history , The early navigators were incredible seamen and in Belem they have a wonderful Maritime museum with the best collection of model ships and nautical history I have ever seen .The monument to the early navigators and the old fort overlooking the Tagus were incredible ,also the monastery de Geronomio and lastly a visit for coffee and pastries at the origional Pastise de Belise.

Many things to see in Belem. Plan well for Belem. Decide to walk around only if you are young and agile because the distances between the Jeronimos Monastery and the Discovery monument and Belem Tower are far too great. The Portuguese have not been kind to travellers in Belem who want to use public transport because the public transport is miles away from both the Tower and the monument. We kept wishing we had opted to take a tour instead of doing Belem on our own.The Coach Museum is extraordinary and definitely something different. I have to read up on how they got their hands on this very impressive collection.

Great trip from Lisbon. We spent most of the day in Belem, after catching tram 15 from the square. As we had a Lisboa card, the tram and everything we visited was free or heavily discounted. Jeronimos monastery was a real highlight and we spent a lot of time here. Also visited Belem Tower, the Discoveries Monument, the pastries shop (of course) and the Belem Coach museum which was wonderful.

A great place to visit. We spent a morning in Belem on our way to Caiscais in April 2013. Visited the monastery as well as the tower. A great time. One of the highlights of our trip. Only about 10 miles from central Lisbon. We took the commuter rail and it was only about 15-20 mins away and very inexpensive to get to. Well worth it.
Beautiful setting for public to explore local history. There is so much history here and the Portuguese have done a marvelous job of telling some of the story here in this park.
Don't miss Belem. This Town was different from Lisbon. Nice history and buildnings, view over the river. Almost the same cost for Taxi as for tram to get there.

White describes the area! Just gorgeous.. Nice place is easy to access with trains, which regularly go from Rossion station or tram (as we did) number 15. Jeronimos monastery was spectacular and done to honour Vasco da Gama discoveries. We visited it on a Liberty day on April 25th so it was no entrance fee. Along nice park we reached another white beauty called Padrao de Descobrimientos monument. This one we liked the most. We went on the top with an elevator and were rewarded with a nice view of the surrounding area. The only thing we disliked was traffic sign right in front of the Monument so it's impossible to make a photo without those ugly signs. We headed towards Torre de Belem which is a nice, 10 minutes walk. Nice tower to see but beware of the stairs on the way to the top. As narrow and steep as they are, they need to serve people on their way up and down. What we disliked? Only the cordion musicians/beggars, sitting whole day on the sun with chihuahua dog, holding the cup. They're several of those and you find them all over Lisbon as well. Poor animals. At least the guy who has the chihuahua should move to the shade.

Great for a short visit. Visited this site for about an hour on a nice spring day. The exterior is very nice to look at and, with a small admission fee, you can explore the interior. Note that there are a lot of narrow staircases that lead several stories up, so if you are claustrophobic or have mobility issues, it might be better to sit this one out. Great views of the harbor.

Free on Sundays BUT. At Belem there is the famous pastelaria selling the unique Pasteis de Belem (custard tarts with a twist); the monastry; the tower (a little walk away) and the monment of discoveries. All are worth seeing even if you only have one day in Lisbon.The entry to the monastry and the tower are free on Sundays but unless desperate to save a few pounds my advice would be to go another day. EVERYBODY goes on Sunday and you are packed like sardines on the trams and have to fight your way round the tower, try and miss the crush at the monastry and not bother with the queue for the lift at the monument.If you do travel on Sunday be aware this is prime pick pocket time - do not stand with you back towards and exit and, if possible, stand well clear of any exit. Also note you can enter the supertram (15) by any doorway - there is a button on the outside if the door has not opened - you may avoid the main crush in this way.

River and museums. Try a bus to Belem. Spend some time in the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos (crowdy but worthy to see it). Visit Torre de Belem (very crowdy but wonderful). See Museu da Marinha - specially if you like ships models.

Great in the sunshine. Easy to visit, by bus or tram- we had to wait for the bus as we didn't have the right change for the tram.it does have a seaside feel about it, and while it sprawls along the river mouth, it is very pleasant, though the amplified buskers did put us off hanging round the Monument to the discoveries for very long.

Pronounced "Bell-eng". Belem is a neighborhood of Lisbon to the west of the city center that is home to many fine historical and cultural points of interest. Take the tram west from Cais de Sodre and get off in Belem. Then start exploring. We visited (English names): the Monument of the Discoveries, the Tower of Belem, the Hieronymite Monastery, the Coach Museum and Café Pastéis de Belém for the famous pastel de natas. We also passed the President's Residence, saw some police motorcades going in and out, and had a wonderful traditional lunch at O Prado restaurant. We also marveled at the many different types of tiled facades along the streets and wandered through some of the parks near the Rio Tejo. Belem is a perfect day trip for those staying in Lisbon.

Easy to spend enjoyable time in Belem.. A very handy hint would be to plan a trip here in advance. Lots to do and see, so a rough plan of action can save tears and time. It gets hot, and the attractions are walkable so take water....and a plan! The tower is a must, the convent and maritime museum and the monument to discoveries. The latter gives stunning 360 views. If you have time, the cultural centre with the excellent modern art gallery is free. Queue for a pasteis an the day is complete. Train from Santos was 3E return.
great place. Went to Belem for the afternoon and it was great! Loved the Tower of Belem and the Pastéis de Belém.

Magnificent. A visit to the Tower of Belem is a must if you are in Lisboa. I suggest purchasing the Grey Line hop on hop off ticket, as it will get you where you want to go, is cheap and very clean and reliable. We never used a taxi and just used the tour bus to get where we wanted to. Belem has to be seen up close to appreciate the wonderful detail in the carving of the stone. Easy access to the facility with great views.
Great place. Ecellent the tower in the Tago, great the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, and fantastic the paistries...a place to walk around really cool
April in Portugal. The Belem Tower is beautiful. The Monument to the Discoveries is also worth the visit. Both have incredible views of the river.

If you don't come here, you're never been to Lisboa. A must see attraction as this landmark is synonymous to Lisboa. Be sure to come in before 930am to have a better view (take better picture with few people on the background), as people belonging to group tours will come in droves. Fortunately, we came in here before 930am and indeed, we got some good pictures. Ola!
Well worth a visit. You need to take a bus to get there but there are plenty. Belem is interesting and can answer some historical questions that you hadn't actually thought about
Belem. Lovely place to wander around and take photographs - or just people watch. Quick trip from Lisbon on the train or tram.

History. I love where it's located. There are so many interesting historical buildings to visit and museums that we can easily spend the entire day here.
It even has a children's play area and we can rent bikes.
And not forgetting to go to Pasteis de Belem.

Interesting For Sure. Very interesting tower - great views for pictures. I wasnt able to go inside, since I showed up at 1645. The tower closes at 1700, but stops admitting visitors at 1645, so plan accordingly. Great park area surrounding it for possible picnic lunches.

Great views and sites. Lots to see: the Discoveries monument from 1960, renaissance Belem tower and the monastery of Jeronimos with the tomb of Vasco da Gama (free up to 2pm on Sundays). Also the splendid Berardo Museum of Modern Art (free).

Lots to see and do. Well worth a trip out of the city centre to Belem. We went out by train and back by tram. It was raining heavily that morning so our first stop was at the Museu Nacional dos Coches. Not somewhere we had planned to visit but on route from the railway station to the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and a handy place to shelter from the rain. Actually quite a fascinating place and well worth a visit.Onto the Mosteiro - very busy as you would expect from the country's greatest national monument. Well worth a visit to appreciate the Manueline style.Thereafter to the Museu Berardo. Rather disappointed to be honest. All a bit over the top. However, a leisurely lunch at the adjoining cultural and conference centre more than made up for this.Then a short walk to the Torre de Belem and energetic climb to the top to enjoy the sunshine as it came out.A walk along the waterside to the Padrao dos Descobrimentos then back to town to catch the no. 15 tram ended a very enjoyable day.Only advice - wear a pair of comfortable shoes and don't plan an energetic evening!

historic but borring. i dont think is nothing special. we went in sunday, when is free and it was sooo many people (in march), that we went in first floor and then see that is impossible, and not worthy

Cultural area with historic buildings. Nice area with a botanical garden, a real huge monastery and some nice places to eat and relax. Get on the plane to Belem, then enjoy a long walk back to the city along the Rio Tejo which gives you the chance to walk past (or better to visit) a lot museums, restaurants and famous sites.
Beautiful place. You have to visit belem! It is a nice location for a day trip from Lisbon. Also, the original store that makes egg tarts is nearby. Got to go and try some.
Very romantic place. This is one of the best place to visit in Lisbon. It is very peaceful and romantic. Don't forget to visit Pasteis de Belem for a coffee and their great deserts..

Belem park. When being in Lisabon, take the opportunity to visit district Belem. Take tram! Beside big monastery there is also nice park and few more monuments/towers beside the river, worth seeing. Park offers relaxing experience. Later take something sweet in local shops.

Trip to Belem a must!. Head out to Belem early - before the tourist buses hit this small suburb of Lisbon. easy way out is tram 15E from parco de comercio. you feel part of the city on a tram! My advice is to get out at the Monastery and head for Belem Tower first (entry5e) walk up the very very small steps - can only imagine how packed it is in the height of the season. walk back via monument to the discoveries and then head across to the Monastery of St Jeronimo where the famed Vasco Da Gama is buried. walk back towards Belem - taking in a famous custard cake in the famed cake shop (blue awning) on the right. Two streets back is the coah museum - that for me was one of the real finds of the trip to Lisbon ...so try and take in a visit before heading back on the ram. Jumping off at Cois Roch stop. on the opposite side you will see big white steps that bring you up to the National Museum of art and artifacts (entry 5e). Go to this museum just to see the Bosch. it is amazing.

Historic site. Beautiful buildings and monuments. lotsa tourists. What we loved the absence of the throng of vendors. the Pasteis of Belem were awesome and so delicate. There was a huge line to get in but it moves very quickly. Lovely park in front of the monastery.WE loved the Discovery monument. On a clear day you can see the Bridge and the Cristo Rei atop the mountain on the other side.
Amazing. It is walking distance from Monastry, so do go there. You can get a look of the Golden gate and King of CHrist statue from there. We went on top of the tower and was really nice.

Worth a stroll along the boardwalk. Belem doesn't have the old world charm of the rest of Lisbon, but it has an awesome sea front and the old monastery and museum. It is also nice to stroll along the boardwalk (dodging the joggers and cyclists) to watch the yachts sail underneath the bridge.

Closes at 5:00pm. This is a unique structure and is well worth a visit. We went right at 5:00pm and it had just closed so we could not go to the top but even strolling around the tower was worth the walk.

Don't miss the hot, fresh cream tarts. Lots of major attractions in the area. Easily reached by tram 15. Essential stop at the bakery with he long line out to the street. Don't worry - it moves quickly. Also, don't forget to sprinkle the sugar and cinnamon packets on the tarts you'll find in the bottom of the bag!

A beautiful location within busy Lisbon. This area is the perfect are to visit when in Lisbon. There are important historical monuments all concentrated within a 20 minutes' walk, there are good restaurants to eat in (from very typical ones to those for a youngest crowd - e.g., McDonald's) and you have a chance to walk by the river for 2 or 3 km in a nice scenary, with green grass all around you and some nice caffes where you can just chill and enjoy a good weather day.

Worth the journey!. Belem is not on the metro service in Lisbon, but is accessible via the trams from Cais de Sodre. The journey itself takes around 20-30 mins. But it is worth the time. The area itself is right on the coast, with several monuments and attractions.When the sun is out, the whole town looks amazing. The 3 main points of interest are Monastery of Jeronimos, Belem Tower & the Padrao Dos Descubrimentos. The view from the top of the tower is stunning, and you can really appreciate the surrounding hilly areas. All 3 are aligned one after the other, and can be visited if you take a route past all 3, which helps if you are short on time. A definite must if you are in Lisbon for a few days!

Neat to See!. This is a neat place to see. I recommend going during the week. There are less people touring it. The stairs are narrow and people are going up and down and you often have to wait for a group of people to go down before you can go up. It is worth the climb to see the view!
A day well spent. Belem is a beautiful area and worth spending a day walking around enjoying the sights. There is a great open air market there on Saturdays where you can buy antiques of all kinds.

quaint town with plenty to see. We took the train from Lisbon to Belem, which was fast and inexpensive. A short walk from the station brings you to the main high street which is lined with cafe's and shops. The monastery is beautiful and worth a visit. The Belem tower is also worth a visit and provides great views.

Try to visit. We used our Carris/metro 24hr 6 euro card and hopped on the modern 15e Tram. As the previous reviewer said it is a lovely walk from Monastery(didn't have time to visit inside) thru park to Monument of Discoveries(also didn't enter) and then along the river to the Torre de Belem which we did visit. If we were to do it again we would go earlier in the day so as to have more time to visit the other sites and also to visit the Torre early in the day. As it is a stone spiral stairs to the top there is a queue from each level to the next. We skipped most levels and went straight to the top. The same queue happens on the way down but people coming up were very helpful and allowed me to pass down while they waited as I had a child with me. The Torre is not recommended for people who have difficulty walking and with very small children(toddler or younger) as when it is crowded you really need your wits about you. Would definetly recommend a trip to Belem.
Interesting, but better on a sunny day. Great day in a beautiful area. Went up the tower, watched the change of the guards , ate pastel de nata. Sadly very busy with tourists and school groups

take time out to go there. Using your Carris/metro 24hr 6 euro card jump on the no.127 tram, visit the extraordinary and beautiful Jeronimos Monastery, then walk through the park towards the river, take the subway to the Monument of the Discoveries (don't miss the huge pavement mosaic), then walk along the river frontage to the Belem Tower. The small 'glass box' cafe to the far side of the tower is a really pleasant lunch stop and they'll direct you to the no.15 tramstop taking you back to Figueira Square in the Alfama district and the start of your afternoon walk up through the intriguing alleys to Castelo de Sao Jorge ... !!

Very interesting neighborhood. Much to see in the area of Belem from the tower by the sea to the Jeronimos Monastery, the gardens and the special pasteles ( little cakes ). This area can fill the best part of your day including a leisurely walk along the waterfront and a lunch on one of the many terrraces. The food in those restaurants is basic typically for tourists but ok. During the summer it will be a bit crowded in the main street and around the restaurants, but the gardens will be a nice respite. if you "hopped" off one of the sightseeing buses check the stops carefully to "hop" back on as they are not where you expect them to be by looking at their map. It is best to ask the driver to show before you get off.

Beautiful Architecture. I really enjoyed a visit to Belem which included a visit to the Geronimo Monastery, the Belem Tower, and the Maritime Museum. The Monastery is a UNESCO world heritage site and the central courtyard/cloister contains remarkable stone work. The Belem Tower is about a half hour walk away along the waterfront and you can buy a combined ticket to see both attractions. It is a lovely setting to see the Tagus River. The Maritime Museum is located beside the Jeronimo Monastery and has a beautiful, comprehensive set of boat models illustrating Portuguese sea history. The display is pretty didactic and not all displays are in English. There also is a wing to this museum with full sized boats which are quite impressive. If you are into sailing and naval history it is worth a visit.Getting to Belem can be a challenge if you go by tram. It is a half hour trip from downtown (Baixa) and if you are on a small trolley it can be quite crowded. The larger, newer trollies are recommended but you need to have change to ride them. Overall, I recommend you see this area.
Delicious cakes!. You must try the pasteles du belen everybody knows where they are, just ask around and you will eventually get there, really nice place too.
museums. Visit the Maritime Museum, Monastery and Coach Museum using the Lisboa card ...includes free trains, buses and trams

Wonderful tower!. Wonderful architecture it is the perfect place to take some nice pictures for futher memories.You can see all the boats and lots of people having fun walked and see the sand and the water.

Excellent. The Discovery monument is a must see and go to the top for spectacular views. Make sure you eat at the Pasteleria and have the local specialty. The coach museum was good as well. Take good walking shoes.

A romantic tower. Thanks to our kind relatives who reside in Lisbon, my husband and I will always remember Lisbon because of Belem Tower. Another World Heritage monument in Lisbon, we were impressed by this beautiful and romantic site. Pretty balconies on each floor, providing a wonderful view on all directions; a romantic view of the Tagus river , the Belem area and the Monument of Discoveries. The Manueline inspired architectural design is there, but one can also see a strong Venetian influence. On the very center of the Tower is a carved image of Our Lady of Safe-Homecoming, facing the river, whom the sailors prayed for protection and a safe voyage (reminded me of a similar image of Our Lady back home).Going up to the summit of the tower, I got dizzy because of the narrow, spiral staircase. I felt claustrophobic because of the heavy human traffic going up and down the narrow spiral staircase. It’s good I brought with me a menthol balm that helped me recover quickly. Truly a memorable experience.

Interesting architecture. An interesting piece of architecture that you don't want to miss it , if you go to Lisbon.
And also interesting experience when you want to go upstairs :).
And, ftom the roof , a nice view.

So much to offer. I came on a beautiful Sunday when nearly all museums in Lisboa are free and I could have been here the entire day if I didn't have further plans in the mid-afternoon. There are several museums in Belem, take your pick, all rated highly on Tripadvisor.At least on the Sunday I visited, there were two very vibrant outdoor markets, one across from the Jeronimo Cathedral, showcasing an eclectic array of second hand goods, and one in the culture centre building which houses the Bernard Museum, showcasing some creative arts and crafts.Other than the museums and the markets, Belem is great for a casual walk along the river, which also offers two large monuments, the Padrao and the Torre. Oh, and I missed this but I was told should have bought a pastry from the shop Pastes de Belem.
Great picture. Great place to take pictures. We just took pictures as our tour did not give us enough time to check out the tower inside. It was none the less a beautiful place to visit
Day trip. You must go here and especially try the "Natas" a Portuguese pastry. They do make the best ones for sure and you can get there with the tour bus ticket

Belem visit. We most enjoyed the Monastery visit - fantastic. The Discoverers Monument is well worth a visit for the views from the top. We also had a coffee and custard tart in the cake shop - don't be put off by the queue - that's to buy to take away - you can go straight in to the cafe.

Impressive Tower. We visited the tower on Easter weekend so the lines were long and it was raining. I would like to see it again with less people and less moisture! But it is an impressive sight and worth the visit.

Nice little day trip.. Pasteis de Belem was lovely and a must for a snack and coffee. The walk down to the Torre is nice on a sunny day. Don't bother going into the tower unless you want the view.Do not visit the Botanical Gardens - they were run down and poorly managed.Had a great lunch at Os Jeronomaios, just a few doors to the right of Pasteis - traditional Portuguese fare at a great price, with friendly staff.

Tower & more.... Belem Tower is a example of Manueline Architectural Style and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Built by Dom Manuel I, despite it's décor, the tower played a military role acting as a fortification to defend the Tagus river estuary against hostile ships. The interior, dark & damp givesthe feeling of a miniature castle. Excellent picture opportunity from the shore. A must see in Lisbon.

Plenty to see. Several years ago, I attempted to walk from central Lisbon to Belem... and gave up because it's further than expected. Take the suburban train and allow at least half a day. The Monument to the Discoveries really does need to be seen close up but, again, note that it is quite a little distance from the Belem Tower... or from the Jeronimos Monastery... and as for the Ajuda National Palace, that's uphill as well! Belem has really benefited from the cultural renaissance. Well worth a visit.

Excellent Monuments. Excellent Monuments and a part of History.The Monument to the Discoveries,Baem Tower and St,Jerome's Monastery are great pieces of architecture.Dont miss the Pasteis de Balem a devince treat !

Go there when it's quiet!. We went there the day before Good Friday--lots of tourists, the tram was packed, and there was a huge line to go into the monastery (so we passed--until next time.) Also a big line for Pasteis Belem, the "famous" pastry shop, so we went a couple of doors down and had an espresso and are favourite custard tarts. There are some beautiful sights in this area, and we only saw a few of them, like the Padrão dos Descobrimentos statue.

Belem the Bethlehem. This is a must visit place at Lisbon. Bethlehem is the Portugese word for the Belem, easy to find if you can get a Metro and have your first stop and walk along the sea side from the Belem towards the ship. You may find a big aeroplace of German, locals jogging and exercising around, fisher relaxing along, and nice walk with your partner surrouding it. There is a Metro stop near e Belem, just dont miss it.

Busy tourist attraction. The church and monastery were spectacular with the tomb of Vasco da Gama, stained glass windows and a beautiful high vaulted ceiling. The famous pastry shop is at Belem with queues all the time for the pasteles de nata although you can get them everywhere in Lisbon.A stroll through the gardens was nice on a sunny day and a pleasant place to sit and relax. You can get there on the open top tour buses or by ordinary tram or bus but be warned, they do get very crowded.

Pastais de Nata!. Take the 15 Tram out to Belem and spend the day there visiting Jeronimos Monastery, a wonderful church with an interesting cloisters and church interior. Tourist buses do spoil the peace a bit so try to dodge their arrival. The archaeological museum was disappointing - as was the maritime museum in the main. We arrived before 2 and so entry to the museums was free and we dipped in to see a few exhibits, but I wouldn't be inclined to pay for either. The Pastais de Belem is WONDERFUL - we had a lovely lunch there...don't be put off by the crowds outside, go through to the back where there is a huge refectory-style dining area. The Museum of modern art in the cultural centre is well worth a visit.
Average place. It was a average if not for the waterfront which made it pleasant on a sunny day. There isnt much to be done in the area. Plan it for only 1-2 hours.

Culture and cakes: best combination. SUCH a beautiful place Belem is. Things to see include the Jeronimos Monastery and Church, which are simply stunning. Belem tower, though "iconic" is not much to look at. And please remember to go to "Pasteis de Belem" shop, not far from the Jeronimos in the village, and get some of those cakes. They are simply some of the best cakes on the planet.

Nice place for a half-day trip from Lisbon. Very easy to reach by train from Cais do Sodre. Great for half a day/day trip. Stroll along the river bank, visit the Belem tower and the amazing Cathedral and try Pasteis de Belem. All are experiences on their own!Recommended!

A great piece of history. The tram journey there was fun. The waterside park, monuments and military history are wonderful. The Monastery is incredible. There are plenty of restaurants etc to choose from, and prices are reasonable.

Tower Power. How this defensive/military monument/outpost excites tourists (as they come out from their Tourist buses) is a wonderful experience. Walk down the stairs to the touch the sand/wave/tide and look up and feel the breeze - ah! an unforgetable experience. The climb through crowded narrow stairway to reach the upper levels' so much fun. Tourists/locals waving their hands up that viewing deck and through those narrow rectrangular windows feels like one is in amusement park. The view from the rooftop and through those windows are spectacular. Didn't completely understand Manueline style until I went in to this tower- rope/globe/lattice work/roof form/spire on its stoneworks greatly appreciated by ones fingertips. This is the power that this wonderful tower offers. This place is not hard to reach. We reach this place by riding one of those sightseeing/drop off-hop in buses for 18 euros per head coming from Marques de Pomball. Use this place to get to Jeronimos Monastery et al.

Go here on a Sunday morning, if possible. Sunday mornings include a military parade just outside of the President's Palace. And it's outstanding. With a band on horseback (!) and an additional marching band and another mounted troupe on horseback. Truly delightful. And Belem has so much more to offer, including the excellent Maritime Museum, and the Coach Museum, and the Jeronimo monastery and the Cultural Center's Modern Art Museum. After a full day there we decided to go back a second day, to cover more. And we didn't do it all. But the parade was an absolute delight.
Beautiful. Very beautiful. Took the yellow sightseeing bus--blue tour-- there, and then switched over to the orange tour. A lot to see there and some great photo opportunities.

MINI CASTLE. This is a very small, but very nice "castle" or fort. Our guide told us it was in the middle of the river, but, over time the river silted up and now it rests on the shore. You can walked around the outside and also inside. Go up to the top - 1 and 1/2 flights of stairs - for a nice view and cool breezes. Good photo ops.
Discovering Lisbon. A quiet part of the city. Castle, Discoveries Monument and Cathedral were intersting. Nata of Pasteis de Belem was delicious.

Belem area and Tower worth a visit. The Belem area of Lisbon is well worth visiting for a long morning/ lunchtime. The areas is very green, with lots of nice gardens, although there is a main road and railway that kind of cuts the seafront off a bit - be eagle-eyed for the crossings!The Torre de Belem was interesting, although there isn't an awful lot to see, it was free with the Lisbon Card. Word of warning, the spiral staircases up are the same ones down and if you are at all claustrophobic, stay on the lower levels!!

The Soul of the city. This famous historical and cultural area provides an excellent illustration of the principle that the Portuguese lose few opportunities of shooting themselves in the foot. Firstly, they have located this area, containing about half the city's main attractions about as far from its geometric centre as is possible. Having done so, they then cut it in two by the rail service to Estoril and Cascais. Most people reach it by Tram no 15 from Metro Station Cais Sodre -------- a 45-minute journey each way including an average wait time. At peak periods, the longer waiting time can add a good half-hour to the journey. There is so much worth seeing in these 20 or so acres that a full day visit should be planned. Pride of place goes to the Hieronymus Monastery with its handsome nave and beautifully carved double-tiered cloisters ----- a favorite venue for fashionable weddings. The building also houses the Museum of Archaeology and the initial section of the Marine Museum in its West Wing. The latter then extends in a U-shape, that encircles the Gulbenkian Planetarium, and does a left-turn to accommodate the largest of its galleries devoted to the Royal Barges as well as a cafeteria. Opposite, but only 30 ft away is the vast complex known as the Belem Cultural Center, a pleasing and impressive modern structure containing nothing that would ever entice you to step inside it. On the other side of the railway, and accessed by a grim underpass, lies the Monument to the Discoveries, decorated externally by some magnificent carving, and internally carrying an elevator to the panoramic roof offering fine views over the Tagus estuary. A pleasant walk along a recently-constructed promenade brings you to the celebrated Belem Tower that served more as a prison than as a genuine defence resource. Going in the opposite direction, towards the centre of town, you will pass on the North side the celebrated Belem Tart Shop that now has a few tables and chairs to help feed the hungry visitor. Further on, one passes the Belem Palace in which the President of Portugal resides, guarded by two bulldogs in uniform. with swords drawn. The East Wing of this Palace, formerly the Riding School, has now become the Coach Museum where a collection of glittering coaches, sedans and cabrioles lined up for inspection displayamazing carvings, paintings and other decorative skills. The area includes two parks with fountains and statues, and plenty of bench seating for reading and picnicking, but a bite of food to chase away the hunger can be had inexpensively in the colorful neighborhood cafes and restaurants, and people-watching is the main free entertainment.

What a shame Lisbon should let itself down so badly like thisLong walk back to the Belem Pasteis bakery - DO NOT MISS THIS - or the Pasteis - served warm and crispy in their vast restaurant = what a fascinating operation and what a stunning product - and not a rip off - best thing we ate in Portugal by miles.Finally, the Coach Museum - really interesting collection of vanity projects (Boy, did their Royalty "Go For It!" or what?) in a beautiful old Indoor Riding School - well worth a visit, we think.

great place for a walk. Amazing place to have a nice walk. quiet with excellent view along the way due to the river side. and at the end you really enjoy the belem tower and the coffee shops near it.

Beautiful Town Loaded With History.. A short train ride from Lisbon is Belem. However, do go and see it even if you do not go inside as it is one of the sights of Lisbon.

Amazing. This a seriously wondeful place. A little outside of Lisbon it is easily accessiable using the HOHF buses from the the City Centre. It feels a million miles away from the hussel and bussel of the city. Chamring relaxed and full off history. There are many lovely sights shops, botiques, cafe bars to visit. Your trip to Lisbon wont be complete without a visit to here.
You must visit. We loved the Maritime Museum and monument to Portugals explores by the river. It was lovely train ride from downtown Lisbon. Be sure to have the famous bakery treats.
Many attractions. At least 4 great places to go in Belem: Jeronimo's Monastery, Padrao dos Descobrimentos, Berardo Cultural Center and you can't miss eating the famous pasteis de Belem.

Beautiful. Very special architecture, well worth a visit. Lovely location by the water. Take a bustrip, and see it along with the great bridge, and the monument for the world travellers who were first to cross the oceans.

superb tower. We had no time to go in alas (we were on a tour), but this fortress in the water was superb! I liked it much better than the Discovery Monument. The design and details were also superb as well. beautiful architecture!

Wow, what a grandeur tower. One of places where you can see, there was a time in history, when Portugal was one of leading countries in Europe. Massive walls were guarding entrance to Lisbon. Interesting is a fact, that this tower used to be build on separated island on right bank of the river, but later it became a part of bank of Tajo. It is definitely worthful to visit!
very interesting historical area. lots of great museums here, all in one area. Make sure you try the pastas de natal (custard tarts)! It is very easy to access this area by public buses & streetcars.

A well spent day. I wanted my daughter to know her own town, so we took a tour around Belem and Lisbon, and Belem is one of the best places in Lisbon, full of sun and historic features and buildings. A must see for all tourists.

So much to see.... Belem has a great mix of sites to see (Jeronimos monastery, Torre de Belem, statue of Discoverers, Pasteis de Belem cafe) and some wonderful restaurants too (Cafe In, No Solo, etc). It's a great place to walk. Y the river too, with views of the Cristo Rei statue and the 25 of April bridge. Worth a trip...

More than Pasteis. Pasteis de Belem is a national treasure, and not to be missed, but there is more to this charming section of Lisbon. Jeronimos, the Torre de Belem, the gardens; it is perfect for strolling through history. It's a daytime adventure, the nighttime is pretty quiet. If you're looking for nightlife, try Chiado, Cais de Sodre or the Docks.

Disappointing. The whole area is a tourist trap. You have to pay a ridiculously high entrance fee, it is crowded wit beggars and thieves, the staff working at the attractions are particularly unfriendly, the way to Belem by public transportations is uncomfortable, the restaurants want to rip you off... The area does not meet the expectations set by all the great talk about Belem...
belem beautiful. this is a microcosm of history with cathedrals monuments to explorers combined with the best pastries in Europe

Fabulous monestary. The monestary is well worth a trip out of the centre. Take the number 15 tram for the central square. you can get a Metro card for one or two days from the station which covers all the buses and trams.

Historical Belem : A world of discoveries not to be missed when in Lisboa.. Coming from the Indian Ocean which Bartholomeu Dias and Vasco da Gama explored 500 years ago , I in turn decided to explore Lisbon's historical area of Belem where many of these great Portuguese explorers embarked on their voyages of discovery. We took the tram 15 from Rossio Square which dropped us at the Jeronimos Monastry.Unfortunately there was a long queue and instead we decided to visit the Maritime Museum founded in 1863 by King Luis to promote maritime history. We then visited the Contemporary Art Museum which incidentally was free. Our visit would have been incomplete if we did not visit the Monumento dos Descobrimentos with sculptures of important historical figures such as King Manuel I, Vasco da Gama, Magellan and Cabral followed by a leisurely walk to Torre de Belem . We ended our day at the famous Pasteis de Belem and on our return had a close look at Ponte de 25 abril which made our visit complete.

One of the best attractions in Lisbon. When in Lisbon we try to get to Belem at least once a week taking the 15E tram. However, if it is raining, definitely stay at home or go to the movies. The best attractions of Belem are enjoyed by walking along the river front, in the sunshine and admiring all the sites there eg the Torre de Belem, the Monumento dos Descobrimentos, Jeronimous Monastery, walking in the gardens, plus enjoying lunch outdoors in the sunshine overlooking the park which all makes for a really lovely day. Recently we saw a place for segway tours along the river which would be great fun. However it can get very crowded at weekends with tourists all keen to enjoy the famous pasteis de nata (Portuguese custard tarts) for which Belem is famous although you can buy them at most bars and cafes in Lisbon. Don't miss it.

A day out at the seaside. Belem is an area not to be missed as it has so many attractions to see. The magnificent cathedral, torres tower. carriage museum.and a choice of lovely Portugese restauants linig the park next to Mcdonalds.

A must. Do not miss Belem, even if you have little time. Take a taxi, go first to the Monumento dos Descobrimentos, a nice homage to the courage of the Portuguese, who faced the unknown in search of other lands. Then go ahead and visit Torre de Belém, a fort that was situated in the middle of the Tagus River in the 1500s. See the copy of the plane Gago Coutinho used to cross the Atlantic, before Lindbergh. Then go to Jeronimos, the monastery that in itself is worth a visit. See the gothic church and the tombs of Vasco da Gama, the navigator, and Luis de Camões, the poet. After, walk back to Fábrica de Pastéis de Bel'ém, for a cup of coffee, tea or hot chocolate with delicious '"pastéis de nata". Don't miss it.

Pasteis de Belem. if you have a sweet tooth and you want to taste a little bit of heaven...don't miss the belems @ Pasteis de Belem. Don't be turned off by the usual line. It usually moves quickly and it guarantees a steady supply of fresh, warm belems. Remember to add cinnamon and sugar. Just the thought of them makes me drool!

Great to see. Great to see, pretty crowded a little difficult to figure out how to get there as there is a railroad along the main street. Look for the underpass and walk under to get to the Belem also easy to get to take bus No.15.

Great place to visit. If you're in Lisbon it's a must to visit this town on the river and see the bridge with the statue that resembles the one of Jesus Christ in Brazil. See the Belem tower and the monastery and also there is a contemporary art museum which is free entrance. It is amust to try the Belém pasties!!!

icon of lisbon, must see, needs a full day visit.. from down town, take tram 15 "E", remember "E", 4 places are to be seen there.1- Jeronimos Monastry, you will be lucky if you attend a ceremony, do visit the attached museum. 2- Belem tower.great view, ( ticket for both is 10 euros, if you go on Sunday it is free ). 3-Cultural center,with inside and outside museums. 4-Monument to the discoveries, with another museum in the basement. do not forget to eat one of the nicest Ice Cream in the world in Italy Cafe. also please do eat Pasteis de Belem in the cafe carrying the same name. if you are to visit one place in Lisbon, please visit Belem area.

Worth a tram ride. The Belem area is packed full of museums, lovely gardens, the Belem tower, as well as the vaguely fascist monument erected by Salazar overlooking the river. Definitely worth a visit.
Awesome!. Great area with interesting museums and a beautiful church. We visited a couple of the museums and rode along the water. It was very enjoyable.

My last goodbye was there !!. Belem takes you back centuries back to the castle , to the art and the serenity of the place there , and ahhhhh theFOOOOD ,next to pasteis de belem which is heavenly ,there is an middle eatern food store which sells shawerma and tahina "beautiful " so have this as lunch and then take a bite of the best sweetest dessert you will probably taste in your life .
Just a little paradise!. I just like the scenery and the tarts in Belhem. I put my feet in the sea whch was warm. The modern Art museum is wfree and well worth a visit.
Nice tower near the tagus river . Nice tower to visit. Nice view on top of the tower. You have to take tram 15e from the city center to the tower.

A beautiful place to visit. The old monastery buildings are breath-taking and beautiful to walk around. Its a nice change from the city of lisbon, near the water etc with lovely gardens, fountains etc. Would reccommend if you have a few days to spend in Lisbon.
Crowded without much to see. We went on Sunday when Belem was free, if I had to pay I might have skipped this site and there was nothing to see.

Some unique monuments. Go to Belem with the oldtimer streetcar no.15, get out at the Mosteiro dos Jerônimos, visit the new Cultural Centre and cross over the traintrack and big road to arrive at the riverside. There you'll find the famous and beautiful Torre de Belem. See also the Padrão dos Descobrimentos.

Don't Miss. It is very much worth the effort to make the short tram ride (Tram 15) takes around half an hour, to Belem. There is plenty to see, but even if you are not interested in Monuments, Forts, or Cathedrals, you have to make the trip to try the authentic Belem Custard tarts, Delicious ! and worth the trip alone.

Must visit. Beautiful area, certainly worth spending about 4-6 hours. The walk from Belem Tower to Monument to the Discoveries is wonderful. Also must visits are the Jerónimos Monastery, and the Church and the coach museum. Best part of Lisbon in my opinion.

Spend half a day here. The monastery of St Jeronomo is well worth a visite. Walk by the sea from the seafarer monument to the Belem tower. There is also a culture center with a big modern museum - and a lot of small, charming places to eat.
Trendy cultural. Much to see, quality of diferent offers in cultural field.Diferent museums and also Cultural Centrum of Belém with concerts ,cultural agenda and art galleries
Marine Museum. Very impressive for all ages. Seeings the country was powerful because of it's ships and exploration; this museum was full of history.

Packed with history. Belem is crammed with places to visit. Check out the Tower, the Monastery, the Monument at the least. The Maritime museum and the Cultural center are worth your time, too. Plan to walk a lot and enjoy one of the famous Belem pastries.

belem tour. a must see..........very difficult in the stairs going up , so the ideal is to arrive at about ten to five so that you have a good half hour there, and have the stairs free of up commers.l advise to take the taxi , as from the tram stop of belem you have a god half hours walk; and the taxi from the center cost us eight euros for four
plenty in this area. interesting historical monuments need to read the guides for the history.Lots of places to relax and get a drink
Nice area to visit. I liked the historical sites, the Belem Tower, monument and the monastary. Definitely worth a visit! Also have a coffee (bica) and a pasteis de Belem in the cafe.
History in front of you. One of the emblematic areas of Lisbon, the Jeronimos, Torre de Belem, Padrão dos Descobrimento or even the Pasteis de Nata make your journey here unforgetable!

It is always nice to return to Belem!. There are many interesting buildings and memorials to see. Luckily, we did travel by the agency bus, so we did not have to be careful for the pickpockets, which tried to rober my husband on tram 15 in 2010

Bedlam in Belem. We have been to Lisboa twice, each time we came here on a SUnday when the museums are free. And each time the lines were long and the trams overstuffed. Suggestion would be to visit the Monastery and Church on a weekday when it would be a little less crazy, both a well worth an visit. We also enjoyed the architecture of the Exhibition Hall (big concrete building on the rivera across from the monastery), had a nice lunch/snack on the Terrace Bar on the third floor.
Loved Belem!. Take the #15 tram to Belem, walk along the seawall, stop at the lovely waterfront cafe for a glass of wine, check out the Monument of Discoveries and the Tower (haunting)...........

Quiet and calm place, do not go on a monday!. I went for a wander by myself to Belem, using the tram outside the Arco da Rua Augusta. It took 20 minutes. The reason why i stated not to go on a Monday is i don't want fellow traveller's to make the same mistake i did (by not reading my guide durr) as most of the places to visit were closed. However, i made good use of my time as the buildings are just as impressive on the outside. there are some restaurants and a little cafe on the sea front which appear not to have all the bustle of Lisbon city center. The Berardo collection was a little disappointing as the collection had changed so i didn't get to see my Warhol check on the net to see current exhibits before making the trip, it is free though.

Interesting but crowded. Plenty to see and do in the compact area of Belem, but even in the off season it is crowded and the ticketing./ access process can be slow - worth a visit for sure but be patient.
Don't miss it!. We did it at the end of our 48h in Lisbon.It is a must to see. The pastel, the Monasterio, the Tower, etc.Do not miss it, even though it is not in down town Lisbon
