Lots of things to see!. At the Belem area, you have the Belem Tower, another tower (forgot the name though), and the Monastery all at walking distance. The place also features Pasteis de Belem, which serves the best egg custards... yum!
Gem by the sea. They say it used to be a defense fortress but I would rather eat my shoes than put that beautiful building to that use.Definitely worth a visit.

Very cool...but get there early. Belem Tower was interesting to explore, but it certainly gets crowded quickly - so make sure to get there early. The staircases get progressively narrower the higher in the tower you go, but the views are good and the history interesting.

Pleasant parks, sad about the noise of traffic, trains and roads. Clearly was a lovely part of the coast before the days of mass transport, trains buses and cars. Needs a sensitive re -consideration- would be lovely without the hustle and bustle.Better when inside the museums and gardens.

Don´t miss Belem. Great place to take pictures, walk, visit museums, eat; you cane easly spend a whole day there, maybe two days. Do to the Torre de Belem in early hours, the light is better, visit the Padrao dos descobrimentos, see the view from the tower, eat pasteis de Belem.

Nice modern art museum (no fee), Pasteis and Monuments .... Belem was a nice place to pass our morning after getting off an overnight bus from Sevilla, ES.The pasteis with Espresso were a good pickmeup and both the Monument to the "Explorers" and the Tower of Belem both had impressive views and well-placed descriptions describing their historical significance.The Cultural Center of Belem (on the waterfront abutting one side of the park that houses the Anthropological Museum/Palace of Belem) had a great free modern art exhibit which I enjoyed more than the famed Reina Sofia in Madrid on the same trip ... nice!!

Lovely Place. Beautiful place and has excellent pastel de Belém, loved!The day was beautiful with a gorgeous sun and enjoy the day could very welland the Portuguese were very simpaticos with everything

wonderland~. it's really a nice place, i spent my afternoon herestanding in the windswept terrace and doing nothingit would be better if u could stay here until sunsetthen u won't forget this beautiful watercolor easily:)
Monuments, Castles and Pastries Oh My!. Worth a morning to visit Belem, see the monuments, museums and catch a warm-out-of-the-oven Pastel De Belem.

Beatiful. Belem is a beatiful place. There are a number of awesome buildings to visit such as the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos and CCB (Centro Cultural de Belém). The gardens near the Torre de Belém are very peaceful and a nice place to rest for a while. It's mandatory to visit the Fábrica dos Pasteis de Belem, a local treasure for cakes.
go sunday. its free and worth the view. not sure how much it is on other days but the cultural center and the monastery also free and nearby on sundays.
Nice. Looks nice from the outside, not much to see inside.Nice place to visit anyway.Reviews must be at least 50 characters. Thanks

A picturesque tower in a lively part of town.. It was cloudy in Rossio square (starting point of tram 15) but in Belem it was fine. To visit the tower one must get off in "centro cultural Belem", walk for half a minute and there's the motorway. The street across cannot be walked because of the railway tracks; there is a bridge with many stairs for this purpose, where I don’t remember seing any provisions made for people with special needs. So if you hate stairs you can get off at "Belem" instead, walk towards the tower and then walk back. It was Sunday around noon and of course there were plenty of tourists there. It's a five storey tower, and while being on the ground floor I saw a huge queue standing. I thought that there were just a lot of people there, waiting to go upstairs. Unfortunately this wasn’t the case. The truth is that on the way to higher floors the path is very narrow, the spiral stairs being about 35 cm wide, this is the only way to the top, and that on the 35 cm stairs there were two queues, one going up and one going down. So bear in mind that sports shoes and 1,5 hour available for this visit are a must; no heavy equipment should be carried – better carry something that can be tied around the neck, like I did with my handbag- since both hands must be used while going downstairs. The tower is really small, when I arrived on the top there was not much of a view, but the view was not what I went there for anyway. The entrance is free until 14:00; at least on Sundays.Of course there are a number of shops selling souvenirs there, but at Rossio square I bought the same things at much cheaper prices. There is a small shop 10-20 meters before tram 15 last stop in Praça da Figueira, and I guess there must be plenty of souvenir selling stores around as well.

Portugal, lisbon Visits. Lisbon's most monumental and historical area is Belem. It was from here that many of the great Portuguese explorers embarked on their voyages of discovery: Prince Henry the Navigator and the first overseas expedition to conquer Ceuta in Morocco, Bartholomeu Dias to round the Cape of Good Hope, the first voyages of Ferdinand Magellan, Vasco da Gama to discover the sea route to India, and Christopher Columbus stopped here on his way back to Europe after discovering the New World. Very historical Beautiful area full of Tourists. walking distance to many areas of food, pastries, garden in front of Belem Palace. But the best place for a drink and pastries is the cafe Antiga Confeitaria de Belem which has been serving delicious custard tarts Portuguese famous Pastries yum yum Good:)
To eat or drink. There's a lot of restaurants and bars all around Belem... and the place is really beautifull, very different to the center, both are sorprising...

PASTRY OF BELEM A MUST EAT!. Situated two doors down from the Starbucks on same street as monastery is a pastry shop with blue awnings. THIS IS A MUST HAVE PASTRY, in fact, Lisbon should require a stamp in your passport for having one before leaving the country! They are fresh out of the oven and warm and delicious. WE saw the Belem Tower, Geronimo Monastery, etc. and this was most memorable! Pasteis de Belem--YUM!!!

When the sun shines you'll love this. The weather played a good'un and so we really saw it at it's best and were able to take an hour plus to enjoy it and the fantasic views. BTW you can get in free - check it's site for details.

The Sea Tower. Architectural atractiv, old and nice detailled work in building stones, diferent configuration, medieval ambience, arms colection. Into a touristic area nearby several monuments and places to wathc riverbank ambience.

I Love Belém!. Very well located in the water front! Great to walk, go to museums ( Belém Cultural Centre, Jerónimo´s Monastery, Belem Tower, etc). have a great view to the river , the other part of it, the brigde, the sea! Dont forget to try the small pastry ( Pastel de Belém!).
A great morning outing. We spent a few hours wandering through Belem. We stopped to have the most delicious Portuguese tarts in Portugal!!! A definite must see.

Hard to get to, but the tower is worth it. Belem isn't in the hustle and bustle of downtown, and it's actually a little work to get to, but I say make a half-day of it, and enjoy! We took the train out there, which drops you about 2 miles from the Tower of Belem. We walked the 2 miles, enjoying sites on the way (a monument, some birds successfully catching fish, a water-side outdoor mini-gym), and then could not get over the Tower. On the way back we walked to the Monestary. From there, we walked the couple blocks into town and took a bus up to the Mae d'Agua which was INCREDIBLE.

Good on a Sunday. Came here on a Sunday as most of the museums are then free between 10 and. As a result it was rather busy for November. There was also a cruise ship in and this area is no their stop off list.
Beautiful place. Visited Belem for some Pasteis de Belem. Which was fantastic. The sceneray in Belem is beautiful and we walked up to the Tour De Belem along the riverside.

History on the Shore!. Belem is easy to access (we did it with the tour bus). It's a dynamic part of the waterfront in Lisbon, and a comfortable stroll at the end of the day. The sunset photos we fantastic!

Free on Sundays. between 10:00-14:00 the monestary, church, tower of Belem and monument are free. Take tram 15 E (the added E is important) to Belem. We stumbled on the changing of the guard (big ceremony) just before we reached the monestary, which added to the fun of the trip. Fabulous masonry in the monestary, take your time to see it all.

Worth the tram ride. Breathtaking cathedral. Beautiful cloisters. Rather dreary walk to Belem tower but well worth it. Tower is spectacular with fantastic views if you scale the narrow stairs to the top. Lisboa ticket gives admission to both attractions. Monument to navigator well worth the ascent by lift. Nice cafe by marina. Don't miss it.

Altis Belem Hotel & Spa. WOW, what a hotel! I thought the Sofitel Grand Legend in Amsterdam was amazing, but this hotel is that plus a work of art. Every detail thought of, little specialty services everywhere. Beautifully appointed and modern. To die for food.

potential not exploited. For a 5 euro fee it costs about a euro every 5 minutes which is steep. Nothing to see downstairs so proceed to the dungeon which was completely empty ! Then up and down a single winding staircase to 4 floor of further emptiness, although the view gets marginally better as you go up and there is some short description tacked to the walls on each floor. Gives you a chance to experience the (un)politeness of the average punter as well. I actually backed up for one mouthy tour guide and his flock only to be completely ignored at the top. You can get stuck for a while in the middle of the tower if traffic on the stairs is heavy. Look from outside but save some cash till someone makes more of an effort.
The Musium around Belem are worth to spend a half day. If you want to know how different types of ships were made and used for Voyages, visit Musiums at Belem.

Lots to do!. There are so many things to do in the Belem area! There is the Belem Tower, of course, but the explorers monument, war memorial, monastary, Pasteis de Belem bakery, coach museum, contemporary art museam are also there. We actually spent two days in Belem. Don't short change yourself on visiting this area, because you might think you can get by with just a couple hours (and if you want to see much of it you can't). It is easy to spend the entire day in Belem because it is well served with restaurants, cafes and dessert venues as well as attractions.

thing you must see in lisbon. Tower of Belem Landmarks Points of Interest, Historic Sites, Monuments, Statues. Belem Tower The Belem Tower is located at the western end of the Avenida de Brasília, in the Belem district. It is a UNESCO World Heritage monumentmore Useful Information: Activities for older children.Definitely a Lisbon Landmark as it is Historic and offers an interesting blend of Architecture. It's situated on the belem waterfront, linking The Monument of Discoveries and, through a very well landscaped "park" area.The tower was built in the 16th century in the Tagus River to control the entrance to the city from the sea. It's open from 10.00 am to 6.30 pm. The admission fee is 5 euros, but I recommend you purchasing the combined ticket for 10 euros which allows entrance to both Belem Tower and Jeronimos Monastery.

Hmm Belem pastries and beautiful buildings. Wow.. I like pastries but these are delicious! Belem Pastries are the original typical little pastries that you MUST try if you are in Lisbon. Belem has also a lot of cultural things to see. Hire a bike and go there along the riverside from Lisboa. It's a half our ride and it's really nice!
Yummy!. You must try the pasteis de Belem, they are excellent! Wonderful town just a short train ride from the heart of Lisbon, home to the most delicious custards on the planet.

See it on the Way to the Monastery. Definately a Lisbon Landmark as it is Historic and offers an interesting blend of Architecture. It's situated on the belem waterfront, linking The Monument of Discoveries and, through a very well landscaped "park" area, the Monastery across the street. Nice spot for a couple of pics, but that's about it....  Not a huge presence, I'm afraid, as it actually appears quite dwarfed by the immense open space around it..... It's value def. lies on what it represents and it's history and not much more. Apreciate the History and architecture, snap a couple of shots then continue on along the Tagus watching locals catch fish as you make your way to the Monastery.... I would probably start here, buy the combined ticket (10 Euros includes the Monastery) and after visiting both sites, make sure to stop at the "Casa Pasteis de Belem" for Java and their delicious "Pasteis de Nata" (see reviews)!! Hope this helps!! KS

Beautiful architecture. The tower was built in the 16th century in the Tagus River to control the entrance to the city from the sea. It's open from 10.00 am to 6.30 pm. The admission fee is 5 euros, but I recommend you purchasing the combined ticket for 10 euros which allows entrance to both Belem Tower and Jeronimos Monastery. It's worth visiting this place as it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Morning in Belem. You can get there on number 15 Tram...spent the morning sightseeing...Torre de Belem, Jeronimo Monastery and the Discovery monument...stopped in Cafe Pastéis de Belém for Um galão (coffee) and pastéis de nata...Belem area is well worth a visit...

Little Belem tower. Belem Tower is highly advertised as a must when in Lisbon but the truth is, it should be just a 10 minute stop for a photo.The tower is actually quite a small structure and it offers little more than an interesting view that gets shadowed by the other monuments around.The best thing to do is just get there while walking down the passage by the sea to enjoy it in a better way and not wasting your time just aiming for that particular spot.

Worth a visit. We went on a Sunday morning when museums are free. We had a short visit to the Church and cloisters which are spectacular, and then to the Naval museum.It is huge and well worth a visit - if you have a couple of hours to spare.A short walk to the waterfront and you will see the Belem Tower within a 10 minute walk. If it's a nice day this is a pleasant walk and the tower is a short visit but provides nice views from the top.

Nice UNESCO site. Belem is a little out of the way to visit, but I think it was well worth the extra effort. We shared a cab with a family that was waiting on the tram stop, and it cost around 10 euros. However, if you have the tram passes, this would be well worth it.When you arrive, follow the river away from the Abril de 25 bridge. You will eventually find the tower. For some reason this was tricky for us, so that's why I give these directions.While you are visiting the bridge be sure to leave time to visit the whole area. There are lovely fountains, eateries (including the famous pastreis de belem!), and churches. The entrance fee was 5 euro. You can walk all the way up to the top of the tower which provides wonderful picture opportunities. The stairs are a bit steep and crowded - so just follow someone up or down, as only one person can go on them at a time.
Majestic sights. The castle is a must see. Especially for the kids. But be prepared to climb lots of stairs, both to get there and once in.
Nice afternoon in Belem. We had a very nice Sunday afternoon in Belem. It is a nice place. I would recommend you to have lunch over there. It is nicer and cheaper!
Lots of turists. Lots of turists although it was low season. Would not go there in summer. Theres better areas in Lísbon to experiance the city. Some nice sights but crowded

old monument tour. beautiful historic monuments on the river banks, near the war memorial, which is pristine; guarded by Portuguese military, with a fire continually lit in rememberence. A beautiful, architecturally astonishing working Monestary, nearby.

A Must. Really, you want to walk the waterfront , look at the tower , the combatants museum and the explorers monument.You get a good view of the bridge and the Christ statue across the river.Cross the steet , away from the river and go into the beautiful monastary chapel with the burial sites of Vasco Da Gama and Camoes.You can get here on the 15 tram and I think the 727 bus.
Lovely things to see. We spent a day at Belém, with the Tower, Jeronimo Monastery and the Discovery monument this part of Lisbon impressed us more than the rest.

Interesting ans sweet!. Great for a stroll along history. From the modern monument to the historical Torre de Belém. Also an interesting sidestep is the Museu da Electricidade (Free).
And have a take-away lunch from Pastéis de Belém!

Good historical place to visit. Beuatiful view and interesting historical site. A lot of people and small stairs.
For everyone OPENING HOURS:
from 10:00 - 18:30
The Tower of Belem does not work on Monday.

Beautiful Belem. The Belem area is well worth a visit. The main attraction is the Geronomos Monastery. It is so well worth seeing. The church itself is amazing with soaring ceilings without any visable support. The cloisters are beautifull and architecture has to be seen to be believed. Belem is on the waterfront so there is a lovely cool breeze from the river, which makes a pleasant change from the centre of Lisbon. Belem tower is also an impressive building and there is an amazing monument on the waterfront called the Decembros monument. There is also river cruises available. We did one which took around two hours. It is nice to see Lisbon from the water and while the trip is not spectacular it is a good way to relax after so much walking. One interesting thing on the cruise was we went under a huge bridge which is a replica of the Golden Gate bridge. It is on two levels and an amazing piece of work.

Tower of Babel would be a better name. This was a great disappointment. Beautifully situated, jutting out into the water, it looked formidable and interesting. However, it has been restored in a Disneyesque way, absurdly so. All the primitive stone has been cosmetically softened, so that it is devoid of any character, similar to a bad face lift. It is a problem that some buildings do suffer from too much "conservation", look at the Sistine chapel ceiling in the Vatican. Unfortunately, this is another. By removing warts and all, the tower ceases to have character, by its very nature, a rampart, to counter maritime aggression. Conservationists take heed.
A must see. Can't visit Lisbon and miss this. An easy tram ride and a beautiful area. Walk along the river side...worth taking the tour...it's a fascinating building.

Tourist must on the Tagus. The combination of the Discoverers' Monument and the Manuline Monastic Church of St. Jerome on Lisbon's riverfront made this visit a "must" in seeing Lisbon. The church (and the attached cloisers, now a museum) was not destroyed in the earthquake of 1755, and it is spectacular, with the tomb on Vasco da Gama and some quite amazing chapels. I am interested in Gothic architecture, so the church was fascinating to me, but even the members of our group who were not so interested seemed to find it quite interesting.

A must in Lisbon. If you want to see the area outside of Lisbon that was not destroyed and rebuilt, this is it. Belem is why I travel. The old and unique all in a small area. From the pastries to the world heritage sites, this area is amazing. The hop on hop off bus takes you to all the spots in Belem. It is worth the money. You get an audio guide to go with it.

Great view point for Lisbon waterfront. The Padrao dos Escobrimentos is a great place for a vista over the bay and Belem. From there you can walk along the waterfront path to Belem Tower, a gothic tower overlooking the waters.

Cute little city!. Belem is right on the coast and it is a small city but with a lot of character and a lot of history. I am glad I was able to make the side trip to visit the city and learn so much about the beginnings of Portugal.

One of my favorite places in Lisbon. Take tram 15 from the city over to Belem...if you go to one of the tobacco shops you can get a round trip ticket for 3.50e. Definitely worth it! We saw the Torre de Belem and went to many of the museums over here as well. You should go early in the morning, see what you want to see, have lunch, and then return!

Good day trip... if you have seen everything else. we spent a few hours here. I would recommend seeing the rest of Lisbon before you head there. There were some great photo opportunities of the river and bridge. The restaurant and cafe scene was disappointing.

Belem never gets old. Undoubtedly a must for a Lisbon visit. If you want to go, you need to go by the always full 15 Tram. I have used it many times but only sat once during the afternoon. You can avoid this by getting in on the first stop at Praça da Figueira. I found out last time that Trams queue one after another and get late because of all the people getting in and buying tickets individually. So, if you want to travel sitting to really enjoy the trip to Belem skip them until you get one where you can sit (there is one every 10-15 minutes).At Belem you must eat the famous pasteis the belem at the shop with lots of people outside. You will know it when you see it, but its worth it. There is lots to see in this area: Parks, museums, the tagus river, the arts exhibition. I would recommend spending a full day to really enjoy it. Return to Baixa late in the afternoon in the now emptier 15 tram.

Great history lesson. If in Lisbon, you must head out to Belem and see both the Tower and the Monastery. Of course, the only way to finish your tour properly is to taste Pastéis de Belém right down the street. Yum!
Impressive building but not worth the trip. Belem is a very impressive building but if you are not interested in walking a big church with masses of people give it a try.
Multiple sites. Nice place to explore. Various attractions, such as Tower and monastry. Easy to reach via tram from Lisbon centre

Not Disney!. This beautiful suburb of Lisbon is easy to visit by bus or tram. The Monument of Discoveries is outstanding and a massive statement, literally! The Torre de Belem is magical like something out of Disney but built long before his empire. This is real history and beautiful too. Climbing the stairs of the tower could prove to be challenging for some people but the views from the top are wonderful and well worth the stuggle. Views of the bridge, monument and the river are great. By the way there is some outdoor fitness equipment on the promenade if you are feeling in need of some exercise, this can be used by anyone!
Good spot to take nice picture. Is a fortified tower and situated by the sea. Nice spot to take pictures, further down the tower, there's a cafe with free wifi. A must visit attraction in Lisbon.
a must vist. strolling around belem was very relaxing and soothing jerome monastery is awesomeseeing the tomb of Vasco da gama was the highlight

Definitely worth a visit. We visited Belém when we had a free afternoon in Lisbon. It is a beautiful area to wander around if you have a few spare hours. We didn't have time to go inside anywhere, but the monuments and the monastery are impressive even from the outside. Make sure to grab a few freshly baked pasteis de nata from the place opposite the bus stop before returning to Lisboa. They are the best you'll find.

A must go in Lisbon region. Even if you have just a few hours free, Belem is a place no one can miss in Lisbon.A walking by the river close to the tower and the "pastelzinho de belem" make any afternoon a good moment to remember in Lisbon.
Full of history. Its a landmark of Lisbon that you can't loose. Its full of history near of others landmarks. The Tejo River is like an ocean. The bridge at the horizon is a great and unique view.

A walk by the river. The area of Belem has a long pedestrian street by the river, worth to have a walk or a ride with your bicycle and a wide park to relax. In the summertime you have to wait in long queues for entering in any place of interest, restaurant etc. A nice place, but not the best in Lisbon.
Belem. Great views, there is also a very sobering memorial to the Portugese military near by, plus a small military museum.

Spend a day here!. There is so much to do here and well worth a day spent here. Start with theTorre de Belem - be really careful about the stairs in the towere - as they are are so narrow. We were stuck on them for c.30 mins as people went up and down - really needs a traffic signal system. However, it was still worth it. Walk round the quayside to the Discoveries monument then on to Jerominos Monastery - go inside to see the tomb of Vasco de Gama. The highlight however is the Pasteis de Belem custard tart shop!. The queue outside is for take aways - go in the shop to the left and keep walking - you go through room after room of cafes. We had 9 tarts, 3 coffess and a hot chocolate for 15euros! This place may be world famous but is still reasonable so locals still use it. You can order tubes of 6 pasteis to go whilst orderign your coffee - they are 6.30 euros for 6 pasteis. The receipe is only known to 3 people and they make over 10,000 a day - that is a recommendation!
Stunning place!. Definitely when in Lisbon visit Belem. Stunning location the St Tropez of Portugal plenty to see and do!

Lovely seaside tower thats a fine example of period Portuguese archietecture. Its a bit confusing long walk from the Jeronimos monastery. But totally worth it. The tram stop is 2 stops ahead. The tower is a nice view, has some old guns on display and gives u a superlative windy view of the city. Must see IMHO. There is no circuit there - do visit both the basement as well as the upper levels incl the rhinoceros.
The rest on the edge of tejo. A fascinating site, lots of light, space and green areas .... a fabulous garden by the river Tagus, where we read, rest, or take a morning exercise ....

Torre de Belém... uau.... This tower, built in its present form, was in fact an adaptation / reconstruction and recovery of the original built in 1936, when the world exhibition, then held in Lisbon, during the Salazar government. Mappa Mundi highlight of which is observable from the top of this tower. a monument to the discoveries and Portuguese expansion. Interestingly, the foundational myths of Lisbon. The Roman Olissipo.

Worth a visit. On our visit to Belem we took in Monastero dos Jeronimos and was very impressed! Also visited the discoveries monument and was impressed, and the Torre de Belem, which unfortunately appeared to be closed. There was huge queues all day long outside the Pasteis de Belem bakery but we did not join the queues. Enjoyed our visit.
Should visit. We decided to visit on Sunday and it was rather busy but still great views, really nice place. Pasties de Belem shop close by so treat yourself to the great tarts...

Have a holiday here. a fabulous area full of museums( carriage, maritime, the Jeronimos monestery) a full range of restourants from Mcdonalds to teriffic local portugeuse and all ony a very short tram ride from Lisbon centre

resembles Swallow's Nest. Tremendous spot! Stands right in the water, which makes it more beautiful. It seemed interesting to know that Torre de Belem is a specimen of Portuguese architecture of the Renaissance period, the more so because it resembles Swallow's Nest in the Crimea so much. Visitors are allowed to all the levels of this peculiar square building. There’re no audio guides or someone to tell its story, just few wall sheets about Lisbon defense system, governors of the Tower and so on. I guess you go there mainly for spectacular views. They are different from each floor and each corner. It is rather crowded in high season; securities try to regulate streams of people, without success, as the stairs are extremely narrow.Tip: to avoid throngs come late in the afternoon.

Nice food. We went to Belém by tram and had a nice meal at the snackbar/restaurante near the first tram stop at Rua Belém 2-8 (forgot the name of the restaurant).Visited the monesteiro (impressive) and the museum before sitting at the waterside near the Torre de Belém watching the sunset with some Bacalhau from Pasteis de Belém.All good.
Must see. We went in the pouring rain, but it is still worth the trip. Near the monastery so a nice add on. Wont take long!

Good Pastry!. Easy on the metro. Wonderful pastrys at Casa Pastels de Belem are wonderful original cream tarts. These are worth the ride for the warm fresh originals. The sights, Jeronimos Monastery, Monument of Discoveries and Coach museum are all outstanding and not to be missed.
Tight for time, wanted to vist the Cathedral and also the Basilica. An unusual building with an interesting history. It is also close the the Vasco Da Garma monument and the naval academy.

Monument on the river. I was a bit confused as to what to do when I arrived in Belem, and walked around listlessly for quite some time. I eventually went into the free part of the church which was really beautiful. I also visited the Maratime museum which took more than an hour and contained lots of model vessels, replica royal barges (my favourite part!) and other nautical things relating specifically to Portugal's past and present navy. When the sun was out it was great to sit by the huge monument on the river, overlooking the bridge - I'm not sure what the monument is dedicated to, but it was impressive nonetheless. Also - don't forget to eat some cakes (my favourite: pastel de nata) before going back to Lisbon (30-ish minutes by tram). Hope that helps!

Awe Inspiring Architecture and Delicious Pastries. The St. Jeronimos Monastery is staggeringly beautiful and seeing this world heritage site is worth the trip to Belem. But, before you leave, take the time to wait on line for a stack of the custard tarts. They, too, are worth the trip (and the wait).

Belem= best pateis de creme. The Antiqua Confiteria de Lisboa is a good place to start visiting Belem. Excellent coffee.. Pateis de creme at Jeronimos. Everything was fine. Nice walks alongside the Tagus river. Beautiful sunsets in Monunument for Infante Enrique

Belem. One of the key architectural sights of Portugal and indeed Europe.Very crowded to begin with and huge queue- with only one chap handling everything at the reception kiosk!Actual church and monastery outstanding- our first experience of Manueline architecture, with it's riot of superbly-executed naturalistic carving. Don't miss sacristy- entered off church rather than monastery and separate (small) entrance fee- fine vaulting and paintings.

A great day. From Cais do Sodre (on the green tube line), Belem can be reached by the tram number 15E. Had a fantastic day in Belem starting at the Jeronimos monastery. It is a beautiful place with beautiful architecture (don't forget to look at the details of the sculptures) and interesting information and exhibition about Portuguese history. A ticket can be bought for the monastery and the tower of Belem for 10 euros which gives a little reduction.Then we had a little break sitting down in the pastry shop to enjoy the famous and delicious Portuguese custard tarts. Lovely tiles in the pastry shop. Then we carried on to the Monument of the discoveries. We hesitated to go up and finally decided to go : we did not regret it, because the view is lovely. Really worth it.Then we visited the Torre de Belem : pleasant place but it can be a bit complicated to go at the top as the staircase to reach it , is very narrow and it is a two-way staircase, people coming down meet the people coming up, one has to be really careful. Then enjoyed a delicious lunch in a little restaurant in Rua Vieira Portuense. Unfortunately I cannot remember the name of the restaurant but it was the one with beautiful flowers haging on top of the entrance. We ate outside and liked the fact that nobody came to "fetch us" when we were looking at the menu. The sardines were delicious, delicious, delicious ! 20 euros for 2 people : 1 main course each, drinks and cheese, bead and olives to start. Big portions.Then we ended the day visiting the coaches museum : another great place in the Belem district.We took our time to enjoy all this. Much more to do in this part of Lisbon but we had decided to go for these monuments and attractions. Belem offers lots of options to suit everybody's taste.

worth a day. found that there was a whole days worth to see here-from the monument to the tower to the monastery-with food in between including the bustling pastry shop with the original pastel de Belem . (did not get to the coach museum)
Pasties de nata. Go to this bakery, a must for their custard tarts. You can sit in and enjoy straight from the oven, delicious.

beautiful Belem. the monastery with its' dramatic courtyard, and carvings all around, the cathedral annex, where a wedding was taking place so you could here the organ playing everywhere, the sheer vastness of the buildings and their intricate floor plan... very beautiful indeed and a must see..
Nice white lady!. Belem tower and the whole area is very nice, get inside the tower, it is worth it, fantastic view and fresh sea wind:)
Amazing. Such am amazing place. We only spent a few hours here however you could spend all day. So much to do and such a lovely place to walk and relax in
Not a must. I found Belem a bit of a dive to be honest... but the sights to see (monument, torre and monastery) are worth a stop off en route to Cascais on a day trip.

A must visit place if you are in Lisbon. The Monument to the Discoveries is fantastic. My favourite monument in Lisbon. Once you have had a look around the monument and the waterfront, go over to the palace across the road and look for the shop selling Pasteis de Belem (small custard tarts). I think this is the place where they were first made - but I'm not certain. There are loads of copies out there but these must be eaten to be believed! You can't miss the shop, it will have a queue outside!
Touristic!. It´s a bit of a trek and is only really worth it if you love the old buildings thing! It´s a nice visit but there is not much else about unless I missed something!

favorite monument. monument of discoveries was incredible on the outside! Don't waste money to climb it - too small and better view from St. George castle; we grabbed lunch and ate in the park to people watch; monestery jeronemo was huge and worth seeing; didn't climb the tower because we had already done the Castle; great day in Belem

Lisbon with kids. It's a beautiful place (a must go place in Lisbon). You can walk and kids can run safely. Inside the tower there are lots of stairs, and you have to watch the children when they are near the windows. Don't forget to eat the Pasteis of Belem (Delicious!).
belem. you should visit the belem tower, Padrao dos Descobrimentos and pasteis de belem here. and also you can eat something in restaurante descobre

Lovely area. Got our €5 day pass, went on metro and then took overground to Belem. Got off at the lovely Monestry paid €7 to enter, a combo ticket for Belem tower and Monestry is €10. It is very ornate enjoyed our trip, well worth a visit. The area around the Monestry is lovely also. Had a look at Belem Tower and a great view of the 25th April Bridge. We then went to the top of the Monument to the Discoveries paid small fee to use the lift to the top. Great views. Tired and in need of coffee we headed to the famous Pastéis de Nata, this is a Portuguese egg tart pastry which we really enjoyed in the restaurant. At €1 each we found room for a second one. The smell of the tarts - just amazing. Just to note another day we travelled by train to and from Estoril and the view from the train of Belem and the Monestry is lovely. I recommend this area.

Belem is well worth a special visit. We had some hours free before having to head to the airport and took a taxi to Belem. I suggest a drop off at the Tower and then you can work your way back past all the sights. The Tower is a smaller example of the architecture that is in spades at the Monastery. and is 5 euros to get in. The views are great along the waterside. You can then walk around the Marina to the Monument to the Discoveries - don't miss the tiled map on the ground. You can then take an underpass under the road and train tracks to the Monastery. If you keep going along the road you come to the Cafe Pastéis de Belém. It is worth having a walk around the inside labyrinth of rooms even if all the tables are taken - it does not feel comfortable or pleasant to actually have anything there. We had the lovely egg tart pastries and much more pleasant cafes in the city.

OVER HYPED. We were disappointed when visiting the tower. To be fair,we were with a group, and time didn't allow to go into the tower, although not sure that would have made a difference. I found Belem in general over hyped.
Xmas Tree. Just went for overnight stay...to see the big Christmas Tree...it was lovelywell worth the visit, lots to see and do...but a bit expensive..
What a waste of a trip. Trams are overcrowded. Cafes are ripping people off. Monastery is far too busy. Area is full of beggars. When we were there one woman was robbed by pickpockets.
Statues and culture. Enjoyed our time spent in the Belem area. Lots of buildings, statues, and parks to visit. Its a bit of a walk to get around but we spolied ourselves with a driver and car.

A "must visit" in Lisbon!. Hop off the tourist bus at Belem and visit the magnificent monastery, the Belem tower, as well as the wonderful "Discoveries monument" - all within easy walking distance of each other. Fascinating history!

Nice Lookout Point. Found the Tower's entrance fee a little stiff for a short visit. The interesting feature of the tower was its narrow corridors to the lookout balconies. One person at a time, please.
Belem museums. Wonderful museums, great sense of history. We particularly liked the Belem Tower, the Monument to the Discoverers and the Monastery of St Jeronimos.

Belém: If you have only one side trip out of Lisbon. Loved the feeling of Belem, the Pastéis de Belém, the outdoor cafés, the Jerónimos, the Maritime Museum, the Belém tower and the Monument to Prince Henry the Navigator. A must-see

Beautiful and worth the trip. Belem is full of amazing historic sights. We took a bus tour around Lisbon and it took us out to Belem. It's spectacular. The monestary and monument to maritime navigators are both not to be missed. The egg tarts are also the best in the city. Be sure to go on any day but a Monday since many places are closed on mondays.

Worth Visiting. I was in the Belem area and saw this site. At the first glance, it did not look impressive from a distance. However, once you walked into the tower (cost 5 euros), that's when you see all the architecture details and the beautiful scenery from different levels. One thing to note is that the stairs in the tower are narrow (think the narrow staircase leading to the top of a church tower) and when there are a lot of people moving from one level to the other, it might take some time to get up and down. I went around 4:30pm; it was not too crowded.

Very Cool!!. The history of this tower is quite interesting and it's well worth a visit. Not much time is needed during the visit if you go early!! It's best to visit the tower right when it opens at 10AM as it's not too crowded!! I recommended getting in line at 9:45AM. As it's best to be some of the first folks to enter. It's much more enjoyable if the tower is not too busy and it makes for some great photo opportunities!!

Pleasant place to stroll by the river. If Lisbon is a little hot and crowded - as it probably will be - take the no 15 tram from Praca do Comercio to Belem. This tram can be very crowded so be on your guard against pickpockets.At Belem visit the sights take a cafe stroll along the waterfront and get some fresh air. If you have time take the ferry across the river
Not worth it. There is nothing much there to see.In general Lisbon is not full of attractions, which makes this good for a change.
Lot for little. We walked all the way to this place and it was average at best. Save yourself the walk unless you enjoy the walk which was good.
Not to be missed while you are in Lisbon. We enjoyed the monastery and Bellem Tower and the traditional custard tart shop which was excellent value

Lovely place, lots to see. We spent the best part of a day visiting the amazing Torre, and the nearby town and monastery (Jeronimos). All really interesting and breathtaking. Visiting in early October was probably a good idea, as the crowds were down on the high season but the weather was glorious.

If I were King this would be my summer Palace. Absolutely loved Belem. The whole area is really cool and it sits right on the water. If you come to Lisbon make time to check this out because you won't be disappointed. Spend at least a half day in this entire area!

a mission to get there,enjoyed it but wouldn't rush back. I would say the Belem Castle is a "must see" attraction and for that reason I am happy to have visited. However we found the tram 15 from Praca do commercio a real pain. Not on time and very very over crowded. Also the tram stopped half way there and we had to vacate due to an accident. However as we were not in a rush we took our time, sat in a local cafe and discovered another route. The buses took us there in the end. The bus stop to actual Belem tower is a good 20 mins walk, albeit a nice scenic stroll along the waterfront with great views of the bridge and Christ statue. The castle itself is quite cute, we didn't bother to pay to go inside or up as we had already seen great views from going up the christ statue.Worth a visit if you have time, but allow for a few transport hitches and take your time to get there and back just in case.

Tower at Sunset. We checked out the tower just before dark. We didn't go inside but the view of it and the surrounding area was worth the trip. In Belem, there are a plethora of things to see anyway. The Tower is definitely worth taking a picture of and it's a good vantage point for checking out the shore and other nearby monuments.
Belem Monastery Museum. The Museu do Mosteiro dos Jeronimos is worth a visit. The architecture is outstanding and impressive.

beautiful views and beautiful cakes. You must visit belem if you visit the sites the monastry is amazing. but there is so much to see here. I'd say a visit the the original bakery for the pasteis de belem with their secret recipe is top of my list for my next visit!!

Great day trip and (mostly free!). We went to Belem on a sunday, when many attractions and museums are free (before 2 pm). We enjoyed st. Georges's castle, the Maritime museum, the contemporary art museum and the discovery Monument. We ate a brief lunch in the cafeteria, adjoining the Maritime Museum. The food was just OK. Another small disappointment was that the film, highlighting much of Lisbon, is no longer at the Discovery Monument. We were told that the contract finished and wasn't renewed. Too bad as it sounded very helpful and interesting to the visitors. However, the castle, museums and monument were great.

Cute town but small.. I should start by saying that we were on a hop on and hop off tour, so we were dropped right in front of the monastery and church. I guess we were expecting more because that area seemed very touristy and as if that was the only thing going for the town. We walked a bit further down past the monastery and the museum of cars to the restaurants and found a great pastry place. The stores and restaurants there all looked good and cute, but there was not much else after that stretch. There is a lovely little park to sit in and just enjoy life and a museum of art too. You probably will not spend more than an hour or two in this area.

Excellent day trip out from the city. Took the tram from the square next to the Museum of Beer. Takes about 20 mins to get there. Toured around and visited the Monument to the Navigators - entrance €3 and Belem Tower - €5. Lovely day in the sun and Belem Tower was good to explore. As the train line runs between the tram stop & the river front there are only a few crossing points. The frequency of trams back to the city centre is not great so keep an eye on the timetable
Amazing monastery with so many details. Fantastic place facing the fountains of Praça do Império with gorgeous two-storey cloisters. Great for photo shooting, day and night.

Good neighborhood. The Belem tower was great. It has fabulous views and canons up close. The spiral staircase stops at each floor but be aware that it gets congested by tourists going both ways and can be claustrophobic. Once you get to the floors, though, they are worth it. There were also great museums in this neighborhood.

The modern art museum, Belem. You need a good half day or one with lunch in the middle to see Belem. Don't miss the Modern Art Museum in it's lovely new, light building. Works there are very impressive including Picasso, Miro and lots of Andy Warhol. The Marine museum is really more interesting for its royal barges as the rest contains a lot of models, great if you are into that. Right across the road is a very nice Portuguese restaurant that serves good food, we very much enjoyed.

Beautiful Tower and surrounding area. The small port, the large modern tower plus the beauty of the historic Belem Tower, all of this sea-front area is beautiful. And then there is the Jeronimos Monastry which is spectacular.

Worth the visit. One of the many sights in Lisbon that you must visit, we the the area Monasterio San Jeronimo and the Maritime museum and walked to Belem, just remember that to catch the bus bback to to the center of lisbon you have to walk back to monasterio and catch the bus there, we were ao tired of walking we got on the first taxi we found and took a ride back, but did not regret the visit to Belem.

Go on Sunday you can get in some places free. There is quite a few things to see in Belem, the Castle, Tower, Monetary, Carriage coach museum and more well worth a day's visit. I did queue up for the Belem custard tarts and fund it was over rated and over priced.

Best area in Lisbon. We loved the Jeronimos Monastery. No great long line up to get in but very beautiful and large. We also walked along the water and saw the Belem Monument and the monument to the explorers. Very interesting. A hidden gem was the Coach museum. The old coaches used by royalty were stunning .
Great collection of sights and museums. Belem is packed with museums, attractions and historic sites. If you are visiting Lisbon, this is a must-visit area.

Three major attractions in Belem. Belem (a taxi ride from the center of Lisbon) is really a suburb of Lisbon and no longer a separate town. I reckon it is worth at least a half-day once you have done the other sights. Main attractions are (i) the very photogenic Belem Tower (built in 1520) at the point where the Tagus meets the Atlantic, and from which the caravels set sail down the great river and into the open sea on their epic discoveries. As you take in the scene, just cast your minds back to Portugals´s Age of Discovery; (ii) the splendid Jeronimos Monastery, built in the early 16th century to commemorate Vasco da Gama´s voyage to India, contains his tomb as well as those of a number of other notables (such as Fernando Pessoa, Portugal´s great poet); and (iii) the National Coach Museum, one of the finest of its type in the world, containing coaches from the 17th to the 19th centuries, including one which took the Spanish King Philip II from Madrid to Lisbon to view his newly-acquired bit of real estate (Portugal). For those with more time, there are a number of other museums in the immediate area.

wonderful afternoon. Belem is a wonderful place to spend an afternoon. You could easily spend all day there. When you go you MUST stop at the Belem pastry shop. It has been serving outstanding pastries for over 175 years. They created what has become the unofficial national pastry of Portugal. They sell up to 25,000 on a weekday and 50,000 on a Sunday! Apparently only three people know the secret recipe for their creme custard filling. It was delicious!

Beautiful view from the Tower. You really have a beautiful view from this Tower, excellent place to take some nice photos.The staircase taking you to the highest level is quite narrow and winding. But even if you don't like small spaces or heights, it is worthwile for the view you get.

Half Day In Belem. It can take a bit of effort to travel out to Belem, but it is well worth the energy. You may want to purchase an all day metro/bus pass for 5 euro. The Monastery of Jeronimos constructed in the Manueline style is amazing, The tower, Torre de Belem, on the edge of the river is also in the Manueline style. It is not far from the monestry. Take public transportation to cut down on walking.When getting on crowded public transportation be vigilant for pick pocketers. Keep backpacks on the front of you. We personally saw three men case out and chose a person to steal from. They bump into you and remove your valuables.The day we went, Saturday, Sept 29th there was no entrance fee,
Like a Tardis. The tower looks quite small from the outside but seems to have a lot to see when you get inside. Loved the views of Lisbon from the tower and also the view over the river.
Worth a visit. Well worth seeing this part of Lisbon, especially the Cathedral....you can walk to Belem, easy to get to.

Beautiful Belem by night. You have a lot to see in and around Lisbon and Belem is definitely one place to go. We visited Sintra and Belem on the same day so it was pretty hectic. However, we got to visit Belem by night and it was amazing. Took a bus from Lisbon and not a tram as many had recommended. The bus journey was pretty quick and it was actually interesting as well. Got down near the Jeronimos Monastery. Looked extremely beautiful. Sadly it was closed when we reached Belem.. would have loved to visit this. We then walked down to the Discoveries monument - spectacular! You need to take a underground pathway to get to the other side of the road. You will find this on the main road close to Vasco Da Gama’s statue.The whole area around the Discoveries monument looked extremely beautiful at night. Felt peaceful and nice to sit near the monument and listen to the waves lapping against the shore. You get a nice view of the Monument of Christ and also the 25 de Abril Bridge (the one that looks like Golden Gate Bridge).We had an excellent dinner at a restaurant close to the monument – Nosolo Italia. It’s a pizzeria + gelato place by the docks. After a great dinner we walked back to the Jeronimos Monastery and took the bus back to Lisbon. Could not see much but found the trip both short and sweet. Had a great trip to Belem!

goregeous pasteis de nata. the best most amazing trip - monastary, museum of modern art and custard tarts - a great day out! the view from the top of the monument on the river - the park with its chinese section and the manicured beds - gorgeous even in 40 degree heat
Pretty place!. We didnt go into any of the attractions just admired them Tom the outside. Ver lovely area and glad we went, took about 20/30 mins from entre of Lisbon on tram.

Tower in the morning. We did something most visitors will not - got to the Torre de Belem rather early in the morning - and there was no one around. Not a soul except for some intrepid anglers at the pier and a couple of joggers. It was beautiful - to be there all alone. And the early morning view of the 25th April Bridge was wonderful. So when we were done we just used the underpass and beat the crowds at Pasteis de Belem and Mosterios dos Geronimos too!

Highly recommend a visit to Belem if you are in Lisbon. A quick affordable train journey down the coast to Belem. I visited the monastery and the famous pasteria there. There are a number of other museums in the area also. It was the highlight of my trip to Lisbon
Pastel de Nata. Amazing town - amazing pastries and coffee. Lineups at pastryshop a photo shoot. Town is very quaint with winding streetsand lots of tourists. Cathedral also.

Great walking to see the sites. Walking from Mosteiros dos Jeronimos to the Torre de Belem is amazing ... and very easy! It's one part of the city that is flat so if you're tired of the hills, head over here for the day. Don't miss the pastries at Pasteis de Belem Backery!!

Belem is a short bus ride from Lisbon. If you have an afternoon to spare Belem is worth the trip. It is a short bus ride from Lisbon. We had a hop on hop off bus pass. There is a coach museum, a monastery, the tower and a few other things to see in the area. I enjoyed the monastery the most. There is a 5 euro fee to get in but you can get a combo pass for the tower also to save some money if you are going to do both.

Nice view. If you are visiting Belem, you have to go to the tower too. We visited the tower in September and it wasn't that busy. However, there is only one stairs where you can go up and down. I can only imagine how crowded that can be in high season. We had to wait to go up several times because there were a lot of other people going down. What I really missed was some information about the history and architecture of the tower. However, it is really worth a visit because of the nice view on top!

An essential part of town. Belem has a lot to offer - the Jeronimos Monastery, the Coaches Museum, the Tower, the Botanical Garden, the Discoverers Monument, pasteis de Belem, local festivals. Worth spending a whole day.
Nothing special. It's a nice area just outside the center of Lisbon. But if you only have 2 or 3 days in Lisbon you shouldn't visit Belem. It's not worth the time.
Beautiful. Take the double decker bus there and get off walk around and hop on again. Best deal ever. You can see the bridge, churches, museums
GREAT HISTORIC SITE.. Visited the Maritime Museum.This is a 'MUST SEE' for visitors to Lisboa.Also entered the great church of Santa Maria.This is very impressive.

Must see area. There's a lot to see in this place, from st. Jeronimo, to the national coach museum, to the marine museum, very interesting, don't miss the monument of the discoveries and the park nearby

A lot to see & taste.. There are a lot of things to see in the city and on the coast. Some churches, parks monuments and an old tower with a lighthouse nearby. The pastelaria's are also a good object to stop for a while and taste the local specialities.

Belém. We loved visiting Belém. It is a nice part of Lisbon to walk around and the attractions are definitely worth a visit. We walked from the train station towards the Jeronimos Monastry, which was really nice walk past two parks and the little village. The Belém tower and the monument of Discovery were also really nice to see.

A must-see. Belem is definitely a very pleasant part of Lisbon. The tower is picturesque and provides great views; the monastery is astonishing, and the maritime museum is quite good, even though not the best I've seen.Also, in contrast with most other parts of Lisbon, the area is clean, which makes it really pleasant to walk.A must-see on a good sunny day!

Just brilliant !. We loved everything about Belem.It's absolutely packed with breathtaking and unique architecture : the Belem Tower ("Torre di Belem"), the Jeronimos Monastery ..., the Discoveries Monument ("Padrao dos Descobrimentos"), ... and also gives great views of others, in particular the 25th April Bridge ("Ponte 25 de Abril").We ended up wandering along the river from mid-afternoon until well into the evening when the sun began to go down. It was truly a lovely place to be and if we weren't in love with Lisbon already, we were then !
A nice place to visit. This is a beautifully restored Fort with other attractions close by. We had planned 3 hours to spend there, but really only needed 1 hr. A must see in Lisbon.
nice attraction. This was a nice attraction, not much else very close. On the grounds you can find some nice and inexpensive souvenirs.

Nice afternoon trip out of the city. After a week of exploring the Lisbon city center and lounging on the beach, we spent an afternoon exploring Belem. The monastery was very pretty, and seeing Vasco de Gama's tomb was an interesting (and surprising) find. The park which separated the monastery from the waterfront was very quaint, as was the stroll from the Monument of the Discoveries to the Belem Tower. The Tower was already closed for the day, as was the Museum for Pop Art, but that was our fault for arriving late in the day on a weekend. Only reason for not rating excellent was the difficulty we had at finding food other than traditional Portuguese, which the vegetarian and non-seafood eater didn't really enjoy too much. :)

Extraordinary. This place tells an extraordinary historical story. Walking along the river you meet places of intrest - tower, monument, castle, monastry, all very close. In between lots of opportunities for refreshments, relaxation in the park, beautiful views.

PLEASANT PLACE. Visited using the open top bus. Monestery very impressive, had a custard tart, very hot day so made use of shade in very pleasant parks scattered throughout the tourist area. Had lunch al fresco, good value for money (so not a rip off area), can't remeber the name though.

Landmark of Lisbon. This little remaining fortress is the landmark of Lisbon. Situated by the seaside, best way to get there is to take the No. 15 Tram. You can get off at the Monastery stop, take a visit (free), then walk about 10 min along the side of the highway to reach Belem. You visit inside Belem, it is about E$5.

Beautiful Belem!. We visited the Torre de Belem which was fantastic. Also the Discoveries Monument and went up inside to the view from the top. The Jeronimos Monastry was also very beautiful. And we also visited Pasteis de Belem - gorgeous custard tarts.

Well worth a visit. Torre de Belem is lovely but has lots of twisty steps so be prepared but wouldn't have missed it. A very pretty building with beautiful Moorish architecture. From there is a pleasant walk along the River Tagus to Ponte 25 de Abril inspired by San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge.

Must visit location. If you are in Lisbon you have to visit Belem, for Belem tower, the famous custard tart cafe and the good quality restaurants. Although I am not sure that the tarts at the famous cafe were much better than any of the others that I had ( only difference seemed to be they were fresh and warm out of the oven) the cafe has grown huge to deal with the queues and is noisey with very little traditional atmosphere, so I would advise you to buy them as takeaway from the front, even so it's one of those must do events.

Absolutely worth the visit!. A full and wonderful day in Belem, so much to see that is worthwhile and when you're there catch a meal at O Prado which is a local restaurant, a full, fresh fish meal with large salad and wine for 10,50 euros! One of the best meals yet! Full of locals.

Scenic and beautiful visit. Took the train from Rossio (10 minute ride) to Belem. Really lovely seafront place. Took a walk along the coastline and the docks to the historic Padrao dos Descobrimentos monument and the Torre de Belem (small and very cute castle). The castle is well worth having a look at and going up inside for great views of Belem and surrounding areas. Lovely area to walk or just sit and relax in. Don't forget to go to the Jeronimos Monastery, just over the road and a 5 minute walk or so. Beautiful inside, well worth a look. Don't bother with the nearby Botanical gardens. Not much going on there and not worth the half hour climb up very steep roads.

Fantastic Area To Explore. What a lovely area to explore for the day. We spent half our day here and were very impressed with what it had to offer, from the Castle which was so nice to the Monastrey such a lovely place.I would not suggest staying here as your base as it is a 19 minute train ride into central Lisbon, however if you have a hire care then this would not be an issue.One word of warning is avoid the Botanic Gardens, they are only 2 euros per person but are really no good - more of a waste on an hour not to mention a hill climb!

A lovely place to spend a Sunday afternoon. We intended to devote the whole of a Sunday afternoon to Belem visting as many monuments as we could fit in.We decided to walk to Belem from our hotel in the Armoreiras area of Lisbon (Dom Pedro Palace) and it was actually a lot further than we anticipated, however the walk alongside the Tagus from Docas area was quiet with very few pedestrians and a few joggers along the riverside path.By the time we'd reached the Padrao dos Descobrimentos at the far eastern end of Belem we'd revised our plans and decided to take it easy instead as it was too hot. There was a little market in the stunning gardens across from the Monastery where we found one of the few public conveniences in Lisbon. After a visit to the famous Pasties de Belem for a taste of their famous custard tarts we strolled further to the Belem Tower.The walk back to the centre of Lisbon was tough. We'd tried to take a train from Belem station but there was nowhere to purchase a ticket.Belem was a grand suburb of Lisbon that probably deserved far longer than we allowed, but didn't really have the atmosphere of Alfama or the Biarro Alto.
An interesting historic site. This is a major historic site in Lisbon that was important to see the point at which the early exploreres sailed from.

Worthwhile excursion. Makes a great day out, catch the tram and start at the monastery. Extraordinary architectural style of OTT gothic with lots of info in English. The tower is a fair walk (on a hot day) but a must to visit, and one can wander back on the river edge. The custard tarts in the cafe are essential, much the best in lisbon, and if there is a queue, go in a side door and find a table and eat in. The waiter was surprised we only ordered two, and he was right, we had to order more!

Many Monuments. The Belem area has many monuments, such as the Tower of Belem, the Discoveries Monument and the Jeronimos Monastery. Besides that there is also the Orient Museum. So you can spend the whole day in the area and not have enough time to see everything.
nothing great. we though this would be much more grand than just a small tower. nothing much to do and see at this place. a big let down it was

Great day out & not far from city centre. Must visit the Monastery of Jerónimos, amazing architecture, calm cloisters & very interesting historical display boards. Buy a famous warm custard tart or two; photograph the Discovery Monument (climb to the top for superb views); stroll along the promenade to the Tower & there's even a beach.

Great view but too crowded. Belem tower dates back to the middle ages and was an important river fortress. Great history but do some research about the site before you go as all the signs and interpretive materials are in Portuguese. In fact, that's pretty common throughout Portugal. Go early in the day when it is cool and less crowded. Also, the ancient stairwells are worn slick from hundreds of years of use so if you are elderly or physically challenged this one may well be too difficult. Also, NOT for small children in parent's arms. You can see the tower from outside fairly well if you decide not to pay the fee but it is a bit of a hike to get there. We combined this visit with lunch at one of the riverside restaurants (pricey and mediocre) and a walk through the gardens and St. Geronimo Monastery and then the carriage museum.
Beautiful Day Out. I loved this lil place with its spectacular Monastery, Tower and Monument to the Age of Discovery. You don't need a full day here but make sure you eat the pastries!

A must do day!. This is a must do while in Lisbon. The ride on the electric tram (15E) was pleasant....We skipped the Coach tour but started at the monastery. I definitely recommend paying for the cloisters. We spent well over an hour wandering there and reading all the material. The monument afforded great views (we skipped the movie). I would definitely go up to the top. The walk to the tower is pleasant. You must walk inland a few blocks to catch the tram back to Lisbon.I found it interesting to be where the discoverers/conquerors began their voyage.
Belem Tower. The views are stunning and the tower of Belem is awesome. Next to the Monuement of the Discoveriers and also Jeronimoes Monestary

Best part of Lisbon. This is an interesting and scenic part of Lisbon. Well worth the journey on the E15 tram from the centre. The museum in the monastery was fascinating and the river front beautiful to walk along with the tower and statue of exploration.

Beautiful tower, but not worth a visit inside. The tower is far from the center, it's a nice building sitting on the river shore, but nothing special inside... Save money and do not buy the ticket to visit the tower.

So much to see in one place.. We spend the day here checking out the Coach and Marine Museum, the monastery and the Monument of Discoveries. A coffee break at the Pasteis de Belem was the icing on a perfect day. Highly recommended for kids and adults.
Great!. One of the most beautiful and important monuments in Lisbon. It´s located along the river near great parks where you can later have a picknik on a sunny day.
A memorable experience. The monastery is architecturally fascinating. The Tower provides an unusual experience with exellent views from the top.
Stunning monastery+pastries. Good place to go for an hour or so-the monastery is beautiful and the pastry shop is amazing. There is not a huge deal more to see here

Hyped a lot, it was just ok. I realize that many travel books herald Belem area. I was not overly impressed with the sites. I will admit that during my visit I kept thinking that the "Age of Discovery" monument is misnamed. I think the sword on the surface of the monument speaks for itself. Might I suggest "Age of Conquest".

A Lisbon Must see!!. The Torre de Belem, the Mosteiro doe Jeronimos and the Padrao do Descobrimentos are all must sees. Free parking available (by Mosteiro) and close to some formal gardens with fountains.Great views of the Bridge de 25 April and the Christ Rei and Tagus. Even our two boys (aged 6&9) loved it around this area!!

Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, its worth a visit!. This place is far from the city centre: there are the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, a Torre de Belém, the Padrao do Descobrimentos and the best "pasteis de Belem" at the patisserie Pasteis de Belem (a typical pastry of Portugal) where you can eat them fresh and warm!

Interesting place. I visited torre de Belem in Portugal with my husband. It's a tower that defended portugal from the seaside. The place is very relaxing as it's directly on the beach and the views are quite nice from the top of the tower. I haven't gone all the way through to the top but just to the middle. Going up is through very tight stairs so it depends on your judgement. My husband went up though and was able to take some nice pics for me from the top while I waited him by the sea and looked upwards. Don't forget to pass by the coffee shop at the far end and taste the pastel nata or Portugal's famous cream tart fresh from the oven. Also a short walk away are many interesting sights including jeromimos monastery and marine museums. The monastery is definitely worth seeing.
Do not Miss. When in this area be sure to see all the sites, it is a wonderful area, If you go on Sunday most of the sites are free until 2 pm

well worth a visit. Probably the most famous symbol of Lisbon (of course along with the famous Tram.28 and Elevador Santa Cruz), this monument looks gorgeous and not to be missed. There is nothing much special inside other than carrying examples of Manueline architectural elements, hence your visit will not probably take more than an hour even maybe shorter. Although the stairs are quite narrow and care must be taken, my advice is to climb and enjoy the view above, the picturesque view of Ponte 25 de Abril (25th of April Bridge) is fascinating. One further "budget" advice is if you have a sunday in Lisbon, from 10:00 am till 14:00 all the monuments are free, so you can easily couple your Torre de Belém visit with Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, Padrão dos Descobrimentos (Monument to the Discoveries) and Museu dos Coches (Coaches Museum). These four must-see attractions are really close and can be reached by Tram no.15 from Praça do Comércio, one more practical budget advice is to buy a day ticket just for 5€ (5,5€ if you do not have a card) from one of the metro stations which is valid for 24h after the first usage, the trams are even more expensive if you pay inside (2.85€ just for one way).

Nice historical area.. A lot of historical sites are located in this area. From Mosterio dos Jeronimos, Torre de Belem (Belem Tower), Padrao dos Descobrimentos, and the famous Pasteis de Belem. You can't go to Belem without making a stop at Pasteis de Belem the famous pastry is to die for.
One of the great european museums for modern art. The marvellous arcitecture - its enormous! - and a lot of interesting exhibitions. Allmost too much - but one have to make choices.

Beautiful, and don't forget the desert. This town is very beautiful, we saw it by ferry....which only shows you the coastal line and then we also took a cab to see all the beautiful attractions. the Tower of Belem is a must see and also the monastery. We went to see the tower on a foggy day and even then it was still beautiful even though we couldn't see too far out, about a 14 minute walk away is the monestery and if you are in town you must have the Pasteis de Belem......they are to die for!!!

Lovely location. Well worth catching the tram to visit - you can buy a travel card costing 5.5 euros. We enjoyed wandering around Belem and walking by the river and having lunch in one of the river side cafes
Nice place for half a day visit. The church n museum are good. Don't forget to eat at the famous pastry shop of Belem. Also the castle at waterfront is worth a trip

A wonderful place to walk by. I was born on the neighborhood so I know it for all m life. It is a really nice neighborhood, by the Tagus river, that has been subject to many improvements all over tha lest few years. I is good for walking by the river, watch the Tagus and its south bank, cycling, eating - a lot of good restaurants on it - and even visit museums and monuments - Jeronimos Monastery, Centro Cultural de Belem with its galleries, Belem Tower, Botanic Garden, Carriages Museum (Museu dos Coches), and may, many other interesting places, among them the President's Official House.
So much to see. Belem is a great way to spend a day, there is so much to see and great open spaces to enjoy the fabulous sights. Don't miss this part of Lisbon.

Great views. Go to belem area in the afternoon, u can visit the tower and then the gardens around and the palaces, don't forget to try the nice nape or cream tart dusted with cinamon during ur visit, u will find nice pastry shops there

Yummy custart tarts and great historical sites. Pasteis de Belem, is a great place for a coffee break and enjoy those wonderful, light, creamy custard tarts encasing in a fine crispy pastry.Once you're energised, walk across the road to the world heritage Jeronimos monastery, then walk further on to Belem Tower and on your way back stop off at the Belem Cultural Center where some of fabulous modern art works are hung in the museum. For a little outskirt area of Lisbon, Belem offers many interesting attractions. We could have easily spent a whole day exploring the place.

Belem. We visited the Belem area of Lisbon on the Lisbon Yellow Bus. This is one of the routes that the Yellow Bus takes in Lisbon and was very interesting with a commentary describing the various attractions - this area has some incredibly beautiful buildings and landmarks.Belem is very famous for Belem cakes and we saw the lines outside the shop that is supposed to be the best in Lisbon - we didn't have the time or inclination to stand in what would have been about an hour in the hot sun to have a little cake so just tasted a few from other shops in the area - they were goodThere are some beautiful monuments in this area and as it runs right along the sea you have a lovely little breeze blowing at times. There is an amazing bridge which looks like you are at the Golden Gate in SanFrancisco. There are a couple of horse drawn carriages available if you wish to have a ride - very popular with children.There are a couple of places to have lunch (or dinner) right on the water and as menus are posted outside you can choose one which suits your budget.

GREAT!!!. Going to Lisbon and not going to Belem, is as you go to NYC nd don`see the Liberty State!! DONT MISS EVER!! You can go by subway until Cais do Sodre station and get the train to Belem, it`s just an station, dont worry. On Belem visit: Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, Torre de Belem, Monumnto dos descobrimentos and the Pastelaria Pasteis de Belem. They are a walk from each other!! Dont forget to have a the best Pastel de Nata of the world on Pasteis de Belem!

Nice day trip. After spending 2 days in downtown Lisbon it was time to see what else there was. Belem is about a 30 minute bus ride (no. 727) towards the west coast. The highlights are the Jeronimos monastery and if you go on sundays it is free. While you are in Belem you must try the famous Pateis de Belem. Just follow the crowds towards this bakery that has kept the recipe a top secret for over a 100 years and makes more than 15,000 of these sweet pastries a day.

Belem is a must!. We toured Belem for an entire day, and it's worth it.The botanical garden at the top of the hill is a great walk and picnic spot. The coach museum is fantastic and the rest of the sites are just as the tour books make them sound - a great day. We walked back and checked out the museum on the way back to Lisbon as well. Make a mission of finding the custard tarts and don't forget the icing sugar and cinnamon!

Monastery. You must, must, must visit the monastery. Don't recommend the yellow bus for getting there, but plan a half day visiting the monastery. Spectacular. It will be a highlight of your trip to Lisbon.

Prison tower. Belem tower is a jewel... But it is to crowded. The inside stairs are usually full of... tourist going up and down. So take care better early morning or later in the afternoon. Great view from up there.
Make sure you get to Belem. We toured Belem and would loved to have spent more time there. Next time i will make a mission of finding the custard tarts!

belem castle is small. quite an interesting fort. the stairs are very narrow and you can get trapped for several minutes but if you can manage them there are 5 floors to explore and enjoy the views of the Tagus

History in a sunny-by-the-river place. If you get there, you'll be impressed by the historical places you can see: Torre de Belem, Jeronimos Monastery, Pasteis de Belem, Monument of the Discoveries. There is a cool-looking park in front of the monastery. The only difficulty would be getting there and moving from one place to the other, as they are at some distance, the only public transport I found was tram 15, and did not see any taxis.

Go back in time!. 3 things: Monastery, Tower and Monument of Discoveries. 1 word: amazing!! Totally worth the 15 minutes it takes to get to Belem. Plus, you can relax with a drink along the river and take in the views of the bridge and Rei Crist as the sites will not take all day.

beautiful surrounding. the Belem Tower stands alone facing the river. It is a beautiful place to visit, don't miss the CCB- Cultural Center of Belém, the Jerónimos monastery, take a walk in the beautiful gardens, enjoy the riverside and the sun, and since you are here take the time to taste the famous pastel de nata, ask anyone where you can buy it and enjoy.
lots to do and see. the president lives here so you know this is a town to visit!MOdern Art collection , parks, famous bakery, monestery

Needs more explanation..... We visited here after going to the nearby Jeronimos Monastery having purchased a combined ticket. We felt that the place was lacking in information which did detract from our visit. The nearby Jeronimos monastery actually had more information on the Belem tower and any information gleaned really came from there. The queues to visit the upper levels were long although this is probably normal in August. Good views of the river and a ' nice' location but overall rather disappointing if you are looking for an explanation on its history, probably best to read up on it before hand. Kids will probably enjoy climbing the stair cases and exploring .

Pasteis de Belém are the best. Great part of Lisboa, with a wonderful cultural center and museum of modern art that provides a free who's who tour in modern art in 90 minutes. Eat the original pasteis de Belém across the street from the Belém monument (don't stand in the long queue but go right in and walk towards the back, there are several rooms where you can sit down and enjoy coffee, drinks, have lunch and of course the pasteis.

Amazing dessert. It was fun to see where the famous dessert from Portugal was made. The town is very simple....just a few streets. It takes about 15 minutes by cab from Lisbon. There is the beautiful Jeronimos Monastery across the street. We only stayed about 15 minutes but were glad we went to this famous bakery.

Cultural centre. Unfortunately we went on a Monday when all the museums were closed except for the fantastic contemporary art museum.Found it really peaceful and less crowded than other big city museums. And the collections are great.

Cakes and a monastery. The Jeronimos monastery looks like a rectangular wedding cake and is built in the really eye catching 16th century Manueline style. It's one of the few buildings to survive the 1755 Lisbon earthquake. You get an idea what the rest of the city once looked like. Nearby is the fascist-era monument to the discoverers, amusing kitsch. And then there are cafes where you can buy the legendary Belem cakes. Other than that - not much else to view. Two hours is enough. Train from Cais do Sodre station.

Must see if you like the the age of Descoveries. The Belem area is a must see in Lisbon, it contains the Belem Tower, the "pedrao", the jeronimos monestery, the military museum with the monument for the Portuguese soldiers and a very modern centre just west of the Tower.The tower itself is good to visit in the morning, as the people are flocking towards the monastery. It has a small dungeon below, a ground floor with lots of cannons, and 5 floors with a lot of facts about its history and the view from the top is beautiful :)

Quick visit and head to Sintra!. Some very nice sites, like the tower, monastery, bakery, etc. but hop in a taxi or rent a car for the day and head to Sintra to see Pena Palace and hit the beaches if you have the time.
