ok. There are a lot of people who visit this attraction, so be warned. It would be better to drop by in the morning as the queues would be not as long. Not much to see inside, but good architecture overall.
Really the best pasteis. We try sooo many pasteis and yes they have the best pasteis de nata in lisbon...The place is always busy but worth it.

Cute little neighborhood. Cute, little neighborhood at the foot of the Bridge, which is awe inspiring rising high over a small, old world city. If you only have two days or less in Lisbon, you can miss it, but if you get the Hop on Hop Off bus, the route goes through it.The Bridge was inspired by the Golden Gate Bridge of San Francisco, California.
Nice to walk around. Its nice just to go to see it. Long tourist waiting lines but if you avoid them you can have a very nice time.
Delicious. You'll find the best and traditional pasteis de Belem right there. Eat them as long as they are warm.

Perfect even if you have just 2 hours to spare. On my last day in Lisbon, I made a super quick trip to Belem - 1.5 hours to be exact excluding traveling time to and from Placa Figueira. Given the limited time I had, I zoomed in on the Jeronimo Monastery and church, as well as grab a few pastries from the famous Pasteis de Belem. The church is free but definitely worth visiting if just to pay homage to Vasco da Gama whose tomb is inside. The entrance to the monastery is €7 if memory serves me well, and well worth the visit. As mentioned in another review, it is Manuelin architecture at its best. Somehow it projects beautiful calmness and light even though I visited on a crowded, hot summer day. As for Pasteis de Belem, do try the famous tarts. I had 3 all by myself! The line seems to be really long around 4pm but eases around 6pm. The staff is efficient, you can also dine in. Do try the savory pastries too. I had what looked like a fried Chinese bun (bao or pau) with chicken stuffing and it was really delicious. Apart from the number 15 tram, there are also other buses plying between Belem and Lisbon city. Apologies I can't remember as I have been traveling for 6 weeks in different cities, but do check as these could be faster than 15.

Appreciate the architecture. This classic architectural wonder is as beautiful in person as it is in the tour books. Well worth a visit. Of course, bring your camera. Enjoy the surrounding area, and go on a weekday if possible to lessen the crowds you encounter.

Do it!!. Definately hop on the train and head out here - truely gorgeous area. Well worth the visit. The tower offers amazing views and be sure to stop into the famous bakery for the custard tarts and more.....

Definitely worth a visit. We spent part of a morning and a long afternoon here. We visited the National Coach Museum, the Monastery and Cloisters, and the Monument to the Discoveries. We thoroughly enjoyed them all. Lunch at the Restaurant Rosa dos Mares was excellent. Don't miss the Casa Pasteis de Belem for the wonderful custard tarts.
Belem. great to walk around Belem, lots to see. definitely recommend the Pasteis de Belem (although beware of the grumpy, rude staff there)

Beautiful Belem. I love the architecture of the monastery in Belem - Manualine at it's best.There are some excellent restaurants and for those who like them - pastiche de Belem are a must - look beyond the queue - inside it goes back for what seems like miles. A lovely place to spend a day mooching around and just experiencing all the history here
Touristic but pleasant. The place is perfect to hang around in parks and coffees, or souvenir shops. It's a nice suburb of Lisbon.

Great experience. The Belem district is a must-see for all travellers to Lisbon. The Belem Tower is worth visiting, the monument is nothing special, but still it is a famous landmark. There is also the Maritime Museum and the Hieronymites Monastery near the shore and I recommend seeing both of them. The museum houses a great collection od ship models and various artefacts, while the monastery is a masterpiece od architecture in the Manueline style.

An unforgettable day touring at Lisbon - Belem. There are a lot of attractions in Belem area. From Art & Design Museum CCB; Jeronimos Monastery; Navy Museum, Belem Tower and gardens; National Coach Museum; Electricity Museum, Botanic Garden and so on. All of them with different kind of offers from history to contemporary art and gardens just to relax or have a picnic.Have a lunch in Almargem, a nice river front esplanade with great salads. At evening go to Pasteis de Belem Factory to try the best cream cake "pastel de nata" in town.On weekends Belem is usually overcrowded. Better go on working days and early in the morning.

great place for a day trip... we went here on a sunday and it was a great place to stroll around, have lunch on the promenade and then have some tasty Portuguese tarts from eponymous belem patisseries..

cream cakes. In Belem you should try the famous cream cake called "pastel de belem".... is really good.There are other atractions like jeronimos monastery, and other to monuments regarding the discoveries...

Well worth visiting but not on a Sunday!. The 16th c. Tower of Belem looking out over the Tagus was the highlight of our visit. The Jeronimos monastery is certainly worth visiting but avoid the free Sundays in summer when the church is overwhelmed by hordes of tourists. It is worth getting away from the tourist route and walking up the streets of Belem to the Palacio Nacional to get a flavour of the neighbourhood. However, be warned - if you visit the Palacio anytime within the last hour before closing the staff will pursue you through the rooms jangling their keys to lock up! The Marine Museum is a more interesting place to visit.

The best part of Lisbon. Place with history which praises Portuguese explorers. Wonderful part of Lisbon city.Must see Jeronimus monastery, Belem tower and Monument of discoveries. Great place also to take pictures of bridge and Cristo rei. Walk along the river and enjoy monuments.

Go early. The sailors monument and the tower of Belem are wonderful sites to see and take pictures at. Be sure to read up on the history of them before going. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds.

Quick 1/2 day visit. Getting to Belem is very easy, it's a short cab ride (8 euros from the Gulbenkian Museum) or a cheap trolley ride away from Praca de Comercio. We visited the Monastery of Jeronimos and the Monument to the Discoveries--and grabbed lunch. You can knock this one out in a few hours!

We loved Belem!. We stayed in the 'newer' part of Lisbon (near the oceanarium etc.) which was great but if I ever return to Lisbon I would stay in Belem! Aside from the perfect custard tars at Pasteis de Belem there are so many monuments to see that are all in walking distance. We went to the monastery/monument to the discoveries & Belem Tower and ate lunch in Belem in a little backstreet place (forgot the name, sorry!) it's a lovely area and definitely worth a days visit while in Lisbon...enjoy!
go early. trams get very crowded and hot, so need to go early just to catch one, Busy area as the coach trips unload, so try to get your timings right
Beautiful. Loved Belem and all its sights it was easy to get to on the local transport ystem, first the metro and then onto a bus. lovely meal by the water front all in all a fantastic day out.
Obligatory. Together with Terreiro do Paço, the most important spot by the river. The Jerónimos Chruch is a very important monument, and the unusual tower (depicted) as well.

Belem. Belem is one of my favourite places in Lisbon. It is worth a day visit at least, with it's Jeronimos monastery, monument of discoveries and tower of Belem. But my favourite place in Belem is a confectionery where famous Pasteis de Belem is made since 1837.
Great area. Loved it down by the water and the Cathedral/Monastery was interesting. Recommend a tour inside the church as the history is interesting. Definitely worth a visit.

Historical "must see". Had a half day free before we left Portugal and spent it in Belem. Interesting and beautiful historical piece but with some climbing if you would like to see the view. We had a beer at the ferry office before we returned to town.It took some time to get a taxi back but this was mid-day on a Thursday.

Worth a visit. Both the castle and Monastery in this area are lovey. The queues were quite long but worth the wait. I would suggest buying the joint ticket at the first one you visit as this grants you fast track entry to the second

Belem - Enjoyable half day trip!. We enjoyed our half day trip at Belem visiting Torre de Belem, Monument to the Discoveries, Jerónimos Monastery etc. We also had an enjoyable afternoon tea at Pasteis De Belem, savouring their crispy and authentic egg tart and tea before we leave Belem.

A Must on your Visit to Lisbon. We walked from the down town to Belem - not a walk for the faint of heart, but well worth it. We took the tram back. You cannot say you have visited Lisbon if you do not visit Belem.
A perfect Sunday destination. The tower, the market, the museums--A nice mixture of tourists and locals. Lots of families the museums are free on Sundays, too!

hop on bus trip. Really enjoyed this trip out to Belem on the open topped bus.
St. Geronimo church was stunning. Lovely custard tart shop.....very famous!
Beautiful was to spend an afternoon while in Lisbon

Too much to take in in one day. Spend a day in the coach museum, stop for pasteis de Belem and you are done for the day. Go back the next and visit this tower and check out the "Portuguese map of discoveries", the marine museum and really too many things to list.

Good place to visit. This is a good place to visit for people interested in
- history
- view
- "hike" on the narrow ladders up to the top
Great custard tarts!. All the sights in Belem are interesting. Easy to get there on the tram from central Lisbon. Custard tarts were delicious!

Great breeze helps walking around interesting place. Church worth a good half hour (and it's free) and then go under the road and train track to the impressive monument on the riverside. We skipped the massive queue for the pastels de nata as you can buy them as good anywhere.

Wonderful surprise. We had planned to spend a few hours in Belem which we thought was a suburb of Lisbon, how wrong we were, spend all day or perhaps 2 days, so much to see and do and lovely parks to visit.

WORTH THR EFFORT TO GET TO. There are lots of buses to get to Belem. The Monastry is fantastic, and the waterfront has several sites to visit. It is one of the places that you feel privileged to have been there. Our friends had twice before visited Lisbon, but never before been to Belem, really loved it too. Catch the bus and enjoy yourselves

Best of Lisbon. We just had little time on an evening to visit Belém, but even in the evening hours with the monuments lighted up it was simply just worth it. I don't really like Lisbon, but walking through Belém is making the trip to this city worth it!
okay. to expensive. its okay to see this tower from the outside.the inside looks just like every other castle. a lot of touristic restaurants and stuff around it, way to expensive to eat there.

Great. I have just went here to check out the buildings, so I didnt go inside of them since most was closed, but I absolutely loved it. The tower of Belem is beautiful, as well the monastry and ofcourse I didnt miss the fountain and the parque and some other monuments.I only found it really disturbing these ladies close to the Belem tower offering their 'towels'. Even after I said, não obrigada, they just kept pushing me to buy their stuff. I tried to ignore them afterwards, but there were so many :(And the tram to there was really crowded and packed. So I hope they let more trams going there. I definitly go back there =D

Belem. If you are in Lisbon make sure you visit the Belem Tower. It is fascinating over the sea. Get bus no 28 and you are there. Also near the tower there is The monument to the Discoveries, which is very beautiful. They are within walking distance to each other. Take your camera with you and best to go first thing in the morning so you can take the best pictures . We went there around 9.30am and it was a good time before coaches with tourists arrived.

A Great 1-Day Side Trip -- How to go at a Fraction of the Price. But do NOT take the arranged tours (i.e. hop on & off bus, etc) because you'll pay 3x or more what you need to pay. It's extremely easy to get there from Lisbon. Walk down to the water, take Bus # 28. It's about a 30 min (maximum) ride and if you buy the metro pass (transportation pass for however many days you are there) it will cost nothing extra to go to Belem. You know when you are there because 80% of the bus stands up to get off -- but just in case -- you would get off at the Monestary in Belem.

Worth the trip. This was the highlight of our trip-- the Monastery is not to be missed and dont skimp on paying to see the Cloisters they were amazing.The queues for the Tower were a bit long but the outside is beautiful. Dont go on a bus tour simply take local transport such as the 727 bus..
Beautiful.. Don't miss the Belem Tower and the Monument Padrao Dos Descobrimentos. The Monastery of Jeronimos is marvellous, especially the facade.

Not far from Lisbon city center, worth the trip. Loved Belem. There is an large, lovely public garden with fountains. The Monastery was really impressive as were the Monument to the Discoveries and the Belem Tower. We visited the church - not the cloisters, and merely viewed the Monument and the Tower from the outside - this makes the trip free - but worth it. We brought a picnic lunch and ate it at the park area near the Tower, sitting on a ledge. We did stop for a beer at one of the riverside cafes, which was a nice way to finish the visit.We took the 15E tram (using our Viva Viagem card) - and due to the volume of people riding the tram and the heat of the day (95 degrees) we got a free sauna. Very uncomfortable ride, but mercifully only about 20 minutes long. Highly recommended as an inexpensive, enjoyable trip outside of Lisbon's city center.

Nice view. This is one of Lisbon's symbols.It's not gonna take you much of your time.We went upstairs but took the elevator.The view from the top is amazing!!You have the river Tagus on one side and the Monasteria Dos Jeronimos on the other.Check it out :)
Amazing belem. I visited belem during a rainy day but the small village it is beautiful under the rain too! Go to see padrao do descubrimiento, and buy one hot god !

It is a very old monument concerning the discovery of the way to go to India by boat.. It was open in 1514, or near, and is there to remind people that a difficult task was succesfully performed...
If you need more informations about this or anyother portuguese monument please contact me by Email. I`ll be glad to help...

Legacy of the 15th & 16th century. Belem is surrounded by many landmarks, built around the 15th and 16th century, when Portugals colonial powers were at teh maximum. The torre de Belem (Belem Tower) and mosteiro dos Jerónimos (Jerónimos Monastery) are such two iconic buildings. More recently, the 1940 built Padrão dos Descobrimentos pays homage to the discoverers and navigators that set sail to the unknown seas, to bring back spices, gold, lands and, unfortunately, slavery.Based on these iconic buildings, Belem flourishes. A constant in and out of tourists arriving in buses means that you'll never be alone. The more recently built Centro Cultural de Belem, CCB (Belem's Cultural Center) showcases many exhibits and performances, and the Museu da Marinha (Navy Museum), built in conjuction with the Astronomy Museum, allows a sneak peak into the caravels and sailing ships that allowed the Portuguese to become the pioneers of globalization.Close to the monastery, there are a couple of delicious pastry shops, one of which specializes in the Pastel de Belem, characterized by a sort of custard cream, served with cinnamon.

Mosterio dos Jeronimos & Torre de Belem. Due to very hot waether and being struck on the travel's first day; I like the historical part. Only minus was we got the Tram 15 to reach there, it was very long and hot ; so it was not so easy to get there. And the way back we had to wait a lot..So if you are not staying around, choose morning times to travel - avoid rush hour of locals!
impressive. Belem and Descobrimentos are so close together that you can spend an entire day here without walking that far. If you haven't been go. If you have been, go again.

Worth a visit. Belem was lovely - visit the coffee shop with the custard tarts, they're amazing! The monastery was spectacular and the tower was interesting. Generally, it's a nice place to visit for a walk around, very pleasant
Sunday morning visit. Since a lot of the attractions are free in Belem on Sunday mornings from 10am-2pm - it was very busy! Long line for the tower, but walked right into the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos.

take your sweet bite... Don´t you dare to come to Lisboa and don´t have a Pastel de Belem (buymore than one per each), I´d recommend to eat it outside, next to the river or in the nice Praca in front of the Monasterio, where you an have a full experience of the nice view and the delicious sweet of this town!.. Also visit the Monasterio and Torre de Belem, just take a walk so you won´t feel so guilty for eayting all the Pasteis you will have..

Nice views, otherwise not a lot to see. My husband and I toured the Tower of Belem - I'm glad we went so I didn't feel like I missed anything, but I don't know that it is compelling enough to go again. The tower itself has little of interest - some cannons on the main floor, a small lower floor that I think used to be a jail, and then you climb up 6-7 flights of stairs and basically can admire some nice ornate decorative carvings on the tower and some pretty views of the surrounding area. It's a good quick stop while in the Belem area, but it didn't "wow" me or make my "must see" list by any means.

A must see if you're visiting Lisbon. The hop-on/hop-off buses will take you here where you will find this interesting place along the water. Check-out the museums, Jeronimo's Monestary. Belem is famous for it's pastry shop where you fill find a long line up of people out the door.
The Cathedral is worth visiting. Even after 2 weeks of visiting churches in Europe, this one was the standout. Fantastic architecture and decor. Worth a visit. Tower of Belem is beautiful as well.

A day's excursion. It's a treck to get out there . . . easy enough on the tram, but it really is a different city. Things are spread out.... you'll do some walking. The feel is modern, not "old Lisbon." Pick a few things to visit. There's a lot to do if you have the energy. We liked the tower the best because of the nice views and history. The Monastery is spectacular for its courtyard. Hint: In both places, if you have your LisboaCard (and you should!) you don't have to wait in line to get in. We also walked along to water, visited to big statue, took some nice pictures, had ice cream, and generally were happy to be on vacation!
Avoid weekends if you can. While some of the museums have free entry on Sundays, the crowds may not be worth the savings. Walk the waterfront.

A great few hours trip out of center of Lisbon. If you have time then you should visit Belem. You can take a tram or bus from city center and it should take to Belem in 15 or 20 minutes. Monuments are worth seeing, but if you doń´t have enough time you better stay in Lisbon, because it is so much nicer to walk through the narrow streets of the city in Bairo Alto, Alfama, Chiado. Monastery and church in Belem are cool, if you visit it on Sundays from 10 to 2, there is no fee :)) I think the regular price it is 7 €.
worth it for the cakes alone. Go, eat cake and you will love it! If its busy, get take away and eat it in the shadded park, lovely.
Don't miss this part of town. Be sure to visit the Pasteis with the blue awning to have their original, 100-year-old recipe pastels de Belem!

Worth visiting. This was a pretty area with parks and next to the bay. It was busy on Sunday when we visited with lots of police presence. We passed many cafes and restaurants and is accessible by tram.
Place to visit. great place to visit Patelerias Belem . No place you will get it better
Great sights. There's a lot to see around, I'd recommend it. It's great to be there, especially in Summer

Torre de Belem well worth a visit. On bank of River Tagus, very scenic tower that was built for defense of Lisbon. It's only a small building but lots of winding steps up inside with few passing places, but worth the effort
What to do on a Sunday.. Join all the Lisboetas out in Belem. Visit the Maritime museum & the Discoverers' monument

Belem is a gem. I loved our day out in Belem..so many lovely things to see and they are all so close together it is treat. You simply have to visit Belem and spend a few hours there. From the best custard tarts to the beautiful monastery, as well as 2 must see sights on the waterfront. Do make time for Belem, it is so worth it.
Tasty Pastries!. We spent a day down in Belem, going to the Belem Palace, the monastary, and a flea market. All of those were great, but those Belem pasteries are reason enough to make the trip!
Go during sunset. Nice area to visit.. especially targeted for tourists. The traditional Belem pastries are good and worth a try

Mix Disney and limestone.... ... and you get Belem Tower! Don't get me wrong - the tower is worth seeing, but you feel that it's something from a fairytale. The location at the shore of the Tagus river is fascinating. It's tiny compared to other forts - castles come bigger in the world of Disney. The ornamentation is rich in detail - once again rather unusual for a fortification - but I'm not sure how much of these details are original and what has been added later.A few practicalities: Entrance 5 EUR. Belem Tower opens at 10 - be there before 11 - there will be quite crowded later on... And the staircase to the top is very narrow for 2 way traffic. Take the tram all the way to Largo da Princesa - take the last road before the tram stop to get to the pedestrian bridge over the railroad tracks. After your visit, you can walk back to the other sights in Belem. On OUR way back to central Belem we 'discovered' a  10 days old cafe named 'Descobre' (discover in Portuguese) - funny... And good food by the way.Another hint: To get a good photo of Belem Tower surrounded by water, you have to show up at high tide.

The day we visited there was a street market over there. There were a lot of good souvenirs to buy for a very good price. We bought a pair of hand towels embroideied by hand and the embroidery was exquisite.The line to buy Pasteis was too long, so we didn't do it.I am on a diet but really wanted some pasteis de Belem, which are famous.
By far the best Lisbon's Area. Is by far the best Lisbon's area. Visit Mosteiros dos jeronimos, torre de belem and of course pasties de belem-the best custard tarts.
Quaint place. Took the metro here from the centre. 5 EUR, good value. Lots to see and do. Worth a trip. The coast restaurants are nice but pricey. Saw the cathedral, art museum and a few statues.
Portugese architecture. All the well known images of Lisbon are here; the bridge, the monastery, the monuments etc. And nice parks too!
Don't miss the Belem bakery. Great bakery, you wont miss it if you are in the area.
BEAUTIFUL PLACE. Belem is a lovely part of Lisbon with a hugh church/monastory. The restaurants were really traditional with great food at good prices an taxis from Lisbon were only about 10 Euros.
Good for views. A beautiful monument from the outside, covered in carvings. Lovely views from the top, but you have to pay.

A pilgrmiage for Pasteis de Belem. Why do you go to Belem? To enjoy the original and the best of the Pasteis the Nata, a traditional Portuguese pastry. One bite and you will understand why. I only give it 4 stars because other than the Monastery (which is great) there's not much to see there.

Belem -- must visit. Belem area has several major museums and attractions. Easy to reach by tram #15 from Plaza de Comercio.
Do not overlook some very nice eateries near by.
The pateis are the best, and I tried them everywhere. Port town with ferries across the bay, the monastery, the tower, beautiful views and of course the pastries.
historic attractio. several nice things to see here use hop on hop off bus
Great views from each floor of the Tower. The views from each floor were fabulous. Taking in the River Tagus and the bridge spanning it.
Worth the visit. Great views of the river from here. Would recommend it.
A beautiful spot on the Tegus River with so much historical value and a tower to climb that affords fantastic views.. The Tower of Belem and the Monestary are worth the visit.

Definitely worth the trip to Belem. Belem is about a 15-20 minute tram ride from downtown, and is a fantastic place to spend the day. I visited the Coaches Museum (stunning display of carriages), Jeronimos Monastery (gorgeous inside and out), Dicoveries monument (the size of the figures is absolutely spectacular to see in person) and Belem Tower (the architecture is stunning, & the views from the tower are absolutely spectacular!)
Nice place. Amazing View from the coast line and building. Must go!

Belem Bus Route (Red Route). Travelled on the open top red route on the bus this was great to see the sites one downside the buses are not very regular, we were told they came by every 20 mins this was more like 45 mins especially on the blue route

Good Views of the River. Take the yellow bus trip to Belem and get off and walk around.
Famous statues on the river front and lots to see.
Pasties De Belem. Having been established in 1876 the pastries I have tasted where to die for!!! The best pastries ever! This is one place I will definitely put in my list to return to.

Pretty with an interesting history. This seafront fortress is worth a visit though it is fairly small and there is not that much information on the place on the inside. Not sure it was worth the entrance fee.
Visit "Pasteis De Belem" Cafe and Bakery. For the ultimate custard tarts !! the best in the world. Catch an old fashioned tram no 15 a fab cake and coffee experience.

afternoon trip. Didn't really do much there.Visited church and botanical gardens
but didn,t rate the gardens
Found a little cafe, where the two gentlemen who were working there /owners were really lovely and welcoming
A beautiful part of Lisbon, easy to reach by public transport and offering a great day out.. It would be churlish to complain about the heat having just escaped a wet UK.
Just know Tower is closed on Mondays. Belem is very nice and you simply need to plan so that you're not there on a Monday just looking at everything from the outside.

A great destination for a half day tour. You can take bus number 5 from the station near Rossio Square and the bus brings you right in front of Jeronimous Monastery. Spend at least one hour admiring the architecture of the monastery. If you are going now, there is an exhibition in conjunction with its 500th anniversary celebration. After the visit to the monastery, you can take a short walk to Pastel de Belem, the famous pastry shop with blue awnings which sells the original Portuguese egg tart since 1837. Get past the hordes of tourists at the counter and go inside to get a seat at a table in the huge hall.you will be served promptly. Next head seaward to the Torre de Belem. Admire the beautiful scenery from the top of the tower before you head back to Lisbon on the same bus.
Must visit in Lisbon. Very nice and relaxing place. Easy to get to great sightseeing but the best part is it the home of Pasteis de Belem
Belem Tower. Best view in town. Walk up or take the elevator for a small fee.
muzeum. Must check out the temporary modern times exhibition!
Relax and learn .... ... about Lisbon old treasures. There's three main attractions that you must see: "Torre de Belém", "Padrão dos Descobrimentos" and "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos"

Amazing monument with amazing views. This monument looks amazing from the distance and as you get nearer the detail is great. We took the lift to the top and our legs went like jelly! The views were brilliant.The area a round it is very recreational and the Belam Tower is only a stones throw away along the river bank. Across the road is a lovely Park in front of the Monastry, Church and Presidential Palace. A lovely place to visit, a great location.
Great views!. This is located on the. Ocean but the views are so different from being in the city and the history of these monuments is so dramatic and beautiful!

Free of charge. Free of charge. You can go down to "prison" and up to top. There is only one stair ways go up and down. This stairway is basically for one person so very careful with little kids or eldery person. Go early and avoid await for the stairways. View from tower is beautiful. You can smell the sea too.
A must see!. A great area of the city worth visiting with plenty of things to do and see but allow a whole day as there is so much you don't want to miss!
Lovely. Lots of sites and museums to wander round, good restaurants and of course the famous 'pasties de Belem'!
beautiful Belem. The Monastry is a must see attraction as is Belem TowerLovely area and walk along seafront promenade
Boring. snooze fest... there was really nothing that exciting about this place... it was just a stone tower... if thats your thing... then go for it.

Belém is a "must see"!. The Belém area is a must see for anyone traveling to Lisbon.
It has some of the most beautiful monuments from the "Manuelino" architecture, along with great museums, cafés and a river promenade you can't miss!

A pleasant surprise. In a short space, there are a few things to see and an opportunity for a pleasant walk (while being watchful for the many cyclists and runners going by). I particularly enjoyed the interior of Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. The Torre de Belem was a nice site from exterior, (was unable to go inside as it had closed). The Padrao dos Descobrimentos was also very impressive to view from exterior. Though I took the elevator up the Padrao, the view was nice, though not a must do. For a quick visit to Belem, could probably do it in 2.5 - 3 hours. I also did have Pasteis de Belem (flaky custard tart) at the famous Antiga Confeitaria - it was very good, since they serve it hot (freshly prepared).

Nice building. Its a beautiful must see sight, not really worth paying to go in though, round the monument is an average park and average sea front, and average restaurant/bar but go across the road 5 mins walk by the Naval Museum and its a lovely area, Belem hosts the best pastry shop in Lisbon a must see and the museum is essential if you studied vasco de gama
A little out of the way, but well worth it.. Beautiful. Check out the most adorable Starbuck's in the world, the Monastery San Geronimo and the beautiful waterview parks.

Nice to visit even if you don't do museums. We went primarily to 'do' the parks and botanic garden. it is busy and touristy but lots of open space and it is on the estuary so has a wide and airy feel. Do walk all the way up and past the castle. There's a amazing unknown warrior monument and small museum at the end. Breath taking. The cross atlantic plane replica is also wonderful.
Must see!. An emotion evoking spot! March 2010 with my Brasileiro querido
Portugal's Age of Discovery. ALl the museums, such as the Cultural Ctr., the Jeronimos, the Marine Museum and the Tropical Garden,

Combine visiting the monastery and the tower. We bought a 24 hour ticket for the public transport for getting here. First, we took the tram number 15E to the stop Mosteiro Jerónimos, which is right at the monastery.The monastery is a lot more impressing outside than inside. I think the outside was the most impressive of the sights I saw in Lisbon. The best part inside was the church of Santa Maria, which can be visited without a fee. A combined ticket for the monastery itself and the tower of Belem costs 10 euros, so even though the the monastery is not the highlight here, the cost is so low, that it's still worth going there.After the monastery, we had lunch in Belem, and then hopped again on the tram and traveled to the stop Largo da Princesa, which is quite close to the tower of Belem. The tower itself is pretty small and also this one looks better outside than inside. If you are claustrophobic, don't bother going in. There are prison cells, that are quite low, and the doorways are even lower. The walk up to the tower is on a narrow winding staircase with 2-way traffic.

belem!!. the place is beautifull i went by the red bus of lisbonsightseeing grey line and had the oputunity of staying there for a few hours befor catching the hop on back to the center the belem tower is really worth a visit also the planetario and jeronimos!!!
Nice area to visit. Definitely go to the Belem Tower and the Monastery, but do not leave town without trying the Pasteis de Belem!
A gem of a suburb. The big draw is the Monastery Jeronimos in this lovely little waterfront village. But I confess that I went for the famous Belem custard tarts - you won't be disappointed!
Great place to spend the day. Take your children there, there is a park next to torre de Belém and don't forget to try pastéis de belém

another must in Lisbon. Take tram No. 15 to get to the Belem Tower, but don't get off at the stop named Belem, but at the stop named "Largo Princesa" - it's the closest to the Tower. You will need to walk 4-5 minutes to get there.The Tower visit costs 5 Euro and it will take about 30 minutes to see it all and take some pictures. The place is surrounded by a large park with a few cafe bars. It takes 5 minutes to walk from the Tower to the monument Padrao dos Descobrimentos, marking the place from where the Portuguese ships started their voyages to the see in the Middle Ages.
Amazing architecture. I liked the rich Manueline architecture of the Jeronimos Monastery and Tower of Belem and walking through the gardens to the riverside by the Discoverers' Monument.
Very cool, a must see.. If you like history and appreciate architecture, then you will like like the Belem. Very neat, plan on spending about an hour or so here.
Nice for a morning or afternoon. Nice seaside town. Struggled to find nice inexpensive places to eat. Someone has said we didn't walk down far enough so top tip - keep walking!
A day trip.. Lots of things to see but the exercise was well worth it!

Lovely. Go for the pasteis de Belem in the Confeiteria, and for a salad and a white wine in the modern but lovely situated white pavillion at the waterside. The monastery church is alos great and of course the torre de belem.

Nice half day trip from Lisboa. Go check out the monestary. GET THE PASTEL DE BELEM at the pastry shop neat themonestary. You can't miss it because line is HUGE, but is moves Very QUICKLY. Check out the old navy/fortress on the water. 10 euros to get in, probably a little over priced. It has very narrow winding stair cases in side to get you to yop. They are one way only, so you have to wait for people coming in opposite direction. don't do this if you are fat or out of shape, you won' t make it. Also, getting to Belem is easy. Take the bus. However, getting back is a pain. Just spend the extra money and take a cab back to Lisboa. Not much else to see here, but the monestary is worth it.
Ate at the Marina.. Very inexpensive restaurants around the marina. Spectacular view of the river Tagus.

transit a nightmare. The jeronimus (?) monastery is amazing, not sure what's so special about the belem tower .... mostly I remember the VERY long wait for the VERY crowded tram (on the way there) and bus (on the way back).
old and new. go see the monastery and then discover the castle from here walk down to find more interesting places

Not much to see, but nice view. This is right on the ocean, so it's a beautiful view. There is not really anything to do except enjoy the view. There isn't really a place to sit, just one cafe along the water. But the view is really nice.
Belem. Very clean and open, near the river with plenty of cafes and restaurants. The home of the original famous 'custard tart.
Quiet area. Nice place, quiet, nice view of the river. However, if you want to be in the heart of Lisbon, don't stay in this area. We were bored.
Beautiful. The location of this fortress is beautiful and a must see.
It is a Lisbon highlite.. This is a great half day walk about, take the time don't on tour, do it on your own and enjoy.
A must see. Brilliantly restore to former glory the monastry is one the most beautiful seen..
Great views. Good location, great views, not that much to see. Combine with a trip to the monastery.
San francisco in Lisbon.... The very mighty sculture and the view over the bridge.
A great walk. Walking arond the area gives you a special feeling. Strongly recommend!
Tour buses and Portuguese Tarts. If you like neither, don't bother. Full of tourists and just too busy.
A trip to Lisbon would be incomplete without seeing Belem.. We particularly enjoyed the Monastery and the Coach Museum.
give it a day. easy to access, wonderful monastery and lovely seafront and...and...and...
Beautiful Waterfront. Nice area to walk along and enjoy the river. Then of course there are the delecious pateries to the right of the monestary!
time for Belem. so much to see allow plenty of time and take the bus tour

A good place for a half-day visit. I started out the day at the Pasteleria de Belem, and was not disappointed by the delicious Pastel de Belem. I was only planning on getting one since I'm on a diet, but something prompted me to get the six-pack and I ate the whole thing. It became my breakfast and lunch, and was simply one of the best pastries I have ever tasted. Such a nice, crispy shell and wonderful, sweet egg custard inside the shell. Amazing, and definitely the best custard tart I had while I was in Portugal. And that's saying a lot, because I tried a lot of them :)The monastery was very crowded but worth the visit. Beautiful and huge. I also visited the Monument to the Discoveries - great pictures if you go to the top - and then went to the Tower of Belem (small, and a bit of a disappointment if you ask me). I thought that Belem was a good half-day trip. People with interest in coaches and maritime museums may enjoy the whole day there, but the monastery, pastry shop, monument and tower were enough for me in one day.

Favorite place in Lisbon. We arrived in Belem on the Yellow Bus tour. The bus stopped right in front of the Monastery. After leaving the Monastery we walked over to Pastéis de Belém and spent 30 minutes in line to get a few custard tarts....not that we wanted just custard tarts - we also wanted chocolate croissant's but the person serving us spoke no english and we didn't speak portugues so we ended up with just custard tarts. After that we walked along the water front Belem Tower and then further along to Belem Tower. Finally we ended up walking back thru the park toward Pastéis de Belém to find a restaurant for lunch. Monument to the discoverers, Lisbon. The fascinating area of Belem in lovely ilsbon has much to offer, an amazing Monastery, the ornate Torre de Belem dominating the harbour Entrance, and the lovely waterfront area. My personal favourite is the magnficent Monument to the Discoveries looking triumphantly out over the Atlantic Ocean.It is styled like the prow of a proud sailing vessel, with the brave explorers peering out to sea, led by the manificent figure of Henry the Navigator, holding a miniature sailing caravel. He is closely followed by Vasco de Gama, Ferdinand Magellan, and many other eminent Portuguese explorers , map makers, and writers, many clutching the tools of their trades. Both sides are carved with these wonderful figures, It is built of polished pale stone, stands 50 metres tall , and was opened in 1960 to commemorate the 500 year anniversary of the death of Henry the Navigator, the driving force behind Portugal's leadership in maritime exploration. The Monument can be climbed by lift, and the top affords magnificent views over the city, the waterfront, and the huge marble world exploration map at the foot of the building.

Spend a Sunday morning visiting Belém to see the tower, Jeronimos monastery, and coach museum. We spent some time browsing through a flea market in the area to the left of the garden in front of the monastery. The "Monument to the Discoveries" is across the busy road, so we saw it from a distance. Finally we also went through the National Coach Museum (it was free after all :-) and had lunch at the os Jeronimos restaurant, followed by café con leche and Pasteis de Belém (popular Portuguese egg tart pastry, called pasteis de nata elsewhere). All in all, it was an excellent way to spend a Sunday morning.Remember to buy a 5 Euro "7 Colinas" pass for metro and tram, see my blog http://nbtmv.blogspot.com/2012/04/visiting-lisbon-portugal.html for details.

An absolute must when visiting Lisbon. This area has so much to see -- it can easily take a full day. The Monastery of Jeronimos is bigger than you can imagine. Amazing fairy tale-like tower, must see!. We visited Belem as a family, and went straight to see the Tower. It's a 10 minute walk from the tram across a pedestrian bridge which runs over a highway and train track. The tower itself is like a fairy tale, shining white, rising from the water, with intricate details. The original tower was farther off shore, but more recently reclaimed land made entrance via a footbridge possible. The entrance fees are modest, and well worth seeing such an interesting tower. The lowest level was a storehouse and prison, and you can't stand to full height if you are of medium adult height or taller. Worth a peek, but just for a few minutes. The real treat (in our opinion) was the courtyard level, where you can first emerge out of doors to see the views up and down the water, including the big bridge, the river traffic, and the shoreline. (Unfortunately the other side of the shore line seems to be mostly power plants, but the Lisbon/Belem side is nice)The tower has many upper levels reached by a narrow stone spiral staircase. The stairs were not overly difficult to navigate, except when pedestrian traffic became congested in both directions. However, we were impressed by humanity -- with no system in place, people chose to wait on each floor to allow groups to come up first before proceeding down, thus minimizing the two-way traffic on the staircase. The upper floors had interesting views, as well as a brief film on the history of the site. You can also gain an appreciation of what it would be like to live there by visiting the many floors.Word of caution -- the stairs are not for the infirm. One member of our party chose to remain downstairs while we visited above. Our 4 year old child was able to navigate reasonably well. Also, the windows were open on each floor so we could see the view, but this also let the wind in, and it was very windy. Dress appropriately for the weather. (And not the best place to visit in the rain, as the view and the outdoor bits are the best!)Allow sufficient time to take lots of photos -- the tower is quite photogenic, with interesting architecture, statues, etc. Don't miss the rhino gargoyle viewable from an alcove in the tower -- our son loved it!

Must see, but take your time. I'm one of those people who likes to savour the 'feeling' of a place, so I would recommend at last a couple of hours to hang out at the tower. Important: If you are claustrophobic, DO NOT go up the middle stone staircase, or if you must up the courage, make sure to do only one flight at a time and give yourself lots of time to chill on the next level. Do not attempt to cover 2 or more flights as it’s extremely narrow and does not accommodate two direction traffic well at all. At times people may actually stop in the middle of it because it’s so crowded to sort out who’s going down and who’s going up. There are a few windows in it, but not many, so be mindful that you don’t end up getting stuck in the windowless part.A neat thing to do when it's not terribly crowded is to shut yourself (and your significant other?) in one of the turrets on the main or second level that have doors that close fully and just sit in there and watch the river, the tide, people on shore. The tower of Belem is for sure a fabulous historic monument - very well preserved and unique - well worth a visit when in the area and free access with the lisboa card. What a shame that there was such a poor welcome (not even an acknowledgment of our existence in front of the grumpy lady at the ticket booth) and there was a distinct lack of information explaining the history of the tower (some limited wall boards). Come on Lisbon tourist board you can do better than this.
Grandeur of Portugal. This is a must: You have to visit the Monastery, the tower of Belem and the monument of the explorers.

A "must see" area - shame about the highway. A lovely old part of Lisbon that must be seen, especially the church and monastery - although the latter was closed on Easter Sunday and (like most museums in Lisbon) every Monday. Belem is spoiled by having the main sites separated from the lovely waterfront by a 4-lane highway and a railway line.

Must-see while in Lisbon. Belem is a great area that you can visit in one day. The Monastary is beautiful, the Belem Tower has a gorgeous view of the river and there are numerous museums. It is a short train ride from Lisbon. You must also visit the Pasteis de Belem and have their custard pastry...it's world renowned and delicious!
Tried public transport back and forth and "survived". Even Sunday Afternoon and lots of visitors it was possible to get a feeling of the atmosphere which might hae been there in the past

Belem is enjoyable but forget the famous custard tarts there. Belem is a close-in suburb and its historical sites are well worth the visit, but ignore all the guide books that tell you that you must have a custard tart from Antiga Confeitaria de Belem. The lines in the sun are an hour long and stretch down the block, there is inadequate seating given the size of the crowd, and MOST IMPORTANTLY the custard tarts one can buy almost anywhere in Lisbon are just as tasty. Sorry to burst your bubble.

Go for the Day. This is a really great place to spend the day, lots to see and do. If you want to see inside the church go early or at lunch time. Take a walk in the park. Take the little sightseeing bus around for a good overview of this pretty place. You have to try the custard pies.
Day trip. If you are into museums, monuments and monastries, Belem will take up a day, There are also very good restaurants there.
Delicious. Beside visiting the monestry and "tropical garden" you should try "pasteis de belem". Really delicious.

Amazing. Tower of Belem was interesting, but it took us 15 minutes to see all we thought there was to see about it. Walk around in the area, the parks are nice and there are all kinds of restaurants and cafes around (and the cafe selling Pasteis de Belem is a must to see, be sure to buy one to see what it's all about. For Finns it may be a bit of a letdown since our pannukakku (if made in a cupcake form) would be very close to it. Still worth it. Monastery of Belem was just amazing. All that detail - I can't imagine how long it has taken someone to finish all that. My tip is (as with pretty much everything): Put your camera away and SEE it all. What's the point of going if you could've just sent someone to tape it all for you? Camera just can't capture the whole of it the same way as the human eye can.
Pastel de belem. it is totaly worth the trip for one of the famous "pasteis de belem". Very close to the monasterium (i only saw from the outside).
Nice!!!. Very nice town with a great green area for the kids. We didn't do much but enjoyed walking and exploring with our 3 kids.

Jeronimos Monastery - Not to be missed. Took Tram 15 from Praca da Figueira out to Belem to explore the area. Got off at the Belem Tower and climbed to the top. Great views of the river Tejo Cristo Rei Monument, bridge and city. Perfect photo opportunities. Then walked along the river to the Padrão dos Descobrimentos. Directly in front of the Padrão dos Descobrimentos there’s a tunnel going underground to cross the street. Upon surfacing on the other side you are right in front of a Jardim Praca do Imperio with a beautiful fountain. There are several Jardims along the street Avenida da India. The Jeronimos Monastery was the highlight of this area. It is a must see. The outer facade, the church and the monastery are very impressive.After a hot morning of viewing the sights I wandered over to “Pasteis de Belem” for a coffee and their signature “pastel de nata“ egg tart pastry. There was a lineup but it was well worth the wait. They were the tarts I tasted while in Portugal. If you are planning on visiting sights in this neighborhood it’s best to get an early morning start. By late morning I noticed the busloads of tourists arriving.

Area not to be left out. We explored this area on our first day in Lisbon. There is a lot to see : Tower of Belem, Jeronimos Monastery, Coaches Museum, Monument to the Discoveries are all close by. We wanted to buy tickets to Tower of Belem but even though it had not been high season yet there was very long queue so we decided not to go. The Monastery is magnificent. It also contains tomb of Vasco da Gama - the famous Portuguese explorer and navigator as well as king Manuel and other Portuguese royalty. Close to Tower of Belem is a place where you can buy souvenirs (good choice, prices are ok too compare to the souvenir shops near the Castle) and get something to eat. (It is located few metres from the sightseeing bus stop - I am not sure if all sightseeing buses stop there) We had a hot dog and a burger. Hot dog was served with small (really tiny ) chips that were on the top of a frankfurter. We paid around €12 for the hot dog, burger and two cans of coke. There are also public toilets close by. If you are planning on visiting all sights in this neighborhood make sure you have enough time to do so. You can easily spend full day there.

Monastery and monuments. Worth a trip out here if you have a spare half day when visiting Lisbon. The monastery is quite spectacular due to its sheer size. I really wanted to see the monument of the Discoveries but it was a tad underwhelming.
One of Portugal's treasures. No trip to Lisbon should exclude this wonderful monument - nor the surrounding area. Quite beautiful
Good place to visit!. A nice location of Lisbon which worth to visit: Belem Tower, Monastery St. Jeronimo and the entire promenade is just great!
Interesting. A very interesting area with lovely gardens and good restaurants. Warning - the queues at the monastary and the famous Belem Bakery can be very long!
excellent place to visit. visited Belem March 2012. good resto at Pasteis de Belem, sight seeing at Padrão dos Descobrimentos, blem tower and Jerónimos Monastery

The must visit place in Lisbon. I was in Lisbon for only a short visit so I was travel around the city by a red double decker bus hop on and hop off. The tower of Belem was amazing place that I HAVE VISIT during my short stay in Lisbon. See this beautiful tower with river tangus as the background and hear a romantic music from the street artist made me don't want to move from this area. Really it was great. Don't forget to walk along the river to find Discoveries Monument and also Jeronimos Monastery another UNESCO world heritage in Lisbon

Wonderful variety. The towers, the monastery and the custard tarts! All wonderful in themselves but within minutes of each other in a wonderful venue on the river bank in Lisbon. The Pasteis de Belem 'facility' is charming and delightfully old-style. The tower at Belem is interesting and a great photo opportunity. The view from the Vasco da Gama memorial is well worth the trip. However, notwithstanding the many delights of Lisbon, the Monastery Jeronimos was stunning, both inside and out. Fabulous sights of Lisbon...
Old part of the city. Very photogenic part of Lisbon. Lots of old world buildings

Far too much interesting sights for one day!. Although we spent a whole day in this part of Lisbon, we really only saw a small portion of what it has to offer. We started our day with a visit to the Ajuda Palace, a former royal palace high up on the hill above Belem. Then we walked over to the Jeronimos Chapel, which has a great view on Belem and the river Tejo, but was unfortunably closed. From there we went down to the riverfront and saw the Padrao dos Descobrimentos from the outside. Then we climbed the Tower of Belem for a good view on the river Tejo. Finally we visited the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, an absolut must see, when in Belem. The beautifully decorated facade, the church with its impressive columns and the absolutely wonderful cloister are worth the long tram ride from the city center. To give our feet some rest and to please our stomach we ended our tour of Belem at the café 'Pasteis de Belem', where you really do get the best custard tarts in the whole wide world. We thought it would be a tourist trap, but after the first two pasteis we definitely knew better and ordered another two immediately.

Towers, Museums, Custard Tarts. Picture the scene: first morning in Lisbon, its raining hard. Cancel plans to visit the castle and Alfama district and head instead to Belem.The bus & tram is simple and easy to use, just hop off in Belem and across the road into the Museu dos Coches (Coach Museum). A huge array of classic coaches and related artefacts to see, housed in a wonderfully ornate building with fantastic painted ceilings. Leave the museum (into much lighter drizzle) towards the Jeronimos Monastery a couple of hundred metres away, stopping on route at Pateis de Belem for a coffee and some eponymous egg/custard tarts. Almost faint in disbelief at how tasty the tarts are, with warm gooey custard and super-flaky pastry. Head outside into sunshine, wonder what the tarts are really made of if they can improve the weather so greatly and cross over to the monastery.View the church and the monastery cloisters with their intricate and ornate stone work, before heading towards the Tejo to climb up the Tower of Discoveries to get a view back across towards the monastery and the rest of Belem. Follow this up with a wander towards the Torre de Belem, climbing up the tower to learn a little of the history of both it and the periods of Lisbon's history. Finish up by heading back to the tram to weave your way back into the middle of Lisbon.A definite must-see area of Lisbon with a number of things to do, see and eat all within easy walking distance of one another - if you do one thing in Lisbon, make it visiting Belem, if only to eat a Pateis de Belem tart!
Beautifull. A beautifull place well kept by the authorities, but also very busy.

Great walk where old and new meet. We loved the walk around this neighbourhood. Well worth a walk. On one side you have the river with views of the bridge and a number of top monuments. There are also quite a few bars and restaurants around with great views.Even though the river side is probably were everything is happening, it would be worth crossing the main road and just getting a bit lost on the side roads towards north. Walking around is just lovely, enjoying the view of many beautiful small titled-covered houses. Very charming area. Tip: - look out for fun little drawings on the ground by the riverside.- check out little roads on the north side.- In case you need to find a taxi back, there is a big hospital across the road from the monument that you can easily get a cab from.

From where Navigators left to India and Brasil. I like small sailing-boats in the river Tagus. The view to Cristo Rei Monument, the Belem Tower, and the bridge over the river.The visit of the Centro Cultural, the Jerónimos Monastery, the Maritime Museum...
Incredible Architecture and History. We stumbled upon this church while driving through Portugal. It was breathtaking and unforgettable. Though, it was a bit crowded and stained with tourism.

Pastis de belem is "aight". Everyone goes crazy for the pastis de belem at the Pastis de Belem. They were probably the nicest of the Portuguese tarts we had during our stay but nothing to write home about.

Monastery & Tower are Must-Sees. Pleasant little district along the coast which you can reach by tram from the centre. The monastery and tower, both UNESCO world heritage sites, are absolute must-sees; fantastic architecture and rich in history. Similarly, the nearby seafront monument is very evocative of the great age of discovery. And while you're out here you must try the locally invented custard tarts!

Been in Lisbon and not in Belem?? come on.... Is almost impossible to miss the attractions of this area and I would say the "proud" of Lisbon...Tower of Belem: BEAUTIFUL... magnificent tower.Monastery of the Hieronymites: another great BEAUTY, the cloister one of the best I've seen in my life.Pasteis de Nata: I avoided this because of the long queue... ok those are the originals, but they can be found in central Lisbon too without having such a long waiting time...The first 2 places simply cannot be missed, others in the area (marine museum, coach museum, planetarium) is up to what you want to do...

lovely, as the rest of Lisbon. went there for a walk on the river, at sunset, found a lovely cafe with good atmosphere, music and lights. if you like to cycle, this is probably one of the few places where you can cycle in Lisbon, along the river. in the area you can find the 'original' bakery where the famous pasteis de nata were invented. you can have them very fresh, but you can expect a cue.

A magical place. Well if you're traveling to Lisbon you must spend an entire day(at least) in Belem. There's so much to see and visit that is overwhelming. Start with Torre de Belem and Padrão dos Descobrimentos, then visit the fantastic mosteiro dos jerónimos and the Coaches Museum, the best in the world. Then finish in centro cultural de Belem with one of the best modern art collections known to men. In the middle of all this enjoy the beautiful area around you where Portuguese sailors departed to amazing voyages of discovery 5 centurys ago... You'll see... it's a magical place!
Botanic Gardens and Sea. nice trip from city. Get the tram form city centre. Everything here you could want, from Palces to Botanic Gardens.

A must-see. Belem, with its famous starting-off place for some of the great explorers in history, is a must-see. Songs have been written about the journey to sea that explorers and fishermen took so many years ago, and these songs have become staples in the Fado liturgy of Portugal.

Best architecture - and pasteis da nata!. Belem is the place to see the best of the Manueline Portuguese style of architecture in Lisbon. The cloisters and cathedral of the Monastery of the Order of St Jerome and the Tower of Belem are all must-see attractions during a visit. There is also the planetarium, the Maritime Museum, the Electricity Museum and the Cultural Centre in the same area. Do not forget to buy your pasteis da nata, the traditional local custard tarts - unbeatable when they are fresh from the oven!
Sunset along the river. Great place to walk along the river and take in the vistas and have a sunset cocktail.

Don' t miss the authentic PASTEL DE BELEM. The real Pastel de Belem is really CRISPY DELICIOUS! Is the same as PASTEL de NATA even though every Portuguese will say it's different. But the one sold in BELEM next to the Mosteiro is the best ever!
great tour. Do not forget to visit Pasteles do Belem... they are amazing!!!

Beautiful area. If you are visiting Lisbon, you have to visit this area! Full of beautiful gardens, you have the Jeronimos monastery, the tropical garden, the Belem Tower, Imperio Square and much more to see. Don't forget to visit the Pasteis de Belem to eat some very good local pastry!

Good, good, good!. I liked it very very much! The monastery of st. Jeronimos was so beautiful!!!!!! I can't imagine such beauty!!! It was grand, big and magnificent! The tower was also very interesting! The stairs were so narrow, that we had to wait, till all people come down from above the tower, and only then went up! And the ocean!!! The words cannot describe it!
very pretty. nice place and we had a lovely lunch at a little cafe, just down the road from the famous pastry place

Visit the Coach Museum .... & Monastry. Was surprised how intricate they are. Stand there and imagine those times!! Walk a block or so South to the Monastry ... Big and impressive when you see the cleaned vs. the not-so.
You have to visit here. We stopped off here on one of the bus trips.What a wonderful place, fantastic architecture, gretat monuments and a beautiful area.

Well Worth the Tram Ride. Obviously a highlight in Lisbon's tourism crown with the spectacular monastery and small Tower. Just a shame that with the billions dumped into the place in the form of a white elephant cultural centre and other projects they have not yet managed to really knit together the seafront split by an ugly busy road and rail lines. Seems this should have been the first priority. Long tedious walk from the Discoveries Monument to the Torre. Catch the lovely little Thai pavillion in the park across the street from the Confeitaria...gifted in commemoration of the 500th anniversary of Thai-Portuguese relations last month.
Traditions. Monument to Portuguese maritime discoveries.Good for a walk in the afternoon, along the Tagus river.

A lovely spot not far away. The monastery is a must-see: the cloisters a wonderful oasis. The Fort also worth a visit as early or late in the day as possible and the numerous cafes near the monastery are competing to keep prices down and service up. Don't miss out on the best pastry shop in town! WAlk back along the river front after scaling the Discoveries monument and enjoy the locals relaxing. Go at least as far as the April 24th Bridge.

One of the most expressive monuments in Lisbon. This beautiful monument is one highlight of lisbon, it was in times, an fort to protect the city and the river from invasor, now it´s a beatiful monument to visit. From here you can have a great view over the Tejo River, 25 April Bridge (same architech as San Francisco Bridge) and over the Belem Gardens.
Impressive. Pay a visit to the church and the monastry environment, don't waste the occasion if you spend at least 3 days in Lisbon
nice neighbourhood. do not forget to try the Pasteis de Nata in Belem, the monesterio de Geronimo is a must see when you are in Belem
Step Into History. A fantastic monument to the courageous seafarers of the 'new world' exploration.

Great old Monastery. The Jeronimo Monastery is an impressive building, a must-see also in it's interior wich is still standing strong at 400+ years. Beautiful architecture, stunning sealings and wonderful cloister. Mustn't miss this site, then wonder around Belèm...
Nice area. Great to just walk along have an exspresso at a little cafe with a taste of the lovely patsteries on offer

Good museums in the area. Plenty of museums in the area, could probably spend the whole day there with everything to see. If you're staying in close to Sodre train station, recommend to take the train to Belem station ( or a taxi, should be relatively cheap).

Cakes and Plants. I really like the botanical garden behind the palace. So peaceful and lovely. The Belem cakes (pastry tart with custard/egg filling) are delectible and the fortress on the waterfront was cool as well.

Top of the Top. Personally and retrospectively I feel that if I had gone to Lisboa and not gone to Belem - I would have missed half of the experience. The monument to the great Navigators, the Convent, the Tower...and specially the place, by the river, the nice cafes, the old building, the "Pasteis de Belem" pattiserie....the whole ambiance of the place is just great - feels like a nice day or half day out of the city - relaxing by the river that opens to the sea....and yet is so close-by.

Cathedral + Riverfront promenade / Tower + Pastéis de Belém - cool!. For me, Belém was like a Prix Fixe menu at a good restaurant - a multi-course offering of what's best / seasonal / can highlight the skills of the place. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos, huge, beautiful, impossible to imagine how many hours of work went into building the building alone, let alone carving all the Manueline work. Paid for by the Portuguese empire / spice / gold trade. Adjancent to the river, Torre de Belém - great view of Belem & Lisbon, amazing sculpture / carvings on it's river-front "prow", and Casa Pastéis de Belém, where you can take a break, enjoy a Bika & a couple of Pastéis. Our waiter, who seemed to have been doing his job there for 30+ years, was great - we we ordered 2 Bika and 4 Pastéis and asked if that was too many / too few of the Pastéis, and he said "1 may not be enough, but more than 2 is definitely too many" with a slight look of "don't be a silly glutton". Loved it!
Beautiful architecture. This is worth a trip out of Lisbon. Amazing architecture. Had a wonderful lunch at the harbour- can't remember name but it was at the sailing club. Highly recommended.

Beautiful Belem. Belem is absolutely worth visiting - I recommend walking along the seaside (it's about two hours) from the centre. Make sure to set out early, perhaps enjoy a lovely lunch at one of the great seaside restaurants, and walk back in the sunset to Lisbon. For those who are interested, there are several museums and cultural sites in Belem, not to mention the delicious pasteis de Belém, a must-try!

only the monastery. the monastery was worthy of the visit it style is different,the tour of belem is very poor,we also tried the local cakes at the famous place that every body advise and we made the queue for nothing,we didn't like it
A must see. This is billed as the most iconic sight within Lisbon. It is great, particularly on a good day and offers great views of the city and the river
a site with lot`s of historie. A very historic place with a fine palace/monestary and sculptures about the explores of the world
Good on Sundays when the museums are free until 2. The Tower is pretty small, the other museums are interesting.
Just a beautiful place to visit!. Indeed very beautiful, picturesque and do not forget the little gems of Belem: the absolute sweets from the greatest pastry shop !!

An interesting place. There's quite a few things to do around here, from the Monastery to the coach museum to the pastis. I took it easy and did the bus tour around. The place was quite quiet (maybe the time of year) and relaxing and I enjoyed pottering around and trying the pastis!

Cool fortified structure, west of Lisbon. Bueatiful design, a number of stories, with a winding staircase leading to a great view at the top. It was a stunning day so you could see the james bond hideouts across the channel. Definitely worth a look probably by getting one of the numerous buses, trams even trains out west. Enjoy.

Lovely area to spend a day and only 30 minutes bus ride from central Lisbon. Loved Torre de Belem, and Padrao dos Descobrimentos.
Mosteiro dos Jeronimos - really exquisite building.

Belem Joy. what a lovely place to travel too. the number 25 tram from Praca de figuero will take you all the way to Belem. Watch out for the stops as there are not alerts on the tram to let you know where you are.. stops include, the Coaches Musem and the Monastery (definately worth a trip out the back of the monestray) and Belem tower. Get a Pastel de Nata, as this is the origin of this delcious tart.
A monument to visit.... Located in one of the amazing areas of Lisbon, its an important monument in the portuguese history...
meh. there are some amazing buildings there and the pastries are to die for but it was a bit much with the hagglers and rush of tourists
pasteis. taste the pasteis de belem,one of the seven gastronomic beauties of Lisbon:
Not to be missed. Beautiful Lisbon neighborhood. The monastery is so-so but the maritime museum and the coach museum are fascinating and unique
Nice day trip. The trip there took a while due to the traffic, we took tram 15. DEFINATELY buy a Lisboa card, otherwise you have to queue for ages in the post-office thingy to buy the tickets

Beautiful Mosterio dos Jeronimos and get to gorge on the delicious Pasteis de Belem!. Area of great historical interest. All the museums are worth going to as most displays are in both English and Portuguese. Presidential Palace is only only on Saturday with guided tour in Portuguese. Belem Palace was a little disappointing compared to the Palaces in Sintra.

Mosteiro de los Jerónimos in Belém is awsome. The building is breathtaking from the outside, but I wasn't prepared for the impression entering the church would make with its grandeur, huge carved stone pillars and the tomb of Vasco da Gama. Great experience even for an atheist.The rest of Belem I have only seen twice from the sightseeing buses, and I skipped by Pasteis de Belem, but I will go back there next time. The area is great when the weather is nice, but one needs time and good shoes to take it all in.

Great for an afternoon stroll, sardines and sweets. Belem was a nice place but not for more than a few hours and maybe lunch and desert if you are strolling around and exploring Lisbon. We had an fantastic grilled sardine lunch near the Presidential Palace. Belem's famous sweets shop was packed. Great sea side views as well and lovely for a picnic.

The monastery is a must-see. The sarcophagus of Vasco da Gama, the intricacy of the cloisters, the vastness of the church ...are all so impressive. We also enjoyed Belem Tower. Very interesting to see the carving of the rhinoceros, first evidence of European knowledge of the animal.

Top Place for me in Lisbon. The monastery and the tower were the two places I iced more in Lisbon. The manuelino style is one of my favorites. The claustro inside the monastery was really nice, but if you are short of time, you can see the interior of the church without queuing. Definitely get into the tower and watch the sunset from there. If I remember correctly both tickets can be bought together.

Cool Monastery & Yummy Pastries. The pastries near the monastary we're awesome (look for line). The church and monastery were beautiful, so was the park near it and the bay area. Nice place to spend a full day in Lisbon

postcards from Lisboa. It's a monument that you are obliged to visit, not only because of it's beauty, but also because of is historic importance.
It's also near other very important monument, the Jeronimo's Monastery, and, if you like something sweet, you are also near another ex libris, the famous "pasteis de Belém".

must see in Lisbon. Tower the Belem is one of most beautiful Lisbon attractions. it is a small, old tower. the entrance fee is about 4 euro but don't forget that Sunday morning (until 2p.m.) it is FREE :)

the great discovers. I could write and write... there is so much information from the mosteiro dos jeronimos and the tower of belem, but do not forget to taste one pastel teh belem! we will not escape from a second or third one! they are so delicious....
The Monastery is impressive!. Beautiful, you have to go there! the whole area deserves a nice stroll along the shore to see the monuments, a visit to the museum and of course the Monastery.
Beautiful. Go at sunset, the location ins fantastic to take some pictures.. and don't miss the famous pasteis de belem.

What's the big deal?. There's a huge church and monestary, but most tourists seem to go for the pastries. I tried them too. They were OK, but nothing special and certainly not worth the wait and awful service.
Must see. This place is more than 500 years, if you come to Lisbon and don't visit it, it's like going to Rome and don't go to the Vatican
Fresh. I loved the riverside space and the Tower of Belem is just outstanding! And of course, the "pastels de belem" are delicious!
You must go here. The famous pastries are awesome! Not like any other versions served around Lisbon. The monastery is great too. Especially liked the cloisters.
Beautiful at sunset. I loved it. It was one of my highlights in the city. It is best to go the Geronimos Monastery and the tower together (combined ticket).
Dont miss the Pasteis de Belem. Since 1837 the recipt is kept on secret. Unforgetable flavor. Ask for 3 at least.

Disappointing and lacking information. When I got to see a local historical attraction I expect to know by the time I leave what actually happened there. This was hardly the case in the Belem tower.Buying the combined ticket with the ministry I went in to find not only a very small site but barely any information. Short info plaques told tiny parts of the story and the short video didn't complete the image enough.The site itself is quite well preserved and it could but much more interesting if properly presented.
Beautiful!. See in the late morning, as the fog lifts and the tourists haven't arrived yet or late afternoon!

Great monuments, great pastries. Belém is a great place to spend a few hours visiting the World Heritage monuments (the Torre de Belém and the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos, which are both superb buildings), the river bank with the Padrão dos Descobrimentos, as well as the numerous restaurants and, last but not least, the Antiga Confeitaria de Belém, with the wonderful pastéis de Belém

Relax and Stroll along the Coast. The must do is of course the Pasteis de Nata! Really great pastry although it's always busy. Don't queue for take away though, walk straight in, deep into the heart of the shop. There are plenty of tables and the homemade hot chocolate is also heavenly. Other than that, take a walk down the coast to see the Tower and just chill.
Very nice area. All the area is worth visiting. The Jeronimo monastery is very nice and the castle by the sea beautiful. Plus the discovery monument by the river.

Nice trip 30 mins from Lisbon. We visited in February so was quiet and we had time to explore the old "castle". Think it was about 7 euros pp. good views and reasonably well preserved. However it's pretty small and I imagine the place would be heaving in peak season. Tourist trap kiosks and snack bars surround it. Avoid their high prices and walk 10 minutes to Belem centre instead

Wonderful place to spend a day sightseeing. Head to Belem for a day of sightseeing, eating and drinking! The Monastery, Maritime museum, Presidential Palace, Discovery Monument and Tower of Belem are all within walking distance. Stop by the pastry shop for some famous Belem Cakes (only 1.05 Euros) and then go next door for a meal of fish stew and draft beer. Afterward, walk through the park or take a stroll by the river. The 28 bus will take you back to downtown Lisbon when you are ready.

pearl of Lisboa. spend there a day, or two! you shouldnt miss this wonderful place! monastery, tower, monument and of course famous belem sweets. yoг can not say, that you were in lisboa, if you werent in Belem

You must see Belem area. You must see the area of Belem which has a lot of cultural places. From modern art 'Centro Cultural de Belem'. Padrâo dos Descobrimentos, a lot of cosy doc restaurants with outdoor serving. You may walk along the Tejo River og take a tour with the YellowBus Carristur. Enjoy.

One of the Top 5 attractions in Lisbon. This area concentrates so many attractions that it deserves maybe two days visiting. It is so important to the history of Portugal and Brasil because, from this place the three caravels left to later discover Brazil. The Mosteiro dos Jeronimos right in front, is a portuguese architectural masterpiece and deserves a detailed visit. Not to mention the famous Belem pastries (sorry to say I found not so good). In order to visit and enjoy all the area attractions, maybe one day is not enough. I suggest that when you get tired, you walk along the riverside up to the Santo Amaro Docks and have lunch (or dinner) at one of the many good restaurants in the area. It is one of the nicest walkways in Lisbon.

So much to do. See all you can - the Tower, the Coach Museum, the Monastery, the pastry shop. There is an INCREDIBLE charm to Portugal, and Belem is a great example of the wealth of history that many don't realize Portugal possesses.

Worth a trip. We took the #15 tram from downtown Lisbon and got off at the stop nearest the Belem Tower. The stop is just a few blocks from the tower and then you need to climb up and down an overpass to cross the street. I believe there is an underpass as well but it was blocked by construction when we visited. My husband climbed to the top of the tower and said it really wasn't worth it; very crowded with lots of people trying to maneuver one set of windy stairs in both directions. If you're facing the water, to the right of the tower is a little monument where we happened to catch a changing of the guards ceremony. I don't think many people know about this as there were fewer than 10 other people watching. We saw the ceremony at 1300 hours on a Sunday. There are restrooms right by this monument that cost 50 cents Euro to use and are fairly clean.We then walked to the Monument of the Discoveries and took the elevator to the top. My husband said the view was actually better than from the top of the tower without having to fight crowds and climb the steps, so I'd recommend this.
