Plan to spend the day. Belem is packed with wonderful sights (not to mention custard tarts). Here are just some of them:Mosteiro dos Jeronimos: A monastery started in 1501 to commemorate the successful voyage of Vasco da Gama to find a trade route to India. While the facade is ornate, boasting a large cast of characters both religious and secular (e.g., Henry the Navigator), the nave is surprisingly austere, with walls of plain stone blocks. This is offset by the carved pillars that support the vaulted ceiling. Many tombs are housed therein, including royalty and -- yes -- Vasco da Gama. The highlight for me, however, is quite the most magnificent cloister I´ve ever encountered -- a two-story cloister enclosed by ornate pillars and a series of lacy triple arches, all carved from pale gold stone.Maritime Museum: The pride of this museum is a vast hall full of royal barges. The most ornate of these is a heavily-gilded monster from the early 18th century, manned by 80 oarsman and last used in 1957 to transport Queen Elizabeth II on a state visit. Museum of Coaches: A festival of coaches, litters, sedan chairs, and accoutrements thereto. The oldest is a 1619 coach that brought Philip III of Spain to Lisbon on a state visit. Palace of Ajuda: The interior of the palace is semi-standard for a palace decorated in the 1860s. Unusual features are a marble conservatory and a room full of ceramics, including ceramic-fronted furniture, a ceramic mirror surround, and a ceramic chandelier. My favorite room was the small but classy music room. There were two bedrooms for the king, one of which was surprisingly austere, with a single bed. Most unusual was the king´s bathroom, boasting brand-new, state-of-the-art 1860s indoor plumbing. I have never before seen a flush toilet with two holes -- a regular-size one and a small one for use as a urinal.Belem Tower: Built as a defensive tower, but boasting magnificent architecture in the Manueline style, which combines Moorish, Gothic, and Renaissance elements. There is a small feature tucked away at the base of a tower that is most unusual -- a stone rhinoceros, thought to be the first depiction of a rhinoceros in Europe.
for a stroll. Belém, besides the gardens, has a lot of places to visit such Jerónimos, CCB, Padrão dos Descobrimentos. Visit it day or night

Quaint area where you can spend the afternoon. Belem was about a 20 minute tram ride outside of the city center. The tram ride was bumpy and loud and it was a little confusing which stop to get off on but it was still worth the trip. One of our guide books had a walking trail of the streets which was helpful and we got to learn a little about the town. There's a beautiful church to visit (which is closed on Tuesdays) and a statue facing the sea which is worth a look. Of course you'll have to stop and get the famous pastry which believe me - you won't be able to eat just one!

Lots to see and do. Be sure to visit Belem when in Lisbon. There is the magnificent monastery, the cultural centre, republic's musuem, and nearby Belem towwe. Tip: do not miss out on the delicious cakes Pasteis de Belem
Beautiful at night. Loved seeing the monuments lit up at night. The custard tarts at the Café Pastéis de Belém are amazing!! Even went back a second time the next day!!
Lissabon from 500 years ago. Torre de Belem and Jeronimos are two master pieces from the old times. Also cebtro cultural and berado museum are very good options. You can walk between this atractions

Make your way to Belem. Although not officially part of Lisbon, you won't know that you are not in Lisbon. The sights in Belem are well worth even half of a day only visit in Lisbon. Do not miss the Mosteiro dos Jerónimos - the Manueline architecture will delight even those who have no interest in architecture. Also be sure to see the Torre de Belém (you can climb for good views of harbor and Lisbon), the Monument to the Discoveries (you can take an elevator for good views of harbor and Lisbon) and the Pasteis de Belem for the infamous Belem tarts. There is an interesting coach museum and a naval lover's maritime museum.

The Pastries of Course!. We went here a number of times. We would walk along the river. The bridge reminded us so much of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco. The walk is very pleasant, maybe about 30 - 45 minutes. We went to the original pastry place a couple of times, the small tarts are really as good as everyone says.There is a peaceful park there, which we sat in for awhile.

Yummy. Pay the 1.5 Euro to ride the elevator to near the top and climb to the open top of the Belem tower to view the "golden gate" bridge, the monastery, and the CCB. Entry to the monastery is free and the nuns there started the Belem pastry shop. The famous pastry is a yummy custard in a cup made of crispy phyllo sheets. When a train passes it sounded like thunder inside the tunnel between the tower and the monastery.

The best " Pasteis de Belem" in town. You can savour the delicious Belem cookies " pasteis de Belem".
in the original store. Only a few meters away you will find the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos . After crossing the main street you have the "Padrao dos Descobrimentos and the tower of Belem.
These are the most visited sights in Lisbon.

Worth the time if you beat the line. I made the mistake of getting to the monestery after 11 in the morning and there was already a line out the door going on to the street. I decided to come back in the afternoon when it was less busy. This did not help, as there was still a line by 4:30 PM.After waiting in line for almost an hour I was finally inside. Unfortunately I only had 20 minutes to take it all in before they were asking people to leave for the closing. This was in September so it is likely that slower times of the year will not be so bad. It was truly Breathtaking and I will be planning ahead as I prepare for my next visit to Lisbon in December.
Could be cleaner and more safe. A must for a visitor but not for staying too long. Could be cleaner and have less beggars like most of the places in Lisbon oldtown.
a wonderful area. the views and the monuments and the pastelles...save time for walking the waterfront and viewing the area in depth
Magestic Architecture. Wonderful architecture and sense of something special in Belem. My visit is only tainted by the long wait for the tour bus back to the city!
heaven in a custard tart!. You must try the Pasteis de Belem. Coffee and two pasteis de nata for only 3 Euro. Excellent and delicious.

Lots to see & do in Belem. Belem is out of Lisbon and worth the effort to get there - use the public transport system, preferably the tram which will get you there in one ride whereas with the buses you have to change part-way through the journey and risk getting yourself lost. The explorers memorial, the cathedral, the maritime museum, the fantastic modern art museum are all worth some of your time
A nice afternoon in Belém. Pretty area just a few minutes from central Lisbon

Nice Cakes. Lovely part of Lisbon, easy to reach on the No. 15 electric tram, nice to walk along the front to the small castle, theres a military museum there, and an eternal flame, flanked by the names of Portugese soldiers fallen through the years. The local speciality is a custard tart type cake, dusted with cinamon, well worth a taste.
Worth getting out of the city centre. Belem Tower was excellent & entry was free. Monastery was expensive, so we didn't go in
GREAT TART. You should not miss this institution! The warm custard filing and atmosphere at this plca is fantastic. Well impressed and would not recommend anybody going to Lisbon to miss it.
spectacular. This tower is a monument of strength and devotion to ideas, love it

Worth it for the pastries alone. Mosteiro dos Jeronimos and the adjacent park are absolutely breathtaking. Pasteis de Belem is an experience unto itself. I don't particularly like pastries, but this place was incredible. A short trip from the center of Lisboa costs 2.85 E on a trolley, or you can take a taxi for under 10 E.
Beautiful!. Make sure you check the tower and go inside for to check out the views!

Belem ? just the tower really.. Took a train a few stops from lisbon to see what the Monument and Belem tower were like, the monument was huge and a nice tribute to the great Portuguese explorers. The Belem tower turned out to be a beautifully built ornate landmark with the sea lapping at it's base but choosing a Sunday was not good as the small cramped areas in the tower were packed with visitors. Couldn't wait to get out to be honest.Had a coffee at the only cafe near by then walked in land a little, over the road bridge and up to the boat museum ( the royal barges are worth a few photos) then back to Lisbon on the train.Recommended if you have half a day with nothing planned.

A must do, very short trip from Lisbon. The Pasteis de Belem, the Toure, the monastery and cloisters and church, the walk along the waterfront, and the stupdendous statue of the great portuguese explorers - all in 2-3 hours, and one short (20-30min) bus or tram ride from Lisbon centre

Belem or Bedlam?. Touristy bad atmosphere mayhem- disrespect of tourist as a consequence. Cue out Belem custard tart shop as bad as Bakewell Pudd shop UK. Hoaching with coach tours...esepc. around monastery. Mod. Art gallery lunch place was good- food by weight like many Vancouver restaurants looking out twds Tagus. Water front was impressive to see the newer monuments and where portuguese Colonial Impulse set out.
Worth the detour!. Amazing sites to visit and definitely need to get some famous custard tarts!
Fabulous. One of my favourite neighbourhoods in Lisbon. It has some of the best sites and great food. Very beautiful place to spend a day especially in the park opposite the monastary.
Picturesque. The monastery was majestic and the flea market, sophisticated.
A wonderful monument. Tower of belem is a marvel and is a monument not to be missed while in Lisbon

Great garden and restaurants. Were you can find a couple of beautiful monuments as Torre de Belém, Mosteiros dos Jerónimo's.Ther are a nice big garden where you can rest and lay down on the grass or make a picnic. There is a Starbucks if you are a fan, or if you prefer local food you have the best cake in town: pastéis de belém.There are also lots of restaurants.

special. liked - pasteis de Belem - special pastry local specific to Belemexcellent quaint cafe. Painted tiles depicting the developmennt and history of Belem are displayed on the wallsLong queues for ordering the pastry though one can go in and eat at a table if availableAlso to see is the monastery- excellent example of 16th century churches

Follow the trail. Followed the walking trail from the Eyewitness Guide. Sunday afternoon - masts of sailing boats in the quay, young women sun-bathing in the park, grilled sardines and cold beer under an umbrella on the boulevard. It doesn't get much better.
A day in Belem. Liked the Torre and the Monastery but it was very busy due to a cruise ship being in port. Berardo museo is a must see!!
Don't miss this if you go to Lisbon. You need to have one full day to see Belem properly.

Belem Bliss. Pastéis de Belém ~ Wow we had read about them but never thought they would taste that good!! Top Tip... Don't queue in the long line.. most people mistake this as the entry, but this is to the shop, go through a door in the middle and you'll find a myriad of rooms to sit and savour..Belem is alive with history, museums, architecture, palaces and the Cathedral.. You need at least a day to explore all that is on offer.. We were lucky enough to be there for the changing of the guard as well as their version of the musical ride.. Fantastic day.. Awesome memories..
A nice place for a wander. Its a nice place to wander around but (unless you are as hungover as i was) there's nothing to keep you here after a couple of hours.

Punishing on the feet, but worth it.. Got the train from the centre of town, which was cheap and easy. It is a bit punishing on the feet if you don't use the bus or tram, but well worth it. The dockside sculpture is most impressive, the tower is excellent value at €5 per head and as for the pastries, heavenly, walk down the main drag, you can't miss it. If you want to eat in, just walk in and sit, don't join the queue which is for take outs only.

ordinary tower with nice views. It looks like a small building but its quite big. Difficult to believe from outside that its a 5 storey structure.The tower itself is very ordinary, like anyother watch tower, but its location is superb. U can have very nice views of Lisbon from the top.
Worth seeing. Nice to walk around. The culture centre was fantastic, I wish we'd have time to see the monastery..
Best part of a Lisbon trip. While Lisbon is a bit tired, Belem is a great area to visit. The Monastery, pastries and food were the best in Belem.
So much to see. Belem is a beautiful part of Lisbon encompassing riverside frontage, the Monastery, Tower, Monument of the Discoverers etc. Good retaurants too.

A must-see part of any trip to Lisbon. Took trolley 15E from Praça da Figueira. Get a window seat - you pass quite a few sights. Yes, there are plenty of pickpockets. They are pretty easy to spot. You will see them board midway during the ride; they tend to travel in twos - one to cause a distraction, and one to steal. They will also stay near the doors for a quick getaway. Keep your bags, backpacks in hand, and if possible, wear a long jacket that covers your pockets. Also, avoid using your iPad or cell phone if near a door.OK, enough of the safety tips... Belem is a fantastic, well-preserved, and beautiful part of Lisbon. Everything is so close together and well-run. It makes for a perfect day trip.Start at the Coach Museum: this is better to do early, because in its current under-sized location, big tour groups will ruin your chance to see anything or take decent photos, although you can overhear some interesting tidbits. If in a rush, just do the first 2 rooms with the most impressive coaches and skip the upstairs (equipment, tools, portraits of royals). You can do this in 20-30 minutes easily.The Casa Pasteis de Belem is a must-visit pastry shop/cafe. See my separate review on it. If you don't try these world-famous custard tarts, you are crazy.The highlight of Belem is the Monastery of Jeronimos (1hr). Beautiful architecture and lots of space. If you have a Lisboa Card, you can cut right to the entrance and bypass the ticket line. See everything. On the day I visited, it closed at 14h00 - check the times before you see anything else in Belem. The cathedral next door is nice, but it's pretty standard compared to the other churches you'll see in Lisbon. The church is skippable if in a rush.The Monument to the Discoveries (15 min) is a big disappointment. They closed down the exhibits and the film on Lisbon. All that's there now is a view from the top for 2.50 Euros, and when it's windy it's very scary. You can get a similar view from the Tower de Belem, and that view is free with a Lisboa Card. Take some photos from the outside, and move on.The Maritime Museum (30-45 mins) is quite good for anyone interested in boats. I ran in to avoid a rainstorm and was pleasantly surprised. Most exhibits are scale models of old ships, but there are actual barges and planes in the final room. A good option on a rainy day, but skippable if doing Belem in a half-day.Torre de Belem (Belem Tower) is historic, beautiful. Again, cut to the front of the line with your Lisboa Card. The Tower has a nice view from the top. It's at the opposite end of town from the Coach Museum. Catch the 15E trolley back to the city here to ensure you get a seat.My main tip would be to visit Belem when it is not raining. I went during a very heavy rain, and it was miserable. I couldn't even take photos of the outside of the monastery, and going to the top of the Belem Tower or Monument of the Discoveries was very scary and dangerous (no good railings).Belem is a definite must-do day trip, and you can even get back to Lisboa for 15h with a stash of the world's best custard tarts!

Ride the tram - E15. A good start to any Lisbon trip and at 4.6 euros for a day travel pass on all transport, a lot cheaper that organised trips. It is worth waiting for the next tram, if you will be at the front of the next queue, as the trip takes 40 mins. You will need to get on at the start of the ride! With a day ticket you can get on and off as you please so you can see the museums and monuments around Belem, of which there are plenty and well worth the ride.

Ahhh...Belem. A must-see place.. LOVED the walk along the waterfront, and the Age of Discovery monument. Being from the United States, I had not seen places like Lisbon, Belem, Sintra, or Cascais, and Belem was fantastic in every way. The pastry shop, the Tower, and the museums (within the gigantic church) were sights I will always treasure.One cannot adequately describe the massive sizes of these sights...huge and beyond your imagination, until you walk beside them, and enter within their walls. I have been fortunate in having visited Belem, reading upon the history of the explorers andworld leaders of their times, in expanding their understanding and knowledge of what was beyond the edges of what they thought earth was....Vasco de Gama, Columbus...great experience to walk on places these insightful men once walked....History continued.

Fun jaunt in Lisbon. I loved visiting Belem. I visited alone because I had friends arriving that eve and we were traveling north. I explored the monastery, coach museum, and art fair in the park (lovely local souveniers) and then ordered lunch to-go and ate in the park under a tree. It was a perfect afternoon for me being solo. Belem is great for families because there's a lot to do in a small location. And it's only ten or fifteen minutes by bus/trolley from Praco do Comercio so you can't go wrong. And don't forget to go to the custard bakery and order the famed pastel de nata.

Two Visits to Belem. 1. After landing in Lisbon, we took a taxi to our hotel (was overcharged -- need to verify fee at the airport). Having most of the day before us, we took a taxi from the Rossio Praca to the Belem District. Saw the Tower of Belem -- great 15th Century river island fort, distinctive Moorish architectural details--, then walked throught the Monastery of Jeronimos -- monument to Vasco de Gama -- and its wonderful Clositers... maybe our best site in Portugal. Serene, peaceful, beautiful. Visited Monument of the Discoveries. Lunch was grilled fish at Restaurtane Os Jeronimos. We took streetcar 15E back to our Fugeria Praca and our hotel. Good 1/2 day outing. 2. Having an afternoon available, we took streetcar 15E from Fugeria Praca to the Belem District. Bought reduced rate streetcar pass at the outlet on Rossio Praca. We went back especially to see the Maritime Museum, which we missed on our first visit. Museum is a wonderful collection of maritime artifacts, ship models, life-sized boats, and luxury royalty barges. Had Pastries at the touristy local pastries shop, but were not impressed.
Worth a visit. A short trolley ride (but watch your wallet, pickpockets abound) leads to a lovely and varied experience.
unmissable tour. The Belem is a unmissable tour. Don´t forget eat a Belem´s pastel
if you didn't go you can't say you've been in Lisbon. dont miss to eat " os pasteis de belém" or visit "Mosteiro dos Jerónimos", this last once can only be compare with Abadia.

worth visiting. take a few hours and pack sandwiches and drinks. After a visit to the beautiful Cathedral, go for a picnic in one of the gardens.
If you miss American junk food, there's a big McDonald's there.

Worth a Visit. The Jeronimos Monastery is beautiful to see. Especially worthwhile is the exhibit that shows major events in history happening around the world on parallel time lines. Little did we know, the Tower of Belem is quite a walk from the monastery, with little shade on a sunny hot day, so I would suggest taking the tram/bus to get there. It probably only merits somewhere between a 2- and 3-star rating. But you can get some beautiful shots. Pastis of Belem is worth going just to say you've been there and ate their custard pastry. We went late in the afternoon, so had no problem finding a table. However, I found the custard way too sweet for my taste. I thought I had better in Hong Kong and Macau. The crust, on the other hand, really was heavenly.

nice. One of my favorite parts from Lisbon with the very special pastel de nata and aromatic portuguese coffee "bica". Here is situated the Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. Here is the Tower of Belem - the Lisbons symbol. Amaing park before the palace of the culture of Belem. Ofcourse here is the river Tejo, the port, the Monument of the Explorers /Padrão dos Descobrimentos/. The tram No 15 from the Lisbon city center /Figeura square or Cais de Sodre/ travel in this zone of the city.
Belem Pastries just the Best. Another lovely town. Must try the pastries:) They are just the best. Get to see how they are made.
so much to see here. The tower, the monastery, the royal coach museum, the marine museum - all so fabulous - you will need a full day!

Do not miss.... Mosteiro dos Jeronimos. We weren't sure what to expect but believe me it is well worth the time. It is BEAUTIFUL! So much detailed work. Due to Sunday mass we weren't able to visit the actual chapel, but know it is a must see! Don't forget to try the Pasteis de Belem, practically next door.The amazing Padrao dos Descobrimentos statue provides a breathtaking view of Lisbon from the top.

Extremely rude, uninterested staff. When attempting to buy tickets we enquired as to whether there was a student discount (asking in Portuguese) and the woman and the till proceeded to ignore us and continue her conversation with her colleague. Finally responding 'nao' she continued to converse ignoring us completely. We left without buying tickets after being treated so badly. We missed out on seeing the inside of the Tower of Belem for this reason.

This tower has an exotic and attractive aspect. Built in the 16th century out into the Tagus River it is a magnificent structure and worth a visit. It is Roman-Gothic with some Arabic decoration that makes it exotic.

Tarts..!. Took the bus to Belem late in the day to try the tarts. Worth the trip and have been searching high and low since I've returned home to Australia for the perfect tart.Sun was setting on the monument and the tower and we got some lovely photos. Wish we had arrived earlier to visit the church. Worth the day trip.

Church Visit. Went there on the Lisbon tourist bus and walked back to Lisbon centre down the edge of the Tagus river, about 2.5hrs not counting stops. Lots of interesting things to see, monastery, statues, palace, cruise liners, good marina with restaurant, locals fishing etc.
Nice place to spend a lazy morning. Chilling and watching the sea by the Belem Tower. Was busy on a week day so I'd avoid weekends.
Do not miss Belém. You must go to Belém, to see the mosteiro de belém e torre de belém, in the end go to pasteis de belém to eath the famous pasteis de nata.
A pleasant option. When you have become a little tired of central Lisbon take the short train journey to Belem and enjoy the waterfront.

Lovely area, lots of restaurants. Buy a 48 hour hop-on,hop-off bus ticket which covers a number of bus lines through the city and all your transport needs are sorted. The buses run frequently and they will get you to all the main attractions. Hop off and explore a particular part of the city, have a rest in the numerous sid walk cafes and go to the next place. Walking in Lisbon can be tiring, the city was built (like Rome) on 7 hills andsome of the roads are really steep. Belem of course is flat, there is a lovely convent to explore or you can just stroll along the sea front and enjoy the environment

Pastries and Art. Just thought I'd say - the pastries here are worth it. Better than the generic ones in town. Seems like chaos when ordering - we ordered them to take away and enjoyed them at our leisure. Also, the art Museum in the CCB was so fantastic. LIsbon ended up being a really arty holiday for us and this was a definite highlight. AND FREE!

Totally out of the way, but a well worth all-day visit. Don't know if you should go to Belem or not? Think no further ... go!Belem is definitely one of the Lisbon areas you don't want to miss. The you have the Discoveries monument, the Belem Tower, the Jeronimos Monastery and the Belem Cultural Centre ... and the Pasteis de Belem!There's so much to see and do in this area, that you'll definitely want to mark a whole day in your itinerary to fully appreciate all this area has to offer. Now, what are you waiting for? Go! :)

A must go in Lisbon. Try to get there by train, it is the fastest and more convenient way. The train lain from Lisbon to cascais has a stop there and it takes only some minutes from Lisbon city center. The whole area is quite tidy now and you can easily move from the Tower to the conquerer's monument and finally to the monastery, which is absolutely astonishing. Then you can indulge yourself with some of the famous pastries made locally

Unforgetable site. This beautiful tower, the symbol of Lisbon, is a must see. It is located in a very calm and nice area by the river, but it needs a fifteen minute walk from the bus/tram station to reach the tower. Nevertheless, it is worth the walking and it defitely calms you down. In the same area one can visit the monument of Descobrimentos and Monastery of St Jerome. A very nice way to spend a morning in Lisbon.

Lovely, but crazy crowded. Stayed in Lisbon and took a side trip to Belem. Let me warn you that the worst meal we had was at Queijadas de Belem (QdB) restaurant which is near the main square. (Inedibile food and the worst waitstaff ever) This restaurant is not listed on Trip Advisor for a good reason. Now on to the Tower, it is interesting, but the crowds were so thick when we were there that we could barely move. We were there on a Sunday which is a free day so that probably added to it. However when we arrived in the main square there was some sort of ceremonial event going on with military dressed regiments, music, men on horseback, and two untameable rotwilers. That was interesting to watch. There was also a flea market in the park which had mostly junky stuff and gypsies begging. The waterfront was lovely though and we enjoyed walking along it to and from the tower.

Take one day to visit Belem. This is a great place to visit. Arrive early because of waiting lines. The tower is very nice to visit and is worth the price. Take the "Tower & Monastery" ticket as you save money. You must climb the stairs all the way up for the full feeling of the tower. The waiting line is a bit cahotic. The Monastery and cathedral are a must see and a very nice example of manueline architecture. It is worth the visit. Walking and lunching in Belem is also very nice. We did the maritime museum (adjacent to the Monastery) which is a MUST do. One of the nicest museum of maritime and discoveries history in the world. Enjoy Belem!

Well worth the visit. We saw Belem as part of our yellow bus tour and realised we would have to go back. You could easily spend two days in this part of Lisbon visiting the many museums, monuments and the monestary. It was one of the highlights of our visit.

Stepping in to Lisbon's history. We took the tram from Lisbon to Belém. It was a Sunday morning and getting bit busy. Tip: walk to the previous tram stop and grab yourself a seat. Sunday's everything has free entry between 10am and 2pm. Belém is an interesting area offering a collection of worthy attractions from the old Tower, the amazing St Jerome Monastery as well as several museums. We stopped off and had a delicious lunch by the water overlooking the river. Everything is in walking distance and you can end the afternoon with a famous custard tart! It can get crowded with queues to see inside the cathedral but these all moved fairly quickly and were manageable.

A little tight inside. If you can on the main vacations you might get a lot of people visiting inside the tower, the stairs to the top are tight and irregular and if there are lots of people it's difficult to go upstairs you have to be patient and brave because sometimes you can feel a little afraid of go up or down in this stairs.But in the top it's a beautiful view you can see the Jeronimo's Monastery and the sea.
Architecture is amazing. Worth taking a trip out to Belem to see this amazing architecture.

It's very an interesting monument with a lot of history !. When visiting this interesting monument we can understand the values and daily activities and life of the past history. The kings always thinking to prepare his sailors to go to new land and conquest it. It was a very important monument for the commerce and the development within Portugal.

Nice area to walk around. This is a nice area to walk around, particularly on a sunny day. The area has been well developed and there are lots of small museums and other points of interest to have a look in, including the fort. It is family friendly and easy to get to from the heard of Lisbon. We caught a bus without any problem.

A bit out of the way but worth the trip. Belem is a lovely neighborhood, it's a bit far from the other areas such as Baixa, Bairro Alto, etc but it's worth the trip. In our opinion just visiting Pasteis de Belem was worth the trip, it is a lovely coffee shop full of history. The pastries were the best I've ever had, if I'm in Lisbon again I will definitely make a trip to Pasteis de Belem. This place has been running since 1837 and they use a traditional recipe to make their famous pastries. It's an old recipe that the monks (in the close by St Jerome Monastery) used to use, they still make it handmade using all the original methods.St Jerome Monastery is breathtaking, the architecture is beautiful. Also, you can see the tomb of Vazco Da Gama inside.

Awesome. Torre Belem is an amazing piece of architecture. Located right on the riverbank, you can look across the harbor and see Lisbon. Adjacent to this is the Navigator's Monument which is also amazing.

Great neighbourhood, but way to touristy. Belém definitely is a very interesting and beautiful place. There are many museums and tourist attractions, but it's completely overrun by tourists of the "Europe in 3 days" kind. There's nothing authentic about this place anymore. Still, it's surely worth a visit because there definitely is a reason so many come and visit the buildings and monuments in Belém. They are beautiful. Plus there are more quiet museums like Centro Cultural de Belém (very interesting architecture).If you're an anthropologist, it's also very interesting to see all kinds of people from the four corners of the world doing exactly the same thing.

A must see in Lisbon. The whole Neighborhood of Belem is fantastic with the Monastery, the Tower and the Monument. The Tower in particular has a wounderfull view with a very cheap ticket, only 3 euros.

Sum is Better than the Parts.. This area is definitely worth checking out if you are in Lisbon. Overall, nothing is too special here or memorable, but everything as a whole is pretty good.We spent one morning here checking out the Torre de Belem, the Padrao dos Descobrimentos, Mosteiro dos Jeronimos as well as we got some Pasteis de Belem.Again, nothing too memorable but everything was pretty decent. We took the train from the Belem station to Cascais and had a nice afternoon there.

Great neighborhood and the best way to see it is on a Segway. Don't miss the chance to ride a Segway in this neighborhood with landmark attractions such as Torres De Belem and Monument to the Discoveries, and the famous pastries called Pastais de Belem.

Great pastries!. Belem is easily accessible from Lisbon through the tram 15 from Praca da Figueira and you get a new view of the waterside as you pass through little neighborhoods. It is a day trip place as, Belem, itself, is not incredibly interesting, but the pastries are absolutely amazing. I would recommend getting the "pasteis de Belem" from their oldest shop, "Antiga Confeiteria", and sit by the Leif to enjoy the 25 of April bridge and the water. On a good day, you would see sailboats and people fishing, and by a good day, I mean there's a good breeze.
Nice walk. The area around the tower is really nice, we walked up all around the area on our way to Cascais.

Beautiful area!. Belem was beautiful. The area itself is full of life, people and marvelous architecture. We did not go inside but toured around the area.You can get to Belem from Cais do Sodre via Tram 15. It takes about 15-20 minutes. While we were at Belem we were lucky enough to see a parade that passed by with drummers and huge characters. Don't forget to make a stop by the Pastais de Belem and enjoy this Portuguese treat! You will be back for more.Also, the Torre de Belem is 2 tram stops further on Tram 15. Check that out as well.Belem is a beautiful area and is a must see while you are in Lisbon.

To be honest-just went for the pastries!. One of the last things we did in Lisbon was visit Belem, mainly because of the reputation of the pastries. Belem actually has a different feel to it than the rest of Lisbon, possibly due to the lack of tagging/graffiti and the large park. But anyway, the pastries blew me away. Less the a euro a pastry you'll buy at least four and want to go back for me. Guaranteed. Couple of good shops to and a museum, but its all about the pastries!

Magnificently Pretty. This lovely tower is one of the higlights of Belem, and indeed Lisbon. Along with the Monument to the Discoveries, the Belem tower is probably one of the most popular images of Lisbon, and it does not disappoint with it's intricate carvings, and beautiful setting on the harbour. You can explore the old dungeons beneath the tower, climb to the top for a great view over Belem, or just admire the tower itself. If you visit on a Sunday before 2pm, it's free!

lovely ovely lovely. after leaving a cery grey london, we arrived in lisbon to bright warm sunshine, we took a bus to belem and went for a delicious lunch ( behind the main street towards the river) and sat under orange trees eating vvvvv cheap seafood. unfortunately i dont remember the name of he restaurant however there were a few close together and they all looked good

If you don't have too much time, skip it. I didn’t really like this place. It’s a tower standing in water. When it’s foggy, you won’t be able to see anything from the tower, you’ll also have difficulties seeing the tower itself. It’s extremely crowded and I suppose this issue should be regulated somehow. You can climb the tower using a very steep and narrow staircase. The effect is that hundreds of people try to go upstairs and downstairs simultaneously (some even with babies in their arms) and the situation is getting rather dangerous sometimes. The tower is pretty nice and I liked the carvings in stone, but I didn’t really see anything spectacular nor especially extraordinary there. I’m sure there’re more interesting places in Lisbon and if you don’t have too much time, I’d suggest skipping it.
The tower is nice. The view from the tower is beautiful and the tower itself as well. But make sure you bring something to drink and prepare to QUE up and down.
The pastries are worth the trip. Belem is an interesting although crowded place: just make sufrre you don't skip the pastries if you go to the trouble of travelling there!

Belem area : masterpieces you canot miss. the first of them is the "torre di belem" along the sea/river shore : absolutely a masterpiece, it looks more likely a disney creation rather than an historical monument. don`t miss the fifth floor terrace , but be careful with the very steepy narrow stairs. on sunday´s before 2 pm entrance is free.the second is the "mosteiro of jeronimos" : absolutely a must !!!! enter the amazing catherdral and don`t miss the cloister ( 7 euros), a unique experience,you feel stone hasn`t been carved but embroidered. they have a very interesting exhibition from the beginning of history to our days where the story of the portuguese expansion goes in parallel with the history of portugal and of the world. it is absolutely worth spending half an hour understanding the intermingling of politics with literature , art and discovery. the third one is the "pedrao do descobrimento" , a suggestive piece of art on the rover shore.at last you will be quite hungry so take your chance and queue up for the "pasteis de belem" next door to the monastery , you fully deserve them. to get a table inside could have taken 45 minutes in low season, good luck if you go in high season!!! nonetheless buy your box of recently baked cookies ("pasteis") which will be given to you with little bags of sugar in powder and cinnamon (so you can dress them at your choice) a good option is to step into the little tasca next door and order a cup of porto or of muscatel and enjoy your cookies !!!

A must see area of Lisbon!. We spent almost a full day visiting the attractions in Belem, including the monestary, the Cultural Center of Belem, the Tower of Belem, and the Monument to the Discoveries. Don't miss the custard tarts at Pasteis de Belem / Antiga Confeitaria de Belem.

Our most favorit area of Lisbon. Every time when we are in Lisbon we make a half day trip to Belem. We enjoy the walk in park by Jeronymos monastery, watching yachts on the river, having a pastery (pasteis de belem at the local shop where it originates from - get in even if there are queues outside, the place has many seating possibilities and the pasteis costs less than one euro) the monastery itself is worth visiting as well as the tower of Belem and maritime museum

Interesting Tower in an interesting area. This was an interesting little tower to go into and explore and it will not take a lot of time. Then there is lots to see and do around it as well, military museum right beside it and then the Discoveries monument is a bit further down the river. Easier to take a care and drive down the the next parking lot as a small harbor will prevent you from easily walking there. Across the street - blocked my train tracks is the Monastary.Note that the Tower is closed on Mondays.
Must go!. 3 must-see attractions close-by (as in walking distance) - Jeronimos Monastery, Discovery Monument, Belem Tower and most of all, the Pasteis de Belem.
Cute Chess peice. This was neat to see. It is free for students too...has a drawbridge and you can climb all the way to the top (very narrow stairs) and look out from the turrets for good views.

A quick, simple visit feels like going back in time.. The tower is not big, and there is not a large amount to see, but the atmosphere and character of the structure were charming and fun.The detail in the building's exterior was a surprise. Most of the ancient buildings we had seen in Lisbon were plain and functional. The stairs going up are super narrow, so you have to make sure no one is coming the opposite way. The rooms were bare and not too interesting. They would have benefited from more information about what they were used for or what they may have looked like at the time they were used.The tower top is simple: just a square with 4 lookout points, but hanging out the window, looking out over the water gives a great sense of the history. It is a quick sight to see. We were in and out pretty fast without rushing.

Must see area in Lisbon. My wife read that Jeronimos Monastery was a #1 must see, so we made the trip to Belem. We took the metro to Cais do Sodre and then the tram to Belem. We also visited the Discover's Monument and Belem Tower. Jeronimos Monastery is very impressive! And you have to have a photo together at Discover's Monument. Belem Tower is small but also a must see place. Belem does give one an interesting perspective of Portugese history. The Portugese were the first Europeans to really venture out accross the oceans to Africa, America, & Asia. Our modern world does begin with the Portugese sea voyages started in the 1400's. Belem is the place to remind us of all that.

Nice trip to Belem. I went at the beginning of December and the place was very quiet and enjoyable. The tower that seems to come out of the water was inspiring and a nice walk from where the tram stops. The Pasteis de Belem shop, although filled with tourists, does make delicious pastries and is definitely worth a stop.

Plan on a full day for Belem. It is an easy tram ride from the center of Lisbon to this riverside suburb and lots to see once you are in Belem (Bethlehem in English). The river views as it flows toward the Atlantic, the bridges, the Discoverer's Monument, the monastary, coaches museum, and more and you can easily spend the better part of a day if you see it all. Make sure you stop at the Pasteis de Belem for the most famous custard treats in Portugal. You can find them all over the country but they are supposed to be at their best here in Belem. Their cafe has been enlarged over the years and has room for hundreds and is often crowded but you can usually find a table if you walk around a bit. And if you only order one you might wish you had another.

Don't Miss the Pastries!. Belem has wonderful sights and amazing historical locations. However, if you go, you MUST stop at Pasteis de Belem. This is a local pastry shop that has been in existence since 1837 and serves the most wonderful custard pastries, pasteis de nata...along with a surprisingly well priced menu of lunch items. We spent a week in Lisbon and visited Pasteis de Belem more than once just for the pastries. If you go, it is located about a half block east of the monastery, just past the bus and trolley stop. Use the door on the left and go inside to sit and eat. Surprise yourself and walk all the way through to see just how huge this place is, then be surprised at how quickly and efficiently you are served.

Lovely day trip to Belem. We had a lovely day visiting Belem. Our favourites were the Tower of Belem and the Maritime Museum. The tower had great views from the top and is very well preserved. The Maritime Museum has some great exhibits on Portugese maritime history including full size royal barges. It is definately worth the 1.50E entrance fee. Beware the No 15 Tram back to Lisbon can be a bit crowded and make you feel like sardines.

Charming. Belem is not just about the tower. It's a nice, quiet area including the Monastery of Jeronimos, the Museum of Coaches, the Marine Museum, the Discoverers' Monument and many others.The Monastery is an impressive building which is worth visiting by all means; it's difficult to describe how beautiful it is. The tower of Belem resembles the monastery in terms of architecture and design; beware that the wind is very strong up there in the tower.The Museum of Coaches is again an interesting place to see; there is an impressive collection of royal coaches, very well preserved or restored, dating back as far as the XVIth century up to the XIXth century.The Naval Museum has a good collection of various items related to navigation but the attraction you must not miss is the collection of old (royal) barges.All these attractions are within a walking distance from one another and from the train station. You can also have a walk along the river side and admire the boats anchored in the harbour.

A sight not to be missed in Lisbon. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is a visually striking attraction with interesting architecture in a memorable setting at the entrance of the Tagus river. It should not be missed.

Better from the outside. As indicated by the other reviewer, this place would be well-served by some information! We bought the pamphlet, and even that didn't do much other than label the rooms - but no info on what those rooms were used for our how they may have been decorated. It's empty inside - except the overrun of people. It was like a cattle call, particularly when everyone is coming and going through the same doors. And the stairs! Up and down the tower shares one spiral staircase - one NARROW staircase - very difficult to navigate. I do have to admit that the view from the top was nice, however.

Great place to relax. We'd had a couple of days sightseeing in Lisbon. So oing out to Belem, sitting out on the waterside, and in the gardens allowed us to chill out for a morning. You'll get some great views, and if you want museums there are plenty there.Get the tram from the Pracio del Comercio. It takes about 20 minutes.

Not that impressive compared to other sights. I thought the Torre de Belem was interesting, but extremely crowded, not particularly evocative of Portugal's past, and in my humble opinion more attractive from the outside than from the inside. It could be made a lot more interesting if there were stories provided inside that gave some context to the Tower and interesting tales of things that had happened there. A small exhibit discussing Lisbon's coastal defenses in particular, defending it from the Drakes of the this world would be particularly interesting. If you are going there because you are also visiting the Moansterio San Jeronimo, I would much rather recommend the interesting archeological museum right next to the monastery.
